                              513 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            February 22, 2016 Monday

Regulatory update: North Carolina Utilities Commission; Frontier Natural Gas
Company, LLC, has issued (G-40 Sub 133) Application for Approval of Corporate
Reorganization and Debt Refinancing

LENGTH: 2831 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Raleigh: North Carolina Utilities Commission has issued the following document
(docket):



 and its

 customers.

 4. The proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier include three

 (3) agreements: (1) Revolving Line of Credit for access to $7.2 million; (2)
Long Term Note in

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 1

 the amount of$8.7 million; and (3) Four Year Term Note for the SAP IT Operating
System in

 the amount of$1.075 million.



 5. As is more fully described in the Application verified by Kevin Degenstein
and

 Jim Sprague, this new corporate structure and the new the intercompany
financing agreements

 through which Frontier will receive its financing require Commission approval
pursuant to

 N.C.G.S. §§ 62-111(a), 62-153, and 62-161 . I am providing this Affidavit
concurrently with,

 and in support of, the Application requesting this approval.

 Corporate Reorganization

 6. Under the current corporate structure, GNI is the ultimate parent of several


 entities including Energy West Incorporated (EWI). GNI also separately owns
other regulated

 utilities that operate distribution systems and an intrastate pipeline in Ohio
and is the parent of

 several unregulated entities as well. EWI is the parent of several regulated
utilities in Montana,

 Maine, and North Carolina, including Frontier Utilities of North Carolina, Inc.
("Frontier

 Utilities"), which is the intermediate holding company for Frontier. A current
corporate

 structure is set forth in Exhibit 1 attached to this Affidavit.

 Having EWI, which is regulated by the Montana Commission, serve as the parent
of

 Frontier Utilities and other regulated utilities, as well as GNI' s ownership
of other unregulated

 businesses in other states, has created in my opinion the potential for
jurisdictional conflict,

 confusion in accountability, and the potential for inconsistent practices among
subsidiaries.

 7. Under the newly proposed corporate structure, GNI would continue to be the

 ultimate parent of Frontier. However, Frontier Utilities will be dissolved and
a new subsidiary

 of GNI (currently designated as a newly formed intermediary company ("NIC") for
the purpose

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 2

 of the Application) would serve as the holding company for Frontier as well as
the other

 regulated affiliates operating in Ohio, Montana and Maine.

 8. The regulated subsidiaries would all become direct, separate subsidiaries of
GNI

 through NIC, not through a variety of different regulated and non-regulated
holding companies.

 GNI will also directly own the other non-regulated companies currently
operating in the Midwest

 and Montana, but these unregulated companies will be separate from the
regulated companies

 The new proposed corporate structure is set forth below in Exhibit 2 attached
to this Affidavit.

 9. It is my opinion and belief that this new proposed structure is beneficial
for a

 number of reasons. It essentially separates Frontier, as a North Carolina
regulated utility, for

 corporate formation, operational, regulatory, and financing purposes and
provides for consistent

 governance over all regulated utilities. It eliminates the concern of potential
multi-jurisdictional

 regulatory conflict and potential confusion by GNI' s current ownership
structure of regulated

 and unregulated subsidiaries. It still provides, however, the benefits of being
part of a larger

 organization with shared resources, expertise, and best practices, economies of
scale, and access

 to capital, as illustrated by the proposed financed discussed below.

 Debt Financing Agreements

 10. As part ofthe last financing case filed in Docket G-40, Sub 105 and
approved by

 Commission Order dated August 8, 2012 ("Refinancing Order"), the Commission
approved a

 credit agreement between Energy West Incorporated ("EWI") and Frontier that
consisted of a

 $30 million unsecured revolving line of credit and a $10 million unsecured
long-term debt

 facility. Frontier was a part of the pool of guarantors of this financing,
along with other EWI

 subsidiaries, and provided a limited recourse guarantee of $12.8 million of the
aggregate amount.

 During the proceedings, the Public Staff expressed concerns that the $12.8
million limited

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 3

 recourse guarantee of Frontier could cause Frontier to guarantee more debt than
EWI had

 borrowed and provided on Frontier's behalf, but ultimately recommended the
approval to avoid

 the risks created by rejection of the proposed refinancing transactions.

 11. That debt package is not in default and is still providing financing to
Frontier, but

 it expires in a little over a year, on April 1, 2017. Since the time of the
Refinancing Order in

 2012, GNI and its subsidiaries, including Frontier, have been exploring
alternative forms of

 financing, as well as a new corporate structure, as described above, to
accommodate and

 facilitate this financing.

 12. Beginning in November 2014, I began identifying potential lenders for

 replacement financing directly to Frontier. I sent letters attached to this
Affidavit as Exhibit 3 to

 Yadkin Bank, BB&T, Carter Banlc & Trust, and First Community Bank requesting
term sheets

 for a Term Loan and revolving Line of Credit for Frontier. I also provided each
ofthese banks

 with information about Frontier in order for them to evaluate and respond to
our request,

 including financial statements, service territory maps, corporate
organizational chart, listing of

 the property, plant, and equipment, schedule of rates for all classes of
customers, schedule of

 largest customers and their annual usage, regulatory reports, pipeline maps
showing the

 transmission, distribution, and service lines, and schedule showing the number
of customers in

 each of the service areas served by Frontier.

 13. To follow-up, I had several individual meetings with representatives from
Yadkin

 Bank and First Community Bank, culminating in meetings by Kevin Degenstein, Jed
Henthorne,

 and me with each banlc on April27, 2015. In addition, I met with
representatives ofBB&T in

 mid-2015. I also had several telephone conversations with bankers at Carter
Bank & Trust to

 assess their interest and answer their questions.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 4

 14. After all of these efforts over several months, the only bank that
submitted a term

 sheet was First Community Bank which is attached hereto as Confidential Exhibit
4. Based

 upon this experience, it is my belief that Frontier's small size was a major
impediment to

 receiving attractive financing options from independent lenders.

 15. I evaluated the proposal from First Community Bank carefully, but concluded
that

 it did not provide the flexibility and terms necessary for Frontier's financing
needs and that

 would allow Frontier to continue to operate successfully and expand as we
intend. It was

 certainly not comparable to the financing being offered through the
intercompany agreements

 with GNI described below.

 16. GNI management, on behalf of its subsidiaries and in consultation with me
and

 my counterparts with the other regulated operating utilities, also solicited
and evaluated debt

 financing options. We evaluated the financing options that were presented and
the

 organizational structure that would allow us to achieve the company's goal and
accommodate the

 necessary financing within the regulatory framework in which we operate. We
have now

 finalized that process and are proposing an organizational structure and
financing arrangement

 that I believe should simplify regulatory oversight, ensure accountability,
improve operational

 efficiencies, and provide sufficient capital to Frontier on the most cost
effective basis.

 17. Under the proposed financing, as explained in the Application, the
currently

 effective amended and restated credit agreement between EWI and Bank of America
("BOA")

 will be replaced by a new senior credit agreement between GNI and BOA ("the BOA
Senior

 Credit Facility"). This GNI financing will take the form of a $42 million
revolving line of credit

 that will be available for a period of five years for GNI to provide funds
pursuant to

 intercompany notes to Frontier and the other regulated operating utilities,
designed to ensure the

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 5

 regulated utilities such as Frontier have adequate access to capital during the
winter season and

 in order to procure gas supply in connection with operations, as well as for
other general

 operational purposes. Guarantees of the BOA Senior Credit Facility will be
required only from

 the unregulated subsidiaries of GNI and from NIC, while GNI will be the sole
Borrower. No

 direct recourse from BOA will extend to regulated subsidiaries downstream ofNIC
such as to

 Frontier. The revolving facility will terminate five years from closing.

 18. GNI also plans to issue up to $50 million ofNew Senior Unsecured Notes
("the

 Senior Unsecured Notes"), the terms of which are fully discussed by James E.
Sprague, GNI

 Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, in his Affidavit. Both the proceeds
from the Senior

 Credit Facility and from the Senior Unsecured Notes will be used to refinance
the existing debt

 and provide financing for general operational purposes and system expansion.

 19. The long-term note, which details the obligations ofGNI as the issuer, as
well as

 the non-regulated subsidiary guarantors, does not include Frontier as a direct
issuer or guarantor

 (similar to the revolving line with BOA). Neither Frontier, nor any of GNI's
other regulated

 operating utilities, will have any obligation for activities, borrowings, or
guarantees provided by

 any other GNI company or directly on the long-term note.

 20. The third component of the financing is a four (4) year term debt facility
in the

 amount of $7.0 million that will be used to consolidate several smaller loans
by GNI used for

 acquisition and development of an SAP software based operating system used by
all of the GNI

 companies (the "SAP Financing"). As is the case with the revolving line of
credit and the long

 term note issuance, GNI will be the sole borrower for the SAP Financing, no
guarantees will be

 required of the regulated operating utilities, including Frontier, and Frontier
will only be

 responsible through an intercompany note between GNI and Frontier for a
proportional piece of

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 6

 the SAP Financing. BOA is the proposed lender on the SAP Financing and will
require the SAP

 Software license to be pledged by GNI as collateral for this $7.0 million loan.


 21. Frontier will not have any guarantees directly to BOA. Based upon the
credit

 available through the BOA Senior Credit Facility, Senior Unsecured Notes, and
SAP Financing,

 Frontier will be eligible to draw a total of$15.9 million for its own
operational needs ($7.2

 million under the revolving line of credit, $8.7 million under the long-term
debt) and in addition

 receive $1.07 5 million from the SAP Financing (of which $820,000 will pay
Frontier's portion

 of the cost of the SAP software, licenses, and installation). If approved,
Frontier will enter into

 three intercompany notes with GNI, without any obligations directly to BOA or
Merrill Lynch

 ("ML"). Under the intercompany agreements, Frontier's only obligations will be
to GNI and its

 exposure is limited to what is has borrowed and used and extends no further.

 22. There are several benefits to Frontier under this financing structure as
compared

 to the structure that has been in place since 2012. First, as mentioned,
Frontier has no direct

 responsibility to BOA for either credit facility. Further, because funds for
the individual

 operating companies are treated separately and are reserved for the operating
subsidiaries under

 distinct, standalone "silos", there is no danger that the needs of other
utilities will impinge upon

 Frontier's access to its own capital or create any risk to Frontier. Upon
approval of the

 intercompany loans requested in this application, the new debt will be put in
place, paying off the

 existing debt and Frontier will execute its intercompany notes for access to
stand-alone line of

 credit through GNI. The other operating utilities will execute their own
intercompany notes and

 have access to their own lines, independent of Frontier and any other GNI
obligations. As a

 result of this structure, there is no potential for cross-collateralization or
cross-default. Also,

 Frontier will have full access to the SAP Software and operating system and all
of the associated

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 7

 developments related to the system although it will only be responsible for a
fraction of the

 development costs. Each of the GNI entities will benefit similarly.

 23. The Company has reviewed its operating needs over the last four years,
which

 have included periods of major construction and capital expansion efforts and
periods when the

 cost of gas has been high during winter months. The total amount of the
proposed debt should

 be sufficient to give Frontier adequate headroom in meeting its operational
needs, including

 anticipated construction, cost of gas, etc. in the years ahead, based on its
current capital

 expenditure forecasts.

 24. In the previous financing proceeding, the Public Staff expressed concerns
with

 Frontier's financial obligations to BOA for the credit facility and its
execution of a limited

 recourse guarantee. The proposed financing arrangement addresses those
concerns. Unlike the

 last financing proceeding, the current financing arrangement is between GNI and
BOA, and

 Frontier and other regulated subsidiaries have no obligations to the ultimate
lender or to each

 other. Frontier will only be obligated for funds to which it has access, and no
other subsidiary or

 GNI will have access to those funds. The intercompany loan agreements between
Frontier and

 GNI will establish the limits of its obligations and make it clear that
Frontier's obligations are

 limited by its borrowings. No assets will be pledged or required by Frontier to
secure access to

 this working capital and long term debt. The only asset that is pledged as
collateral for any of

 the three facilities is the SAP Software, pledged by GNI. This structure should
significantly

 reduce or even eliminate the prior concerns that the Public Staff had regarding
Frontier's

 obligations.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 8

 25. Frontier has continued to add to its infrastructure to access new market
areas and

 to expand service in its service territory. As noted in the testimony filed in
Frontier's annual

 review of gas costs dockets, the number of customers served by Frontier has
increased 26% from

 2011 to 2012, 28% from 2012 to 2013, 27.7% from 2013 to 2014 and 11.8% from
2014 to 2015.

 Frontier needs both short-term and long-term debt resources in order to have
sufficient access to

 meet cyclical cash flow needs throughout the year, to pay fixed expenses during
non-heating

 months, to benefit from seasonal opportunities and provide operational
flexibility to lower

 overall costs, and to provide long-term financing for capital investments to
allow it to continue to

 grow as it has over the past few years.

 26. I believe that the proposed intercompany agreements with GNI offer the most
cost

 effective option for financing for Frontier. What I have learned over the past
year is that many

 lenders are not familiar with the utility and gas industry and are hesitant to
lend or offer credit at

 a premium in order to cover their perception of potential risks. In addition,
financing is an area

 where there are economies of scale. At the parent level, due to the size of the
facility, GNI is

 better able to secure more favorable interest rates and other terms, and pass
those benefits on to

 Frontier through the intercompany agreements.

 27. Finally, I want to note that Frontier currently has a shared services
agreement with

 EWI, which has been previously filed with the Commission. This agreement
allowed EWI to

 charge Frontier for shared services. Since EWI will no longer be the parent of
Frontier, the

 Company will need to enter into a new shared services agreement with NIC (and
NIC will in turn

 enter into a similar agreement with GNI). The new shared services agreements
shall contain the

 same terms as those in the existing agreement; the only difference is that
current intermediate

 holding company has been substituted for GNI as the party to the agreement with
Frontier.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 9

 Under these arrangements, centralized administrative and professional services
such as

 accounting, legal, engineering, technology systems, data management or other
shared services

 for GNI subsidiaries are provided. Expenses that arise from the individual
needs of any specific

 subsidiary are directly assigned to that entity. This will continue to ensure
that Frontier's

 ratepayers are only responsible for those expenditures necessary for the
efficient and reliable

 operation of Frontier. This new shared service agreement will be filed with the
Commission

 upon approval of the corporate reorganization,

 Further affiant sayeth not.

Regulatory update: North Carolina Utilities Commission; Frontier Natural Gas
Company, LLC, has issued (G-40 Sub 133) Application for Approval of Corporate

LENGTH: 2831 words

DATELINE: Lahore

 13. To follow-up, I had several individual meetings with representatives from
Yadkin

 Bank and First Community Bank, culminating in meetings by Kevin Degenstein, Jed
Henthorne,

 and me with each banlc on April27, 2015. In addition, I met with
representatives ofBB&T in

 mid-2015. I also had several telephone conversations with bankers at Carter
Bank & Trust to

 assess their interest and answer their questions.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 4

 14. After all of these efforts over several months, the only bank that
submitted a term

 sheet was First Community Bank which is attached hereto as Confidential Exhibit
4. Based

 upon this experience, it is my belief that Frontier's small size was a major
impediment to

 receiving attractive financing options from independent lenders.

 15. I evaluated the proposal from First Community Bank carefully, but concluded
that

 it did not provide the flexibility and terms necessary for Frontier's financing
needs and that

 would allow Frontier to continue to operate successfully and expand as we
intend. It was

 certainly not comparable to the financing being offered through the
intercompany agreements

 with GNI described below.

 16. GNI management, on behalf of its subsidiaries and in consultation with me
and

 my counterparts with the other regulated operating utilities, also solicited
and evaluated debt

 financing options. We evaluated the financing options that were presented and
the

 organizational structure that would allow us to achieve the company's goal and
accommodate the

 necessary financing within the regulatory framework in which we operate. We
have now

 finalized that process and are proposing an organizational structure and
financing arrangement

 that I believe should simplify regulatory oversight, ensure accountability,
improve operational

 efficiencies, and provide sufficient capital to Frontier on the most cost
effective basis.

 17. Under the proposed financing, as explained in the Application, the
currently

 effective amended and restated credit agreement between EWI and Bank of America
("BOA")

 will be replaced by a new senior credit agreement between GNI and BOA ("the BOA
Senior

 Credit Facility"). This GNI financing will take the form of a $42 million
revolving line of credit

 that will be available for a period of five years for GNI to provide funds
pursuant to

 intercompany notes to Frontier and the other regulated operating utilities,
designed to ensure the

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 5

 regulated utilities such as Frontier have adequate access to capital during the
winter season and

 in order to procure gas supply in connection with operations, as well as for
other general

 operational purposes. Guarantees of the BOA Senior Credit Facility will be
required only from

 the unregulated subsidiaries of GNI and from NIC, while GNI will be the sole
Borrower. No

 direct recourse from BOA will extend to regulated subsidiaries downstream ofNIC
such as to

 Frontier. The revolving facility will terminate five years from closing.

 18. GNI also plans to issue up to $50 million ofNew Senior Unsecured Notes
("the

 Senior Unsecured Notes"), the terms of which are fully discussed by James E.
Sprague, GNI

 Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, in his Affidavit. Both the proceeds
from the Senior

 Credit Facility and from the Senior Unsecured Notes will be used to refinance
the existing debt

 and provide financing for general operational purposes and system expansion.

 19. The long-term note, which details the obligations ofGNI as the issuer, as
well as

 the non-regulated subsidiary guarantors, does not include Frontier as a direct
issuer or guarantor

 (similar to the revolving line with BOA). Neither Frontier, nor any of GNI's
other regulated

 operating utilities, will have any obligation for activities, borrowings, or
guarantees provided by

 any other GNI company or directly on the long-term note.

 20. The third component of the financing is a four (4) year term debt facility
in the

 amount of $7.0 million that will be used to consolidate several smaller loans
by GNI used for

 acquisition and development of an SAP software based operating system used by
all of the GNI

 companies (the "SAP Financing"). As is the case with the revolving line of
credit and the long

 term note issuance, GNI will be the sole borrower for the SAP Financing, no
guarantees will be

 required of the regulated operating utilities, including Frontier, and Frontier
will only be

 responsible through an intercompany note between GNI and Frontier for a
proportional piece of

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 6

 the SAP Financing. BOA is the proposed lender on the SAP Financing and will
require the SAP

 Software license to be pledged by GNI as collateral for this $7.0 million loan.


 21. Frontier will not have any guarantees directly to BOA. Based upon the
credit

 available through the BOA Senior Credit Facility, Senior Unsecured Notes, and
SAP Financing,

 Frontier will be eligible to draw a total of$15.9 million for its own
operational needs ($7.2

 million under the revolving line of credit, $8.7 million under the long-term
debt) and in addition

 receive $1.07 5 million from the SAP Financing (of which $820,000 will pay
Frontier's portion

 of the cost of the SAP software, licenses, and installation). If approved,
Frontier will enter into

 three intercompany notes with GNI, without any obligations directly to BOA or
Merrill Lynch

 ("ML"). Under the intercompany agreements, Frontier's only obligations will be
to GNI and its

 exposure is limited to what is has borrowed and used and extends no further.

 22. There are several benefits to Frontier under this financing structure as
compared

 to the structure that has been in place since 2012. First, as mentioned,
Frontier has no direct

 responsibility to BOA for either credit facility. Further, because funds for
the individual

 operating companies are treated separately and are reserved for the operating
subsidiaries under

 distinct, standalone "silos", there is no danger that the needs of other
utilities will impinge upon

 Frontier's access to its own capital or create any risk to Frontier. Upon
approval of the

 intercompany loans requested in this application, the new debt will be put in
place, paying off the

 existing debt and Frontier will execute its intercompany notes for access to
stand-alone line of

 credit through GNI. The other operating utilities will execute their own
intercompany notes and

 have access to their own lines, independent of Frontier and any other GNI
obligations. As a

 result of this structure, there is no potential for cross-collateralization or
cross-default. Also,

 Frontier will have full access to the SAP Software and operating system and all
of the associated

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 7

 developments related to the system although it will only be responsible for a
fraction of the

 development costs. Each of the GNI entities will benefit similarly.

 23. The Company has reviewed its operating needs over the last four years,
which

 have included periods of major construction and capital expansion efforts and
periods when the

 cost of gas has been high during winter months. The total amount of the
proposed debt should

 be sufficient to give Frontier adequate headroom in meeting its operational
needs, including

 anticipated construction, cost of gas, etc. in the years ahead, based on its
current capital

 expenditure forecasts.

 24. In the previous financing proceeding, the Public Staff expressed concerns
with

 Frontier's financial obligations to BOA for the credit facility and its
execution of a limited

 recourse guarantee. The proposed financing arrangement addresses those
concerns. Unlike the

 last financing proceeding, the current financing arrangement is between GNI and
BOA, and

 Frontier and other regulated subsidiaries have no obligations to the ultimate
lender or to each

 other. Frontier will only be obligated for funds to which it has access, and no
other subsidiary or

 GNI will have access to those funds. The intercompany loan agreements between
Frontier and

 GNI will establish the limits of its obligations and make it clear that
Frontier's obligations are

 limited by its borrowings. No assets will be pledged or required by Frontier to
secure access to

 this working capital and long term debt. The only asset that is pledged as
collateral for any of

 the three facilities is the SAP Software, pledged by GNI. This structure should
significantly

 reduce or even eliminate the prior concerns that the Public Staff had regarding
Frontier's

 obligations.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 8

 25. Frontier has continued to add to its infrastructure to access new market
areas and

 to expand service in its service territory. As noted in the testimony filed in
Frontier's annual

 review of gas costs dockets, the number of customers served by Frontier has
increased 26% from

 2011 to 2012, 28% from 2012 to 2013, 27.7% from 2013 to 2014 and 11.8% from
2014 to 2015.

 Frontier needs both short-term and long-term debt resources in order to have
sufficient access to

 meet cyclical cash flow needs throughout the year, to pay fixed expenses during
non-heating

 months, to benefit from seasonal opportunities and provide operational
flexibility to lower

 overall costs, and to provide long-term financing for capital investments to
allow it to continue to

 grow as it has over the past few years.

 26. I believe that the proposed intercompany agreements with GNI offer the most
cost

 effective option for financing for Frontier. What I have learned over the past
year is that many

 lenders are not familiar with the utility and gas industry and are hesitant to
lend or offer credit at

 a premium in order to cover their perception of potential risks. In addition,
financing is an area

 where there are economies of scale. At the parent level, due to the size of the
facility, GNI is

 better able to secure more favorable interest rates and other terms, and pass
those benefits on to

 Frontier through the intercompany agreements.

 27. Finally, I want to note that Frontier currently has a shared services
agreement with

 EWI, which has been previously filed with the Commission. This agreement
allowed EWI to

 charge Frontier for shared services. Since EWI will no longer be the parent of
Frontier, the

 Company will need to enter into a new shared services agreement with NIC (and
NIC will in turn

 enter into a similar agreement with GNI). The new shared services agreements
shall contain the

 same terms as those in the existing agreement; the only difference is that
current intermediate

 holding company has been substituted for GNI as the party to the agreement with
Frontier.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 9

 Under these arrangements, centralized administrative and professional services
such as

 accounting, legal, engineering, technology systems, data management or other
shared services

 for GNI subsidiaries are provided. Expenses that arise from the individual
needs of any specific

 subsidiary are directly assigned to that entity. This will continue to ensure
that Frontier's

 ratepayers are only responsible for those expenditures necessary for the
efficient and reliable

 operation of Frontier. This new shared service agreement will be filed with the
Commission

 upon approval of the corporate reorganization,

 Further affiant sayeth not.

                                US Official News

                            February 22, 2016 Monday

Regulatory update: North Carolina Utilities Commission; Frontier Natural Gas
Company, LLC, has issued (G-40 Sub 133) Application for Approval of Corporate
Reorganization and Debt Refinancing

LENGTH: 2831 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Raleigh: North Carolina Utilities Commission has issued the following document
(docket):



 and its

 customers.

 4. The proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier include three

 (3) agreements: (1) Revolving Line of Credit for access to $7.2 million; (2)
Long Term Note in

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 1

 the amount of$8.7 million; and (3) Four Year Term Note for the SAP IT Operating
System in

 the amount of$1.075 million.



 5. As is more fully described in the Application verified by Kevin Degenstein
and

 Jim Sprague, this new corporate structure and the new the intercompany
financing agreements

 through which Frontier will receive its financing require Commission approval
pursuant to

 N.C.G.S. §§ 62-111(a), 62-153, and 62-161 . I am providing this Affidavit
concurrently with,

 and in support of, the Application requesting this approval.

 Corporate Reorganization

 6. Under the current corporate structure, GNI is the ultimate parent of several


 entities including Energy West Incorporated (EWI). GNI also separately owns
other regulated

 utilities that operate distribution systems and an intrastate pipeline in Ohio
and is the parent of

 several unregulated entities as well. EWI is the parent of several regulated
utilities in Montana,

 Maine, and North Carolina, including Frontier Utilities of North Carolina, Inc.
("Frontier

 Utilities"), which is the intermediate holding company for Frontier. A current
corporate

 structure is set forth in Exhibit 1 attached to this Affidavit.

 Having EWI, which is regulated by the Montana Commission, serve as the parent
of

 Frontier Utilities and other regulated utilities, as well as GNI' s ownership
of other unregulated

 businesses in other states, has created in my opinion the potential for
jurisdictional conflict,

 confusion in accountability, and the potential for inconsistent practices among
subsidiaries.

 7. Under the newly proposed corporate structure, GNI would continue to be the

 ultimate parent of Frontier. However, Frontier Utilities will be dissolved and
a new subsidiary

 of GNI (currently designated as a newly formed intermediary company ("NIC") for
the purpose

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 2

 of the Application) would serve as the holding company for Frontier as well as
the other

 regulated affiliates operating in Ohio, Montana and Maine.

 8. The regulated subsidiaries would all become direct, separate subsidiaries of
GNI

 through NIC, not through a variety of different regulated and non-regulated
holding companies.

 GNI will also directly own the other non-regulated companies currently
operating in the Midwest

 and Montana, but these unregulated companies will be separate from the
regulated companies

 The new proposed corporate structure is set forth below in Exhibit 2 attached
to this Affidavit.

 9. It is my opinion and belief that this new proposed structure is beneficial
for a

 number of reasons. It essentially separates Frontier, as a North Carolina
regulated utility, for

 corporate formation, operational, regulatory, and financing purposes and
provides for consistent

 governance over all regulated utilities. It eliminates the concern of potential
multi-jurisdictional

 regulatory conflict and potential confusion by GNI' s current ownership
structure of regulated

 and unregulated subsidiaries. It still provides, however, the benefits of being
part of a larger

 organization with shared resources, expertise, and best practices, economies of
scale, and access

 to capital, as illustrated by the proposed financed discussed below.

 Debt Financing Agreements

 10. As part ofthe last financing case filed in Docket G-40, Sub 105 and
approved by

 Commission Order dated August 8, 2012 ("Refinancing Order"), the Commission
approved a

 credit agreement between Energy West Incorporated ("EWI") and Frontier that
consisted of a

 $30 million unsecured revolving line of credit and a $10 million unsecured
long-term debt

 facility. Frontier was a part of the pool of guarantors of this financing,
along with other EWI

 subsidiaries, and provided a limited recourse guarantee of $12.8 million of the
aggregate amount.

 During the proceedings, the Public Staff expressed concerns that the $12.8
million limited

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 3

 recourse guarantee of Frontier could cause Frontier to guarantee more debt than
EWI had

 borrowed and provided on Frontier's behalf, but ultimately recommended the
approval to avoid

 the risks created by rejection of the proposed refinancing transactions.

 11. That debt package is not in default and is still providing financing to
Frontier, but

 it expires in a little over a year, on April 1, 2017. Since the time of the
Refinancing Order in

 2012, GNI and its subsidiaries, including Frontier, have been exploring
alternative forms of

 financing, as well as a new corporate structure, as described above, to
accommodate and

 facilitate this financing.

 12. Beginning in November 2014, I began identifying potential lenders for

 replacement financing directly to Frontier. I sent letters attached to this
Affidavit as Exhibit 3 to

 Yadkin Bank, BB&T, Carter Banlc & Trust, and First Community Bank requesting
term sheets

 for a Term Loan and revolving Line of Credit for Frontier. I also provided each
ofthese banks

 with information about Frontier in order for them to evaluate and respond to
our request,

 including financial statements, service territory maps, corporate
organizational chart, listing of

 the property, plant, and equipment, schedule of rates for all classes of
customers, schedule of

 largest customers and their annual usage, regulatory reports, pipeline maps
showing the

 transmission, distribution, and service lines, and schedule showing the number
of customers in

 each of the service areas served by Frontier.

 13. To follow-up, I had several individual meetings with representatives from
Yadkin

 Bank and First Community Bank, culminating in meetings by Kevin Degenstein, Jed
Henthorne,

 and me with each banlc on April27, 2015. In addition, I met with
representatives ofBB&T in

 mid-2015. I also had several telephone conversations with bankers at Carter
Bank & Trust to

 assess their interest and answer their questions.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 4

 14. After all of these efforts over several months, the only bank that
submitted a term

 sheet was First Community Bank which is attached hereto as Confidential Exhibit
4. Based

 upon this experience, it is my belief that Frontier's small size was a major
impediment to

 receiving attractive financing options from independent lenders.

 15. I evaluated the proposal from First Community Bank carefully, but concluded
that

 it did not provide the flexibility and terms necessary for Frontier's financing

 would allow Frontier to continue to operate successfully and expand as we

                              516 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                 The State Journal- Register (Springfield, IL)

                           October 10, 2013 Thursday

SECTION: IL NEWS; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 358 words


The backlog of loan approvals through the U.S. Small Business Administration has
continued to grow since funding lapsed Oct. 1, local program coordinators said
Wednesday.

Private and not-for-profit lenders continue to process applications. But SBA is
not signing off on loans during the partial government shutdown.

A voicemail message at the SBA branch office in Springfield said help is not
available, as a result of the funding lapse.

"We use them all the time," said Kevin Lust, director of the Illinois Small
Business Development Center at Lincoln Land Community College.

Lust said SBA loan guarantees are popular, especially with start-up businesses
that have difficulty obtaining conventional financing. While no applications
were pending at the time of the shutdown, Lust said further delays will only
make it more difficult for would-be entrepreneurs.

The SBA guarantee also reduces risk for the banks, Lust said.

"SBA will guarantee up to 90 percent of the loan," he said. "If you borrow
$100,000 and never make a payment, the bank is only out $10,000."

The president of Growth Corp., a Springfield not-for-profit that is one of the
nation's largest SBA loan partners, said the company processes applications up
to the point SBA approval is required.

"Although it generally takes us a week or less to put together our part," Doug
Kinley said in an email, "the backlog at SBA is growing fairly quickly."

Growth Corp. facilities SBA "504" loans for major equipment and real estate
purchases in Illinois, as well as parts of Missouri, Indiana, Iowa and Kentucky.

The company processed more than $368 million in investments in 2012.

SBA has continued to accept disaster loan applications during the shutdown.

The SBA shutdown has complicated the work of SCORE, the Service Corps of Retired
Executives, said John Bury, chairman of the SCORE chapter in Springfield. Bury
said the volunteer group often refers clients to SBA and relies on the agency
for workshops on starting or expanding small businesses.

"We can't use it for our clients, which is a problem," Bury said.

Tim Landis can be reached at 788-1536. Follow him at twitter.com/timlandisSJR.

LOAD-DATE: October 11, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Article

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2013 The State Journal- Register
                              All Rights Reserved


                              517 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                 therecord.com

                            April 25, 2009 Saturday
                                 Final Edition

Quebec lends Alcoa M$50 to ride out 'storm'

BYLINE: Ross Marowits

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C5

LENGTH: 442  words

DATELINE: MONTREAL


The Quebec government has joined workers, suppliers and the City of Baie Comeau
in helping U.S. aluminum producer Alcoa to withstand the economic slowdown by
agreeing to a $50-million loan to preserve jobs.

The five-year, low-interest loan comes more than a year after the province
provided $228 million in loan guarantees toward Alcoa's US$1.2-billion
modernization project.

The aluminum business has taken a big hit since Alcoa committed to one of the
largest private investments in Quebec in years.

Aluminum prices have plunged as demand, particularly in the automobile and
construction sectors, has plunged during the global economic slowdown.

Quebec Finance and Economic Development Minister Raymond Bachand applauded Alcoa
for preserving its plans for Quebec and said the provincial government loan will
help the company to withstand the economic slowdown.

"It ensures the prosperity of Alcoa's different plants and gives it the means to
overcome the storm with strength and courage,'' he said yesterday.

The government hasn't attached any additional conditions to the loan beyond
minimum employment levels required as part of the March 2008 loan guarantee.

Alcoa spokesperson Pierre Despres said the Pittsburgh-based mining giant may
have been forced to take "extreme measures'' such as the closure of a series of
giant aluminum potlines at the North Shore smelter if the government hadn't
provided it help.

"We want to protect the level of employment," he said in an interview.

"That's in our mind key for the future of the plant to keep our employees
working."

The government assistance comes a couple of weeks after unionized employees at
Baie Comeau and two other facilities agreed to reduce weekly work hours by up to
15 per cent.

The city, 400 kilometres northeast of Quebec City, also agreed to reduce
municipal taxes and suppliers trimmed their costs by up to 15 per cent.

The Baie Comeau smelter uses an inefficient Soderberg technology. With 1,550
employees, Alcoa is the largest employer in the North Shore community.

Preliminary work has begun to upgrade the facility, including the closure of
several aluminum potlines.

But the major projects to boost capacity by 110,000 tonnes to 548,000 tonnes are
slated to begin by the end of 2010 and be completed in five years.

As a result of the modernization commitment, Alcoa renewed its power contracts
for 25 years with Hydro-Quebec for 1,562 megawatts of electricity for the
Baie-Comeau smelter and others in Deschambault and Becancour.

Alcoa Canada president Jean-Pierre Gilardeau said the government loan positions
the 52-year-old smelter to profit once the economy turns around.

LOAD-DATE: April 25, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: NEWS

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                 Northeast Missouri Electric Power Cooperative

                                3705 Business 61
                               Palmyra 63461-0191

* * * * * * * * * * EVENTS * * * * * * * * * *


USDA Reaches Goal To Fund $250m In Smart Grid Improvements

   Sep 07, 2012

   The U.S. Development of Agriculture (USDA) reached its $250m goal to finance
smart grid technologies to help modernize nation's electric system. USDA also
announced nine rural electric cooperatives and utilities in 10 states including
North Carolina will receive loan guarantees to make improvements to generation
and transmission facilities and implement smart grid technologies.With the
announcement of more than $27m in smart grid investments, USDA has met President
Obama's goal and has further enabled rural utilities to make efficiency
improvements to the electric grid that will help consumers lower their electric
bills by reducing energy use in homes and businesses.Tom Vilsack, secretary at
USDA, said, Grid modernization and deployment of 'smart grid' technology will
increase the reliability and efficiency of electric power generation. Providing
reliable, affordable electrical service contributes to stronger rural economies
and is the backbone for a prosperous rural America. These loans will help ensure
that rural areas can retain existing businesses, support new ones and have
reliable, up-to-date infrastructure. The administration has outlined a framework
for a modernized electric system that will benefit all Americans. This framework
lays out a number of public and private initiatives, including a goal of $250m
in loans for smart-grid technology deployment as part of the USDA's Rural
Utility Service, which is focused on upgrading the electric grid in rural
America. This $250m investment in loan funds for smart grid technologies means
infrastructure investment at virtually no cost to the taxpayer. These
technologies will facilitate the integration of renewable sources of electricity
into the grid, help avoid blackouts and restore power quicker when outages
occur, and reduce the need for new power plants. North Carolina's Piedmont
Electric Membership Corporation received a $30m guaranteed loan from USDA to
extend its system by 52 miles and help provide service to about 1,000 new member
consumers. The cooperative will also increase capacity for 100 current consumers
and improve the reliability of about 40 miles of line. The cooperative installed
a new automated meter system (AMI) with funds from a previous loan and will
invest approximately $150,000 of the funds from this new loan on new AMI meters
for the 1,000 new member consumers. USDA also announced that two other
cooperatives in North Carolina will receive loan guarantees. Brunswick Electric
Membership Corporation will receive a $21.5m loan to build and improve 220 miles
of distribution line and make other system improvements. Edgecombe-Martin County
Electric Membership Corporation will receive a $6.4m loan. The firm will use
about $1m of the loan to install automatic meters (AMIs). The following is a
list of rural utilities that will receive USDA funding, which is contingent upon
the recipient meeting the terms of the loan agreement. Tri-State Generation and
Transmission Association, Inc. will receive $140.5m loan to build 50 miles of
transmission line and make upgrades to the existing generation and transmission
facilities in Colorado, Nebraska, New Mexico and Wyoming. The loan amount
includes $21.8m in smart grid projects and $808,780 in environmental
improvements. The Ark Valley Electric Cooperative Association, Inc. will receive
$6.13m loan to build and improve 355 miles of distribution line and make other
system improvements in Kansa. The loan amount includes $2.01m in smart grid
projects. Stearns Cooperative Electric Association will receive $23.6m loan to
improve 147 miles of distribution line and make other system improvements in
Minnesota. The loan amount includes $974,085 in smart grid projects. Agralite
Electric Cooperative will receive $5.2m loan to build and improve 61 miles of
distribution line and make other system improvements in Minnesota. The loan
amount includes $180,968 in smart grid projects. Northeast Missouri Electric
Power Cooperative will receive $30.1m loan to build and improve 24 miles of
transmission line, build three new substations and make other improvements in
Missouri and Iowa. The loan amount includes $500,000 in smart grid projects.
Edgecombe-Martin County Electric Membership Corporation will receive $6.4m loan
to build and improve 310 miles of distribution line and two miles of
transmission line and make other system improvements in North Carolina. The loan
amount includes $1.1m in smart grid projects. Piedmont Electric Membership
Corporation will receive $30m loan to build and improve 108 miles of
distribution line and five miles of transmission line and make other system
improvements in North Carolina. Brunswick Electric Membership Corporation will
receive $21.5m loan to build and improve 220 miles of distribution line and make
other system improvements in North Carolina. Chippewa Valley Electric
Cooperative will receive $6m loan to build and improve 88 miles of distribution
line and make other system improvements in Wisconsin. The loan amount includes
$255,833 in smart grid projects. The $269m in loan guarantees announced are
provided by USDA Rural Development's Rural Utilities Service (RUS). The funding
helps electric utilities upgrade, expand, maintain and replace rural America's
electric infrastructure. USDA Rural Development also funds energy conservation
and renewable energy projects. USDA, through its rural development mission area,
administers and manages housing, business and community infrastructure programs
through a national network of state and local offices. Rural Development has an
active portfolio of more than $172 billion in loans and loan guarantees. These
programs are designed to improve the economic stability of rural communities,
businesses, residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in
rural America.


Northeast Missouri EPC Deploys Exalt Microwave Backhaul Systems

   Aug 25, 2010

   Exalt Communications, Inc. (Exalt) has announced that Northeast Missouri
Electric Power Cooperative (Northeast Missouri EPC) has deployed Exalt advanced
microwave backhaul systems. The Exalt systems now carry SCADA traffic for power
generation and transmission facilities as well as IP voice, video surveillance
traffic, and data for customer information systems operated by Northeast
Missouri EPC's eight member cooperatives.The systems to support both TDM
(time-division multiplexing) and Ethernet traffic in Northeast Missouri EPC's
evolving network.A long-time user of microwave technology, Northeast Missouri
EPC serves 21 counties in northeastern Missouri and southeastern Iowa. The
company selected Exalt systems because they deliver the native TDM and Ethernet
capabilities that allow Northeast Missouri EPC the flexibility, high
performance, and reliability to build on existing TDM infrastructure investments
while they transition to IP and prepare to support new initiatives such as smart
grid, Exalt said. Jack Elmore, communications manager at Northeast Missouri EPC,
said: We have been migrating away from T1 lines since 2007, and we needed
microwave backhaul systems that can support both TDM and Ethernet. The Exalt
systems support both types of traffic natively, and they have made it very easy
for us to move away from T1 lines. We now carry T1 traffic on only two of our
microwave links, and we expect to turn that off soon. Like other power
generation and transmission companies around the US, Northeast Missouri EPC said
that it is constantly seeking higher efficiency as it serves local utilities.
With its member cooperatives now deploying smart meters and other technologies
that require high-performance Ethernet networking, Northeast Missouri EPC has
had to evolve its network from T1-based to Ethernet. The Exalt systems have made
this an easy transition. Amir Zoufonoun, CEO of Exalt, said: With native TDM,
native Ethernet, and mission-critical reliability built into every Exalt
microwave backhaul system, we enable companies like Northeast Missouri EPC to
leverage their investments in TDM infrastructure while they migrate to IP. This
pay-as-you-grow functionality is invaluable to any utility that wants to
minimize the costs, business disruptions, and support challenges that are
typical when migrating to new technology.

                                  Farm Weekly

                           January 14, 2016 Thursday

Seal Tanami Road says Smith

BYLINE: JACINTA BOLSENBROEK

SECTION: FARM BUSINESS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 657 words


WA Liberal senator Dean Smith has called on the WA government to prioritise the
upgrading and sealing of Tanami Road in the East Kimberley.

Mr Smith, WA Transport Minister Dean Nalder and his Northern Territory
counterpart Peter Chandler, a group of State and Territory transport industry
representatives and Halls Creek shire officials in October drove down the Tanami
Road to see for themselves what a difference sealing it would make.

Following this trip, the Federal Government sought a list of preferred projects
from WA, Queensland and the NT for funding under the $600 million Northern
Australia Roads Package.

The roads package was announced in the Northern Australian White Paper, which
identified the Tanami Road and the Outback Highway as "key roads".

The WA government has yet to provide its list of preferred roads projects to the
Federal Government, but it is understood that the matter is expected to be
considered by State cabinet soon.

Mr Smith called on the WA government to make the upgrading, including the
sealing, of the Tanami Road a high order priority for funding under the federal
program.

"The Tanami Road is considered by many in WA's far north as a priority because
it will provide important access for WA's far-northern pastoral and agricultural
industries to Australia's domestic markets in the south east,'' he said.

"Improvements to the Tanami Road will provide greater access and security for
those indigenous communities and resource tenements located along its stretch.

"The key to success is to guarantee that the WA government identifies the road
as a key project so that it will align with the Federal Government's stated
interest in upgrading this vital transport link.

"The vast distances separating WA's northern communities, ports, and population
centres means modern road transport infrastructure is critical to building WA's
northern towns and communities, growing their local economies and improving
export opportunities.

"A clear commitment from the WA government, combined with the potential of
private sector investment, the provision of concessional loan guarantees is a
powerful step in developing a cost effective, commercially viable and
fast-tracked model to improving vital road infrastructure for industry and
communities across northern WA."

Mr Smith hoped progress could be made ahead of next week's consultations in
Darwin between federal, State and territory officials on the Turnbull
government's Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility program.

The program will provide up to $5 billion in concessional loans to help deliver
major economic infrastructure projects in Australia's north, in partnership with
the private sector.

Mr Smith said the project should be given priority status by both the
Commonwealth and WA governments as he hoped the Northern Australia Roads Package
combined with the Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility would provide the
primary source of public and private funding to stimulate infrastructure
development across northern Australia.

Mr Nalder said the Tanami Road is a priorities on his list.

"In October, I joined with Senator Smith to examine the condition of Tanami Road
and I understand and appreciate the appeals for funding from Senator Smith and
others," he said.

"Tanami Rd is one of a number of priorities that we will be submitting to the
Federal Government for consideration.

"It has social and economic attributes that make it a worthwhile project.

"There are, however, many competing projects which make it difficult to commit
further at this stage."

Tanami Road is 1014 kilometres long, stretching from the Great Northern Highway
just south of Halls Creek in WA to the Stuart Highway near Alice Springs.

Some NT sections have been sealed, or are about to be sealed, leaving some 790km
unsealed.

The Tanami Road, which is 311km long to the WA border, services Aboriginal
communities, tourism, pastoral and mining industries and is a strategic road
link.

LOAD-DATE: January 13, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


             Copyright 2016 Fairfax Media Publications Pty Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                                  Farm Weekly

                           January 14, 2016 Thursday

Seal Tanami Road says Smith

BYLINE: JACINTA BOLSENBROEK

SECTION: FARM BUSINESS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 657 words


WA Liberal senator Dean Smith has called on the WA government to prioritise the
upgrading and sealing of Tanami Road in the East Kimberley.

Mr Smith, WA Transport Minister Dean Nalder and his Northern Territory
counterpart Peter Chandler, a group of State and Territory transport industry
representatives and Halls Creek shire officials in October drove down the Tanami
Road to see for themselves what a difference sealing it would make.

Following this trip, the Federal Government sought a list of preferred projects

Australia Roads Package.

The roads package was announced in the Northern Australian White Paper, which
identified the Tanami Road and the Outback Highway as "key roads".

powerful step in developing a cost effective, commercially viable and
fast-tracked model to improving vital road infrastructure for industry and
communities across northern WA."

government's Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility program.

The program will provide up to $5 billion in concessional loans to help deliver
major economic infrastructure projects in Australia's north, in partnership with
the private sector.

Commonwealth and WA governments as he hoped the Northern Australia Roads Package
combined with the Northern Australia Infrastructure Facility would provide the
primary source of public and private funding to stimulate infrastructure
development across northern Australia.

and I understand and appreciate the appeals for funding from Senator Smith and

unsealed.

The Tanami Road, which is 311km long to the WA border, services Aboriginal

                                US Official News

                              March 7, 2014 Friday

Washington:2015 Budget Request Favors Small Reactors, Revives Nuclear Tax

LENGTH: 1136  words

DATELINE: Washington


Nuclear Energy Institute has issued the following news release:

The president's 2015 budget proposal for the Department of Energy seeks to
re-impose a multi-billion-dollar tax for the cleanup of DOE-owned uranium
enrichment facilities, a move the nuclear energy industry has rejected as
redundant and unfair. But other aspects of the budget, notably increased amounts
to support small reactor development, are more in line with industry goals.

This year marks the fifth time that the Obama administration has requested
reinstatement of the decontamination and decommissioning tax, even though
Congress has consistently turned it back.

"It is highly disconcerting that the Obama administration again is trying to
impose a 10-year tax of $200 million annually on nuclear energy companies to
finance the cleanup of DOE enrichment facilities in Kentucky, Ohio and
Tennessee," said Alex Flint, NEI's senior vice president for governmental
affairs.

"Previous Congresses have rightly rejected this attempt to force the industry to
again pay into the Decontamination and Decommissioning Fund, given that the
industry long ago met its $2.6 billion financial commitment under a 1992 law for
this important environmental protection program," Flint added.

Meanwhile, Flint noted, the federal government has not met its own requirements
to pay into the fund.

In other areas, the budget requests $97 million to support certification and
licensing assistance for two small reactor designs being developed by Babcock &
Wilcox and NuScale under a cost-share public-private partnership with DOE. This
represents an increase from the $70 million request for 2014, though a slight
reduction from the $110 million enacted by Congress.

Flint complimented DOE for its "solid support" for small reactor technology.
"Small, scalable nuclear energy facilities not only can be an innovative
addition to our electricity mix, they also can be a linchpin in U.S. efforts to
regain global leadership in clean energy technologies through international
sales of components and services," he said.

Flint added that small reactors offer an opportunity to deploy nuclear energy to
remote areas and as replacements for existing fossil-fueled plants that have
reached the end of their lifespans.

Overall, the DOE budget request for nuclear energy line items would provide $863
million, 17 percent higher than the $735 million requested for 2014 but 3
percent less than the $889 million enacted by Congress. Congress approved the
transfer of $94 million for the Idaho National Laboratory's Safeguards and
Security Program from defense accounts into the Office of Nuclear Energy in
2014, which is reflected in the 2015 request.

Most line items only saw modest changes, with a marked upward direction in those
programs related to nuclear research and development.  Reactor concepts research
and development would be trimmed by $12 million to $100 million, but DOE added a
new one-year initiative at $27.5 million called Supercritical Transformational
Electric Power Generation. The budget increases funding for nuclear energy
enabling technologies by $7 million, to $78 million.

However, the budget also requests harsh cuts for programs to train the next
generation of nuclear industry workers and advance nuclear energy education. It
would zero out university programs that support scholarships, fellowships and
junior faculty at four-year institutions and community colleges, as it has in
previous years. Congress has restored the funds each time.
USED FUEL

The administration allocated $27 million, a considerable increase, from the
Nuclear Waste Fund to complete the Yucca Mountain used fuel repository license
application review and support the Nuclear Waste Technical Review Board.
Overall, the budget includes $79 million for research, development and
integrated waste management system activities for used fuel transportation,
storage, disposal and consent-based siting of interim storage facilities.

The budget request includes a legislative proposal that would establish a $5.7
billion, 10-year management plan for used fuel and radioactive waste. The plan
would authorize annual appropriations of $200 million a year and beginning in
2018 start additional appropriations from the nuclear waste fund fee and
balances remaining in the nuclear waste fund to cover program costs.  The
proposal would also fund and authorize the Environmental Protection Agency to
begin a revision of generic disposal standards for siting of used fuel and
high-level waste facilities.

However, the budget proposes stopping DOE's MOX program, which would halt
construction of the mixed oxide fuel fabrication facility at the Savannah River
site in South Carolina--which is presently about 60 percent complete.

Calling the MOX program "a cornerstone of U.S. nonproliferation activities,"
Flint said stopping the program "will leave weapons-grade plutonium in a
weapons-usable state for the foreseeable future."

"By all objective measurements, the MOX program has proven to be a technological
success, has achieved the highest levels of safety, and has served as an
economic driver in South Carolina and nationally with more than 4,000 American
vendors in 43 states contributing to the effort," Flint said.

The MOX fuel, which would be fabricated from recycled surplus defense-origin
plutonium and uranium, is potentially a fuel for the domestic nuclear energy
industry. American Nuclear Society spokesman Craig Piercy said at a March 5
teleconference that this was likely to be "the marquee issue" in the budget
process, pitting fast reactor advocates in Congress against those favoring MOX
as a means to use reprocessed fuel.
LOAN GUARANTEES

Funding for DOE's loan guarantee program remains consistent in this budget
request, with $18.5 billion authority. DOE recently finalized the first nuclear
energy-specific loan guarantee of $ $6.5 billion to Southern Co. and its
partners to help finance the construction of two new reactors at the Plant
Vogtle site in Georgia.

Loan guarantees are not an actual appropriation and, therefore, do not represent
an outlay of taxpayer dollars when the projects they support are successfully
completed. For nuclear power projects, recipients must pay a substantial
origination fee, negotiations over which delayed final approval for the Southern
Co. loan guarantee. The guarantees aim to boost investor confidence and allow
worthy projects to obtain financing on more reasonable terms that ultimately
will lower the cost of electricity generated by the projects.

The accompanying chart shows DOE's budget numbers in categories relevant to the
nuclear energy industry. It will appear in Nuclear Energy Overview periodically,
revised to follow the federal appropriations process through the year.

For further information please visit: http://www.nei.org/

LOAD-DATE: March 12, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              All Rights Reserved

                             National Mortgage News

                                  May 30, 2011

Vendors Bundle Outsourcing, Tech For the Industry

BYLINE: Austin Kilgore

SECTION: SPECIAL REPORT; Pg. 11 Vol. 35 No. 35

LENGTH: 1077  words


Large originators and servicers have long relied on the efficiencies and cost
savings of outsourcing for a long time, some going as far as building their own
offshore facilities, known as "captives" among business process outsourcers,
explained Jon Cleaver, vice president and practice head of mortgage BPO services
at Wipro Gallagher Solutions, the Franklin, Tenn.-based mortgage subsidiary of
the India-based global conglomerate Wipro Technologies. But now, vendors like
Wipro and others are offering custom outsourced services, combined with loan
origination technology to small and midsize lenders, he said.

"Whether it's a large, middle or even community banking market, each group is
going to have a specific need," he said. "The more flexibility we can provide to
each client, the easier we're going to be able to meet that need."

Approximately 25% of Wipro's 120,000 associates work in its BPO businesses,
while the rest focus on information technology in a variety of industries. Wipro
has long provided mortgage industry outsourcing, but purchased Gallagher
Financial Solutions in 2008 to acquire its loan origination system, NetOxygen.
Now, WGS offers its LOS as a standalone technology, as well as a bundled package
that combines back-office underwriting and closing services performed in
outsourcing centers.

By providing both the technology and the outsourcing, workers at both the
outsourcer and lenders have access to the same Web-based systems and workflow.

"Strategically, you are working with one vendor who has skin in the game and a
deep knowledge of the process and the technology," said Anil Raibagi, CEO of the
Wipro Gallagher Solutions unit. "That helps you focus on your core business,
which is originating loans and allowing your partner to deal with the back
office."

Mortgage outsourcers like WGS and ISGN, another global firm with mortgage
operations based in Bensalem, Pa., typically pick up the process after a local
loan officer has taken the application from a prospective borrower. The
outsourcer can conduct any combination of underwriting and settlement services
tasks, as well as closing and post-closing delivery. Some lenders chose to
handle certain steps in the process and outsource others. Since both sides are
using the same technology and workflow, the partnership is more integrated.

Small and midsize lenders use outsourcing differently than large lenders,
explained Chetan Patel, executive vice president at ISGN, another provider of
bundled technology and BPO services.

Small banks with volatile origination volume-anywhere from single digits to a
few dozen loans a week-don't want the overhead associated with full-time staff
for underwriting, so they outsource it. They can pay either per closed loan or
in stage-based pricing, where incremental steps in the process are paid
piecemeal.

"The fallout ratio in this space is pretty high," Patel said. "If they want to
pay per closed loan, the price is a little bit higher, but if they want to pay
per registered loan, then the price gets cheaper."

Some lenders chose to list these costs on the good-faith estimate and HUD-1 as
origination costs, while others roll that cost into the application fee. By
outsourcing the back-office operations, Patel said small lenders can realize
cost savings up to 30%.

It's a different strategy for larger lenders, who tend to retain 60% of their
expected volume in-house and outsource the remaining 40% of their volume.

"With market fluctuation they believe their volume will never dip below 60%,"
Patel said. "We have commitments from them that 40% of their volume is coming to
us or a definite number of loans and above that is the market fluctuation."

When a large originator sees a spike in business, they outsource it to keep
costs and turn times down.

ISGN offers two different LOS platforms, one for small lenders and another for
larger clients. Both technologies integrate with ISGN's outsourcing services.
The company is in the process of bringing a new platform to market that combines
the strengths of both platforms into a single browser-based LOS for both
segments of the market, called Catapult.

In addition to the overhead cost savings, Patel said ISGN offers a guarantee on
its underwriting services. "If an on-staff underwriter makes a mistake, there is
no recourse because he's your employee," he said. "With an outsourcing
arrangement, if we make a mistake, there is recourse available because we
provide a guarantee on the underwriting."

While lenders of all sizes are outsourcing mortgage originating, it's not always
happening from offshore facilities. Wipro has a center in Tennessee that handles
mortgage work, including consumer facing call center activity, and another
nonmortgage facility in Atlanta that won an award in 2009 for promoting job
growth in the area. Likewise, ISGN has major domestic centers in Connecticut,
Florida and Texas and satellite offices in Michigan, Georgia and Pennsylvania.

ISGN's Michigan center in the Detroit suburb of Livonia was previously part of
Fiserv's loan fulfillment solutions, where tasks like broker price opinions,
loss mitigation and closing and settlement services were handled. Since ISGN
acquired the business at the end of 2009, it's consolidated those tasks into its
Connecticut center. But ISGN's presence in Livonia, an area with an unemployment
rate near 12%, will continue, Patel said. Instead, the Livonia center is being
revamped to handle due diligence work for servicers dealing with high levels of
borrower foreclosures and bankruptcies. "In the long term, we are not pulling
out of Livonia. We are looking to add in different types of services...because
we can get the staff and resources available at an attractive price."

Wipro also sees benefit in having domestic outsourcing. "I still talk to people
today where the minute you say outsourcing they picture some back office
overseas location," Cleaver said. "You're seeing an evolution and an education
and a maturity of not only the outsourcing from a vendor perspective, but also
from the lender side of the house."

Lenders don't want to appear as if they're outsourcing work overseas during a
time of high unemployment, Cleaver said. "With everything that's gone on the
last couple of years, everybody's sensitive about everything. From a lender's
perspective, it's a sensitive issue," he continued. "But from a long-term
strategic analysis, you've got to do what's right for the company and its
longevity."

URL: http://www.nationalmortgagenews.com//

LOAD-DATE: May 31, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: NMN
