                              570 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             August 10, 2015 Monday

Illinois: USDA invests in renewable energy, energy efficiency projects

LENGTH: 705  words

DATELINE: Springfield


Financial Managers Society has issued the following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced $63 million in loans and grants for
264 renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide that USDA is
supporting through its Rural Energy for America Program (REAP).

"This funding will have far-reaching economic and environmental impacts
nationwide, particularly in rural communities," Vilsack said. "Investing in
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects supports home-grown energy
sources, creates jobs, reduces greenhouse gas pollution and helps usher in a
more secure energy future for the nation."

These REAP projects are expected to generate and/or save 207.8 million kilowatt
hours (KWh) of energy - enough to power more than 13,600 homes for a year.

For example, Bradley Phillips, owner of A.B. Phillips & Sons Fruit Farm, is
receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in
the village of Berlin Heights, Ohio. The system will generate nearly 13,000
kilowatt hours of electricity annually. Phillips grows apples, peaches, pears,
plums, raspberries, cherries and grapes on a farm that has been in his family
for more than a century.

Blue Sky Poultry, Inc., of Bainbridge, Ga., has been selected for a $16,094
grant to install a solar array on the roof of the poultry houses. The array is
expected to generate 36,300 kWh of electricity per year.

Stokes Farms, LLP, of Chatfield, Minn., is receiving a $19,750 grant to install
a 10 kW wind turbine. When operational, the project is expected to generate
30,000 kWh of electricity per year.

Lakeview Biodiesel, LLC will use a $3.3 million loan guarantee to help acquire a
Missouri biodiesel plant and make improvements to bring it online to produce
enough biodiesel to run approximately 16,500 vehicles annually.

In North Carolina, South Winston Farm, LLC is receiving a $4 million loan
guarantee to finance a 7 megawatt solar array system that is expected to
generate enough energy to power 994 households per year.

Funding for the projects announced today is contingent upon the recipients
meeting the terms of the grant or loan agreement.

Here are two examples of how REAP has helped rural businesses:

In 2014, Mt. Abram, a ski area in western Maine, finished installing an
803-panel solar photovoltaic system that was financed with a $235,000 REAP
grant. Mt. Abram is the first solar-powered ski area in the state and the
second-largest solar-powered ski area in the country. The solar array will
generate 280,000 kWh in energy each year and meet about 70 percent of the
resort's power needs.
Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack visited Progress Solar in North Carolina in
September 2014 to highlight a $3.4 million REAP loan guarantee the company
received to install a solar array. Today, the 46-acre farm produces enough solar
energy to power 540 average-sized homes each year.
Eligible agricultural producers and rural small businesses may use REAP funds to
make energy efficiency improvements or install renewable energy systems,
including solar, wind, renewable biomass (including anaerobic digesters), small
hydroelectric, ocean energy, hydrogen, and geothermal.

The next application deadline for REAP grants is November 2, 2015. USDA will
issue a notice of available funding with more details on how to apply in the
coming weeks. REAP was created by the 2008 Farm Bill and was reauthorized by the
2014 Farm Bill.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, USDA has supported more than 9,600
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide through REAP. During
this period, the Department has provided more than $291 million in grants and
$327 million in loan guarantees to agricultural producers and rural small
business owners.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                                US Official News

                             May 17, 2014 Saturday

Washington: USDA invests $78 M to support locally-produced food

LENGTH: 316  words

DATELINE: Washington


The Institute of Food Technologists has issued the following news release:

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack has announced that U.S. Dept. of
Agriculture (USDA) is making a $78 million investment in local and regional food
systems, including food hubs, farmers markets, aggregation and processing
facilities, distribution services, and other local food business enterprises.

"The 2014 Farm Bill has given USDA new tools, resources, and authority to
support the rural economy," said Vilsack. "Consumer demand for locally-produced
food is strong and growing, and farmers and ranchers are positioning their
businesses to meet that demand. As this sector continues to mature, we see
aggregation, processing, and distribution enterprises across the local food
supply chain growing rapidly. These historic USDA investments in support of
local food give farmers and ranchers more market opportunities, provide
consumers with more choices, and create jobs in both rural and urban
communities."

Vilsack said that $48 million in loan guarantees for local food projects is now
available through USDA's Rural Development's Business and Industry Guaranteed
Loan Program, and $30 million is available through competitive grants via the
Agricultural Marketing Service's (AMS) Farmers Market and Local Foods Promotion
Program.

The 2014 Farm Bill requires USDA to set aside at least 5% of Business and
Industry (B&I) program loan guarantees for projects that focus on local food
business enterprises. Details on how to apply for local food funding through the
B&I program are available on the Rural Development website. Applications are
accepted on a rolling basis. The B&I program has the authority to fund local
food infrastructure in urban areas as long as the project supports farm and
ranch income and expands healthy food access in underserved communities.

For more information please visit: http://www.ift.org

LOAD-DATE: May 18, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                            August 8, 2015 Saturday

USDA Invests $63 Million to Support 264 Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency
Projects Nationwide

LENGTH: 708  words

DATELINE: Washington


U.S. Department of Agriculture  has issued the following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced $63 million in loans and
grants for 264 renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide that
USDA is supporting through its Rural Energy for America Program (REAP).

"This funding will have far-reaching economic and environmental impacts
nationwide, particularly in rural communities," Vilsack said. "Investing in
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects supports home-grown energy
sources, creates jobs, reduces greenhouse gas pollution and helps usher in a
more secure energy future for the nation."

These REAP projects are expected to generate and/or save 207.8 million kilowatt
hours (KWh) of energy - enough to power more than 13,600 homes for a year.

For example, Bradley Phillips, owner of A.B. Phillips & Sons Fruit Farm, is
receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in
the village of Berlin Heights, Ohio. The system will generate nearly 13,000
kilowatt hours of electricity annually. Phillips grows apples, peaches, pears,
plums, raspberries, cherries and grapes on a farm that has been in his family
for more than a century.

Blue Sky Poultry, Inc., of Bainbridge, Ga., has been selected for a $16,094
grant to install a solar array on the roof of the poultry houses. The array is
expected to generate 36,300 kWh of electricity per year.

Stokes Farms, LLP, of Chatfield, Minn., is receiving a $19,750 grant to install
a 10 kW wind turbine. When operational, the project is expected to generate
30,000 kWh of electricity per year.

Lakeview Biodiesel, LLC will use a $3.3 million loan guarantee to help acquire a
Missouri biodiesel plant and make improvements to bring it online to produce
enough biodiesel to run approximately 16,500 vehicles annually.

In North Carolina, South Winston Farm, LLC is receiving a $4 million loan
guarantee to finance a 7 megawatt solar array system that is expected to
generate enough energy to power 994 households per year.

Funding for the projects announced today is contingent upon the recipients
meeting the terms of the grant or loan agreement.

Here are two examples of how REAP has helped rural businesses:

In 2014, Mt. Abram, a ski area in western Maine, finished installing an
803-panel solar photovoltaic system that was financed with a $235,000 REAP
grant. Mt. Abram is the first solar-powered ski area in the state and the
second-largest solar-powered ski area in the country. The solar array will
generate 280,000 kWh in energy each year and meet about 70 percent of the
resort's power needs.
    Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack visited Progress Solar in North Carolina
in September 2014 to highlight a $3.4 million REAP loan guarantee the company
received to install a solar array. Today, the 46-acre farm produces enough solar
energy to power 540 average-sized homes each year.

Eligible agricultural producers and rural small businesses may use REAP funds to
make energy efficiency improvements or install renewable energy systems,
including solar, wind, renewable biomass (including anaerobic digesters), small
hydroelectric, ocean energy, hydrogen, and geothermal.

The next application deadline for REAP grants is November 2, 2015. USDA will
issue a notice of available funding with more details on how to apply in the
coming weeks. REAP was created by the 2008 Farm Bill and was reauthorized by the
2014 Farm Bill.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, USDA has supported more than 9,600
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide through REAP. During
this period, the Department has provided more than $291 million in grants and
$327 million in loan guarantees to agricultural producers and rural small
business owners.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

                              573 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                   The Star Phoenix (Saskatoon, Saskatchewan)

                             May 20, 2010 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Care home deal scary reminder of bad old days

BYLINE: The StarPhoenix

SECTION: FORUM; Pg. A14

LENGTH: 701  words


It's an inauspicious start for a government that only weeks ago opened
Saskatchewan's door wider to providing more health-related services through
private third parties, saying taxpayers wouldn't be paying a dime more for them
than they pay through the publicly run system.

No matter how Health Minister Don McMorris tries to explain that the Saskatoon
Health Region's contract with Amicus Health Care Inc. to build a 100-bed
long-term care home in Saskatoon is a good deal for taxpayers, troubling
questions remain about the deal.

Quite apart from the minister using the health region as a cat's-paw to distance
the government from the project, which is being built on the basis of an
untendered contract let by Amicus to a company headed by a generous supporter of
the Saskatchewan Party, there's little "innovative" about the arrangement, as
Mr. McMorris describes it.

Never mind that the minister tried to claim that the details were still being
worked on when in fact a memorandum of understanding had been signed in March
and shovels hit the dirt in April, this is a publicly funded project whose
eventual beneficiary will be the nominal private developer.

To all appearances, and to anyone with a memory of the state of Saskatchewan's
books over the past couple of decades, the financial arrangement between Amicus
and the government (the health region being the political puppet) has all the
earmarks of being a loan guarantee.

Despite Mr. McMorris's exhortation that, "We're not going to the bank and
signing any sort of note for Amicus," it will be interesting to see how the
provincial auditor views an arrangement that has taxpayers paying a premium of
$3,000 a day to offset the company's capital costs for the 100 beds, or about
$1.1 million a year if the $185-per-bed rate doesn't change.

And with the government on the hook for the expected 25-year mortgage Amicus, a
subsidiary of the Catholic Health Ministry of Saskatchewan, has taken out should
either party decide to terminate the deal, this arrangement is a good
old-fashioned loan guarantee of the kind that once had Saskatchewan's books in
an absolutely frightening mess.

For a cash-strapped provincial government, it might seem like a good idea to try
to fob off such funding arrangements as somehow being a unique approach to doing
the public's business via third parties, but a closer look suggests they are
hardly sound public policy.

The current system requires third parties that operate facilities to put up 35
per cent of the costs of such projects and the province the rest, with ownership
remaining with taxpayers. In this case, even though Amicus takes out the
mortgage, the loan is fully backed by taxpayers who pay a higher-than-usual fee
for the services of the facilities in order to compensate the company and the
company gets eventual ownership.

The fuss created in 2006 when St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Humboldt, which was
owned by the Saskatchewan Catholic Health Corp. but was publicly funded, decided
it would no longer perform elective tubal ligation surgeries is informative.

The hospital's board decided that the new hospital to replace St. Elizabeth's
would be turned over to the health region when 69 per cent of residents from the
surrounding 40 communities indicated they'd prefer it to be run under secular
policies.

With the new Saskatoon long-term care facility designed to include about 20
suites to accommodate couples, what will be the decision if a gay couple chooses
to apply for residency in this publicly funded facility that's owned by a
Catholic organization?

If all taxpayers including gay people are paying the mortgage and the marriage
is legal, can Amicus deny them a home?

Of course, for cash-strapped politicians whose thinking is limited to four-year
electoral cycles, that's a problem for another day and a different minister.

But public policy should be for the longer term, especially when it involves a
25-year mortgage and people's lives.

- - -

"Democracy cannot be maintained without its foundation: free public opinion and
free discussion throughout the nation of all matters affecting the state within
the limits set by the criminal code and the common law." - The Supreme Court of
Canada, 1938

LOAD-DATE: May 20, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Business; Editorial

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Washington: USDA Invests $63 Million to Support 264 Renewable Energy and Energy
Efficiency Projects Nationwide

LENGTH: 707  words

DATELINE: Washington


United States Department of Agriculture has issued the following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced $63 million in loans and
grants for 264 renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide that
USDA is supporting through its Rural Energy for America Program (REAP).

"This funding will have far-reaching economic and environmental impacts
nationwide, particularly in rural communities," Vilsack said. "Investing in
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects supports home-grown energy
sources, creates jobs, reduces greenhouse gas pollution and helps usher in a
more secure energy future for the nation."

These REAP projects are expected to generate and/or save 207.8 million kilowatt
hours (KWh) of energy - enough to power more than 13,600 homes for a year.

For example, Bradley Phillips, owner of A.B. Phillips & Sons Fruit Farm, is
receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in
the village of Berlin Heights, Ohio. The system will generate nearly 13,000
kilowatt hours of electricity annually. Phillips grows apples, peaches, pears,
plums, raspberries, cherries and grapes on a farm that has been in his family
for more than a century.

Blue Sky Poultry, Inc., of Bainbridge, Ga., has been selected for a $16,094
grant to install a solar array on the roof of the poultry houses. The array is
expected to generate 36,300 kWh of electricity per year.

Stokes Farms, LLP, of Chatfield, Minn., is receiving a $19,750 grant to install
a 10 kW wind turbine. When operational, the project is expected to generate
30,000 kWh of electricity per year.

Lakeview Biodiesel, LLC will use a $3.3 million loan guarantee to help acquire a
Missouri biodiesel plant and make improvements to bring it online to produce
enough biodiesel to run approximately 16,500 vehicles annually.

In North Carolina, South Winston Farm, LLC is receiving a $4 million loan
guarantee to finance a 7 megawatt solar array system that is expected to
generate enough energy to power 994 households per year.

Funding for the projects announced today is contingent upon the recipients
meeting the terms of the grant or loan agreement.

In 2014, Mt. Abram, a ski area in western Maine, finished installing an
803-panel solar photovoltaic system that was financed with a $235,000 REAP
grant. Mt. Abram is the first solar-powered ski area in the state and the
second-largest solar-powered ski area in the country. The solar array will

resort's power needs.
    Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack visited Progress Solar in North Carolina
in September 2014 to highlight a $3.4 million REAP loan guarantee the company
received to install a solar array. Today, the 46-acre farm produces enough solar
energy to power 540 average-sized homes each year.

make energy efficiency improvements or install renewable energy systems,
including solar, wind, renewable biomass (including anaerobic digesters), small
hydroelectric, ocean energy, hydrogen, and geothermal.

The next application deadline for REAP grants is November 2, 2015. USDA will
issue a notice of available funding with more details on how to apply in the
coming weeks. REAP was created by the 2008 Farm Bill and was reauthorized by the
2014 Farm Bill.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, USDA has supported more than 9,600
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide through REAP. During
this period, the Department has provided more than $291 million in grants and
$327 million in loan guarantees to agricultural producers and rural small
business owners.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

                                US Official News

                            August 11, 2015 Tuesday

Washington: USDA Invests $63 Million to Support 264 Renewable Energy and Energy
Efficiency Projects Nationwide

LENGTH: 708  words

DATELINE: Palouse Grain Growers


Palouse Grain Growers, The State of Washington has issued the following news
release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced $63 million in loans and
grants for 264 renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide that
USDA is supporting through its Rural Energy for America Program (REAP).

"This funding will have far-reaching economic and environmental impacts
nationwide, particularly in rural communities," Vilsack said. "Investing in
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects supports home-grown energy
sources, creates jobs, reduces greenhouse gas pollution and helps usher in a
more secure energy future for the nation."

These REAP projects are expected to generate and/or save 207.8 million kilowatt
hours (KWh) of energy - enough to power more than 13,600 homes for a year.

For example, Bradley Phillips, owner of A.B. Phillips & Sons Fruit Farm, is
receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in
the village of Berlin Heights, Ohio. The system will generate nearly 13,000
kilowatt hours of electricity annually. Phillips grows apples, peaches, pears,
plums, raspberries, cherries and grapes on a farm that has been in his family
for more than a century.

Blue Sky Poultry, Inc., of Bainbridge, Ga., has been selected for a $16,094
grant to install a solar array on the roof of the poultry houses. The array is
expected to generate 36,300 kWh of electricity per year.

Stokes Farms, LLP, of Chatfield, Minn., is receiving a $19,750 grant to install
a 10 kW wind turbine. When operational, the project is expected to generate
30,000 kWh of electricity per year.

Lakeview Biodiesel, LLC will use a $3.3 million loan guarantee to help acquire a
Missouri biodiesel plant and make improvements to bring it online to produce
enough biodiesel to run approximately 16,500 vehicles annually.

In North Carolina, South Winston Farm, LLC is receiving a $4 million loan
guarantee to finance a 7 megawatt solar array system that is expected to
generate enough energy to power 994 households per year.

Funding for the projects announced today is contingent upon the recipients
meeting the terms of the grant or loan agreement.

Here are two examples of how REAP has helped rural businesses:

In 2014, Mt. Abram, a ski area in western Maine, finished installing an
803-panel solar photovoltaic system that was financed with a $235,000 REAP
grant. Mt. Abram is the first solar-powered ski area in the state and the
second-largest solar-powered ski area in the country. The solar array will
generate 280,000 kWh in energy each year and meet about 70 percent of the
resort's power needs.
    Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack visited Progress Solar in North Carolina
in September 2014 to highlight a $3.4 million REAP loan guarantee the company
received to install a solar array. Today, the 46-acre farm produces enough solar
energy to power 540 average-sized homes each year.

Eligible agricultural producers and rural small businesses may use REAP funds to
make energy efficiency improvements or install renewable energy systems,
including solar, wind, renewable biomass (including anaerobic digesters), small
hydroelectric, ocean energy, hydrogen, and geothermal.

The next application deadline for REAP grants is November 2, 2015. USDA will
issue a notice of available funding with more details on how to apply in the
coming weeks. REAP was created by the 2008 Farm Bill and was reauthorized by the
2014 Farm Bill.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, USDA has supported more than 9,600
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide through REAP. During
this period, the Department has provided more than $291 million in grants and
$327 million in loan guarantees to agricultural producers and rural small
business owners.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

contact:
editorial@plusme.com

                                US Official News

                            August 11, 2015 Tuesday

Virginia: USDA Invests $63 Million to Support 264 Renewable Energy and Energy
Efficiency Projects Nationwide

LENGTH: 712  words

DATELINE: Richmond


Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services has issued the
following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced $63 million in loans and
grants for 264 renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide that
USDA is supporting through its Rural Energy for America Program (REAP).

"This funding will have far-reaching economic and environmental impacts
nationwide, particularly in rural communities," Vilsack said. "Investing in
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects supports home-grown energy
sources, creates jobs, reduces greenhouse gas pollution and helps usher in a
more secure energy future for the nation."

These REAP projects are expected to generate and/or save 207.8 million kilowatt
hours (KWh) of energy - enough to power more than 13,600 homes for a year.

For example, Bradley Phillips, owner of A.B. Phillips & Sons Fruit Farm, is
receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in
the village of Berlin Heights, Ohio. The system will generate nearly 13,000
kilowatt hours of electricity annually. Phillips grows apples, peaches, pears,
plums, raspberries, cherries and grapes on a farm that has been in his family
for more than a century.

Blue Sky Poultry, Inc., of Bainbridge, Ga., has been selected for a $16,094
grant to install a solar array on the roof of the poultry houses. The array is
expected to generate 36,300 kWh of electricity per year.

Stokes Farms, LLP, of Chatfield, Minn., is receiving a $19,750 grant to install
a 10 kW wind turbine. When operational, the project is expected to generate
30,000 kWh of electricity per year.

Lakeview Biodiesel, LLC will use a $3.3 million loan guarantee to help acquire a
Missouri biodiesel plant and make improvements to bring it online to produce
enough biodiesel to run approximately 16,500 vehicles annually.

In North Carolina, South Winston Farm, LLC is receiving a $4 million loan
guarantee to finance a 7 megawatt solar array system that is expected to
generate enough energy to power 994 households per year.

Funding for the projects announced today is contingent upon the recipients
meeting the terms of the grant or loan agreement.

Here are two examples of how REAP has helped rural businesses:

In 2014, Mt. Abram, a ski area in western Maine, finished installing an
803-panel solar photovoltaic system that was financed with a $235,000 REAP
grant. Mt. Abram is the first solar-powered ski area in the state and the
second-largest solar-powered ski area in the country. The solar array will
generate 280,000 kWh in energy each year and meet about 70 percent of the
resort's power needs.
    Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack visited Progress Solar in North Carolina
in September 2014 to highlight a $3.4 million REAP loan guarantee the company
received to install a solar array. Today, the 46-acre farm produces enough solar
energy to power 540 average-sized homes each year.

Eligible agricultural producers and rural small businesses may use REAP funds to
make energy efficiency improvements or install renewable energy systems,
including solar, wind, renewable biomass (including anaerobic digesters), small
hydroelectric, ocean energy, hydrogen, and geothermal.

The next application deadline for REAP grants is November 2, 2015. USDA will
issue a notice of available funding with more details on how to apply in the
coming weeks. REAP was created by the 2008 Farm Bill and was reauthorized by the
2014 Farm Bill.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, USDA has supported more than 9,600
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide through REAP. During
this period, the Department has provided more than $291 million in grants and
$327 million in loan guarantees to agricultural producers and rural small
business owners.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

Virginia: USDA Invests $63 Million to Support 264 Renewable Energy and Energy
Efficiency Projects Nationwide

LENGTH: 712  words

DATELINE: Richmond


Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services has issued the
following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced $63 million in loans and

receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in

Washington: USDA Invests $63 Million to Support 264 Renewable Energy and Energy
Efficiency Projects Nationwide

LENGTH: 708  words

DATELINE: Palouse Grain Growers


Palouse Grain Growers, The State of Washington has issued the following news
release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced $63 million in loans and
grants for 264 renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide that
USDA is supporting through its Rural Energy for America Program (REAP).

"This funding will have far-reaching economic and environmental impacts
nationwide, particularly in rural communities," Vilsack said. "Investing in
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects supports home-grown energy
sources, creates jobs, reduces greenhouse gas pollution and helps usher in a
more secure energy future for the nation."

These REAP projects are expected to generate and/or save 207.8 million kilowatt
hours (KWh) of energy - enough to power more than 13,600 homes for a year.

For example, Bradley Phillips, owner of A.B. Phillips & Sons Fruit Farm, is
receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in

                               dailyrecord.co.uk

                       March 17, 2015 Tuesday 1:46 PM GMT

Ineos launches Scottish pro-fracking public relations drive;
Luxembourg-based chemicals giant says its shale gas public information programme
will aim to inform local Scottish communities about unconventional oil and gas
using an "evidence based approach"

BYLINE: By Scott McCulloch

SECTION: BUSINESS,BUSINESS NEWS

LENGTH: 783 words


Chemicals giant Ineos has launched a new shale gas public information programme
with the aim of informing local Scottish communities about unconventional oil
and gas using an "evidence based approach".

The Luxembourg-based company, which has recently acquired various licenses for
shale gas 'fracking' across central Scotland and northern England, says its
public relations campaign will be rolled out from mid-April the areas where
Ineos already has Shale gas licenses.

A series of films called "The Fracking Facts" will also be screened to support
presentations which Ineos said will also be rolled out later to other
communities within Scotland's shale gas belt.

The local meetings will be led by Ineos upstream director Tom Pickering and
"supported by other Ineos staff", with the first meetings scheduled to be held
in Denny, Alloa, Falkirk, Kilsyth and Cumbernauld in April.

The chemicals giant has pledged to give communities within fracking sites up to
six per cent of total revenues, which it says equates to £2.5 billion "over the
next 10 to 15-years".

The Scottish Government has implemented a moratorium on granting planning
consents for hydraulic fracturing or "fracking" - the method by which the gas is
extracted - until a a full public consultation is carried out alongside further
research into the technique to look at planning, environmental regulation and
the impact on public health.

Ineos Upstream chief executive, Gary Haywood, said: "The Scottish government
wants the public to be fully informed about Shale gas production and we are
determined to help.

"We are launching Scotland's biggest Shale gas information programme to make
sure that local communities get a chance to hear the facts rather than the myths
about Shale gas."

Ineos have engaged London-based public relations firm Media Zoo to manage its
publicity drive, having previously engaged the firm to manage media during the
industrial dispute at the Grangemouth refinery last year.

Last year Ineos had threatened to close the Grangemouth refinery unless staff
accepted new pay and pension terms and the UK and Scottish government's provided
financial support to its long-term survival plan for Grangemouth.

Central to the survival plan were government-backed loan guarantees Ineos needed
to build the largest ethane gas storage and processing facility in Europe at the
Grangemouth site, which Ineos said would allow it to import cheaper shale gas
from the US.

This move had stemmed from Ineos reporting in 2012 an "adverse impact" from the
closure of the Elgin gas field in the North Sea resulting from a gas leak which
saw the field closed for much of the 2012 year, with full production expected to
return by 2015.

In July of last year, the UK government provided Ineos with a £230 million loan
guarantee to fund construction of the ethane storage tank, with Ineos reported
to have also invested £300 million as part of its Grangemouth survival plan
agreement.

Then in August 2014, Ineos announced it was moving into UK shale gas exploration
after agreeing a deal for a 51 per cent stake in a 400 sq km exploration licence
area in Central Scotland, which includes the Grangemouth site and surrounding
area.

Last September, Ineos announced it would give six per cent of shale gas revenues
to local communities in a bid to win support for its plans to drill in central
Scotland - a proposal reiterated by the group in today's announcement.

Ineos Upstream chief Gary Haywood says the US shale gas contracts it has in
place to power the Grangemouth plant will only guarantee supply for 15-years,
and the long-term future of the plant is dependent upon Ineos being allowed to
develop its fledgling UK shale gas business.

Last week Ineos announced it had acquired 50 per cent stakes in seven shale gas
licences in north west England and the remaining 49 per cent stake in the PEDL
133 licence area in central Scotland from Igas Energy.

PEDL 133 covers 329 square kilometres of the Midland Valley of Scotland, which
includes INEOS' Grangemouth refining and petrochemical complex and surrounding
area.

The UK Government is widely supportive of shale gas extraction, with Prime
Minister David Cameron stating in January 2014 Britain is "going all out for
shale" in the belief the UK's energy markets could be transformed on a par seen
in the US.

In September 2014 the UK Government announced plans to allow fracking companies
to drill under people's land without their agreement despite a 99 per cent
rejection rate from the 40,647 respondents to the consultation.

The coalition government argues the current laws allowing landowners to block
development of fracking under their property would lead to delays and higher
costs for operators.

LOAD-DATE: March 17, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication

JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDAR


                      Copyright 2015 Trinity Mirror, Plc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              581 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                               Irish Independent

                           October 15, 2015 Thursday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

Bank loan rules are 'choking enterprise in SMEs'

BYLINE: Colm Kelpie

SECTION: BUSINESS WEEK;BUSINESS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 498 words


THE almost universal requirement by banks for personal guarantees for SME loans
is curtailing enterprise, the agency tasked with monitoring lending to small and
medium enterprises has warned.

Credit Review office chief John Trethowan also told the Irish Independent that
businesses need to start paying closer attention to their credit scores because
legacy issues from the crises can weigh on their ability to get credit.

The review office said negative credit ratings should not, in all cases, be a
reason for declining credit.

The need to provide personal guarantees for business loans has long been a
bugbear of small businesses.

In a submission to the Central Bank as part of the latter's review of the code
of conduct for business lending to SMEs, the Credit Review Office said the issue
of personal guarantees needs to be addressed.

"This is a major issue for SMEs and the almost universal requirement for SME
credit facilities to be personally guaranteed is stymieing enterprise," the body
stated.

Mr Trethowan said banks have returned to being cashflow lenders, but with
collateral. "They always are looking for some form of backup, as well as
ascertaining whether the business can repay the proposed loan," he said.

"If it's a limited company and there are no assets in the company, then they
will go for a personal loan guarantee (PLG), or a letter of guarantee, from the
promoter of the business if he or she has any assets just to back it up," he
said.

"You have to look at each case as it comes along. We would be against just banks
asking wholesale for security, but if it's part of a deal that's going to get
the credit for the SME, then I would assume the promoter wouldn't be entering
into a loan that they couldn't see there were to repaying as well. In some
cases, it's fine."

Mr Trethowan also said businesses need to be aware of their credit rating.

"Our business community has been through hell. A lot of them have missed
payments and have various defaults on the credit scores. It's very important
that people have a good credit score and know what their credit rating is," he
said.

"Right across Europe there is a lot of ignorance in businesses about their
credit scores and their credit ratings and yet banks are using them all the time
as part of the assessment process."

Mr Trethowan said the Central Bank is building a new credit ratings system which
will be launched in the coming 12 months.

In its Central Bank submission, the Credit Review Office said negative credit
ratings should not, in all cases, be a reason for declining credit.

"Many good entrepreneurs have impaired credit ratings due to the impact of the
recession and if the issue that gave rise to the impaired credit rating has been
addressed, this should be taken into account in the credit assessment process."

In its latest assessment report, published earlier in the year, the Credit
Review Office said 2014 was the best year for loan sanctioning by AIB and Bank
of Ireland since monitoring began in 2010.

LOAD-DATE: October 15, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: IIN


             Copyright 2015 Independent Newspapers Ireland Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                              582 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Banks Offer Alternative to Liability Insurance;
Renewable Lines of Credit for Municipalities May Be Less Expensive, More
Flexible

                            January 2, 1987, Friday

By LYNN BRENNER

DATELINE: NEW YORK


In a new program designed by a municipal bond insurer and an insurance broker,
local banks will soon be selling renewable lines of credit to municipalities as
a cost-effective alternative to traditional liability insurance policies.

Commercial banks can't legally sell insurance, but the renewable line of credit
is functionally a very similar product. Municipal Liability Claims Funding, a
new program created by Ambac Indemnity Corp. and Alexander & Alexander Inc.,
will enable local banks to offer lines of credit to replace or complement
traditional municipal liability insurance policies.

Ambac, a major insurer of municipal bonds, will guarantee the municipalities'
ability to repay these banks, should their lines of credit be drawn on to pay
claims.

According to Ambac and Alexander & Alexander, the combination of a renewable
line of credit and a financial guarantee will be less expensive than traditional
liability insurance for many municipal entities.

A municipality participating in the program would essentially buy an annually
renewable line of credit from a local bank and a financial guarantee from Ambac.
The firm's guarantee confers Ambac's top credit rating on municipal borrowers.

''We expect banks will be able to offer municipal entities lower commitment fees
and interest rates as a result of the loan guarantees,'' said H. Russell Fraser,
president and chief executive officer of Ambac.

''In addition,'' he said, ''banks should be more likely to lengthen the maturity
of the loan facility while relying on Ambac's underwriting expertise.''

''Municipal Liability Claims Funding is a financial solution to an insurance
problem,'' said Michael K. White, president and chief executive officer of
Alexander & Alexander.

The program will allow banks to provide municipalities a guaranteed line of
credit ranging from a minimum of $2 million to a maximum of $50 million per
year.

Terms and conditions of the line of credit will be determined by the local bank
in conjunction with Ambac.

Mr. White and Mr. Fraser said this program can be more cost effective than
municipal bonds. Use of the line of credit is at the discretion of the municipal
entity and is only drawn down if needed.

It can be used to complement traditional insurance programs by filling gaps at
various levels of primary, excess, or catastrophe coverage for the liability
exposure of public officials and police professionals as well as other risks.

Ambac and Alexander & Alexander stressed that their program is designed to
enhance relationships between banks and their communities.

The idea, they said, is to help communities meet their specific funding needs
''through a cooperative effort with local financial institutions rather than by
forcing them into the framework of existing financial products.''

Ambac Indemnity is a major financial guarantor. The company guarantees timely
payment of principal and interest on municipal bonds in the event of default by
the issuer.

Ambac's majority owner is Citibank. Minority investors in the firm include Ambac
management, Xerox Financial Services, and Stephens Inc., an investment bank.

Alexander & Alexander is an international insurance brokerage and risk
management consultant.

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 541 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1987 American Banker, Inc.

                                US Official News

                           September 5, 2013 Thursday

Utah: Agriculture Secretary Announces Electric System Improvements in Eight
States

LENGTH: 841  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Department of Agriculture, The State of Utah has issued the following news
release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced funding for projects in eight
states, including Virginia, to improve electric service for about 10,000 rural
residents. Rural Utilities Service Administrator John Padalino made the
announcement on the Secretary's behalf in Norfolk, Va., during the 2013 regional
meeting of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association. The loan
guarantees are made available through the U.S. Department of Agriculture's
(USDA) rural utilities program and include more than $11 million in smart grid
project funding.

"These investments will continue to ensure safe, reliable and affordable service
for rural residents, farmers, and commercial and industrial consumers," Padalino
said. "This funding, which is part of the Obama Administration's vision for a
new rural energy economy, includes investments in smart grid technologies that
modernize our nation's electric system and improve its operation."

For example, the Central Virginia Electric Cooperative will use USDA funding to
build 327 miles of line and invest more than $1.1 million in smart grid
technologies across 14 counties. The following is a list of rural electric
utilities that will receive USDA funding, contingent upon the recipient meeting
the terms of the loan agreement.

Iowa

Midland Power Cooperative - $25,300,000. Funds will be used to serve 530
customers, build 552 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $520,000 for smart grid projects.

Kansas

Lane-Scott Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $28,460,000. USDA funds will be used to
serve 580 customers, build 121 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $3,000,000 for smart grid projects.
    Bluestem Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $12,850,000. Funds will be used to
serve 431 customers, build 62 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $312,000 for smart grid projects.

Missouri and Iowa

United Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $26,625,000. Funds will be used to serve 652
customers, build 167 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements.

North Carolina

Halifax Electric Membership Corporation - $4,050,000. Funds will be used to
improve 2 miles of distribution line and make other system improvements.

New Mexico and Texas

Lea County Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $24,508,000. Funds will be used to serve
1,158 customers, build 138 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $75,000 for smart grid projects.

Ohio

South Central Power Company - $64,000,000. Funds will be used to serve 5,160
customers, build 558 miles of distribution line, 34 miles of transmission line
and make other system improvements. The loan amount includes $6,370,485 for
smart grid projects.

Virginia

Central Virginia Electric Cooperative - $22,100,000. Funds will be used to serve
1,989 customers, build 327 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $1,157,330 for smart grid projects.

The $207.9 million in USDA loan guarantees announced today will be used to build
nearly 2,000 miles of line, fund more than $11 million in smart grid projects
and make other system improvements. Since 2011, USDA has invested more than $526
million in smart grid technologies nationwide.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

USDA's investments in rural communities support the rural way of life that
stands as the backbone of our American values. President Obama and Agriculture
Secretary Vilsack are committed to a smarter use of Federal resources to foster
sustainable economic prosperity and ensure the government is a strong partner
for businesses, entrepreneurs and working families in rural communities.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, has a portfolio of programs
designed to improve the economic stability of rural communities, businesses,
residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in rural
America. USDA has made a concerted effort to deliver results for the American
people, even as the Department implements sequestration - the across-the-board
budget reductions mandated under terms of the Budget Control Act.

USDA has already undertaken historic efforts since 2009 to save more than $828
million in taxpayer funds through targeted, common-sense budget reductions.
These reductions have put USDA in a better position to carry out its mission,
while implementing sequester budget reductions in a fair manner that causes as
little disruption as possible.

For further information please visit: http://www.usda.gov/

LOAD-DATE: September 5, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2013 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                              585 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             August 7, 2015 Friday

Arizona: USDA Invests $63 Million to Support 264 Renewable Energy and Energy
Efficiency Projects Nationwide

LENGTH: 712  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Department of Agriculture has issued the following news release:

WASHINGTON, August 7, 2015 - Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced
$63 million in loans and grants for 264 renewable energy and energy efficiency
projects nationwide that USDA is supporting through its Rural Energy for America
Program (REAP).

"This funding will have far-reaching economic and environmental impacts
nationwide, particularly in rural communities," Vilsack said. "Investing in
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects supports home-grown energy
sources, creates jobs, reduces greenhouse gas pollution and helps usher in a
more secure energy future for the nation."

These REAP projects are expected to generate and/or save 207.8 million kilowatt
hours (KWh) of energy - enough to power more than 13,600 homes for a year.

For example, Bradley Phillips, owner of A.B. Phillips & Sons Fruit Farm, is
receiving an $18,000 grant to install a photovoltaic solar system on his farm in
the village of Berlin Heights, Ohio. The system will generate nearly 13,000
kilowatt hours of electricity annually. Phillips grows apples, peaches, pears,
plums, raspberries, cherries and grapes on a farm that has been in his family
for more than a century.

Blue Sky Poultry, Inc., of Bainbridge, Ga., has been selected for a $16,094
grant to install a solar array on the roof of the poultry houses. The array is
expected to generate 36,300 kWh of electricity per year.

Stokes Farms, LLP, of Chatfield, Minn., is receiving a $19,750 grant to install
a 10 kW wind turbine. When operational, the project is expected to generate
30,000 kWh of electricity per year.

Lakeview Biodiesel, LLC will use a $3.3 million loan guarantee to help acquire a
Missouri biodiesel plant and make improvements to bring it online to produce
enough biodiesel to run approximately 16,500 vehicles annually.

In North Carolina, South Winston Farm, LLC is receiving a $4 million loan
guarantee to finance a 7 megawatt solar array system that is expected to
generate enough energy to power 994 households per year.

Funding for the projects announced today is contingent upon the recipients
meeting the terms of the grant or loan agreement.

Here are two examples of how REAP has helped rural businesses:

In 2014, Mt. Abram, a ski area in western Maine, finished installing an
803-panel solar photovoltaic system that was financed with a $235,000 REAP
grant. Mt. Abram is the first solar-powered ski area in the state and the
second-largest solar-powered ski area in the country. The solar array will
generate 280,000 kWh in energy each year and meet about 70 percent of the
resort's power needs.
    Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack visited Progress Solar in North Carolina
in September 2014 to highlight a $3.4 million REAP loan guarantee the company
received to install a solar array. Today, the 46-acre farm produces enough solar
energy to power 540 average-sized homes each year.

Eligible agricultural producers and rural small businesses may use REAP funds to
make energy efficiency improvements or install renewable energy systems,
including solar, wind, renewable biomass (including anaerobic digesters), small
hydroelectric, ocean energy, hydrogen, and geothermal.

The next application deadline for REAP grants is November 2, 2015. USDA will
issue a notice of available funding with more details on how to apply in the
coming weeks. REAP was created by the 2008 Farm Bill and was reauthorized by the
2014 Farm Bill.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, USDA has supported more than 9,600
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide through REAP. During
this period, the Department has provided more than $291 million in grants and
$327 million in loan guarantees to agricultural producers and rural small
business owners.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2015 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited

                              586 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                          September 28, 2011 Wednesday

USDA tours co-op

BYLINE: By HOWARD WEISS-TISMAN / Reformer Staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 401 words


Wednesday September 28, 2011

BRATTLEBORO -- U.S. Department of Agriculture staff were on hand Tuesday to get
a first hand look at the ongoing construction at the Brattleboro Food Co-op.

USDA backed up a $4.2-million loan, which was crucial for the co-op to move
ahead with its expansion project, and Deputy Secretary Kathleen Merrigan, along
with other USDA employees from the Montpelier office, toured the site.

Merrigan is from Greenfield, Mass., and she said she has shopped at the
Brattleboro Food Co-op.

"I'm excited about this unbelievable expansion," she said. "People ask what
happens to their tax dollars and here is a perfect example of where those
investments go."

The Brattleboro Food Co-op is building a brand new store across the parking lot
from the existing building.

The USDA loan guarantee helped secure about half of the estimated $9 million the
co-op is investing in the new building.

USDA Rural Development State Director Molly Lambert said the loan guarantee fund
supports development outside of agriculture, though she added that when a
project with strong ties to agriculture, such as the co-op, comes up,
administrators are more likely to give it a greenlight.

"Our role is to create and save rural jobs and increase economic opportunities
and this project will do both," Lambert said.

USDA Rural Development Business Programs Director David Robinson said the loan
guarantee program is sometimes the only way for private groups to get the
financial backing they need to move ahead with large projects.

Robinson said the co-op, which supports more than 100 jobs and is vital to the
local farming economy, is a good example of using federal money to put together
a development project that is largely privately driven.

"This is a big part of this story," said Robinson. "This is not just the
government working by itself, but partnering with the private sector to help
make a project like this happen."

Project Manager Tom Appel said the co-op is still hoping to open the new store
in April.

He said the project has had a few construction delays, as workers tried to keep
the project moving forward, while the old co-op was open.

Appel said the store is going to try to remain open throughout the transition,
though there might be periods when it is closed while co-op staff members are
moving into the new building.

Howard Weiss-Tisman can be reached at hwtisman@reformer.com or 802-254-2311,
ext. 279.

LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Alex Gyori of the Brattleboro Food Co-op, right, gives Agriculture
Deputy Secretary Kathleen Merrigan a tour of the store, Tuesday morning.
(Zachary P. Stephens/Reformer)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


   Copyright 2011 MediaNews Group, Inc. and New England Newspaper Group Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              587 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                           The Herald (South Africa)

                            August 7, 2014 Thursday

Transnet secures credit guarantee

BYLINE: Linda Ensor

SECTION: ECONOMY, BUSINESS & FINANCE

LENGTH: 383 words



 TRANSNET has secured a R6-billion funding guarantee from United States export
credit agency US-Exim for the funding of the diesel locomotives the company is
buying from General Electric (GE).


 The group chief executive of the state-owned ports  rail and pipeline company
Brian Molefe  said yesterday the guarantee was a massive thumbs-up from the
international investor community  affirming Transnet's credit- worthiness and
South Africa's attractiveness as an investment destination.
 "The guarantee from US-Exim enables Transnet to raise funds in the markets for
the financing of the General Electric locomotive transaction. It allows for
Transnet to negotiate favourable repayment terms  including the tenor and
interest rates.
 "The required funding will be raised through bank loans supported by the
US-Exim guarantee. The terms of funding to be backed by the guarantee will be
dependent on a number of factors  including market conditions  pricing and
investor appetite " Molefe said.
 The facility will be drawn over a three-year period in line with the delivery
schedule for the locomotives. The repayment period is 14 years. Molefe said this
term would extend Transnet's debt maturity profile while improving the match
between assets and liabilities.
 In March  Transnet announced an agreement to purchase 599 electric and 465
diesel locomotives from four original equipment manufacturers  including GE.
 The guarantee is mainly intended for GE's share of the locomotives - 233
locomotives as well as other acquisitions from the manufacturer.
 The locomotives are part of Transnet's fleet renewal programme - a key element
of the company's seven-year R312-billion investment programme. The majority of
the locomotives are to be built at Transnet's engineering and manufacturing
facilities throughout South Africa.
 The contracts require stringent supplier development  skills development and
localisation commitments in line with government policy.
 Molefe said the agreement was in line with the company's agreed funding
strategy which was premised on diversifying sources of finance in a cost
effective manner.
 Funding from the debt capital markets accounts for only a third of Transnet's
investment programme - the remainder will be raised from cash generated from the
group's operations.

LOAD-DATE: August 10, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: Herald


                    Copyright 2014 BDFM Publishers PTY Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              589 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                            The Times of India (TOI)

                           February 26, 2011 Saturday

Minorities demand banking facilities be extended

SECTION: JAIPUR

LENGTH: 378 words


JAIPUR: A meeting of the annual credit plan for minorities for the next
financial year was held in Jaipur on Friday.

The members urged the banks and financial institutions to put in special efforts
to extend banking facilities to the minorities.

The meeting expressed concern over the low quantum of commercial loan
disbursement to minorities, which has remained at just 6%. This is despite
religious minorities accounting for 11% of the state's population.

The meet was attended by state-level bankers, project managers of SC
corporations of the districts and officials of the minorities corporation, NGO
representatives and leaders of the minority community including former MLA Mahir
Azad and Muntaz Masi.

The meeting also discussed strategy to encourage credible and genuine loaning
and take measures to end discrimination against minorities.

It was also noted that over the last decade, only 71 students from minority
community could avail of educational loans amounting to Rs 4. 90 crore, while
loans to women has been restricted to Rs 96 lakh and a total of 2500 people have
benefitted from these loans.

Since 2008, minority lending has increased by 132%. The expert group proposed an
relax the income limit for taking educational loans presently at Rs 40, 000 and
Rs 55,000 in rural and urban areas respectively. This would help more people to
avail of the benefits.

Principal secretary Rohit R Brandon assured that the proposal will be forwaded
to the government, and education loans will be given priority.

Women self-help groups and joint liability groups with cross guarantee will also
be given due consideration, along with trained and working entrepreneurs, said
Brandon.

He said a review meeting will be held in every three months to monitor the
progress of the efforts. The matter will be taken up at the state-level bank
committee meeting to be held on March 16, and at district-level meetings.

Brandon also promised to issue directions to the district collectors to
regularly review the 15-point programme of the Prime Minister and minority
credit as a standing agenda item.

He said the department would come out with an integrated credit plan and appoint
credit facilitating centres to give handholding support to the loanees.

For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

LOAD-DATE: February 25, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              590 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            September 9, 2013 Monday

Washington: Agriculture Secretary Announces Electric System Improvements in
Eight States

LENGTH: 838  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Department of Agriculture, The Government of USA has issued the following
news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced funding for projects in eight
states, including Virginia, to improve electric service for about 10,000 rural
residents. Rural Utilities Service Administrator John Padalino made the
announcement on the Secretary's behalf in Norfolk, Va., during the 2013 regional
meeting of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association. The loan
guarantees are made available through the U.S. Department of Agriculture's
(USDA) rural utilities program and include more than $11 million in smart grid
project funding.

"These investments will continue to ensure safe, reliable and affordable service
for rural residents, farmers, and commercial and industrial consumers," Padalino
said. "This funding, which is part of the Obama Administration's vision for a
new rural energy economy, includes investments in smart grid technologies that
modernize our nation's electric system and improve its operation."

For example, the Central Virginia Electric Cooperative will use USDA funding to
build 327 miles of line and invest more than $1.1 million in smart grid
technologies across 14 counties. The following is a list of rural electric
utilities that will receive USDA funding, contingent upon the recipient meeting
the terms of the loan agreement.

Iowa

Midland Power Cooperative - $25,300,000. Funds will be used to serve 530
customers, build 552 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $520,000 for smart grid projects.

Kansas

Lane-Scott Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $28,460,000. USDA funds will be used to
serve 580 customers, build 121 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $3,000,000 for smart grid projects.
 Bluestem Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $12,850,000. Funds will be used to serve
431 customers, build 62 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $312,000 for smart grid projects.

Missouri and Iowa

United Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $26,625,000. Funds will be used to serve 652
customers, build 167 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements.

North Carolina

Halifax Electric Membership Corporation - $4,050,000. Funds will be used to
improve 2 miles of distribution line and make other system improvements.

New Mexico and Texas

Lea County Electric Cooperative, Inc. - $24,508,000. Funds will be used to serve
1,158 customers, build 138 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $75,000 for smart grid projects.

Ohio

South Central Power Company - $64,000,000. Funds will be used to serve 5,160
customers, build 558 miles of distribution line, 34 miles of transmission line
and make other system improvements. The loan amount includes $6,370,485 for
smart grid projects.

Virginia

Central Virginia Electric Cooperative - $22,100,000. Funds will be used to serve
1,989 customers, build 327 miles of distribution line and make other system
improvements. The loan amount includes $1,157,330 for smart grid projects.

The $207.9 million in USDA loan guarantees announced today will be used to build
nearly 2,000 miles of line, fund more than $11 million in smart grid projects
and make other system improvements. Since 2011, USDA has invested more than $526
million in smart grid technologies nationwide.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

USDA's investments in rural communities support the rural way of life that
stands as the backbone of our American values. President Obama and Agriculture
Secretary Vilsack are committed to a smarter use of Federal resources to foster
sustainable economic prosperity and ensure the government is a strong partner
for businesses, entrepreneurs and working families in rural communities.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, has a portfolio of programs
designed to improve the economic stability of rural communities, businesses,
residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in rural
America. USDA has made a concerted effort to deliver results for the American
people, even as the Department implements sequestration - the across-the-board
budget reductions mandated under terms of the Budget Control Act.

USDA has already undertaken historic efforts since 2009 to save more than $828
million in taxpayer funds through targeted, common-sense budget reductions.
These reductions have put USDA in a better position to carry out its mission,
while implementing sequester budget reductions in a fair manner that causes as
little disruption as possible.

For more information please visit: http://www.usda.gov

LOAD-DATE: September 9, 2013

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              591 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                     The Idaho Business Review (Boise, ID)

                                August 31, 2009

Pocatello pitches in to help struggling polysilicon maker

BYLINE: Zach Hagadone

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 564  words


As Hoku's planned Pocatello-area polysilicon plant stumbles under financing
woes, the city is stepping up to help. Mayor Roger Chase said his office, along
with the Bannock Development Corporation, is working to secure a federal
alternative energy development loan guarantee for the Hawaii-based firm, which
manufactures polysilicon for the solar panel market.

"I would imagine that that we'll have the grant prepared here in the next week,"
Chase said in an interview late last week. "We think it's probably 30 to 60 days
out before we'll know. That's what I'm thinking. "

Nordic Windpower, another alternative energy firm with a manufacturing facility
in Pocatello, received such a loan guarantee in July.

"Between Nordic and Hoku, and of course Petersen Inc., those are our big
companies with the potential for growth," Chase said. "It's a critical cog. One
of the main things we're going to work on is alternate energy, and we'll
continue to help find funding from other sources. "

Development at Hoku's $390 million plant was put on hold earlier this summer
because the company is between $106 million and $121 million short of the
funding needed to complete it. Matters have been further complicated by liens of
about $16 million that were filed against the company by JH Kelly, the general
contractor on the project, and several of its subcontractors.

The liens, which were reported last week by the Associated Press, are the result
of delinquent payments to the Longview, Wash.-based contractor and other firms
working on the project, said Hoku CEO Dustin Shindo. He added that they weren't
unexpected, given the challenges facing the company.

"The liens are really just part of what we expected when we slowed our
construction down and we are actively working to secure the additional financing
to complete the plant," Shindo said in an interview.

He went on to say that because of the way polysilicon plants function, parts of
the facility can be completed sooner and production can begin before full
build-out.

"Ultimately, right now the best thing to say is we need $30 million to $50
million to get things going again, which is less than the total amount," he
said. "It might not be as daunting as other people might think. "

In the meantime, Shindo said none of the workers hired as operators have been
laid off, and the company is working with its contractors to settle the liens.
The good news is that Hoku recently received foreign trade subzone status from
the federal government, which will enable it to purchase foreign-sourced raw
materials duty-free. The company is "pursuing all opportunities and avenues" for
raising capital, including the potential sale of the company, Shindo said.

"That's something I think people would expect," he said.

Chase said the project is important to the community not only for the jobs and
economic boost it would provide, but also as a symbol. He believes the plant
will be built regardless of who owns it.

"Number one, there's about $100 million on the ground out there and nobody can
just walk away from that," he said. "Number two, there's a shortage of
polysilicon in the world. If they don't build it somebody else will.

"It's very important to us," he continued. "Just from the perspective of the
community feeling good about itself in these economic times, it's good to see
that steel structure going up. "

Calls to JH Kelly were unreturned.

LOAD-DATE: September 1, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: General news

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
