herein. RUS requests that stakeholders provide, in writing, any information or
analysis they believe to be relevant to the implementation of the 2014 Farm Bill
provisions. By further notice in the Federal Register, RUS may terminate, limit,
or otherwise modify the process of obtaining information from interested
parties. RUS encourages interested parties to review the 2014 Farm Bill in its
entirety.
Request for Comment Back to Top

Stakeholder input is vital to ensure that implementation of the provisions of
Section 6019 of the 2014 Farm Bill continue to support the agency's mission,
including ensuring that new regulations and policies do not overly burden the
agency's borrowers and their customers. The following questions and discussion
items are posed to guide stakeholder comments. RUS welcomes pertinent comments
that are beyond the scope of these questions. RUS is requesting comment and
discussion on the following topics:

Maximizing Loan Guarantees. Provision A of Section 6019 of the 2014 Farm Bill
directs the agency to "maximize the use of" loan guarantees for projects that
will serve rural communities with populations greater than 5,500. RUS has an
existing regulation for loan guarantees where the Agency guarantees quality
loans for the construction or improvement of water and waste projects serving
the financially needy communities in rural areas (7 CFR 1779). In addition, RUS
has an existing regulatory requirement that applicants must certify in writing,
and the Agency shall determine and document, that the applicant is unable to
finance the proposed project from their own resources or through commercial
credit at reasonable rates and terms (7 CFR 1780.7(d)). The agency currently
does not limit its guaranteed program or test for credit to those communities
with populations of greater than 5,500. The agency requests responses and
comments on the following questions:

1. To what degree do the agency's existing regulations fulfill the requirements
of this section? What, if any, modifications are needed to fully address the
requirements of Provision A?

2. Should RUS require all eligible applicants with a population exceeding 5,500
to apply for a guaranteed loan prior to applying for a direct loan or grant?

3. If not, what criteria should the agency apply in determining whether
applicants should be required to first apply through the guaranteed program?

4. How should the agency handle applicants that do not want to seek commercial
credit or guaranteed loans when they are eligible for the agency's direct loan
and grant program?

5. Are there any other limiting factors or conditions (financial ratios, minimum
loan amounts or other), beyond the 5,500 population required by Provision A of
Section 6019, that the agency should screen for prior to referring borrowers to
cooperative and commercial lenders for guaranteed loans?

6. What barrier(s), if any, to participation in the Water and Waste Disposal
Guaranteed Loan Program exist for eligible rural entities? Can they be addressed
through implementation of Section 6019?

7. Are there any other issues not mentioned in items 1through 6 that should be
considered in implementing this provision of Section 6019?

Materiality Standard. Provisions B and C of Section 6019 of the 2014 Farm Bill
directs RUS to establish a materiality standard for assessing the impact on
ratepayers in determining when the agency should use direct loans or loan
guarantees. WWD Program regulations, 7 CFR Part 1780, require the agency to
provide loan and grant funds for water and waste projects serving the most
financially needy communities. The existing regulations further require the
agency to provide financial assistance that results in reasonable user costs for
rural residents, rural businesses, and other rural users. The agency presently
uses the median household income of the service area as well as a comparison of
at least 3 similar systems cost to ensure reasonable user costs to the
ratepayers. The agency requests comment on the following topics:

8. To what degree do the agency's existing regulations fulfill the requirements
of this section? What, if any, modifications are needed to fully address the
requirements of Provisions B and C?

9. Should the agency apply Provisions B and C only for eligible projects in
rural communities in which the population exceeds 5,500 to ensure a standard
approach in assessing the impact on rate payers?

10. What factors should be considered in determining the materiality standard
described in Section 6019? For those factors, what is to be considered a
material difference in cost to rate payers?

11. How should RUS define the level of impact to ratepayers at which the agency
will use a direct loan rather than loan guarantee? Should it be based on a set
dollar increase, a percentage of median household income, or some other
approach? If an applicant qualifies for the agency's grant, should this exclude
the applicant from this provision?

12. Under what circumstances should an applicant that is eligible for the direct
loan program be allowed to seek a direct agency loan if they meet or exceed the
materiality threshold?

13. What is the best way to ensure the availability of accurate and timely
information regarding rates and terms of lenders participating in the guaranteed
program so that the impact on rate payers of direct versus guaranteed loans can
be assessed?

14. Are there any other issues not mentioned in items 8 through 13 that should
be considered in implementing this provision of Section 6019?

Interim Financing: Provision D of Section 6019 of the 2014 Farm Bill directs the
agency to require potential borrowers to seek financing from private or
cooperative lenders for projects requiring greater than $500,000 in interim
financing. RUS's existing regulation allows for interim financing for all loans
exceeding $500,000, where funds can be borrowed at reasonable interest rates on
an interim basis from commercial sources for the construction period (7 CFR
1780.39(d)). The agency requests comment on the following topics:

15. To what degree do the agency's existing regulations fulfill the requirements
of this section? What, if any, modifications are needed to fully address the
requirements of Provision D?

16. In your opinion what constitutes "reasonable interest rates?"

17. Should the impact on rate payers be considered in determining what is
reasonable?

18. In cases where an applicant initially seeks interim financing from private
or cooperative lenders and those lenders indicate a willingness to provide
financing, does this provision of 6019 prevent the applicant from seeking and
obtaining other non-private or non-cooperative lenders interim financing when
doing so would result in a reduction in the overall project cost?

19. Provision D requires the applicant to seek interim financing from private or
cooperative lenders. Should applicants/borrowers still have the option to
decline offers for interim financing? In what instances should this be allowed?

20. Are there any other issues not mentioned in items 15 through 19 that should
be considered in implementing this provision of Section 6019?

Referral to Private or Cooperative Lenders. Provision E of Section 6019 of the
2014 Farm Bill directs the Agency to determine if an existing direct loan
borrower can refinance their direct loan with a private or cooperative lender,
including with a loan guarantee, prior to RUS providing a new direct loan. This
language is consistent with RUS's existing regulatory and servicing
requirements. Applicants must certify in writing and the Agency shall determine
and document that the applicant is unable to finance the proposed project from
their own resources or through commercial credit at reasonable rates and terms
(7 CFR 1780.8(d)). In addition, if at any time, it appears to the Government
that the borrower is able to refinance the amount of indebtedness then
outstanding, in whole or in part, by obtaining a loan for such purposes from
responsible cooperative or private credit sources, at reasonable rates and
terms, the borrower will, upon request of the Government, apply for and accept
such loan (7 CFR 1782.11). The agency requests comment on the following topics:

21. To what degree do the agency's existing regulations fulfill the requirements
of this section? What, if any, modifications are needed to fully address the
requirements of Provision E?

22. What process should be used by the agency to refer eligible applicants to
other lenders?

23. What minimum information should be required of the applicant to ensure that
the costs of the referral are not overly burdensome on rural communities?

24. What should the agency do if a potential borrower, who is eligible for the
program, does not want to refinance older loans or use an outside lender?

25. Does Provision E exclude those existing borrowers who are seeking a new loan
that would qualify for an agency grant?

26. What documentation should the agency require of the borrower if they claim
they are unable to refinance with a private or cooperative lender, including
with a loan guarantee?

27. How should the agency handle cases where a private or cooperative lender
indicates a willingness to refinance agency loans, but the applicant believes
that refinancing would be detrimental to their operations and cause an undue
burden on their rate payers?

28. Do commercial and cooperative banks have a threshold (population, dollars,
financial ratios or other) at which they would not consider projects as
candidates for refinancing?

29. Are there any other issues not mentioned in items 21 through 28 that should
be considered in implementing this provision of Section 6019?
Listening Session Back to Top

The RUS will hold the Section 6019 Listening Session on Wednesday, December 10,
2014, to receive comments from stakeholders and the public. Oral comments
received from this listening session will be documented. All attendees of this
listening session who submit oral comments are requested to submit a written
copy to help RUS accurately capture public input. In addition, stakeholders and
the public who do not wish to attend or speak at the listening session are
invited to submit written comments which must be received by the date indicated
in the DATES section above.

At the listening session, the focus is for RUS to hear from the public. This is
not a discussion with RUS officials or a question and answer session. As noted
above, the purpose is to receive public input that RUS can consider in order to
implement the provisions of Section 6019 of the 2014 Farm Bill. RUS is
interested in receiving input on all aspects of the implementation of these
provisions.

The listening session will begin with brief opening remarks from Agency
leadership in Rural Development. Individual speakers providing oral comments are
requested to be succinct (no more than five minutes) as we do not know at this
time how many participants there will be. We request that speakers providing
oral comments also provide a written copy of their comments. See the ADDRESSES
section above for information about submitting written comments. All
stakeholders and interested members of the public are welcome to register to
provide oral comments; however, if necessary due to time constraints, a limited
number will be selected on a first come, first serve basis.
Instructions for Attending the Listening Session Back to Top

Space for attendance at the listening session is limited. Due to USDA
headquarters security and space requirements, all persons wishing to attend the
listening session in person or via phone must send an email to
WEPFarmBill@wdc.usda.gov by Monday, December 8, 2014, to register. Registrations
will be accepted until maximum capacity is reached. Once registered, you will
receive an email on how to access the listening session remotely. To register,
provide the following information:

First Name
    Last Name
    Organization
    Title
    Email
    Phone Number
    City
    State
    Indicate if you will attend in person and if you wish to provide oral
comments.

Upon arrival at the USDA South Building, registered persons must provide valid
photo identification in order to enter the building. Visitors must enter the
South Building on the Independence Side, 4th Wing. Please allow extra time to
get through security. Additional information about the listening session,
agenda, and directions to get to the listening session, will be available at the
USDA Farm Bill Web site
http://www.usda.gov/wps/portal/usda/usdahome?navid=farmbill.

Dated: November 4, 2014.

Jasper Schneider,

Acting Administrator, Rural Utilities Service.

                              626 of 998 DOCUMENTS


            Colorado Springs Business Journal (Colorado Springs, CO)

                                August 25, 2006

Government entity helps 53 Colorado companies obtain loans to manufacture and
export goods overseas

BYLINE: Amy Gillentine

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 532  words


A little-known government entity is responsible for helping 53 Colorado
companies - with a total export value of nearly $236 million - obtain loans to
manufacture and export goods overseas. The Export-Import Bank was created in
1934 to encourage banks to underwrite exporting ventures. The bank guarantees 90
percent of any loan written for companies for the purpose of manufacturing goods
to be exported.

"The Export-Import Bank is a quasi-government U.S. agency," said George Boutin,
director of the Greater Colorado Springs Chamber of Commerce's Office of
International Affairs. "It insures risks that community or investment banks
might not be willing to take to exporters to sell goods overseas. If they are
concerned they won't get paid, the bank programs will guarantee the loans in
cooperation with private banks. " Joe Ringer, a senior business development
officer for the bank, oversees business transactions in Colorado, New Mexico and
parts of east and west Texas. He will be the keynote speaker during a chamber
luncheon on Aug. 29. Ringer has more than 30 years of domestic and international
banking experience, and has been the Export-Import Bank since 1992. "We work
with all sizes of corporations," he said. "But we focus on small businesses, the
ones who need our help the most. I'm going to be in Colorado to try to encourage
more banks to use our programs, and to let companies that are interested in
exporting know that we can help. " The ExIm Bank, as it's known in industry
circles, does not issue loans. It underwrites capital programs for small and
medium sized production facilities. Any company that needs working capital to
manufacture goods for export, or buy goods for export, is eligible for the
bank's underwriting program. "Very few banks want to get involved with this,"
Ringer said. "We're trying to get more of them interested. We need to increase
our exports. " The ExIm Bank has underwritten loans for companies in 17 cities
in Colorado, Ringer said. Four companies in El Paso County have benefited from
the bank's programs, according to its Web site, www.exim.gov. But the bank, an
independent government agency, does more than underwrite loans, Ringer said. It
also provides a post-export program. "Sometimes countries we export to will want
to buy things on credit," he said. "Many companies ask for cash in advance or
operate with a line of credit. We issue short and medium term credit in those
cases. " The program has one main purpose. "By increasing exports, we can
increase the number of jobs available in the community and in the country,"
Ringer said. He points to the burgeoning trade deficit as a reason why more
banks should back companies willing to export goods. The trade deficit is
nearing $700 billion and the trade deficit with China is $200 billion, he said.
"As a country, we need to export more goods," he said. "That's why our focus is
on the small businesses, people who need our help. We'll work with any size
company, however. " Boutin said the program should be popular in the Springs.
The city boasts $1.6 billion worth of exports each year, and he said his office
is continually trying to encourage more exports from the city.

LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                US Official News

                           October 29, 2016 Saturday

Washington: USDA Announces Streamlined Guaranteed Loans and Additional Lender
Category for Small-Scale Operators

LENGTH: 823 words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture  has issued the following
news release:



 The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) today announced the availability of a
streamlined version of USDA guaranteed loans, which are tailored for smaller
scale farms and urban producers. The program, called EZ Guarantee Loans, uses a
simplified application process to help beginning, small, underserved and family
farmers and ranchers apply for loans of up to $100,000 from USDA-approved
lenders to purchase farmland or finance agricultural operations.





 "Over the past seven years, we have been transforming our loan programs at USDA
so that they can be attainable and useful to all kinds and sizes of producers,"
said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "These EZ Guarantee Loans will help
beginning and underserved farmers obtain the capital they need to get their
operations off the ground, and they can also be helpful to those who have been
farming for some time but need extra help to expand or modernize their
operations. USDA's Farm Service Agency has offices in nearly every county in the
country, and we encourage all farmers, including those in urban areas, to stop
in and inquire about this program."



 USDA today also unveiled a new category of lenders that will join traditional
lenders, such as banks and credit unions, in offering USDA EZ Guarantee Loans.
Microlenders, which include Community Development Financial Institutions and
Rural Rehabilitation Corporations, will be able to offer their customers up to
$50,000 of EZ Guaranteed Loans, helping to reach urban areas and underserved
producers. Banks, credit unions and other traditional USDA-approved lenders, can
offer customers up to $100,000 to help with agricultural operation costs.



 According to the 2012 Census of Agriculture, 75 percent of all farm operations
gross less than $50,000 per year. EZ Guarantee Loans offer low interest rates
and terms up to seven years for financing operating expenses and 40 years for
financing the purchase of farm real estate. USDA-approved lenders can issue
these loans with the Farm Service Agency (FSA) guaranteeing the loan up to 95
percent.



 USDA is providing a 90-day period for the public to review and comment on
program improvements. To review program details, visit www.regulations.gov,
reference RIN 0560-AI34 and follow the instructions to submit comments.



 More than half of all FSA loans go to new farmers and more than a quarter to
underserved borrowers. FSA also offers loans of up to $5,000 to young farmers
and ranchers though the Youth Loan Program. Loans are made to eligible youth to
finance agricultural projects, with almost 9,000 young people now participating.
More information about the available types of FSA farm loans can be found at
www.fsa.usda.gov/farmloans or by contacting your local FSA office. To find your
nearest office location, visit http://offices.usda.gov.



 USDA's EZ Guarantee Loans are an additional tool to support strong local and
regional food systems, as well as organic agriculture. Across USDA, the Know
Your Farmer, Know Your Food Initiative coordinates the Department's policy,
resources, and outreach efforts related to local and regional food systems. Over
the past seven years, USDA has helped provide consumers a stronger connection to
their food with more than $1 billion in investments to over 40,000 local and
regional food businesses and infrastructure projects since 2009. Industry data
estimates that U.S. local food sales totaled at least $12 billion in 2014, up
from $5 billion in 2008.Learn more about USDA investments connecting producers
with consumers and expanding rural economic opportunities online at USDA Results
- New Markets, New Opportunities.



 USDA works to strengthen and support American agriculture, an industry that
supports one in 11 American jobs, provides American consumers with more than 80
percent of the food we consume, ensures that Americans spend less of their
paychecks at the grocery store than most people in other countries, and supports
markets for homegrown renewable energy and materials. Since 2009, USDA has
provided $5.6 billion in disaster relief to farmers and ranchers; expanded risk
management tools with products like Whole Farm Revenue Protection; and helped
farm businesses grow with $36 billion in farm credit. The Department has engaged
its resources to support a strong next generation of farmers and ranchers by
improving access to land and capital; building new markets and market
opportunities; and extending new conservation opportunities. USDA has developed
new markets for rural-made products, including more than 2,700 biobased products
through USDA's BioPreferred program; and invested $64 billion in infrastructure
and community facilities to help improve the quality of life in rural America.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact:

 editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: October 31, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              629 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           October 29, 2016 Saturday

Washington: USDA Announces Streamlined Guaranteed Loans and Additional Lender
Category for Small-Scale Operators

LENGTH: 823 words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: United States Department of Agriculture  has issued the following
news release:



 The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) today announced the availability of a
streamlined version of USDA guaranteed loans, which are tailored for smaller
scale farms and urban producers. The program, called EZ Guarantee Loans, uses a
simplified application process to help beginning, small, underserved and family
farmers and ranchers apply for loans of up to $100,000 from USDA-approved
lenders to purchase farmland or finance agricultural operations.





 "Over the past seven years, we have been transforming our loan programs at USDA
so that they can be attainable and useful to all kinds and sizes of producers,"
said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "These EZ Guarantee Loans will help
beginning and underserved farmers obtain the capital they need to get their
operations off the ground, and they can also be helpful to those who have been
farming for some time but need extra help to expand or modernize their
operations. USDA's Farm Service Agency has offices in nearly every county in the
country, and we encourage all farmers, including those in urban areas, to stop
in and inquire about this program."



 USDA today also unveiled a new category of lenders that will join traditional
lenders, such as banks and credit unions, in offering USDA EZ Guarantee Loans.
Microlenders, which include Community Development Financial Institutions and
Rural Rehabilitation Corporations, will be able to offer their customers up to
$50,000 of EZ Guaranteed Loans, helping to reach urban areas and underserved
producers. Banks, credit unions and other traditional USDA-approved lenders, can
offer customers up to $100,000 to help with agricultural operation costs.



 According to the 2012 Census of Agriculture, 75 percent of all farm operations
gross less than $50,000 per year. EZ Guarantee Loans offer low interest rates
and terms up to seven years for financing operating expenses and 40 years for
financing the purchase of farm real estate. USDA-approved lenders can issue
these loans with the Farm Service Agency (FSA) guaranteeing the loan up to 95
percent.



 USDA is providing a 90-day period for the public to review and comment on
program improvements. To review program details, visit www.regulations.gov,
reference RIN 0560-AI34 and follow the instructions to submit comments.



 More than half of all FSA loans go to new farmers and more than a quarter to
underserved borrowers. FSA also offers loans of up to $5,000 to young farmers
and ranchers though the Youth Loan Program. Loans are made to eligible youth to
finance agricultural projects, with almost 9,000 young people now participating.
More information about the available types of FSA farm loans can be found at
www.fsa.usda.gov/farmloans or by contacting your local FSA office. To find your
nearest office location, visit http://offices.usda.gov.



 USDA's EZ Guarantee Loans are an additional tool to support strong local and
regional food systems, as well as organic agriculture. Across USDA, the Know
Your Farmer, Know Your Food Initiative coordinates the Department's policy,
resources, and outreach efforts related to local and regional food systems. Over
the past seven years, USDA has helped provide consumers a stronger connection to
their food with more than $1 billion in investments to over 40,000 local and
regional food businesses and infrastructure projects since 2009. Industry data
estimates that U.S. local food sales totaled at least $12 billion in 2014, up
from $5 billion in 2008.Learn more about USDA investments connecting producers
with consumers and expanding rural economic opportunities online at USDA Results
- New Markets, New Opportunities.



 USDA works to strengthen and support American agriculture, an industry that
supports one in 11 American jobs, provides American consumers with more than 80
percent of the food we consume, ensures that Americans spend less of their
paychecks at the grocery store than most people in other countries, and supports
markets for homegrown renewable energy and materials. Since 2009, USDA has
provided $5.6 billion in disaster relief to farmers and ranchers; expanded risk
management tools with products like Whole Farm Revenue Protection; and helped
farm businesses grow with $36 billion in farm credit. The Department has engaged
its resources to support a strong next generation of farmers and ranchers by
improving access to land and capital; building new markets and market
opportunities; and extending new conservation opportunities. USDA has developed
new markets for rural-made products, including more than 2,700 biobased products
through USDA's BioPreferred program; and invested $64 billion in infrastructure
and community facilities to help improve the quality of life in rural America.

                             The New Times (Kigali)

                          September 16, 2010 Thursday

BRD's Trade Finance Transactions Hit Rwf2 Billion

BYLINE: Berna Namata

LENGTH: 504  words

DATELINE: Kigali


Rwanda Development Bank (BRD) has said that its trade finance transactions have
hit Rwf 2 billion, an indication that the business community is progressively
signing up to the facility to engage in international trade.

Launched in March this year, BRD's trade finance facility provides financial
support to the business community involved in international trade. "Exporting
and importing requires greater financial flexibility and reserves than buying or
selling locally. The faster and easier the process of financing an international
transaction, the more trade is facilitated," Innocent Bulindi, the Director of
Finance at BRD told Business Times Tuesday.

The facility also facilitates local importers with medium and long-term loans as
well as import letters of credit which act as a guarantee for unfamiliar foreign
suppliers. "Importers need a letter of credit to buy goods overseas and sell
them in the domestic market before paying for imports. This requires access to
short-term financing and that is where our trade finance comes in," Bulindi
said.

Explaining the role of the facility, Bulindi said that BRD is focusing on
building up adequate trade infrastructure to boost international competitiveness
of the local business community. This, he said, will increase the trade and
export potential of the economy.

While BRD has been focusing on importers, Bulindi said the Bank has plans to
bring exporters on board. "We have been focusing on import letters of credit but
we have so many people who are exporting coffee, tea, leather and minerals; they
need export letters of credit," he said.

However he stressed that for exporters the bank is focused on strengthening the
performance of traditional exports including coffee and tea. "For instance we
have a niche market in coffee - instead of going into other sectors that will
not be as profitable as the coffee sector - we would rather strengthen coffee,"
he explained.

With high prospects for growth in the export sector that are anticipated to grow
by over 20 percent this year, Bulindi said the bank is evaluating export
companies to identify viable business prospects.

"We are in the process of forming a working partnership with OCIR Café to
develop a combined program for selected companies to benefit from these
facilities." Since 2003, BRD has been supporting farmers in form of soft loans
to build coffee washing stations and to expand their businesses.

This year, the Bank says it will disburse approximately Rwf 4 billion in form of
loans to boost national exports. However, Bulindi said the Bank is challenged by
limited financial resources which curbs its potential to support the business
community.

According to the official, BRD may not meet its target of investing
approximately $ 11 million in trade finance for this year due to limited access
to financial resources. BRD, in which government is the biggest shareholder with
38.8 percent shares, aims at eradicating poverty especially in rural areas
through investment in agriculture and other projects.

                                 The Bond Buyer

HUD to Go Ahead With $57 Million Taxable Note Sale;
, After 6-Month Delay

                             June 15, 1987, Monday

By Robert Taylor


After nearly six months of delay, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban
Development in two weeks will go ahead with its first taxable sale ever, with
$57 million of notes for federally guaranteed private loans.

The book-entry-only offering, which will be held by Depository Trust Co., was
originally slated to sell in January, but according to Joseph S. Fichera, a vice
president in the corporate finance department at Smith Barney, Harris Upham &
Co., problems with the technical aspects of the federal guarantee and the
commitments from the participating municipalities delayed the sale.

Paul Webster, director of the financial management division for HUD's assistant
secretary for communities, planning, and development, added that "it was largely
a matter of getting enough notes together to sell for the underwriters to feel
comfortable with the deal."

Smith Barney structured the deal, which is the first offering of its kind since
Congress last year ordered the agency to develop a new private market financing
program to provide loans guaranteed under HUD's Section 108 program. Mr. Fichera
said it is also the first cabinet-level department other than the Treasury to
sell taxable debt.

Under the old Section 108 guidelines, municipalities could borrow money from the
Federal Financing Bank, an agency that lends money to other federal agencies
through loans or securities purchases. The loans used Community Development
Block Grants as collateral. But in 1985, Congress prohibited the bank from
buying guaranteed loans.

With the new private financing program, Mr. Webster said, the agency plans to
bring taxable notes to market two or three times every year.

The first offering will finance eight projects in seven municipalities located
in Puerto Rico, New York, California, and Michigan, Mr. Fichera said. The
largest project will require $35 million to acquire land for a Chrysler facility
in Detroit, Mr. Webster added; the average financing needs of each of the
participating communities is about $7 million.

Although the new program will not allow municipalities to borrow money as
inexpensively as they were able to under the former program, which had been
about 1/8 of a percentage point above the rate of comparable U.S. Treasury debt,
Mr. Webster said the spread on the new bonds should still be "fairly decent,"
noting that there are no prepayment provisions for any of the community's
financing agreements.

"I think most communities have been looking to HUD to get a program in place,
even though the financings will be more expensive," Mr. Webster said, adding
that he does not believe municipalities have any resistance to participating in
a taxable program.

The noncallable notes will have maturities ranging from one to six years, Mr.
Fichera said, and besides the federal guarantee, they will also include security
from Community Development Block Grants.

Along with Smith Barney, Salomon Brothers Inc., which is running the books, and
Citibank are also underwriting the offering. Citibank provided interim financing
for the communities' projects until the note offering came to market, Mr.
Webster said. The preliminary offering statement should be available this week.

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 543 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                  Korea Times

                          September 26, 2000, Tuesday

Export-Import Bank of Korea Supports Domestic Industries

LENGTH: 1237 words


   Established in 1976, the Export-Import Bank of Korea has focussed on
supporting the domestic export-related industries by providing financial funds
with low and long-term rates for nearly 25 years.

As its proven experiences and great achievements indicate, the primary objective
of the bank is to facilitate the development of the national economy and enhance
economic cooperation with foreign countries.

In 1999, the Korean economy achieved 10.7 percent rate of economic growth, the
highest among the crisis-hit countries in Asia.

Such a rapid recovery may be attributed to the painstaking implementation of
huge restructuring programs, throughout both the public and private sectors
nationwide.

Also, the export-driven economic policy _ in which the bank is always at the
center _ has been one of the key factors in materializing the economic momentum.

The bank has contributed to rehabilitating the Korean economy through providing
a variety of financing funds to exporters as well as importers.

These timely and enhanced efforts by the bank to complement the financial market
failure resulted in a remarkable lending increase by 58 percent to 9,458 billion
in 1999.

The most eye-catching increase, however, is the outstanding expansion of the
rediscounted trade bills. The rediscounted trade bills have increased from 845
billion won in 1998 to 3,655 billion won in 1999.

Meanwhile, overseas investment and import credits were set back at as much as
96.0 percent and 51.0 percent, respectively. The special program introduced in
1998 absorbed the nosedive in performance of overseas investment credits and
import credits.

In line with the increasing reconciliation between the two Koreas, highlighted
by the historic summit meeting in August and the government initiative to
revitalize bilateral exchanges and cooperation, the bank has been operating the
South and North Korea Cooperation Fund (SNKCF) since 1991.

Private sectors and non-governmental organizations providing aid to North Korea
are entitled to receive financial assistance from the Fund.

Since its establishment, the Fund has mainly managed to assist government-level
humanitarian aid projects and is expected to contribute to the improvement of
inter-Korean relationships by boosting economic cooperation between the two
Koreas.

The Fund's sources are contributions from the general budget account and
non-government sources, borrowing from reserves and financial returns on the
Fund's portfolio investments.

In 1999, there was an increase of 26.3 percent in funding over the 656.2 billion
won of the previous year. The increase was due to borrowings from the management
fund for the loan to Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO).

The total volume of the Fund at the end of the year stood at 829.1 billion won.

The total volume of inter-Korean trade was $333 million in 1999, an increase of
50.2 percent from $222 million in 1998. Trade volume recorded it highest figure,
even marking an 8.1 percent increase over 1997. The South Imports totaled $121
million and exports were $212 million in 1999, an increase of 31.8 percent and
63.4 percent, respectively, from a year earlier.

Meanwhile, the main role of the bank is to support the developing countries by
lending loans at low rates.

Korea's official development assistance (ODA) accounts for two forms of
bilateral and multilateral aid. The bilateral aid consists of loans and grants.
Bilateral loans refer to the Economic Development Cooperation Fund (EDCF) loans.

The EDCF is also expected to contribute to the prosperity of the global economic
community by assuming responsibility commensurate with the nation's present
international status.

In that regard, EDCF's activity can be viewed as a means of sharing resources of
its accumulated development experiences with the developing countries.

In addition, the bank exerted considerable efforts to support small and
medium-sized companies with various financing schemes.

Export loan disbursements in 1999 went up by 20.4 percent to 7,687 billion won,
compared with the previous year. Loans on rediscounted trade bills accounted for
47.3 percent of total export loan disbursements during the last year.

However, re-lending facilities last year showed a drop of 69.4 percent to 17.6
billion won from a year earlier, and not only on the basis of loan
disbursements. There was also a sharp fall of 72.2 percent to 13.9 billion on
the basis of loan commitments. The credit lines were also reduced from 62 in 35
countries to 52 in 32 countries.

Poor business outcomes in re-lending facilities last year resulted primarily
from prolonged depression in main markets such as Central and South American and
Southeast Asian.

In case of guarantees, the bank has supported exporters by providing various
types of guarantees, such as advance payment guarantee, performance guarantee,
retention payment guarantee, maintenance guarantee, and others.

In 1999, total guarantee commitments decreased by 22.5 percent to 2,919 billion
won from the previous year's level of 3,768 billion won.

The guarantee commitments for overseas construction projects last year, however,
surged to 461 billion won, a huge increase of 207.3 percent from 1998. At the
end of 1999, the guarantee obligations outstanding totaled 4,523 billion won.

The bank raised a net total of 8,325 billion won during 1999, a 7.9 percent
increase over the previous year's 7,714 billion won.

Most of the funds raised during the year were self-generated from the repayment
of the bank's outstanding loans. The total loan repayment by the bank's clients
during last year reached 8,575 billion won, up by almost 30 percent from 6,634
billion won in 1998.

The unexpectedly large growth in loan repayment was partly attributable to the
government's policy to reduce the debt-to-equity ratio to below 200 percent for
large corporations, as part of a corporate restructuring program.

Furthermore, there was a capital subscription of 800 billion won during last
year, 700 billion won from the Bank of Korea, and another 100 billion by the
government.

The total paid-in capital as of the end of 1999 reached 2,475 billion won,
compared to 1,675 billion won at the end of 1998.

Unrelated to capital increase but nonetheless notable was the government's
transfer of 153.6 billion won of its holding of the bank's capital to Korea
Development Bank, which is 100 percent owned by the government, as part of the
government's capital contribution to KDB.

Consequently, the Bank's ownership as of the end of 1999 is as follows; the
government, 54.8 percent, the Bank of Korea, 39 percent; KDB, 6.2 percent.

Under the circumstances, the bank's task will be to improve the quality as well
as to increase the volume of overseas investment projects.

Although it will be a challenge, with the new confidence gained from the
economic recovery, the bank will continue to strive to gradually extend the
quality of its service.

It will work towards meaningful improvement of its financing terms, including
the terms and conditions of the loans.

The bank will sincerely implement the experience gained during the financial
crisis as well as during our rapid economic growth in earlier decades, and will
also strive to improve aid effectiveness.

            Reports SEC Filings Press Releases Proprietary Databases

                                February 2, 2017

                              Sonali Bank Limited

                      35-42, 44 Motijheel Commercial Area
                                   Dhaka 1000
                                   Bangladesh

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

COMPANY OVERVIEW


   Sonali Bank Limited (Sonali Bank) is a commercial bank. The bank provides a
range of banking and other financial products and services. It offers wide range
of products and services such as deposit accounts, education deposits, medicare
deposits, marriage savings deposits, monthly earnings deposits, letters of
credit, rural credit, micro credit, consumer credit, crop lending, import and
export finance, housing loans, gold loans, SME loan, foreign currency accounts,
investment bonds, debit cards and credit cards. In addition, it offers
international banking services, Islamic banking services, industrial financing,
SME banking services, ancillary services and foreign remittance services.
Through these products and services, the bank serves its individual and
corporate clients. It distributes its products and services through a network of
branches and online. The bank has a presence in Bangladesh, the UK, the US,
Saudi Arabia and India. Sonali Bank is headquartered in Dhaka, Bangladesh.


BUSINESS DESCRIPTION:



Sonali Bank is a financial service provider based in Bangladesh. The bank offers
a range of commercial banking and financial products and services to individual,
commercial, corporate and institutional clients. The bank operates through a
network of 1,208 domestic branches and two overseas branches in India as on
December 31, 2015. It also has presence in the UK, the US, Saudi Arabia and
Kuwait.

The bank classifies its product and services into nine divisions: Personal
Banking, Rural Credit Facility, Micro Credit Facility, International Banking,
Industrial Financing, Deposits and Credit Schemes, SME Banking, Foreign Currency
Account and Investment Bonds.

The bank, under Personal Banking division, offers funds transfer services,
locker facilities, and corporate client services, saving accounts, daily profit
accounts and trade finance.

Under the Rural Credit Facility division, the bank offers loans to agricultural
sector under the Special Agricultural Credit Program to the farmers, who are
affected by the natural disaster. The bank also provides help to young
entrepreneurs in the agricultural sector.

Under the Micro Credit division, the bank offers various program to improve the
living condition of the people, for self employment, and for rural
socio-economic development and to reduce poverty in urban and semi-urban and
rural areas. The few programs offered by the bank include Bank-NGO linkage
wholesale credit, goat rearing, lamb rearing, fruit, herbal, medicinal and
nursery development credit scheme and loan program for disabled person. Under
this division, there are 32 micro credit projects been run by the bank.

The bank, under International Banking division, offers pre-shipment and post
shipment credits, facilitates supplier's credit, letters of credit, foreign
currency guarantees, convertible and non convertible Taka accounts, non-resident
foreign currency deposits, resident foreign currency deposits, bill purchasing
and discounting, import collection services and shipping guarantees, export
letters of credit advising, and post import financing.

Under Industrial Financing division the bank offers finance to cottage
industries, small-medium-large scale industries and self-employed person. Its
major offering include software development and data processing finance, finance
to large scale industries through banks' consortium, and special investment
scheme for cottage and small industries. The bank also offers low rate of
interest finance to the thrust sector such as agro-based industries, stuffed
toys, frozen foods, manufacture of artificial flowers, oil and gas, and
sericulture and silk industries. It also offers finance to textile industry,
sweater industry, tourism, hotel and resort facilities, power generating plant,
pharmaceutical industry, hospitals and clinics, LPG, CNG filling and conversion
plant.

The bank, under Deposit and Credit Schemes division, offers education deposit
schemes, medi-care deposit schemes, rural deposit schemes, marriage saving
schemes, monthly earning schemes, double benefits schemes, school banking
schemes, consumers credit schemes, special small credit schemes, loan for
diagnostic center and information technology finance credit schemes.

Through SME banking division, the bank offers loans to small and medium
enterprises. Its offering includes term loans, project loans and working capital
loans.

The bank, under Foreign Currency Account division, offers foreign currency
accounts, non-resident foreign currency deposit accounts, and resident foreign
currency deposit accounts.

Whereas, the bank's Investment Bond division provides wage earners development
bonds, US dollar investment bonds, government treasury bill and bonds, and US
dollar premium bonds.

The bank also operates through two subsidiaries, Sonali Exchange Company
Incorporated (SECI) and Sonali Investment Limited.

                       Eureka Times Standard (California)

                            March 18, 2009 Wednesday

Supervisors approve airport loan with conditions

BYLINE: Jessie Faulkner/The Times-Standard

SECTION: NEWS; Local

LENGTH: 435 words


The Headwaters Fund board proposal that a $515,000 loan for airport runaway
safety improvements be converted to a grant if the federal government doesn't
approve the passenger fee charges expected for local funding didn't get an
immediate nod from the Humboldt County Board of Supervisors Tuesday.

Ultimately, the board voted unanimously to authorize the loan with the caveat
that the matter come back if Congress did not authorize the passenger facility
charges -- or a similar local funding mechanism -- necessary to repay the loan
rather than simply converting it to a grant.

Community Development Services Director Kirk Girard proposed that the loan,

needed to provide matching funds for an $8.7 million Federal Aviation
Administration grant to bring the Arcata-Eureka Airport's runways to FAA safety
standards, would be repaid with passenger facility charges. The repayment,
Girard said, would commence in August 2011.

However, the U.S. Congress had not yet authorized the next round of passenger
facility charges.

If Congress does not reauthorize that local source of funding -- which currently
amounts to a $4.50 per passenger -- Girard proposed that the loan be turned into
a grant. The chance of the federal government not reauthorizing the passenger
facility charge is very, very low, he said.

Public Works Director Tom Mattson agreed that it was a very remote possibility
that local funding would be unavailable to pay back the loan. Both underlined
the importance of ensuring that the runway safety improvements were completed.

"This retains our ability to guarantee commercial service for the foreseeable
future at that airport," Mattson said.

Third District Supervisor Mark Lovelace asked whether there were other options

to consider, in the event that the next round of passenger facility charges were
not approved. County Administrative Officer Loretta Nickolaus proposed that
staff to bring the matter back to the board if Congress doesn't reauthorize the
passenger facility charges.

Some in the audience questioned the legitimacy of designating Headwaters Funds
for the requested loan.

For McKinleyville resident David Elsebusch the unasked question on Headwaters
Fund applications is what the applicant would do if the grant or loan wasn't
made. He argued that it's likely the applicants would find funds elsewhere. He
also questioned the legitimacy of the county, which oversees the Headwaters Fund
allotments, providing those funds for its own projects.

"It's not part of the general fund," he said, "but you're using it that way."

Jessie Faulkner can be

reached at 441-0517 or

jfaulkner@times-standard.com.m

LOAD-DATE: March 18, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                              635 of 998 DOCUMENTS


             National Post's Financial Post & FP Investing (Canada)

                            August 23, 2005 Tuesday
                                National Edition

Banking on bands: Native communities, flush with cash from land claim deals,
find the big banks beating a path to their door

BYLINE: Barbara Shecter, Financial Post

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Pg. FP1

LENGTH: 1653  words

DATELINE: MANITOULIN ISLAND, Ont.


MANITOULIN ISLAND, Ont. - When the only bank branch on the Wikwemikong native
reserve here closed six years ago it spelled big trouble for Walter Manitowabi
and his family.

The Manitowabis run the supermarket, hardware store, gas station and a handful
of other businesses serving the 3,000 permanent residents of this picturesque
island in Lake Huron, a six-hour drive north of Toronto. "As the community
members left every Friday to do their banking [in nearby towns], they would do
their shopping elsewhere," he explained. So finding another bank willing to
locate on the small reserve "was a priority to us."

Two years later, in 2001, Mr. Manitowabi's family began taking deposits and
cashing cheques on behalf of Royal Bank of Canada, in exchange for a slice of
the banking service fees. His retail business came flooding back.

The establishment of the "agency" bank was obviously a tiny event in the world
of big banking. But it represented the eagerness of Canada's biggest bank to
forge relationships in a previously ignored segment of Canadian society --
native reserves.

The reason: anticipated and unprecedented economic development.

Canada's biggest banks all took an interest in developing business relationships
with aboriginal groups in the mid-1990s when the prospect of land claim
settlements and self-government promised large pools of money for First Nations
groups that would be spent on business and infrastructure development.

Specific land claim settlements in the past 10 years have put almost
$1.2-billion in the hands of First Nations groups, says Margot Geduld, a
spokesperson for Indian and Northern Affairs Canada. The average amount of the
126 settlements was $9.4-million, with more than 100 specific claims still being
negotiated, Ms. Geduld said.

"The demographics really just speak [for themselves]," says Carla Woodward,
national manager of aboriginal banking at Royal Bank.

"There will be faster growth in this segment looking out five to 10 years than
there will be in the overall business community," Ms. Woodward added.

Agency branches, such as the one on Manitoulin Island, allow Royal Bank to serve
aboriginal communities and establish relationships without the expense of
opening and maintaining a branch that may see little use compared with an urban
location, says Ms. Woodward.

It is a big change from 20 years ago, when it would have been a rarity for any
aboriginal person to receive a bank loan from one of Canada's big banks, says
Daniel Brant, chief executive of The National Aboriginal Capital Corporation
Association.

"You might've had the assets of Donald Trump, and you still couldn't get a bank
loan," says Mr. Brant, whose association represents more than 100 aboriginal
financial pools that received initial federal funding to invest in high-risk
ventures and startups.

Without grassroots relationships, the big banks risk missing out on future
opportunities ranging from real estate development and business loans to
individual money management.

Mr. Manitowabi and the Wikwemikong reserve represent a microcosm of what Royal
Bank is trying to do. The former band chief, who is a trained accountant, has
become one of the bank's biggest boosters. He recently took out a loan and a
line of credit to start his latest business: a used car lot.

During a recent meeting with Mary Lynn Odjig, general manager of the Wikwemikong
Development Commission, Mr. Manitowabi urged her to get in touch with his
contact at the Royal Bank. His reasons are clear. Mr. Manitowabi credits his
relationship with the bank for keeping his 40 employees working and his strip
mall of retail shops in business.

Becoming an agent of the bank "did help us a lot, and I'm sure all the other
businesses in the community," he says.

On some of Canada's nearly 2,900 reserve lands, Canada's biggest banks have
extended loans for projects ranging from from on-reserve mortgages -- tailored
to get around provisions in the Indian Act that prohibit natives from pledging
their land and fixed buildings as collateral to secure a loan -- to the creation
and expansion of businesses to support oilsands development and nickel mining.

On the big projects, the large institutions have tended to stick to the more
conservative ventures, often backed by the federal, provincial and territorial
governments that have historically funded all major development.

Aboriginal banking programs also include scholarships, stay-in-school programs
and other forms of assistance. Royal Bank sponsors the Canadian Executive
Service Organization's national MBA Experience Program, which teams graduate
students with aboriginal leaders to work on economic development projects.
Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce sponsors the National Aboriginal Achievement
Awards, a major annual event.

RBC's Ms. Woodward, who is herself Metis, says these initiatives are integral to
relationship building.

"It's beyond corporate citizenship," she says. "It's a smart business decision."

The banks do not break out the results of their aboriginal banking divisions,
and one analyst described them as having "negligible impact" on operations.
Still, Ms. Woodward and Ron Jamieson, senior vice-president of Aboriginal
Markets at the Bank of Montreal, say the returns adequate or the lenders
wouldn't be there.

Members of the aboriginal community must meet the banks' standard lending
criteria, including a demonstrated ability to repay. Government guarantees are
often required.

Increasingly, though, the banks are content with guarantees from band councils.

To qualify as a guarantor, the band has to be in good financial shape, or at
least be on track if there has been trouble in the past, says Mr. Jamieson.

"We don't penalize bands for being or having been in third-party management [by
government, but] we're not in the business of losing money," he says.

"Those who are out of control and don't care that they're out of control, we
don't choose to bank with them."

Among Canada's big lenders, Royal and BMO appear to be most active in building
aboriginal relationships through on-reserve branches and agencies.

Toronto-Dominion is involved in a partnership with the Saskatchewan Indian
Equity Foundation called First Nations Bank of Canada, which began opening
branches in 1997. There are four branches today, including one in Saskatoon and
one in Winnipeg.

Bank of Nova Scotia operates four on-reserve branches located in West Vancouver;
Standoff, Alya.; The Pas, Man.; and Rama, Ont.

Most new bank branches these days are strategically placed in fast-growing urban
locations, but much of aboriginal banking is taking place in small communities
far from the major cities.

BMO serves the tiny Labrador community of Nain, where severe weather routinely
strands residents and visitors for days. More important, Nain is also closely
associated with the nickel development at Voisey's Bay.

Royal Bank has an agency bank in northwestern Ontario town of Webequie, which
has 600 residents and is accessible only by plane. The town is 300 kilometres
north of Pickle Lake, with the nearest major centre being Thunder Bay, far to
the south.

One multi-million project funded by Royal and the federal government this year
was a $5.4-million expansion of a laundry and dry cleaning facility on Alberta's
Whitefish (Goodfish) Lake First Nation, home to about 2,000 people.

The large facility is needed because the reserve is close to the oilsands
development in the Fort McMurray area. The Goodfish Lake Development Corp., the
band's economic development arm, runs a sewing and garment operation and retail
store that also cater to the oil and gas industry, according to Indian and
Northern Affairs Canada.

On their own, the banks are looking to develop business relationships with
individuals by funding mortgages and small business ventures.

One area in which banks are increasingly accepting bands as guarantors is in the
on-reserve mortgage lending business, which like the rest of Canada is riding
the low interest-rate fuelled real estate boom.

BMO, for example, gets around the inability to seize houses by making the band
responsible for finding a replacement family if the mortgage cannot be paid.

Mr. Jamieson says defaults are low because the banks will not extend mortgages
to those without the usual qualifications of a steady incomes and a solid credit
history.

The Royal Bank business loan for Mr. Manitowabi's fledgling used car lot on
Manitoulin Island -- really just a handful of cars bought at a southern Ontario
auction -- was secured without the usual third-party guarantee from either the
federal government or the reserve's band council.

The bank looked favourably on the inventory and accounts receivable of the
family businesses as security, Mr. Manitowabi says.

The bank was also willing to look at the family's track record of running
successful businesses on the reserve for more than 35 years, he says. Mr.
Manitowabi's father, Andrew, now 83, started with a single gas pump and a small
variety store stocked with "anything he could get his hands on" which was run
out of one of the rooms in the family's home in the 1960s.

"My dad had a really tough time getting the business to where it is now," he
says.

Called "Andy's," the expansive retail operation on one of Wikwemikong's main
drags includes a fully-stocked hardware store, supermarket and gas station that
would not look out of place in any mid-sized town near a tourist destination.
The family also has a construction business.

But the Manitowabi family remains an exception on the Wikwemikong reserve.

Ben Kanasawe, a friend of Mr. Manitowabi's, runs a trout farm that ships
thousands of pounds of fish a year to southern Ontario and is now entering its
sixth year of operation. The fish farm continues to rely on government funding
earmarked for native development and farming, says Mr. Kanasawe.

The risky nature of the business and its relatively short life make it
unsuitable for the banks, he says.

LOAD-DATE: August 23, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:
Colour Photo: Tyler Anderson, National Post; Walter Manitowabi stands at First
Nations Auto Sales on Wikwemikon Native Reserve. He credits his relationship
with the bank for keeping his 40 employees working.

                                 BusinessWorld

                            August 18, 2015 Tuesday

Quedancor failed to collect loans worth P7 billion - CoA

BYLINE: Melissa Luz T. Lopez

SECTION: Pg. S1/5

LENGTH: 245 words


UNCOLLECTED LOANS of the state-run Quedan and Rural Credit Guarantee Corp.
(Quedancor) stood at P7 billion, deepening the agency's losses, the Commission
on Audit (CoA) said.

The company has yet to collect on loans extended to farmers and fishermen, with
the greater part of the total past due for as much as 10 years, state auditors
said.

According to data gathered by the CoA, P6.6 billion or 94% the funds should have
been collected at least five years ago. However, the agency was only able to
recover P105.5 million last year despite a mediation program.

This worsened Quedancor's financial position, with the government credit
facility operating at an eight-year loss of some P11.6 billion.

"The Accounts Receivable account comprises the significant portion of the total
assets, with a net realizable value of P1.731 billion or 51.84 per cent of the
total assets of P3.339 billion (net of all allowances)," auditors said in a
report on the firm's 2014 operations.

"With more than 50% receivables comprising the total assets, collection
efficiency is of utmost importance as it will greatly affect liquidity."

Auditors also pointed out that Quedancor should "revisit existing collection
strategies" to already recover the outstanding loans so as to improve the
agency's financial position.

"Its financial performance needs improvement to meet its obligations which are
already due and demandable and sustain its capability to provide guarantee on
loan programs," the CoA added.

                         TendersInfo - Project Notices

                             June 30, 2015 Tuesday

First InnovativeWeek: This 3 day conference will be focused to the financial
instruments, facilities and measures launched under Horizon 2020 to enhance
access to finance for research, innovation and SMEs.

LENGTH: 408  words


EU contribution: EUR 350 000
Objective: The overall aim of the project is a 3 day High level international
conference, which will raise awareness of the potential for the financial
instruments and accompanying measures launched under Horizon 2020 to enhance
access to finance for research, development and innovation. The role of the
preparation of the investment project provided by Innovfin advisory will be
outlined in compliance with the Political guidelin announced by President
Juncker.A special attention will be given to concrete measures supporting
innovative SMEs.

A particular focus will be the possible interactions between Horizon 2020
financial instruments, COSME~s, and European Structural & Investment Funds
(ESIF), as well as with instruments at national and regional level. The event
will bring together policy-makers, financial intermediaries and representatives
of the research, innovation and business communities.The specific objectives of
the conference are:Firstly, help businesses and other types of organisation
engaged in research and innovation (R&I) to better understand how to gain
access, via financial instruments, to loans, guarantees, counter-guarantees and
hybrid, mezzanine, equity finance and non-banking initiatives supporting
R&I.Secondly, exchange views on the implementation of Horizon 2020 financial
instruments (innovfin large, innovfin midcap guarantee, innovfin mid-cap growth
finance, innovfin SME guarantee, and Innovfin SME VC) and accompanying measures
(innovfin advisory). Thirdly, improving the up-take of new Horizon 2020
financial instruments such as the SME Finance Initiative; the launch of a pilot
facility supporting the technology transfer process; and new focuses on major
societal challenges in the field of energy and infectious diseases. Finally, the
European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Investment Fund (EIF) will
participate in this conference and provide their role, as entrusted entities, in
charge of the implementation of Horizon 2020 financial instruments.

                     The Idaho Business Review (Boise, ID)

                                November 9, 2009

USDA Rural Development busy with business loans in Idaho

BYLINE: Brad Carlson

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 865  words


Demand has been rising for Business and Industry loans backed by U.S. Department
of Agriculture Rural Development.

Idaho in the Sept. 30 fiscal year logged 31 loans compared to 26 in 2008, 15 in
2007 and four in 2006. USDA Rural Development's obligation in Idaho was
$7,785,000 in 2006, $17,402,505 in 2007, $35,821,997 in 2008, and $35,700,339 in
2009.

Daryl Moser, USDA Rural Development director of business programs in Boise, said
Idaho's 2009 volume was considered strong in fiscal 2009 as nationwide Business
and Industry loan volume dropped along with most business lending.

"Access to credit in rural areas is, even in good times, challenging," he said.
A lender could consider a certain service or retail business "riskier in Salmon
than downtown Boise" due to a shortage of not only customers but also of
alternative uses for a vacated building or space, he said.

Crafting a good business plan is vital. "Now, more than ever, they need to have
done their homework," Moser said.

"Loan quality has been good for a number of years" in Idaho, he said.

Idaho reported a delinquency rate of 3 percent or lower on USDA Rural
Development Business and Industry loans recently, compared to about 9.5 percent
nationwide, Moser said. Idaho has a good group of lenders that are experienced
with this type of loan and in many cases are more conservative and in better
shape overall than many of their counterparts across the country, he said.
Nationwide volume was the highest ever in 2008, he said.

Proposals in 2009 were as strong or stronger in 2009 than in years past in Idaho
as lenders focused on the most creditworthy borrowers and the best business
plans. Moser said USDA Rural Development Business and Industrial loans are less
prevalent during high-growth economic periods when lenders are booking more
conventional loans. They are popular now, for the right kinds of deals, and
feature competitive interest rates.

Business and Industry loans increase in number and in total volume, typically,
when credit tightens market-wide, he said. Compared to operating-capital loans
that the U.S. Small Business Administration backs, Rural Development business
loans do not go to many startups and are in rural settings only - though more
borrowers and areas qualify as "rural" than commonly thought, he said.

Some banks are showing interest in offering rural Business and Industry loans
for the first time, and others who already do so are marketing them to a larger
extent, Moser said. The program can be attractive to banks because USDA Rural
Development guarantees 60 percent to 80 percent of the loan based on the loan's
size, and because banks were able to sell the loans into the secondary bond
market - helped by the government backing - even as many other secondary markets
froze.

Loan volume could be the highest ever in fiscal 2010 as pent-up demand plays a
big role, Moser said. More projects were "in the pipeline" for the first month
of the fiscal year than is typical, and it appears banks that had been in
wait-and-see mode for a year "have seen the worst and need to do deals," he
said.

Federal economic-stimulus legislation more than doubled the program's available
funds for the current fiscal year and made some fees and guarantees more
favorable, he said. He expects all of the stimulus funding - which would expire
Sept. 30 unless legislation extends it - to be used. Tapping stimulus money
bodes well for carrying over, to fiscal 2011, regular year-to-year funding, he
said.

USDA Rural Development staff in Idaho can approve a loan of up to $10 million in
the state without going to Washington, D.C., for final approval, Moser said,
noting that most states can approve a loan of $5 million to $7.5 million
themselves. Much of Idaho is rural, and "we have developed some expertise over
the years," he said. "We have a good reputation nationally. "

Local USDA Rural Development staff and the lender work closely with the
applicant in putting loans together. Loan servicing also is done locally, and
this "local touch" enables Rural Development staff to work with the lender and
borrower if the borrower subsequently faces challenges, said Kerrie Hurd, USDA
Rural Development business program specialist in Boise.

Partnerships are vital for the agency's various programs, including loan
guarantees and grants, she said. Partner entities include lenders, economic
development organizations, small business development centers and community
groups.

USDA Rural Development's Intermediary Relending Program directs funds to
intermediaries that in turn provide loans for business facilities and community
development projects in rural areas. Eligible intermediaries include public
entities, nonprofit corporations, tribes and cooperatives.

The Intermediary Relending Program allows promising but not yet "bankable"
businesses to access capital and establish a business credit history, Hurd said.
The business often partners with a bank and the intermediary. The program often
used in businesses with ample fixed assets that can be used as collateral.

Demand for the Intermediary Relending Program has increased, Moser said. "The
intermediaries are limited in their funding, unfortunately," he said.

                        Progressive Media - Company News

                            August 29, 2013 Thursday

Olam receives $120m loan to expand food processing operations in Nigeria and
India

SECTION: RETAIL BANKING AND LENDING; Dried Food

LENGTH: 175 words



HIGHLIGHT: World Bank Group member International Finance Corporation (IFC) has
approved a $120m loan to Singapore-based food processor Olam International under
a five-year agreement to finance upgrades and expansion of five food processing
facilities in Nigeria and India.


According to Olam, the project will benefit local communities by creating
employment and new market opportunities for small-scale farmers to sell their
crops.

Olam plans to use the investment to develop its Hemarus sugar milling and Spice
processing facilities in India as well as Crown Flour Mill, Mechanical cashew
processing and Sesame hulling facilities in Nigeria.

The Crown Flour Mill will process imported wheat into flour for domestic bakers.

By 2015, the remaining four facilities will integrate over 45,000 smallholder
farmers from surrounding regions into Olam's supply chains allowing them to
supply their crops directly to the processing units which guarantees a market
for their products.

IFC's agribusiness strategy aims to promote food security, inclusive growth, and
environmental and social sustainability in agricultural supply chains.

IFC works with supply chain integrators to provide small farmers and rural
businesses with access to finance and inputs such as equipment and seeds, advice
and extension services, and access to markets.

                              The American Banker

W. Va. Banks Approve Ski Resort Rescue

                            June 14, 1979, Thursday

Special to the American Banker

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.VA


Several banks in West Virginia have given their tentative approval to a plan
that would allow a private investor to lend $1.3 million to the Snowshoe ski
resort in eastern West Virginia.

Snowshoe, which draws about 120,000 skiers each winter from the Washington,
Baltimore and Pittsburgh metropolitan areas, has been in financial trouble since
it was started in the early 1970s.

The massive complex atop a mountain was intended by its North Carolina
developers to be the major ski area for the Mid-Atlantic region of the nation
and its initial outlay was costly -- costs from which it has never quite
recovered.  Charleston National Bank, with the aid of other banks, packaged a
loan for the project.

But three years ago Snowshoe went into bankruptcy and the Federal court set
forth a plan by which the complex, which includes a lodge, condominiums and
four-season recreation facilities, could get new financial blood.  S. Franklin
Burford, a Elkins, W. Va., coal operator, took over Snowshoe and assumed much of
its debts.

But several successful seasons have not been enough to save the resort and Mr.
Burford has fallen behind on a current $2.5 million loan from Charleston
National.

Meanwhile, Fred Haddad, president of Heck's, Inc., a Charleston-based discount
store chain, and a member of the board of Charleston National, has agreed to put
up $1.3 million of his money for the resort, provided collateral can be
provided.

The problem is that as many as 15 banks hold the existing collateral and,
theoretically, nothing is left to secure Mr. Haddad's loan.  However, state
officials, who are trying to save the resort, say that without Mr. Haddad's
personal loan the facility may not be able to make it.

For one thing, banks are not willing to invest more money in the facility and
the Economic Development Administration is not willing to guarantee any more
loans to Snowshoe.

However, state officials said this week that they were convinced that EDA might
be willing to approve new guarantees if new private investment dollars are
injected -- namely, Mr. Haddad's money.

Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th has agreed to build a road at state expense to the
resort -- a road that the state earlier refused to build.  Miles Dean, a former
court-appointed trustee for Snowshoe and now state finance commissioner, said he
is trying to find a way to top Federal grants for sewer work by claiming the 250
condominium occupants at Snowshoe as a separate residential community.

Mr. Dean said it would be sad to allow Snowshoe to fold because its problem is
not whether it can eventually make it but if it can survive an immediate need
for cash.  He said the facility took in $12 million last year, but must have
more cash available to stay competitive.  Mr. Dean said he was searching for
other businesses interested in investing private dollars.

Charleston National Bank, the primary lender, would like that too, its officials
have been quoted as saying.

Up until last week, banks had refused to give up any of their collateral so that
Mr. Haddad's $1.3 million proposition could work.  But a meeting was held in
Washington with U.S. Sen. Jennings Randolph, D., W. Va.  At that meeting, Mr.
Randolph's spokesman Phillip McGance said several unnamed banks gave their
tentative approval to a plan that would allow Mr. Haddad to make the loan.  The
deal, Mr. McGance said, would give the private investor the collateral he
desired.

Because of the resort's indebtedness, it has been necessary to get the bank's
approval before Snowshoe can take on any more obligations.  That has happened,
but specifics must be worked out, said Mr, McGance.

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 612 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    San Gabriel Valley Tribune (California)

                              March 6, 2009 Friday

Bakery owner hopes to tap into SBA loan

BYLINE: By Ryan Carter, Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 654 words


WHITTIER - Norma Nielsen was a step away this week from closing her bakery - for
good.

The strain of recession, coupled with an upside down credit market, had her and
husband Terry, considering closing her Churrolandia Bakery and The Funnel Cake
Factory, which had been open since August of 2006.

Instead, starting next week, the bakery will be closed on Mondays. To cut costs,
Nielsen also had to hold back kitchen hours and reduce labor costs. The business
will remain open the rest of the week.

"This is devastating for us to close on Mondays," she said.

But it was a last-ditch effort based on Norma Nielsen's glimmer of hope: Small
Business Administration programs and the economic stimulus package Congress
passed last month.

From the $787-billion stimulus, the SBA is receiving $730 million in federal
funding for SBA credit programs for 2009 and 2010.

That's in addition to President Barack Obama's fiscal year budget projection to
support loan guarantees of $28-billion to small businesses.

Nielsen, who pays $1,500 to $2,000 in utility bills a month, on top of her rent,
was eyeing the SBA's revamped loan guarantees.

Loans don't come directly from the SBA. Rather, they come from banks contracted
with the SBA. The SBA then backs those loans - traditionally up to about 75
percent.

But with new federal funds, the SBA is backing up to 90 percent of some of its
basic loans.

And one program in the works will provide 100 percent guarantees on loans for
viable businesses having an immediate economic hardship. The program would
provide up $35,000 to cover up to six months worth of payments to the underlying
loan. The business would not have to start repaying the loan until one year
after the final disbursement, according the SBA.

"Definitely, that's what I might take advantage of," Nielsen said. "That's what
I'm in the process of doing."

That's what SBA officials want to hear.

The idea is to get businesses buying and banks lending again - two forces that
have been on the decline as the economy contracts, said SBA District Director
Alberto G. Alvarado.

"We've seen a real precipitous decline in our lending over the years," he said.
"We've seen a decline of 70 percent ... over two years."

There's a buzz over the new lending, he said, but he acknowledged that he's
heard some banks are talking about holding out.

"That concerns us," he said.

Stimulus funds will be used on a variety of programs. They include:

Allotting $50 billion to the SBA's program for micro-loans, which allow the SBA
to make loans to local nonprofit, community based lenders such economic
development corporations. Among the lending programs is one that allows loans to
businesses up to $35,000.

Reducing loan fees in the SBA's 7(a) and 5(a) loan programs. 7(a) programs are
the SBA's most basic business loans.

Waiving or reducing fees in certain loan programs while lowering loan costs
borrowers and lenders.

Bolstering funds for investment organizations.

Temporarily increasing the SBA guarantee limit on surety bonds to up to $10
million, from $2 million. The idea is to help construction companies acquire
necessary onds for contracts, Alvarado said.

"I think they are viable programs," said Jack Kyser, founding economist at the
Los Angeles County Economic Development Corp. "In this economy, any little bit
is going to help. You have a lot of small business owners who are holding on by
a finger nail."

The question is, whether banks will help them hold on.

So far, as bailout money is approved, banks have insisted they are lending to
credit worthy borrowers, even as legislators and economists say those that have
received funds are holding on to the money.

Kyser said many banks are still heavy into SBA lending.

Nielsen doesn't have much time to wait. If lending doesn't come, the smell of
wafting fresh bread will be a thing of the past.

"I'll probably have to put it up for sale," she said of her business.

ryan.carter@sgvn.com

(626) 962-8811, Ext. 2720

LOAD-DATE: March 6, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
