                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                             June 7, 2007 Thursday
                         State Edition; Coastal Edition

Little River Apparel to expand in Belfast

BYLINE: WALTER GRIFFIN OF THE NEWS STAFF

SECTION: Pg. B3

LENGTH: 392 words

DATELINE: BELFAST


The expansion of Little River Apparel will double the size of the facility and
boost production of chemical warfare protective uniforms for the military.

Federal, state and local officials attending Wednesday's groundbreaking ceremony
at the Belfast Business Park said the $2 million expansion would also add
additional jobs to the community. Managed by the Group Home Foundation, Little
River Apparel provides employment for the handicapped and disabled. The company
has 200 employees in Belfast.

Group Home Foundation Executive Director Harold Siefken said the company's
production and warehousing is currently divided among three separate facilities.
He said the expansion would bring all the components under one roof and allow
for better control of production costs. The project calls for adding 26,000
square feet to the existing 25,000-square-foot building.

"We'll consolidate everything into one building, which will make life a whole
lot more efficient," Siefken said. "It will also provide us with much-needed
additional production space."

The project was funded with a $1,750,000 construction loan from Camden National
Bank and a $250,000 loan from the Eastern Maine Development Corp. The U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Rural Development office provided loan guarantees
for the expansion project.

Michael Aube, state director of USDA Rural Development, described the Little
River project as fitting the agency's ideal profile for financial assistance.
Not only will it increase job opportunities in rural Waldo County, it also will
provide employment for those with disabilities. The agency provided $206 million
for projects in Maine last year, he said.

"We try to help build and sustain rural communities, and this project clearly
provides that in Belfast," Aube said.

Jonathan Daniels, executive director of EMDC, described the project as
"absolutely fantastic." Daniels said this was his agency's 40th year in business
and that the Little River project was one of the best it had been involved with.

"This expands economic opportunities for the disabled work force and also
contributes to the national defense," Daniels said.

Representatives from the offices of Republican Sens. Olympia Snowe and Susan
Collins and Rep. Michael Michaud, D-Maine, as well as members of the Group Home
Foundation board of directors, also attended the groundbreaking.

                               Business Recorder

                             January 8, 2016 Friday

Small, marginalized farmers: Credit guarantee launched

BYLINE: RIZWAN BHATTI

SECTION: Vol. 52 No. 08

LENGTH: 714  words


State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) launched the credit guarantee for small and
marginalized farmers aimed at enhancing their access to formal credit. The
scheme, funded by the government, will provide 50 percent risk coverage against
the principal outstanding on loans to small and marginalized farmers by
commercial, specialized and microfinance banks.

The federal government has made an initial allocation of Rs one billion in the
federal budget FY 2015-16, for the scheme which may be topped up annually. The
allocated funds will be used to create a guarantee fund. The scheme will cover
production loans up to Rs 100,000 and the loan tenor will be based on cropping
cycle up to a maximum period of one year. However, for sugarcane crop with 18
months cropping cycle, the loan tenor will be fixed in accordance with its
cropping cycle. The purpose of borrowing may include meeting working capital
requirements, purchase of input supplies, rentals of farm implements, etc.

The objective of the scheme is to encourage participating commercial,
specialized and microfinance banks (Participating Financial Institutions) to
lend collateral-free to small and marginalized farmers to meet their working
capital requirements. All the commercial, specialized, and microfinance banks,
which are in reasonably good financial position and have considerable
share/expertise in agriculture finance, will be considered as PFIs.

According to AC and MFD Circular No 01 0f 2016, with a view to enhance access of
small and marginalized farmers to formal credit, the State Bank is launching
'CGSMF' with the funding support of government of Pakistan. The scheme will
provide risk sharing to Participating Financial Institutions (PFIs) against
their collateral free lending to small and marginalized farmers and all farmers
cultivating up to five acres of irrigated and ten acres of non irrigated land
shall be eligible under the Scheme.

The SBP said that the scheme would provide an opportunity to PFIs to explore the
financing potential in this underserved market segment which constitutes
majority of the farming community. Therefore, banks are advised to develop
specific financing products and align their business models to meet financing
needs of small and marginalized farmers on a sustainable basis, it added.

The scheme will be applicable across the whole country including Azad Jammu and
Kashmir, FATA and Gilgit-Baltistan. Credit guarantee limits will be allocated to
all banks involved in agricultural financing. Non agri. lending banks are also
encouraged to approach Agricultural Credit and Microfinance Department for
allocation of guarantee limits in this regard.

The scheme will provide credit risk coverage of 50 percent of the outstanding
loans (principal) in case of non-repayments, after being classified as
"substandard" (as per the classification criteria laid down in Prudential
Regulations for both Agriculture Financing and Microfinance Banks,
respectively). The remaining 50 percent of the credit risk will be borne by the
PFI.

The issuance of credit guarantee limits will be subject to compliance with
provisions of the scheme and other instructions issued by SBP from time to time.
SBP/SBP:BSC will have the right to withdraw its approval of guarantee, if it is
discovered, at any stage, that the borrower was not eligible for financing under
the scheme at the time of extension of the loan facility. In such an event, the
PFI will bear 100 percent of the credit risk of such borrower.

The scheme will exclusively apply to small and marginalized farmers/tenants
across the country owning/cultivating irrespective of land ownership or
lease/tenancy of 5 acres for irrigated land and 10 acres for rain-fed land.
According to SBP, as per Agriculture Census 2010, 5.35 million farm households
(out of total 8.3 million) have land-holding up to five acres in Pakistan. These
small farmers have a significant share in the national agricultural output.
Despite their significance, the small and marginalized farmers face difficulties
in accessing formal credit due to small landholding and lack of collateral. As a
result, they are forced to borrow from informal sources on unfair terms.
Therefore, the scheme has been designed to enhance access of small and
marginalized farmers to formal credit.

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2016 Business Recorder
                              All Rights Reserved


                              682 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                 The Advertiser

                          September 28, 1989 Thursday

Marineland: bad luck and good fortune

BYLINE: ROD HARTLEY

LENGTH: 1310 words


Rod Hartley (left), Director for State Development and Technology, argues that
problems concerning the future of the animals at Marineland, and disinformation
about the project, are threatening the development of the site.

THE task of deciding Marineland's future has been as complex as it has been
time-consuming. Both bad luck and good fortune have played a role, but the
common thread running through many months of negotiations has been a
determination to find a solution which is fair to all, and best for the State.

That has been achieved, and it would be tragic if the exciting plans for a major
hotel development on the Marineland site were to be jeopardised by a new round
of unnecessary hysteria.

Of greatest concern is the suggestion that a veil of secrecy has been drawn over
the whole issue to cover incompetence, blackmail and some kind of skulduggery.

The facts are these:

Marineland suffered financial problems from its opening in 1969 and within three
years the Government had to step in and save the facility. In 1987, Tribond
Developments Pty Ltd leased the complex with plans to redevelop it. Vital to
these plans was that Marineland would continue operating during redevelopment,
so that cash flow from visitors could sustain the business.

The buildings and facilities had deteriorated badly. This was pointed out to the
company's managing director, Mr Rod Abel, but his professional opinion was that
they were adequate to last for the necessary nine to 10 months.

Tribond had sufficient funds to continue operating, but was looking to borrow
the $9 million required for the brand new development and sought a Government
guarantee.

This guarantee was approved by the Treasurer on the recommendation of the
Industries Development Committee, which comprises MPs from both the Liberal and
Labor parties. During its investigations, the IDC heard evidence from Tribond
officials. Some members inspected Marineland and the whole committee was aware
of its poor state.

There were some risks involved, as there always are with projects for which a
Government guarantee is sought. The IDC is used to such circumstances and agreed
with my department that the risks were worth taking.

With a loan secured, Tribond took over the running of Marineland and set about
the redevelopment task. Operating problems were encountered and they ran into
problems when it was discovered that facilities began deteriorating more rapidly
than anyone had envisaged. The business could not operate profitably.

At Tribond's request, the Government reluctantly agreed to allow some money
under the guarantee to be used for working capital - to ensure Tribond had the
necessary funds to feed and look after its dolphins.

However, as deterioration continued the complex was closed to the public.
Tribond was left with significant accumulated debts and no revenue, and became
technically insolvent.

The Government immediately began helping Tribond to find a buyer for its venture
while continuing to fund Marineland's day-to-day needs.

After intensive investigations, which took much longer than I would have liked,
a potential buyer was introduced by Peter Ellen, Tribond's Hong Kong-based
architect. Zhen Yun, a Hong Kong-based Chinese development company, put forward
plans for a major hotel and convention centre development incorporating an
oceanarium. Vital to this proposal was Tribond's expertise in running the
oceanarium.

Negotiations continued along these lines, but the South Australian community had
begun to express concerns about the concept of an oceanarium and, in particular,
the need to catch new wild dolphins to maintain numbers.

T HE Government was aware of these concerns but, having granted a licence to
Tribond to catch dolphins, felt an obligation to transfer this licence to the
new owner, Zhen Yun, and offered to do so.

At this time, building unions threatened bans on the site - there is some
confusion as to whether these were ever enforced.

However, by this time, Zhen Yun itself had become aware of the community's
feelings and decided not to proceed with the oceanarium. There was no pressure
on it to make this decision. The company simply did not wish to develop
something which the local community did not seem to want. It was keen that its
first major development in Australia should be successful and have local
support.

And it is important to remember that this will be a major development. The hotel
complex to be built on the Marineland site will be a tremendous boost to the
State's tourism industry and bring in more than $100 million in revenue over the
next 40 years.

The decision not to proceed with an oceanarium was a further blow to Tribond,
and the Government was faced with a double dilemma. As guarantor, and given that
no investor was willing to take on Tribond's obligations, the Government was
obliged to meet Tribond's debts to the bank should the company go out of
business. It also felt an obligation to the Abel family, which was facing
bankruptcy, partly because the buildings previously owned by the Government had
deteriorated so quickly.

The Government acted to clear up these financial problems quickly so Zhen Yun
could proceed with confidence.

An official receiver was called in and all creditors are now being paid in full.
Compensation payments were offered to Tribond and its owners. This was
formalised in an agreement and, as is not unusual in such settlements between
organisations, to protect both parties the agreement included a provision that
neither side would release details. The Government did not feel it appropriate
to publicise the financial affairs of the Abel family and, from its own point of
view, did not want to set a precedent by highlighting the payment of
compensation.

The agreement was signed, in the presence of the company's lawyer, on a Saturday
to meet urgent time constraints imposed by Zhen Yun's timetable. This was hardly
an unusual practice for a busy Government department.

Very full details of all costs involved have subsequently been provided on
several occasions in Parliament despite claims to the contrary. However, the
Minister of State Development and Technology, Mr Arnold, while publicly
identifying the total compensation payments of $590,000 on several occasions,
has steadfastly refused to provide a breakdown of the actual payments to the
three individuals concerned. To do so would have been in breach of the
agreement. However, the matter has been brought into the public arena and even
these details have been released.

At no time has there been an attempt to hide the costs involved with this issue.
For the record, the total cost to the South Australian Government to August 30
was $5.63 million. In addition, the Government is continuing to provide about
$50,000 a month for the maintenance of the dolphins at Marineland and will do so
until their future is decided. It has a moral obligation to do so, and I believe
all South Australians would support this position.

These costs were unavoidable if the Government was to meet its objective of
finding a solution which was fair to all.

More significantly, they will be overwhelmed by the direct benefits which will
flow from the development at West Beach. The net financial benefit of this
project after all costs will easily exceed $100 million.

But those benefits could still be lost. There is a very real danger that the
misinformation which is being spread about Marineland will destroy Zhen Yun's
confidence in South Australia as a viable base for its exciting development.

Recent allegations about secrecy and incompetence are as potentially damaging as
they are wrong. It is particularly distressing that there has been an attempt to
politicise a project which proceeded with bipartisan support.

LOAD-DATE: September 23, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo: rod hartley; table: receivership payments

JOURNAL-CODE: ADV

                              683 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                             The Guardian (London)

                                January 28, 1985

Pul-out hits job creation / Ending of exchange rate guarantee

BYLINE: By PETER RODGERS

LENGTH: 219 words


The Government has withdrawn an exchange rate guarantee which made it possible
for the European Commission to extend cheap loans to small and medium-size
businesses outside the development areas. The business is to be taken up by
commercial banks at higher interest rates,

The move has stopped a loan programme amounting to about pounds 15 million since
the end of 1983, which was one of the few ways business in high unemployment
areas such as inner London could get preferential assistance.


The end of the scheme has also halted negotiations by the Greater London
Enterprise Board to take over administration of some of the funds on an agency
basis. The scheme has been run by clearing banks, but GLEB volunteered to handle
funds on behalf of Brussels. A GLEB spokesman said, 'We had not agreed it with
the commission but we were making good progress and were optimistic that we
would be able to negotiate an arrangement.'

The Government withdrew the guarantee for the facility, called the New Community
Instrument, on December 18 on the grounds that new sources of finance for small
and medium businesses have now been developed by the banks.

But another reason is that the Treasury no longer wants the burden of an
exchange rate guarantee covering variations in the value of sterling

LOAD-DATE: June 13, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1985 Guardian Newspapers Limited


                              684 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               India Pharma News

                        June 24, 2013 Monday 6:30 AM EST

ASLA Commends Reintroduction of Community Parks Revitalization Act

LENGTH: 529  words


New Delhi, June 24 -- The American Society of Landscape Architects commends
Congressman Albio Sires (NJ) for reintroducing today the Community Parks
Revitalization Act (CPRA), which would help communities to rehabilitate existing
and develop new community parks and outdoor recreational facilities.



Today, many communities are suffering from deteriorating infrastructure, chronic
stormwater management issues, lagging economies, limited green spaces, poor
health and chronic disease. Community parks and other outdoor recreation
facilities have a proven record for revitalizing communities by: increasing
economic development; improving public health; increasing daily physical
activity; reconnecting children with nature; reducing crime; and providing safe,
healthy alternatives for youth.

The Community Parks Revitalization Act (CPRA) will stimulate neighborhood
economic growth by leveraging limited public resources to generate community
reinvestment. Specifically, the bill will authorize grants for park and
recreation agencies, which must be matched with local funds. Grants could be
used to rehabilitate existing and develop new community parks and recreational
infrastructure. Additionally the bill now includes an innovative financing
mechanism that would establish a program for secured loans and loan guarantees
for the development of parks and recreation infrastructure. Notably, this
program, modeled after the popular Transportation Infrastructure Innovative
Financing Act (TIFIA), would allow either large scale projects such as trail
systems, or multiple communities to bundle multiple projects together allowing
eligible entities to take advantage of low cost financing.

"Considering that more than 80 percent of the U.S. population now lives in urban
areas, it is critical that our nation's leaders recognize the importance of
quality of life in the communities where most American live," says Barbara
Tulipane, President and CEO of the National Recreation and Park Association.
"The CPR Act emphasizes the vital role local parks and recreation plays in
shaping and improving the economic vitality, environmental and physical wellness
of urban communities in the country."

According to Nancy Somerville, Hon. ASLA, executive vice president and CEO of
ASLA, the Community Parks Revitalization Act is a crucial opportunity to
strengthen American communities.

"ASLA supports legislation that will assist with the rehabilitation and
construction of urban parks and recreational facilities across the country,"
said Somerville. "Parks provide significant economic, social, and environmental
benefits to everyone in the community. Parks are not just pretty places, but
critical to the fabric of our daily lives."

Somerville also noted that landscape architects, many of whom are part of small
businesses, plan and design community parks and other outdoor recreational
spaces. They help encourage physical activity by making spaces more accessible,
attractive and sustainable. Exposure to nature reduces stress and improves mood.
These spaces also absorb stormwater runoff, saving cities millions of dollars
and, more importantly, promoting healthier, happier lifestyles.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                 The Bond Buyer

Tax Legislation: Senate Panel FHLb Proposal Must Narrow Focus, Report Says

                            July 15, 1999, Thursday

by Amy b. Resnick



Unless it is more carefully targeted, a Senate Finance Committee proposal to
allow the Federal Home Loan banks to guarantee up to $500 million in tax-exempt
school bonds each year could "accomplish little for those districts that
actually need it,'' a new study concludes.

A 16-page economic analysis of the proposal completed last month by the
Congressional Research Service concludes that "because FHLbs are subsidized,
introducing them as the new competitor into the (bond insurance) market would
not be economically efficient.''

The 12 FHLbs, which have begun offering letters of credit for bonds beyond their
initial purpose in housing, don't see it that way.

Jonathan West, general counsel to the Indianapolis FHLb, said home loan banks
across the country "want to do more in the area of economic development ... and
if you look at the issues and how we are structured, there is no federal
guarantee with regard to Federal Home Loan banks."

but report authors barbara Miles and Dennis Zimmerman, both finance specialists
at the CRS, said a bond guarantee by the FHLbs would constitute an indirect
federal guarantee to those school bonds, because "the inference is drawn by
investors in capital markets that the federal government would not allow the
FHLbs ... to fail such that investors would lose their money."

In general, the tax code does not allow bonds to be tax-exempt and carry a
federal guarantee, except in certain, specific cases.

Where FHLbs and other government-sponsored enterprises are concerned, the code
provides an exception for bonds issued for the specific line of business the
enterprise was formed to pursue.

The proposal -- which was introduced by finance committee chairman William V.
Roth, R-Del., and approved by the panel in May as part of its education bill --
would make another exception for up to $500 million in school bonds each year.

West said some bond counsel have determined that a letter of credit from a FHLb
does not constitute a federal guarantee, thereby allowing bonds other than those
for housing deals bonds to remain tax exempt.It is not clear if Roth's bill
would resolve the question for bonds other than those issued for school
construction.

Despite that, however, the report concludes that a guarantee for school bonds
through the FHLbs could harm the competitiveness of the private bond insurance
and credit enhancement markets. In addition, a direct federal grant program for
school districts that can't afford other forms of credit assistance "would
probably" do less damage.

The report found that aggregate investment in school facilities has been growing
relative to other state and local services and state and local taxpayers have
increased the amount of money being spent on school construction over the last
20 years.

but the authors wrote that "economic efficiency would be served by careful
targeting of any additional subsidy to the affected communities."

Specifically, they conclude that "only 1% of issues clearly had lower ratings
(triple-b or lower) that insurance could help raise." Their evaluation of bonds
also found that "the great majority of issues and dollars of school district
bonds have no need for a price reduction to purchase insurance."

The report also finds that bonds insured by FHLbs would see a greater interest
rate reduction than those insured by traditional bond insurers "due to their
implied federal guarantee."

The authors conclude that the implied federal guarantee would result in a lower
yield on FHLb-insured bonds than on bonds insured by private firms and
commercial banks.

"The clear implication ... is that were they not constrained by the $500 million
limit, the FHLb enhancements could displace currently offered private insurance
completely, even though the FHLbs would be pricing their enhancements in a
manner consistent with the risk they would be accepting," the authors wrote.

Copyright c 1999 American banker, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
http://www.bondbuyer.com

SECTION: WASHINGTON; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 668 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Prince Rupert Daily News (British Columbia)

                            December 17, 2007 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Meat plant part of $33m success story; Northern Development Trust Fund has
helped 100 northern projects

BYLINE: Leanne Ritchie, The Daily News

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 459  words


Communities and ranchers in B.C.'s North will soon have a new facility to
process local meat, thanks to financing support from the Northern Development
Initiative Trust.

The funding, for Northwest Premium Meats Co-op in Telkwa, marks the 100th
project approved by the trust.

Economic Development Minister Colin Hansen and Northern Trust chair Bruce
Sutherland announced the funding at an event at the meat processing site near
Smithers last week.

The Northern Trust is providing a $433,000 loan guarantee to facilitate
financing by agricultural producers, investors and the Bulkley Valley Credit
Union for the $1.6-million project.

"Optimism is building as new opportunities for economic diversification are
emerging," said Hansen.

"Northern B.C. is poised to become a key logistical player in British Columbia's
Asia Pacific Initiative. As well as serving central Interior and Northwest
markets, Northwest Premium Meats has the potential for export development to
Asia with chilled container shipping through the Port of Prince Rupert."

"This project demonstrates the power of the regional trust model, which helps
communities build their own economic futures," added Sutherland. "The Northern
Trust is working with communities to diversify and grow the regional economy,
and with local ranchers to build this facility that will assist them to meet new
provincial meat regulations."

"The opening of this new plant will be very important to the region, ensuring
that meat produced throughout the Northwest is safe and meets health and
inspection standards," said Dennis MacKay, MLA for Bulkley Valley-Stikine.

"The plant will also ensure producers and meat retailers in the local community
have adequate capacity to support their needs."

The Telkwa facility will handle 3,000 animals per year starting in early 2008,
with chill coolers, meat processing and custom packaging for local restaurants,
retail outlets and consumers. The plant will create 13 jobs initially, with two
more expected in the next two years.

In the two years since the Northern Trust's inception, the board, assisted by a
small staff group, has committed more than $33 million in loan and grant funding
to economic diversification projects in central and northern B.C. with a total
value of $208 million.

Within the Skeena Queen Charlotte Regional District, Port Clements has accessed
a $7,500 grant for economic development capacity building, as have Masset and
Queen Charlotte.

The District of Port Edward took a loan/grant for community development worth
$350,000 (expecting to repay $195,000) and the Prince Rupert Regional Community
Foundation received a matching grant of $25,000.

However, the city of Prince Rupert has yet to apply for any projects related to
the North Development Trust.

                                 BusinessWorld

                            January 29, 2016 Friday

DBP fund releases more loans to small businesses

BYLINE: Imee Charlee C. Delavin

SECTION: Pg. S2/1

LENGTH: 381 words


THE INDUSTRIAL Guarantee and Loan Fund (IGLF) managed by the Development Bank of
the Philippines (DBP) saw its loan releases to small and medium enterprises
(SMEs) continue to increase last year from 2014 levels, topping lending
expectations for 2015.

In a statement on Thursday, the state lending facility said approved small
business loans reached P4.23 billion last year, exceeding the P4- billion year
target as actual releases stood at P3.94 billion.

"Both loan approvals and releases were driven by short-term loans comprising 62%
of total releases and 58% of total approvals," the state-led bank said.

IGLF provides loans to micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME), in particular
those in the countryside, seeking to fund working capital and capital
expenditure requirements.

DBP said the fund had direct benefit on small businesses involved in private
education services, health care, tourism, transport services, trading,
agribusiness, food manufacturing and construction.

DBP said as of end-December, IGLF's total loan portfolio reached P4.49 billion,
up by P1.17 billion or 35.6% from previous year's P3.31 billion.

The number of MSME accounts under retail lending from DBP's Small and Medium
Investment Loans for Entrepreneurs mainly increased by 165%.

"Other loan growth came from wholesale loans to partner financial institutions
lending to countryside enterprises," it said.

"IGLF has continuously been searching for ways to be more responsive to the
financing needs of MSMEs that have significant impact on employment, income
generation, and value-adding to indigenous resources, and that contribute to
community welfare and development," it added.

Meanwhile, in addition to its loan releases, IGLF has also been a main
contributor to the Credit Surety Fund program approved by the Bangko Sentral ng
Pilipinas, DBP said.

IGLF's performance continues to indicate favorable management of resources. It
has paid out almost all its foreign obligations to the World Bank, and with only
the Asian Development Bank having a remaining balance of P349 million, the state
lending facility said in the statement. It added that IGLF ended 2015 with a
P103-million net income.

The state lending facility said it has grown the government's initial investment
to P6.75 billion from P803 million.

                              Indian Banking News

                       April 2, 2015 Thursday 6:30 AM EST

Standard & Poor's Ratings Services Assigns 'AA' Stable Credit Rating to
Clearinghouse CDFI

LENGTH: 553  words


April 2 -- Clearinghouse Community Development Financial Institution
(Clearinghouse CDFI)--a for-profit corporation serving California, Nevada,
Arizona, New Mexico and Native American Communities--announced today that
Standard & Poor's Ratings Services (S&P Ratings) has assigned its 'AA' issuer
credit rating to the organization. In the process, Clearinghouse CDFI has become
the nation's first non-depository CDFI to be assigned a credit rating from S&P
Ratings. An 'AA' issuer credit rating indicates that the organization has a
"very strong capacity to meet financial commitments."

"This strong rating validates our corporate commitment to financial performance
and demonstrates that community development lending, when properly underwritten
and structured, is a sustainable business model," said Clearinghouse CDFI
President and CEO, Douglas Bystry.  "We hope this rating will allow us to
increase our lending efforts in low-income and distressed communities where we
operate."

In issuing the credit rating, S&P Ratings cited Clearinghouse CDFI's minimal
loss exposure, which can be absorbed through its reserves and unrestricted
equity; extremely low-risk debt profile; strong history of loan performance
dating back to the institution's founding; consistent profitability and
total-equity-to-total-assets ratio; consistent growth in loans and assets; and
experienced and prudent management.

Clearinghouse CDFI bridges the financing gap between conventional lending
standards and the needs of low-income and distressed communities. Since the
company's inception in 1996, it has funded a total of $1.1 billion in loans,
financing 1,570 community development projects that have created or retained
more than 12,000 jobs. Examples of Clearinghouse CDFI funded projects include:
multi-family affordable housing, nonprofit facilities, educational facilities,
small businesses, commercial projects and faith-based endeavors.

"Farmers and Merchants Bank of Long Beach is pleased to be a shareholder of
Clearinghouse CDFI," said Henry Walker, President of F&M Bank. "As one of
California's strongest banks, we deeply understand and appreciate the ongoing
dedication and fiscal responsibility it takes to receive such an impressive
rating."

Clearinghouse CDFI has been a leader in the CDFI industry, with a number of
other "firsts" in its history. It was the first non-depository CDFI to borrow
from the Federal Home Loan Bank system in 2012. In 2014, it was the first CDFI
to draw funds under the CDFI Fund Bond Guarantee Program, with a facility of
$100 million in long term debt capital. Today, Clearinghouse CDFI has almost
$200 million in total assets with total equity exceeding $33 million.
Clearinghouse CDFI also recently received B Corp Certification in 2014 from the
nonprofit B Lab. B Corps are companies who meet rigorous standards of social and
environmental performance, transparency, and accountability, and use business as
a force for good.

"We hope this investment grade rating will attract additional investors,
particularly socially conscious and "impact" investors, who have been unaware of
the financial strength of community development lenders and the opportunity to
directly invest in this sector," said Bystry.

More information is available at: http://www.clearinghousecdfi.com.

Source: Clearinghouse CDFI

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

                                 The Bond Buyer

                              June 22, 2015 Monday

Infrastructure Bank and PAB Bill Introduced in Senate

BYLINE: Naomi Jagoda

SECTION: INFRASTRUCTURE Vol. 1 No. 34329

LENGTH: 621  words


WASHINGTON - Sen. Mark Warner, D-Va., has introduced legislation to create a
national infrastructure bank that could provide direct loans and loan guarantees
to help finance infrastructure projects of regional or national significance.

The bill would also increase the national volume cap for tax-exempt
private-activity bonds for qualified highway or surface freight transfer
facilities to $16 billion from $15 billion. The national limitation had been
established by a highway bill enacted in 2005, and as of May 12, about $11
billion of the cap had been allocated, according to the Federal Highway
Administration.

The bill - S. 1589: the Building and Renewing Infrastructure for Development and
Growth in Employment (BRIDGE) Act - has been referred to the Senate Finance
Committee. It was introduced on June 16 and is cosponsored by a bipartisan group
of 10 senators, including Sen. Roy Blunt, R-Mo.

The legislation was introduced as Congress continues to debate infrastructure
funding and financing methods. The current extension of spending from the
Highway Trust Fund expires July 31 and the fund's highway account is expected to
have a shortfall as early as August.

"The BRIDGE Act will create jobs, keep American businesses competitive, and
expand U.S. commerce and trade," Warner said in a news release. "At a time when
Congress has once again kicked the can down the road - passing 33 short-term
patches instead of a long-term surface transportation bill - this legislation
demonstrates that there is a real willingness to work together in a responsible,
bipartisan way to get moving on important investment priorities."

The bill would create an entity called the Infrastructure Financing Authority
which could provide financial assistance for transportation, water and energy
transmission projects. The IFA would be independent of existing federal
agencies.

To be eligible for financial assistance from the IFA, a project would have to
have a public benefit. Also, a project's expected costs would need to be at
least $50 million, though a rural infrastructure project's anticipated cost
would only need to be at least $10 million.

The chief executive officer of the IFA would create and manage an Office of
Technical and Rural Assistance within the authority to help identify projects
that could receive financing and serve as a resource to states, localities and
parties in a public-private partnership.

A loan or loan guarantee made by the IFA could be no more than the lesser of 49%
of expected project costs or the amount of the project's senior obligations if
the loan or loan guarantee doesn't receive an investment-grade rating.

The total amount of loans and loan guarantees made by the IFA could not be more
than $10 billion per year for the first two fiscal years of its operations, $20
billion per year for fiscal years three through nine, and $50 billion for any
fiscal year after that.

The legislation would streamline the permitting process for projects that are
approved for IFA loans and loan guarantees by instructing the president to
convene a meeting of representatives of permitting agencies to establish a
permitting timetable and to coordinate concurrent permitting reviews.

The IFA would initially be appropriated as much as $10 billion, which could make
$300 billion or more in total project investment possible, according to Warner's
office. Five percent of the IFA's funding would have to be used for rural
projects. Fees associated with the loans and loan guarantees would be used to
make the IFA self-sustaining over time.

Warner introduced a similar bill in the last Congress which had similar
bipartisan support but did not include an increase in the volume cap for highway
and freight transfer PABs.

URL: http://www.bondbuyer.com

                       The Daily Gleaner (New Brunswick)

                            January 20, 2012 Friday

N.B., Maine back Twin Rivers' loans

BYLINE: SHAWN BERRY Legislature Bureau

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 402  words


The New Brunswick government is extending a $7.5-million loan guarantee to Twin
Rivers Paper Company.

The provincial cabinet approved the five-year guarantee on Dec. 15. It's part of
a deal that also sees Maine's state financing authority insure much of a $5.27
million loan.

Twin Rivers, the new company that emerged after the bankruptcy of Fraser Papers,
operates the Edmundston pulp mill and the Plaster Rock sawmill. The company has
about 400 employees in New Brunswick.

"The province of New Brunswick is guaranteeing a new term loan of $7.5 million
as part of an overall financing package. This guarantee is part of a package for
working capital purposes to help preserve New Brunswick jobs," said Bruce
Macfarlane, a spokesman for Business New Brunswick.

Twin Rivers is a leading manufacturer of lightweight specialty packaging,
publishing and label papers. The company also has operations in Quebec and
Maine.

Its paper mill in Madawaska, Maine employs about 600. That plant gets its pulp
through pipes from the mill in neighbouring Edmundston.

Twin Rivers said the guarantees from Maine and New Brunswick will allow the
company to finance working capital requirements in support of the company's
strategic initiatives.

"This support from FAME (Finance Authority of Maine)and BNB and the continued
support of CIBC are expected to provide the momentum to allow us to continue
towards our strategic objectives while giving us greater financial flexibility
to manage our business," Wayne Johnson, vice- president of finance, said in a
statement.

The company said the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, its current lender, has
approved an extension and amendments to Twin Rivers' existing revolving credit
facility.

The Finance Authority of Maine has agreed to insure 90 per cent of a
$5.27-million loan.

In a statement, the authority said its actions will help accelerate the
company's strategic initiatives and help maintain jobs.

"Part of a larger financing package, the deal will enable the company to
maintain 630 jobs in Maine and 400 jobs in New Brunswick," a statement from the
authority said.

"FAME is pleased to support Twin Rivers Paper and the Madawaska mill, which is a
vital asset to the community and to the state as a whole. Our expectation is
that the mill will remain competitive on a global basis and continue to employ
hardworking Mainers," said Susan Snowden, the chairwoman of the authority's
board.

                              691 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD)

                              July 7, 2009 Tuesday

The Daily Record News Briefs: July 7, 2009

BYLINE: The Daily Record Staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1110  words


Too many fliers?

The Baltimore County Council is considering a bill that would bar businesses
from leaving fliers on windshields. The council was scheduled to vote on the
bill Monday evening. The bill would also restrict delivery of unsolicited fliers
to homes and apartments. Advertisers would have to include a toll-free number on
each flier that homeowners could call to request that fliers no longer be
delivered to their address. Violators would face fines of $500 for a first
offense, and $1,000 for subsequent offenses. The county attorney's office said
it believes the proposal could withstand legal challenges.

Pratt Library hours

Enoch Pratt Free Library officials say budget constraints are forcing them to
close some library branches on some days and end late-night hours for the
telephone reference service. The Central Library will be open from 10 a.m. to 7
p.m. Monday through Wednesday and 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Thursday through Saturday.
The Telephone Reference Service will be open from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday
through Wednesday and 9 a.m. and 5 p.m. Thursday through Saturday. No full- or
part-time employees were laid off or furloughed. They all were transferred to
vacancies elsewhere within the system.

Community grants

The Neighborhood Grants Program of the Baltimore Community Foundation recently
awarded $107,713 in grants to 24 community-led projects in neighborhoods across
Baltimore City and Baltimore County. BCF's Neighborhood Grants Program is
supported in part by the William Donald Schaefer Civic Fund at BCF, created last
year as a living legacy for former Governor Schaefer. The recent sale of
Schaefer's house, donated to BCF, augmented the fund. Among those organizations
receiving grants are Ashland Garden Community, Brooklyn Church of God, and
Friends of Patterson Park, to name a few.

GM plant restart

Workers are preparing General Motors Corp. 's Powertrain Baltimore Transmission
Plant in White Marsh to return to full production. Plant spokesman John Raut
said about 40 people, including the maintenance, material and reliability
workers, returned to work Monday to get the plant ready to start. Raut says
about 200 hourly workers and 40 salaried workers will return Tuesday for full
production. The plant makes Pontiac six-speed Allison transmissions and a hybrid
2-mode. Raut says the plant was closed for about eight weeks because the plants
it supplies in Michigan and Texas were down.

New Energy device

Burtonsville-based New Energy Technologies Inc. will be field testing its
recently completed MotionPower prototype at a Burger King drive-thru in the New
York metro area. The prototype is designed to generate electricity from the
movement of cars and light trucks. Engineers hope the device could eventually be
installed at high-traffic locations such as toll booths, traffic intersections,
rest areas, travel plazas, border crossings, neighborhoods with traffic calming
zones, and drive-thrus. The firm has filed nine new patent applications with the
United States Patent and Trademark Office in order to protect novel features of
its technology.

Smiths Detection prototype

Edgewood-based Smiths Detection, in partnership with Physical Sciences Inc.,
will showcase a prototype of an advanced standoff chemical detector at the Utah
Dugway Proving Ground. Known as the Adaptive InfraRed Imaging System (AIRIS), it
provides the capability to detect, identify and track chemical material from
distances greater than five kilometers. Smiths Detection recently launched the
Light Chemical Detector 3.3. The company sells chemical detectors and warning
systems to armed forces and emergency response teams across the globe. Testing
of AIRIS will take place July 6-24.

Merkle acquisition

Merkle, based in Columbia, announced that its wholly owned subsidiary
CognitiveDATA is acquiring the Minneapolis-based catalog marketing services firm
CMS Direct. All three companies are privately held, and the value of the
transaction, which is expected to close July 31, was not disclosed. CMS Direct
employs approximately 50 at its Minneapolis office, which will remain the
operational center of CognitiveDATA's catalog marketing service offerings moving
forward.

USEC loan

Bethesda-based USEC Inc. is expecting the U.S. Department of Energy to make a
decision on a conditional commitment for a loan guarantee by early August. A
loan guarantee conditional commitment would allow the firm to continue with its
American Centrifuge Plant, currently being built in Piketon, Ohio. The American
Centrifuge project supports more than 5,700 jobs, and more than 2,300 additional
jobs would be created within a year once loan guarantee funding commences. USEC
has invested nearly $1.5 billion in the project and needs a DOE loan guarantee
to secure the substantial portion of the remaining financing needed to complete
the project.

Mikulski jobs program

Sen. Barbara Mikulski says she is seeking federal funds to help Maryland and a
private foundation continue an innovative program that puts low-income, mentally
ill people to work. The Maryland Democrat told a news conference Monday in
Frederick that she is seeking $725,000 in next year's federal budget to cover 8
percent of the cost. The state has committed about $6.5 million, and the Owings
Mills-based Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation another $1.7 million. The
program is managed by the Baltimore-based Sheppard Pratt Health System.
Operators say it has helped 500 people find jobs since September.

Gilchrist award

Gilchrist Hospice Care, Maryland's largest hospice provider, has been awarded a
Circle of Life Citation of Honor from the American Hospital Association. The
recognition is a shared honor with Greater Baltimore Medical Center, of which
the hospice is an affiliate organization. Gilchrist was among five honorees
chosen this year out of 50 who applied for the awards program. The honors will
be presented July 24 at the American Hospital Association/Health Forum
Leadership Summit in San Francisco.

Rydex mutual fund

Rockville-based Rydex5/8SGI has introduced a mutual fund designed to provide
long/short exposure to commodities. The new Rydex5/8SGI Long/Short Commodities
Strategy Fund can provide exposure to up to 14 different commodity constituents
including natural gas, gasoline, heating oil, lead, Brent crude oil, WTI crude
oil, wheat, soybeans, corn, copper, aluminum, nickel, silver and gold. Long and
short positions are determined by the rules of the fund's underlying index,
which evaluate the historical price trend (and the consistency of the trend) of
each index constituent. The index is rebalanced on a monthly basis and features
a built-in risk management mechanism.

LOAD-DATE: July 8, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: General news

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2009 Dolan Media Newswires
                              All Rights Reserved


                              692 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                             The Malaysian Reserve

                           September 05, 2016 Monday

Maybank maintains stable SME loan repayment amid industry challenges

BYLINE: R Kamalavacini

SECTION: C - CENTRAL; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 402 words


Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) does not expect repayment delinquencies from the
small and medium entreprise (SME) segment despite the economic headwinds faced
by the country.

Senior executive VP and head of community financial services Datuk Hamirullah
Boorhan said Maybank's strong asset quality and customer base had resulted in a
positive loan repayment from SMEs.

Hamirullah said as at December last year, debt-to-equity ratio for SMEs was at
1.95% and as at June 2016, it was reduced to 1.9%.

"It's stable. We want to make sure that the ratio is lower than 2%. Anything
below 2% is good for us and certainly we will look to improve it.

"Generally in the (banking) industry, there are some stress. But with good asset
quality, we are able to manage (the stress) with good repayment from SMEs. Our
ratio is still stable," he said after the Maybank inked a partnership with
Credit Guarantee Corp Malaysia Bhd (CGC) to provide RM1.5 billion in loans to
SMEs under CGC's portfolio guarantee scheme.

Under the scheme, SMEs can apply for Islamic or conventional financing
facilities from Maybank from as low as RM50,000 to a maximum of RM1.5 million
with a fixed tenure of up to seven years.

While the application is processed by Maybank, 70% from the principal financing
will be guaranteed by CGC.

This is the third time Maybank has collaborated with CGC to provide such
financial assistance to SMEs.

In 2014, Maybank via CGC approved RM1.26 billion in financing while another
RM1.1 billion was channelled in 2015 to assist SMEs.

"We have improved the disbursement turnaround time from five working days to two
working days. We hope this will further help SMEs stay competitive," said
Hamirullah.

This year, Maybank aims to disburse loans amounting to RM3 billion to SMEs
compared to RM2.7 billion last year.

More than 6,000 SMEs have benefitted from the portfolio guarantee scheme since
Maybank partnered with CGC in 2013.

CGC president cum CEO Mohd Zamree Mohd Ishak said the corporation aims to
increase SMEs outreach by 15% in value and 5% in numbers this year.

Mohd Zamree said CGC is looking to provide RM4 billion in guarantees and
financing, and from that amount, 70% or RM2.8 billion would be derived from the
portfolio guarantee scheme.

"Despite the challenging times that we are facing both on the domestic and
global fronts, we remain cautiously optimistic that we will achieve our
targets," he said.

                                Daily Times (PK)

                            March 3, 2010 Wednesday

'Banks to revamp lending mechanism for agri financing'

LENGTH: 722  words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, March 3 -- Syed Salim Raza, Governor State Bank of Pakistan has prodded
banks to revamp and restructure their agriculture lending mechanism through
innovative products and by adopting best practices.

Presiding over a mid-term review meeting of the 'Agricultural Credit Advisory
Committee' (ACAC) held at the State Bank of Pakistan on Tuesday, Raza said
future economic growth during the next four to five years and beyond will be led
by the agriculture sector.

"If we want to have sustained growth, it can only be achieved through developing
agriculture sector. Banks must come up with efficient ways to revolutionise
agriculture lending," he asserted.

He emphasised on the banks to adopt group-based lending, wholesaler lending to
Micro-finance Banks (MFBs), Micro-finance Institutions (MFIs) and lending to
small & marginalised farmers, who are in majority. Banks should devise
strategies for lending to farmers in livestock, dairy, fisheries, etc. and for
developmental purposes including farm implements, water conservation and
infrastructure, he added in this regard Habib Bank Ltd., National Bank of
Pakistan & Askari Bank Ltd. have made some good progress.

SBP Governor stressed banks should establish close liaison with farmers'
associations for financial literacy & marketing of agriculture industry, loan
products and for the recovery of outstanding loans. Similarly, farmers'
associations should also develop close linkages with banks, provincial
agriculture & extension departments, input suppliers, agriculture marketing
companies, etc. and arrange programmes to disseminate knowledge & skills to the
farmers at grass root level', he added.

Referring to several initiatives taken by the State Bank for promoting
agriculture financing, Mr. Raza talked about launching of Pilot Project Phase II
for disbursement of agri. credit in 28 underserved districts, introduction of
One Window Operation, relief package for agri loans in NWFP & FATA, 'Credit
Guarantee Scheme' for small farmers for war affected areas, refinancing facility
for modernization of rice husking mills & cotton ginning factories, training
programmes for the officials of Credit Administration & Risk Management
Departments of banks, etc.

He said the State Bank is working on the development of 'Credit Guarantee
Scheme' for small & marginalised farmers, simplification of agri lending
procedures & turnaround time, Model Shariah compliant products for agriculture
financing, market development for agri commodities through warehousing system
and trading at National Commodity Exchange Limited. The warehousing system will
facilitate small farmers to realise prices and avail banks' collateralise credit
through warehouse receipt.

While giving a brief overview of the sector, SBP Governor said that the
agriculture sector has shown an average growth of 4.5 percent in the last five
years and it provides livelihood to 66 percent of the population. However,
banks' credit to farmers has remained almost stagnant i.e. 42-45 percent of the
credit requirements of the farming community and approximately 2 million against
6.6 million farm household being served, he pointed out. The share of agri.
credit in total banks' credit has declined from 6.8 percent in 2005 to 4.7
percent in June 2009, while the target for agri credit for the current fiscal
year is Rs 260 billion against estimated overall credit requirement of Rs 533
billion. Mr. Raza pointed out that major reasons for the below par performance
of banks, as far as agri credit is concerned, are the lack of interest, product
development and human resource problems.

Representatives from farmers' associations and other stakeholders also pointed
out various hurdles in the promotion of agri financing. The SBP Governor asked
the banks to resolve the issues in disbursement of agri loans to the farming
community.

Representatives from Zarai Taraqiati Bank, National Bank and Habib Bank informed
the participants about various initiatives taken by these banks to boost agri.
credit. Representatives of commercial banks have assured the ACAC meeting that
the agri disbursement target of Rs 260 billion for this fiscal year would be
met. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily Times. For more
information on news feed please contact Sarabjit Jagirdar at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement,
please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              694 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                         The Evening Sun (Hanover, PA)

                            October 6, 2001 Saturday

Recycling firm plans no cuts or closings;
Company with facility in Conewago Township has filed for bankruptcy protection.

BYLINE: By VERA KLINKOWSKY Evening Sun Reporter

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 517 words


Recycling Technologies International officials have no plans to cut jobs or
close the Conewago Township facility even though the company filed for
bankruptcy.

Officials filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy with the United States Bankruptcy
Court in Harrisburg Aug. 17 as a result of a cash shortfall and decreased sales
of 15 percent, said Timothy Leighty, vice president of operations.

Chapter 11 protects a business from creditors, allowing it time to reorganize
and turn business around.

Since June 1994, the company has recycled shredded tire material purchased from
permitted tire collectors and processors. The tire material is turned into
rubberized flooring, auto parts and other rubber products.

"There has been an industrial recession for a long time," Leighty said. "The
budgets of townships and businesses have tightened up and we are feeling the
brunt of it."

To help keep business afloat, Dodge-Regupol Inc. of Lancaster, which owns 50
percent of Recycling Technologies International, gave the company $600,000.

"We believe the company is undercapitalized and needed the money to continue
operations," said George Soukas, Dodge-Regupol chief financial officer. "I feel
within a year the company will be in a better position."

To keep Recycling Technologies' financial situation stable, Soukas said he hopes
the company can increase its current recycling rate of 50 million pounds of tire
material to make the company more profitable.

In June 2000 the business received a visit from Gov. Tom Ridge, who delivered a
$3.2 million state loan to the company. Recycling Technologies is required to
recycle more than 120 million pounds of shredded tire material originating from
Pennsylvania by 2008 under the terms of the grant, awarded through the
Department of Community and Economic Development loan.

The stipulations include the company giving priority to accepting shredded tire
materials from the Department of Environmental Protection's tire sites and from
cleanup by the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources and Pennsylvania
Cleanways.

Once the company fulfills the requirement, the loan becomes a grant and the
money does not have to be repaid, said Mary Marshall, spokeswoman for the state
department of conservation and natural resources.

The company used the $3.2 million loan to buy $2.8 million of equipment and make
$400,000 in facility upgrades, Leighty said.

The company, which employs 31 people, informed officials at the state Department
of Community and Economic Development about filing for bankruptcy during early
summer, Marshall said.

If the company does not complete the work, the company will be charged 2 percent
interest on the loan amount for last seven years, she said.

And if the company goes out of business before fulfilling the requirement of
recycling more than 120 million pounds of tire material, the state department of
conservation and natural resources would put a lien on the company's equipment
and require a guarantee from Dodge-Regupol that the loan will be paid in full,
Marshall said.

LOAD-DATE: October 13, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Copyright 2001 The Evening Sun


                              695 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                            Global Capital Euroweek

                                  June 6, 2016

US backs another $1bn of Ukraine Eurobonds, timing unclear

BYLINE: Francesca Young

SECTION: UKRAINE US AID BOND

LENGTH: 335  words



HIGHLIGHT: Ukraine and the US have signed an agreement for a further $1bn of
loan warranties to be used on a five year Eurobond issue.


The Ministry of Finance said that it is expecting a "record low expected
interest rate of not higher than 2% p.a. "" the lowest interest rate in the
history of Ukraine" for the bond.

The guarantee is the third USAID loan warranty received by Ukraine from the US.
The previous two guarantees enabled Ukraine to tap the international capital
markets for $2bn, through $1bn 1.847% 2020s in 2015 and $1bn 1.844% 2019s in
2014. Citi, JP Morgan and Morgan Stanley placed the 2020s and Citi and JP Morgan
placed the 2019s.

The agreement was signed by Minister of Finance Oleksandr Danylyuk on behalf of
the Ukrainian government, by US Ambassador to Ukraine Geoffry Payett on behalf
of the US government and also by representative of the USAID mission Joel
Sandefour.

The loan warranty agreement is a part of the bilateral and multilateral economic
support for Ukraine which includes a four year IMF extended fund facility
programme.

"It reflects increasing support for the economic reforms pursued by the
Government of Ukraine," said the Ukraine Ministry of Finance. "The agreement is
aimed to support economic reform programmes of Ukraine which are also supported
by the IMF, USAID and other members of the international community. It should
also facilitate access of Ukraine to the international capital markets."

The ministry said the funds raised will be used to provide social aid to its
most financially vulnerable citizens to protect them against economic impacts
including rising gas prices.

A DCM official in London said that to his knowledge no banks have yet been
mandated for the new USAID backed Eurobond and that the timing of the deal is
unclear.

"The timing will probably be dependent on the IMF programme," he said. "I can't
see them printing it until the next tranche is released."

One analyst said that he expected a July agreement for the release of the next
credit tranche from the IMF. Jerome Vacher, an IMF representative in Ukraine,
said that the IMF will assess the state of reforms delivered over June.

                              696 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                     The Telegraph-Journal (New Brunswick)

                           January 16, 2016 Saturday

Safe Harbour shelter closure leaves 10 youth in danger of being homeless

SECTION: GREATER SAINT JOHN; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 927 words


SAINT JOHN * Safe Harbour, which opened less than a year ago, will close its
doors in two weeks leaving its board of directors scrambling to find homes for
10 youth.

Unless they come up with $540,000 to remove a lien on the new building,
unfortunately the doors will close, said Kit Hickey, Safe Harbour secretary and
treasurer.

"We have outstanding capital costs which must be paid," she said "And we were
not able to get a loan guarantee that we needed in order to finance the balance
of the construction costs."

The youth homeless shelter has been Jensen Robichaud's home for a little more
than a month.

Friday morning, the 17-year-old was canvassing the uptown area with a sign that
says "save Safe Harbour" in an attempt to keep the youth centre open, even if
for just a little bit longer, he said.

"I've got friends who've been through so much stuff, more than me," said the
teen, looking around at his Safe Harbour "family."

"And if this place shuts down they'll all be on the streets because most of them
have nowhere else to go. I have no where else to go (either)."

Staff have been delivered layoff notices, including Austin Perry, a youth
support worker, who said in an email Friday that the decision came as a
surprise.

"This is not such a great idea for the Saint John area, especially with so many
teens out on the street or just with no place to sleep for a night," he said,
adding he's worked at Safe Harbour since it opened in March 2015. "To think that
the kids as of now at Safe Harbour will not have a place to stay by the end of
January is terrifying.

"By Safe Harbour closing down, it will mean there is going to be a bigger
struggle for some teens that need to find a place to have a roof over their head
for a night or even two months."

Prior to construction, Safe Harbour received financial commitments from a number
of foundations and organizations - some firm, some conditional.

"Due to the urgent need for a facility like Safe Harbour in our community, we
proceeded with construction, confident that each conditional commitment would
become a firm agreement over time," said Hickey, adding they didn't consider the
impact changing economic and political factors would have on those commitments.
"Further problems arose when the costs of construction exceeded our original
budget in excess of $200,000."

The group has asked for a $100,000 grant and $440,000 loan guarantee from the
province, which would remove the lien and allow the group to continue with their
capital fundraising program.

The non-profit has been working diligently for many months hoping they would
find a solution to the outstanding debt, said Hickey.

"Unfortunately we were not able to do so," she said. "But we are continuing in
our efforts to secure the loan guarantee that we need in order to satisfy the
contractor. We are working very hard to avoid this closure. We are doing
everything that we possibly can."

Hannah Harvey, 17, is currently staying at Safe Harbour and said she found out
on her birthday, Thursday, she not only is being kicked out of her new home, she
is also pregnant.

"I have to worry about what I'm going to do not only for myself but another
person," she said. "I have no idea what I'm going to do because this is the
place I relied on."

Hickey reassured staff are working very closely with case managers from Social
Development and the Teen Resource Centre to ensure that all 10 youths at Safe
Harbour are adequately and safely rehoused.

"The truth is there is not a good alternative," she said. "But we are doing
everything we can, working with partner organizations and social workers, to
ensure each of our youth have a solid exit plan and somewhere to go."

Matthew McLeod, 21, another live-in resident, said the staff have helped him
with a number of things - housing, appointments, addictions problems and with
going back to school.

"This place is something that needs to be open in Saint John or there's going to
be an epidemic of problems like this."

Brenda Murphy, co-ordinator with the Saint John Women's Empowerment Network,
agreed.

"This is a concern to the community because we know the youth being helped there
were housed safely and had their basic needs met but, it also got them back into
school, completing their education and hopefully moving on from there," she
said.

Since the youth transition house opened last March, the facility has helped 55
youth with such things as housing, counselling and educational needs.

"For me the biggest piece is education," said Murphy. "I know our premier talked
earlier this week about education as the key to eliminating or reducing poverty.

"And so the risk is great with these youth that they will no longer continue
their education if they are no longer in a safe environment."

If Safe Harbour cannot find a way to keep its doors open, the building will be
sold to pay the outstanding capital costs, said Hickey.

"First and foremost we need to remove the lien," she said, adding it will
hopefully be done with a combination of a grant and loan guarantee. "We are
confident we can fundraise 50 per cent of the ($425,000) operating budget, but
need a commitment from a major funder for the other half - this is critical not
only for the obvious financial aspects but because of the leverage it would give
us with other potential funders."

Robichaud said Friday that he won't stop fighting for his home and will continue
to canvass the uptown area for help of any kind. "I'm a fighter for the things I
believe in, and Safe Harbour is one of them," he said. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2016
Telegraph-Journal (New Brunswick)

LOAD-DATE: January 16, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2016 The Telegraph Journal
                              All Rights Reserved


                              697 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                  September 28, 1978, Thursday, Final Edition

Religious Leaders Backed in Plan to Reopen Steel Mill

BYLINE: By Marjorie Hyer, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A28

LENGTH: 574 words


A coalition of religious leaders seeking federal backing for an ambitious plan
to reopen a Youngstown mill yesterday won the promise of a $100 million federal
loan guarantee if it comes up with a plan acceptable to the government.

In addition, presidential assistant Jack H. Watson Jr. told a delegation from
the Mahoning Valley (Ohio) Ecumenical Coalition that their proposal for
reopening the plant under community ownership will "get priority attention" from
the administration's lateragency Coordinating Committee, of which he is
chairman.

Watson who chaired the 95-minute White House meeting with the coalition leaders,
promised to get back to them within three weeks with the federal government
response to the proposal.

Yesterday's promise of federal assistance came a little over a year after the
colsing of most of the Campbell Works of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Co.,
which ultimately cost the community an estimated 7,700 jobs.

Even before the plant closed, Protestant, Catholic and Jewish leaders had come
together, first to deal with the shock of the sudden, massive unemployment and
then to see if economic alternatives could be found.

The Ecumenical Coalition commissioned a $350,000 study, funded by the Housing
and Urban Development Department, by the Washington-based National Center for
Economic Alternatives.

The study concluded that it was technically feasible to reopen the plant as a
worker-and-community-owned operation.  But the cost for the unique venture was
put at $525 million over a period of eight years, with most of the money coming
from loans.

Robert T. Hall, assistant secretary of commerce, who also met withthe coalition
leaders yesterday, said that the $100 million in guaranteed loans has been "set
aside for a project which is economically viable" to deal with the Youngstown
situation.

The report by the National Center for Economic Alternatives envisions loan
guarantees of $300 million, a figure Watson told reporters he did not consider
outlandish.  He added that he had "very little doubt that we can, between the
public sector and the private sector, put something together that cna work."

The coalition will also make a formal request for a $16 million grant HUD,
according to the Rev. John Sharick, vice chairman.  He said this would be part
of an estimated $50 million needed to purchase the cosed down plant and put
together a management team to operate the facility.

Within the past eight months the coalition has raised a little more than $4
million from Youngstown local residents, and organizations.

Some of the church leaders indicated privately that they were counting on the
political pressures of the November election to give them added leverage with
the Carter administration.

A poll commissioned by the Republican National Committee and published Sept. 10
by the Youngstown Vindicator showed that both President Carter and Democratic
incumbent Congressman Charles J. Carney trailing markedly in the perception of
voters as to who is "having an impact" on the area's economic crisis.

"This political thing works in our favor," observed the Rev. Charles Rawlings of
Cleveland.

"I don't think the Democrats can win without our support," he said of the large
numbers of clergy throughout Ohio's industrial area allied with the Coalition.
That support, he indicated, would be for many clergy, contingent on the
administration's reaction to the economic crisis.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1978 The Washington Post


                              698 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           September 9, 2014 Tuesday

Nevada: USDA Announces Major Investments to Modernize Service, Improve the
Reliability of Rural Electric Systems

LENGTH: 393  words

DATELINE: Carson City


The State of Nevada has issued the following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced that USDA is investing more
than $518 million in rural electric cooperatives to improve the delivery of
electric power to communities in 15 states. This funding is part of nearly $50
billion that USDA has invested in infrastructure improvements since 2009.

"We must invest in America's infrastructure to promote sustainable economic
development in our rural and urban communities," Vilsack said during a White
House summit on infrastructure financing. "Enhancements to the nation's electric
grid make a huge difference for communities across the country and support
President Obama's efforts to build a stronger rural economy."

More than $23 million in today's funding is targeted for smart grid
improvements, which better manage and increase efficiencies in our nation's
electric system. Smart grid technologies, such as automated meter reading and
load management automation, allow for more efficient control over the use of
power to better meet customers' needs. USDA has a long history, dating back to
1935, of working with rural utilities to deliver infrastructure and service
improvements. Through the years, these investments have brought new economic and
social opportunities and have enhanced the quality of life in the nation's rural
communities.

The investments announced today are provided through USDA's Rural Utilities
Service (RUS), which also administers infrastructure programs that bring
broadband, safe drinking water and improved wastewater treatment facilities to
rural communities.

Today's loan guarantees for electric systems will build or improve more than
5,600 miles of line in rural areas. For example, in New Mexico, a $14.1 million
loan will fund a 1 MW photovoltaic facility, 74 miles of line, and make other
system improvements. The loan includes $518,400 for smart grid projects and $3.4
million for the renewable project. The Carroll Electric Membership Corporation
in Carrollton, Ga., will receive $20.6 million to build or upgrade 441 miles of
line and devote $93,000 to smart grid technology.

The following is a complete list of loan recipients and projects receiving
funding under today's announcement.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: September 10, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              700 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                            January 12, 2010 Tuesday

ECC raises sugar price by Rs7/kg

BYLINE:  IMRAN ALI KUNDI

SECTION: Vol. XXIII No. 340

LENGTH: 525  words


The Economic Coordination Committee (ECC) of the Cabinet on Tuesday decided to
increase the price of sugar at the outlets of Utility Stores Corporation (USC)
by Rs 7 per kilogram. The ECC met under the chairmanship of Federal Finance
Minister Shaukat Tarin at the PM Secretariat. Ministry of Industries and
Production briefed about the progress of implementation of the National Sugar
Policy 2009-10.

Sources informed TheNation that the decision has been taken because sugar is
available almost at double rates (above Rs 70 per kg) in the open market as
compared with the rates at USC. In this regard, Ministry of Industries and
Production presented a proposal to increase the price of sugar by Rs 7 per kg
i.e. from Rs 38 to Rs 45 per kg. The ECC also approved the bailout package for
Pakistan Steel Mills in view of the acute financial crunch experienced by PSM.

The meeting approved bail out package for PSM to meet its requirements, term
loan facility of Rs 8 billion for 5 years in favour of Pakistan Steel based on
government guarantee by consortium of banks led by the National Bank of
Pakistan. Running finance facility of Rs 2 billion, renewable on yearly basis,
would also be available in favour of Pakistan Steel Mills based on government
guarantee by consortium of banks led by the NBP.

The ECC agreed that there should be timely announcement of support price for
wheat, and ensuring timely availability of farm inputs at affordable prices with
special emphasis on water conservation and its judicious use. The ECC gave
approval to the measures including export of rice to Middle East, Iran, Europe
or any other market on government-to-government basis. It said sales and exports
would be done through qualified agents and brokers, while $ 900 per tonne would
be the minimum base price for super basmati within 5 percent limit of broken
rice.

Standardised Security Agreements was also approved in meeting for hydropower
projects under the Policy for Power Generation 2002. The ECC authorised the
Board of PPIB to approve any project specific amendment in the Standardised
Security Hydropower. The ECC approved the recommendations of the Committee on
Revival of Risalpur Export Processing Zone, which include allowing export of the
manufactured goods from the REPZ as trading items to Afghanistan via land route.
Export Processing Zone Authority, Board of Directors, will decide revision of
lease rates/annual ground rent, meanwhile 30 percent export of manufactured
goods to tariff area will be allowed.

It was also approved that provinces might avail re-lending of the foreign loans
on the same terms and conditions on which loans are signed by the government. In
this regard the provinces would be allowed to issue their own bonds. While
considering the issue of passing on the German grant/soft loan to PPAF for
livelihood support and promotion of small community infrastructure project, the
ECC approved relaxation of following terms before signing the Agreement: Passing
on of Euro 14,860,399.40 grant to Project Executing Agency (PPAF) as a grant,
and passing on of Euro 16,701,660.86 loan to Project Executing Agency (PPAF) as
a grant.
