                              701 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          Business Day (South Africa)

                            August 7, 2014 Thursday
                              Business Day Edition

Transnet lands R6bn US funding guarantee

BYLINE: LINDA ENSOR

SECTION: ECONOMY, BUSINESS & FINANCE

LENGTH: 351  words


Transnet lands R6bn US funding guarantee

CAPE TOWN - Transnet has secured a R6bn funding guarantee from US export credit
agency, Export-Import Bank of the US (US-Exim) for the funding of the diesel
locomotives the company is buying from General Electric (GE).

Transnet group CE Brian Molefe said yesterday that the guarantee was & a massive
thumbs-up from the international investor community, affirming Transnet's
creditworthiness and SA's attractiveness as an investment destination.

& The guarantee from US-Exim enables Transnet to raise funds in the markets for
the financing of the GE locomotive transaction,& Mr Molefe said.

& It allows for Transnet to negotiate favourable repayment terms, including the
tenor and interest rates,& he said.

& The required funding will be raised through bank loans supported by the
US-Exim guarantee.

& The terms of funding to be backed by the guarantee will be dependent on a
number of factors, including market conditions, pricing and investor appetite.&
The facility will be drawn over a three-year period in line with the locomotives
delivery schedule. The repayment period is 14 years. Mr Molefe said this term
would extend Transnet's debt maturity profile while improving the match between
assets and liabilities.

In March, Transnet announced an agreement to purchase 599 electric and 465
diesel locomotives from four original equipment manufacturers, including GE. The
guarantee is mainly intended for GE's share of the locomotives, which is 233
locomotives as well as other acquisitions from the manufacturer.

The locomotives are part of Transnet's locomotive fleet renewal programme - a
key element of the company's seven-year R312bn investment programme. The
majority of the locomotives are to be built at Transnet's facilities in SA.

Mr Molefe said the agreement was in line with the company's agreed funding
strategy which was premised on diversifying sources of finance in a
cost-effective manner. Funding from the debt capital markets accounts for only a
third of Transnet's investment programme, the remainder will be raised from cash
generated from its operations.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                    Copyright 2014 BDFM Publishers PTY Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              702 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                 African Banker

                               September 24, 2012

EBID's prospects remain encouraging

LENGTH: 1214 words


In sound financial shape and enjoying sustained growth, the ECOWAS Bank for
Investment and Development (EBID) prospects are encouraging.

Established in 2004 to replace the former Fund for Cooperation founded in 1975
with a capital of about $1.5bn, 70% held by the 15 member statesof the Economic
Community of West African States (ECOWAS), ECOWAS Bank for Investment and
Development (EBID) plays a key role as a stimulator of growth within the 15
state ECOWAS regional economic community, grouped in an economic space that
stretches over six million square kilometres with a population of about 307m.

After reporting a net loss of UA3.1m in 2010, the ECOWAS Bank for Investment and
Development (EBID) posted a profit expressed in Units of Account (UA -
equivalent to the Special Drawing Right (SDR) of the International Monetary Fund
of UA1.886m in 2011 by consolidating its operational activities.

Compared with December 2010, an analysis of the provisional audited accounts of
the Bank reveals an increase of 6.8% on the total balance sheet, which rose from
UA285,228m to UA304,700m.

The consolidation of the financial intermediation activities of EBID in a
difficult economic context where Africa is still reeling from the effects of the
euro-zone crisis, bodes well for a healthy financial standing and, above all,
translates into the ambitions of one of the most dynamic development financing
institutions of the continent.

EBID intervenes in both the public and private sector with a particular focus on
infrastructure that continues to be the bane of the sub-region. In 2010, the
Bank adopted a Strategic Plan for the period 2010-2014 with three major
priorities: infrastructure development, rural development and private sectors
development. The Bank aims to inject $1.5 billion into the economy of the
subregion ; that is US$300m each year for five years.

After eight years of operations between 2004 and 2011, the Bank approved 138
projects for a total amount of about $1.45bn

At the end of December 2011, the level of its total commitments amounted to
UA619 million, the equivalent of $985m for 107 active projects in sectors as
diverse as infrastructure, transportation, energy, telecommunications, industry,
and the environment.

In pursuit of the objectives set by the Board of Governors of EBID, operations
undertaken by the Bank from 1 January to 31 December 2011 were targeted at
strengthening its interventions in the 15 member states, improving the
management of the institution and intensifying its resource mobilization
strategies to finance operations.

Midway through the implementation of this programme, the immediate conclusions
are that the Bank has not relented in its quest for additional sources of
financing that can significantly support its loan portfolio that constitutes the
sole guarantee for its viability and profitability. Beyond that, the actual
effects of the interventions of this financial institution in the regional
economy have been that at least $160m in financial resources have been mobilised
in 2011 alone. The Bank also intends to mobilise $70m from Afrexim Bank and IDC.

With regard to operational activities during the year 2011, 21 projects,
including 16 private projects were appraised. The board also approved the
financing of 17 projects including 13 direct loans, three equity participations
and one guarantee for a total of UA118,488,034 ($188.66m).

With regard to agreements signed, the volume of loans granted by the Bank in
2011 amounted to UA105,966,063 ($168,718,106) for the implementation of 15
projects in Benin, Burkina Faso, Côte d'Ivoire, The Gambia, Guinea, Nigeria,
Sierra Leone and Togo.

In respect of supervision, 22 projects were monitored during the period. Faced
with the increased growth of the volume of its commitments, the Bank continued
to enhance its capital base through stable and technical resource mobilisation
activities with bilateral partners both outside and within ECOWAS in order to
support its interventions. The bilateral partners are primarily the Government
of India, the Global Environment Facility (GEF), the African Development Bank
(AfDB), the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa (BADEA), the French
Development Agency (AFD), AFREXIM BANK, the OPEC Fund for International
Development (OFID), the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) of South Africa
and the Office of Technical Assistance (OTA) of the US Treasury.

The Bank has never relented in its quest for additional sources of financing
that can significantly support its loan portfolio that constitutes the sole
guarantee for viability and profitability. In all, not less than $160m in loan
resources have been mobilised for the year 2011 alone. At the same time, the
Bank is to mobilise $70m from Afrexim Bank and IDC..

EBID is thus firmly committed on several fronts as evidenced by the dynamism of
its operational activities which increased by 12. 3% thanks to its volume of
commitments from 1 January to 31 December 2011 compared to the situation as at
the end of December 2010.

Despite these performances and efforts made in this area, EBID's main challenge
remains the mobilisation of adequate resources, especially at the community
level to enable the Bank to fully focus on its role as a development lever and a
catalyst for growth in the region, and to live up to its billing as an efficient
instrument for the fight against poverty, wealth creation and employment
genration for the welfare of the people of the region. n

EBID: Bashir Mamman Ifo, a manager from within as President

Having headed the ECOWAS Bank for Investment and Development as acting President
following the departure of Mr. Christian Narcisse Adovelande, Bashir Mamman Ifo
was appointed President of the Bank by the Board of Governors during their
meeting held on Monday 10th October, 2011 in Accra, Ghana.

Bashir Ifo is, essentially, a humble, courteous and easily approachable man.
Known for being industrious, particular and rigorous, the EBID's president (who
has effectively been at the helm of the Bank for two years) has been nurturing
high ambitions for the Bank where he has built his entire career.

Ifo is 52-years old and hails from Nigeria. As the then vice-president in charge
of Finance and Corporate Services, a position he had held since December 2007,
he assumed the interim of the former president of EBID, when his predecessor was
called upon to head a sister financial institution that is also located in Lome,
the Togolese capital.

Ifo belongs to the new breed of African managers. He was privileged to
participate and witness the institutional and strategic reforms of EBID,
particularly the transformation that took place in 1999. At the time he was
appointed as vice-president in charge of Finance and Corporate Services, he had
already served 13 years within the international financial institution.

He joined the ECOWAS Fund in 1995 where he occupied a number of senior positions
in the Departments of Finance, Treasury and Administration.

A banking and finance graduate from the prestigious Ahmadu Bello University,
Zaria Nigeria, Ifo also holds an MBA in Business Administration (Finance).

ECOWAS Bank for Investment and Development (EBID)

128 Boulevard du 13 janvier, BP : 2704 Lomé - Togo | Tél : +228 22-21-68-64 |
Fax : +228 22-21-86-84

                                 African Banker

                               September 24, 2012

EBID's prospects remain encouraging

LENGTH: 1214 words


In sound financial shape and enjoying sustained growth, the ECOWAS Bank for
Investment and Development (EBID) prospects are encouraging.

Established in 2004 to replace the former Fund for Cooperation founded in 1975
with a capital of about $1.5bn, 70% held by the 15 member statesof the Economic
Community of West African States (ECOWAS), ECOWAS Bank for Investment and
Development (EBID) plays a key role as a stimulator of growth within the 15
state ECOWAS regional economic community, grouped in an economic space that
stretches over six million square kilometres with a population of about 307m.

After reporting a net loss of UA3.1m in 2010, the ECOWAS Bank for Investment and
Development (EBID) posted a profit expressed in Units of Account (UA -
equivalent to the Special Drawing Right (SDR) of the International Monetary Fund
of UA1.886m in 2011 by consolidating its operational activities.

Compared with December 2010, an analysis of the provisional audited accounts of
the Bank reveals an increase of 6.8% on the total balance sheet, which rose from
UA285,228m to UA304,700m.

The consolidation of the financial intermediation activities of EBID in a
difficult economic context where Africa is still reeling from the effects of the
euro-zone crisis, bodes well for a healthy financial standing and, above all,
translates into the ambitions of one of the most dynamic development financing
institutions of the continent.

EBID intervenes in both the public and private sector with a particular focus on
infrastructure that continues to be the bane of the sub-region. In 2010, the
Bank adopted a Strategic Plan for the period 2010-2014 with three major
priorities: infrastructure development, rural development and private sectors
development. The Bank aims to inject $1.5 billion into the economy of the
subregion ; that is US$300m each year for five years.

After eight years of operations between 2004 and 2011, the Bank approved 138
projects for a total amount of about $1.45bn

At the end of December 2011, the level of its total commitments amounted to
UA619 million, the equivalent of $985m for 107 active projects in sectors as
diverse as infrastructure, transportation, energy, telecommunications, industry,
and the environment.

In pursuit of the objectives set by the Board of Governors of EBID, operations
undertaken by the Bank from 1 January to 31 December 2011 were targeted at
strengthening its interventions in the 15 member states, improving the
management of the institution and intensifying its resource mobilization
strategies to finance operations.

Midway through the implementation of this programme, the immediate conclusions
are that the Bank has not relented in its quest for additional sources of
financing that can significantly support its loan portfolio that constitutes the
sole guarantee for its viability and profitability. Beyond that, the actual
effects of the interventions of this financial institution in the regional
economy have been that at least $160m in financial resources have been mobilised
in 2011 alone. The Bank also intends to mobilise $70m from Afrexim Bank and IDC.

With regard to operational activities during the year 2011, 21 projects,
including 16 private projects were appraised. The board also approved the
financing of 17 projects including 13 direct loans, three equity participations
and one guarantee for a total of UA118,488,034 ($188.66m).

With regard to agreements signed, the volume of loans granted by the Bank in
2011 amounted to UA105,966,063 ($168,718,106) for the implementation of 15
projects in Benin, Burkina Faso, Côte d'Ivoire, The Gambia, Guinea, Nigeria,
Sierra Leone and Togo.

In respect of supervision, 22 projects were monitored during the period. Faced
with the increased growth of the volume of its commitments, the Bank continued
to enhance its capital base through stable and technical resource mobilisation
activities with bilateral partners both outside and within ECOWAS in order to
support its interventions. The bilateral partners are primarily the Government
of India, the Global Environment Facility (GEF), the African Development Bank
(AfDB), the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa (BADEA), the French
Development Agency (AFD), AFREXIM BANK, the OPEC Fund for International
Development (OFID), the Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) of South Africa
and the Office of Technical Assistance (OTA) of the US Treasury.

The Bank has never relented in its quest for additional sources of financing
that can significantly support its loan portfolio that constitutes the sole
guarantee for viability and profitability. In all, not less than $160m in loan
resources have been mobilised for the year 2011 alone. At the same time, the
Bank is to mobilise $70m from Afrexim Bank and IDC..

EBID is thus firmly committed on several fronts as evidenced by the dynamism of
its operational activities which increased by 12. 3% thanks to its volume of
commitments from 1 January to 31 December 2011 compared to the situation as at
the end of December 2010.

Despite these performances and efforts made in this area, EBID's main challenge
remains the mobilisation of adequate resources, especially at the community
level to enable the Bank to fully focus on its role as a development lever and a
catalyst for growth in the region, and to live up to its billing as an efficient
instrument for the fight against poverty, wealth creation and employment
genration for the welfare of the people of the region. n

EBID: Bashir Mamman Ifo, a manager from within as President

Having headed the ECOWAS Bank for Investment and Development as acting President
following the departure of Mr. Christian Narcisse Adovelande, Bashir Mamman Ifo
was appointed President of the Bank by the Board of Governors during their
meeting held on Monday 10th October, 2011 in Accra, Ghana.

Bashir Ifo is, essentially, a humble, courteous and easily approachable man.
Known for being industrious, particular and rigorous, the EBID's president (who
has effectively been at the helm of the Bank for two years) has been nurturing
high ambitions for the Bank where he has built his entire career.

Ifo is 52-years old and hails from Nigeria. As the then vice-president in charge
of Finance and Corporate Services, a position he had held since December 2007,
he assumed the interim of the former president of EBID, when his predecessor was
called upon to head a sister financial institution that is also located in Lome,
the Togolese capital.

Ifo belongs to the new breed of African managers. He was privileged to
participate and witness the institutional and strategic reforms of EBID,
particularly the transformation that took place in 1999. At the time he was
appointed as vice-president in charge of Finance and Corporate Services, he had
already served 13 years within the international financial institution.

He joined the ECOWAS Fund in 1995 where he occupied a number of senior positions
in the Departments of Finance, Treasury and Administration.

A banking and finance graduate from the prestigious Ahmadu Bello University,
Zaria Nigeria, Ifo also holds an MBA in Business Administration (Finance).

                     The Telegraph-Journal (New Brunswick)

                            December 4, 2007 Tuesday

'Marginally viable today'; Forestry Even with a $17-million loan from the
province, no guarantees for Atholville mill

BYLINE: Reid Southwick Telegraph-Journal

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 633  words


The manager of an Atholville pulp mill is offering no guarantees it will stay in
the province over the long term, even after it received a multi- million-dollar
loan from the Liberal government.

Business New Brunswick officially announced Monday a $17.3-million investment in
the mill, with the only condition that its owners match the funding and spend it
on upgrades.

The mill, owned by Aditya Birla Group, a global conglomerate, and Tembec Canada,
a national forestry firm, said it will spend the total $32.3-million investment
on key upgrades to remove bottlenecks in the mill's operations, boosting its
daily capacity from 300 to 360 metric tonnes, and keeping 275 workers employed.

But Peter Vinall, president and chief executive of AV Group, which manages the
mill, said Monday there are "no guarantees" it will continue operating over the
longer term.

"We're marginally viable today, and with these investments we will be viable for
the foreseeable future," he said. "But things can change; the exchange rate can
go up, energy prices can change. There are many, many variables to consider. "

AbitibiBowater announced last week unstable market conditions are forcing it to
close its Dalhousie mill next January, putting roughly 350 people out of work.

That is the latest development to rock the province's forestry sector, as just
61 mills are left in the province and only 16 of those are operating at full
capacity.

Mark Arsenault, president and chief executive of the New Brunswick Forest
Products Association, said Monday AV Cell's unwillingness to make a long-term
commitment to stay in the province is justified, given these market
uncertainties.

"No company can foresee their future under these circumstances," he said. "
Guarantees are difficult to make in difficult times. Obviously, you want to see
investments and people working toward solutions."

A spokesman for Business New Brunswick echoed Arsenault's comments.

"There is always an uncertainty as it's a tough sector of the economy," said
Ryan Donaghy. "But it's certainly a good sign when a company has the foresight
to invest in their facility to do upgrades, to increase their capacity in order
to compete in the global market place.

Vinall said the upgrades are among the mill's top priorities in the foreseeable
future.

"The important thing for us is to focus on the things that we can control and
not be distracted by the things that we can't control," he said.

The AV Group president said the firm will work aggressively to improve its
operating costs and overall efficiencies, and step up its lobby efforts with the
province in a bid to bring down energy and wood costs.

Vinall said he will be meeting with provincial officials in the near future to
advocate a series of policy proposals that will accomplish his overall goals.

Two of those proposals include a reduction in the cost of Crown wood and the
extension of a policy that places a levy on the sale of sawmills between
operators in the province and another levy if Crown wood allocations exchange
hands.

Funds from the sales, according to the policy, are re-allocated into the
community to pay for economic development.

The policy, announced in August, was designed to compel smaller outfits to bow
out of the game while others increase their holdings and benefit from the
efficiency of larger production. The policy is up for renewal at the end of this
month, though no decision has yet been made.

"We have a significant amount of dormant capacity in the province, and it's time
for some change," said Vinall, referring to the mass volumes of Crown land left
by closed mills in Bathurst, Miramichi and, soon, Dalhousie.

"There needs to be some natural mechanisms to allow natural consolidation, being
mindful of the local communities and the need to do our best to preserve jobs."

LOAD-DATE: December 4, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                      Mt. Vernon Register-News (Illinois)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 10, 2008 Wednesday

New business coming to King City

BYLINE: Tesa Culli, Mt. Vernon Register-News, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 381 words


Sep. 10--MT. VERNON -- The city will be getting a new business, as an Idaho
company has been given the thumbs up by the Revolving Loan Committee to receive
$120,000 for equipment for a new production facility.

High Ridge Designs, LLC, located in Victor, Idaho, caters to a niche market
selling, designing and creating resort T-shirts and sweat shirts.

"Our customers are resorts and the recreation industry across the country,"
Hondo Miller of High Ridge Designs told members of the committee on Tuesday. "We
ship a ton of product to the east coast, and we've been trying to find a good
way to help with the cost by opening another facility ... We've been evaluating
opening a more eastern printing facility."

Three couples started the company in Idaho, but have their roots in St. Louis
and Kansas City, Mo. Miller said local businesswoman and city council member
Mary Burgan and Chris Barker are friends, and "the light bulb went off."

"We started talking with Mary, who we knew had a building," Miller said. Miller
explained the company will be leasing a 21,000 square foot section of the former
Heavy Duty/Dowser building on Industrial Drive from Burgan, and has already
shipped some equipment to the site.

The company will not be accepting local orders for T-shirts, concentrating on
its developed market.

"No revenues will be going out of the community, but we'll be bringing business
into the community," Miller said of the company plans, adding orders and
accounting will continue to be part of the Idaho operation, with printing and
shipping being the primary focus of the Mt. Vernon facility.

The committee approved a $120,000 loan at 2.75 percent interest for seven years.
The loan will be secured with the equipment and a personal guarantee from Miller
and his wife.

The recommendation from the committee will go to the City Council for final
consideration.

To see more of Mt. Vernon Register-News or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.register-news.com/. Copyright (c) 2008, Mt. Vernon Register-News,
Ill. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                                 The Australian

                            February 5, 2016 Friday
                               Australian Edition

MacBank CAF unit bulks up

BYLINE: Gretchen Friemann, Financing

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 508  words


Macquarie's low-profile corporate and asset finance business continues to
expand, seeing asset growth of 23 per cent during the December quarter.

The business, which extends from aircraft leasing to car dealer financing, has
emerged as a key contributor. Just five years ago it supplied just 10 per cent
of Macquarie's profits. In 2015 that figure more than doubled to 27 per cent,
transforming the unit, as chief executive Nicholas Moore pointed out yesterday
in a quarterly update held in Sydney, into a top contributor to the group's
overall earnings, outstripped only by Macquarie's Asset Management division.

Yet the division known as "CAF" remains out of the spotlight. Its joint head,
Ben Brazil, nicknamed "Brains" by his former mentor, Mr Moore, remains an
elusive figure who shuns publicity.

He finally made an appearance yesterday, addressing the market for the first
time about how the relatively opaque lending unit is run.

In the early days, Mr Brazil's appearance at CAF attracted media attention.
Macquarie had recently received a government guarantee and commentators claimed
the sudden expansion of a little known division was designed to capitalise on
the bank's top notch credit rating at the expense of taxpayers. CAF was accused
of cashing in on a favourable spread that enabled it to source money cheaply and
capture hefty returns.

The accusation was that CAF was cashing in on the spread - the cost of sourcing
the money and the return.

It's a line adamantly rejected by Macquarie, which stressed the bank pays 1 per
cent a year for all funding issued under the guarantee, equating to
approximately $200m per year. A spokesperson said the bank had not issued new
debt under the guarantee since August 2009.

Yet the expansion of CAF is viewed as another example of Macquarie's enduring
ability to reinvent itself.

In his presentation, Mr Brazil, who led the bank's failed attempt to buy out the
London Stock Exchange in 2005, stressed his unit's strategy centred on two
central pillars: flexibility and a thirst for returns.

The lending arm now oversees a $10.1bn loan portfolio, and holds close to 500
exposures across a diverse range of companies and sectors. Its list of borrowers
in Australia included Sydney Airport, AGL, Genesis Healthcare and Mantra Hotels.

One of its largest and highest-profile loans was to the failed toll road,
Brisconnections, which was recently sold to Transurban for close to $2bn. That
transaction is expected to close within the next few months, although it's not
clear whether the returns from CAF's exit will wash in to the annual results.

Either way, Mr Brazil stressed the deal was not "significant" to the group's
profits.

The high-ranking banker, who is also a director of Crown Casinos and a confidant
of billionaire James Packer, told investors and analysts his unit adopted an
"open minded and flexible approach" to funding and the deployment of capital.The
central principle, he stressed, was to ensure "that whatever return level is
available more than compensates for the risk we are taking on".

LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: The Australian

                              All Rights Reserved


                              707 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                           Daily Independent (Lagos)

                            January 30, 2011 Sunday

Pitfalls of Property Acquisition, By Ubosi [analysis]

BYLINE: Chudi Ubosi

LENGTH: 2037  words


The Nigerian real estate market provides one of the most unique markets in the
entire world, with prices rivaling major world cities on a per square metre
basis. Lagos-based realtor,

, in this treatise lists 10 vital points of note on property acquisition in the
country. He laments that the real estate in question is hardly serviced by
adequate physical and social infrastructure, and the fact that top dollar or
pound is being paid to live in the best neighborhoods on offer does not
guarantee the best in terms of basic amenities, which are taken for granted in
other climes.

A key issue of property acquisition in Nigeria is that real estate values are
high. Nigeria has one of the highest real estate values in the world in relation
to the infrastructure and services offered by the neighbourhoods where these
properties are sited.

One of the major problems with property acquisition in Nigeria is the absence of
long-term mortgage facilities, similar to what obtains in the developed
countries of the world. This has been attributed to the absence of savings by
individuals and so the bulk of money available to the financial institutions for
lending are short-term deposits with 90 percent of them having less than 365-day
tenor.

The import of this is that the few building societies and primary mortgage
institutions operating in Nigeria as well as the financial institutions can
barely seriously finance property acquisition. Though it is regularly claimed by
these institutions that they will provide the necessary finance, it is not
difficult to discover that the facility is indeed a commercial loan couched as a
mortgage loan with interest rates sometimes reaching as high as 20 to 25 percent
per annum.

The institution set up by government to facilitate home ownership was the
Nigeria Building Society - now Federal Mortgage Bank of Nigeria (FMBN). One of
the objectives of the bank is to provide finance for Nigerians to purchase or
build their own homes through the National Housing Fund (NHF).

The conditions for accessing the facility - a maximum of N15 million - are
stringent, and only the patient and persistent end up accessing same. Up till
last year the maximum anybody could be loaned was N5 million. This N5 million
limit may have been a large sum of money in the 1970s but, with the astronomical
rise in values, it would hardly make an impact on the finances of those who can
really access it.

The most current figures on the FMBN website indicate that the two years
preceding 2005, the bank collected N15 billion as contribution from
stakeholders, whilst giving out N10 billion as loans, and this was for the
delivery of 13,672 units of housing at various locations nationwide.

There is also the high cost of registering/formalising title in the name of the
purchaser. Many states charge what is known as a Consent Fee. This is basically
saying that the governor of the state in which your property is located has
consented to your purchase of the property. These powers are derived from the
Land Use Act of 1978.

In Lagos State for example, this consent fee is usually charged at 15 percent of
the property value and is made up of stamp duties and capital gains tax, among
others. The fact that one can pay the 15 percent Consent Fee does not also
guarantee speedy processing of title change, and the process can take from a
minimum of about three months in Lagos to as much five years in other states.
The public service beaurcracy and bottlenecks see to that.

Once again, it is advisable that as soon as a property purchase transaction is
concluded, the buyer should commence the process of title perfection in his/her
name.

Gated communities exist all over Nigeria, and it is usually advisable to as much
as possible locate one's residence within them.

The reason is not farfetched: as a result of the poor impact of government,
residents within these communities band together to provide themselves with
facilities and services.

Security is better, cleanliness of the roads; drainage and cutting of lawns is a
communal issue. Of course, a monthly levy is paid by all residents usually
dependant on property size and accommodation. The residents associations are
made up of residents and they basically administer the estate.

These associations are so strong that they can sometimes control and influence
the quality and density of development on properties to be developed within
their estates.

This may sound very strange to the uninitiated in matters of land transactions
in Nigeria, but it is true, particularly for private land.

A registered title document is not a guarantee that you will have peace on your
newly bought land or property. This is in the sense that there may be on-going
litigation - which can sometimes take as long as 15 years before resolution -
and which may escape the eyes of a lawyer, during the process of undertaking due
diligence on the title documents.

There is also the case of unresolved disputes over land/property ownership
despite registered title to same.

The solution remains the use of a good property lawyer (not all lawyers are well
versed in the intricacies of property transactions no matter how much they may
say to the contrary) and the thorough investigation of title not only at the
Land Registry but also with a few well placed questions about the vendor and the
reasons for the sale.

There is a phenomenon in the Nigerian real estate market called the "omo onile."
This literally translates to the "children of the owners of the land."

It is a development that originated in the south western part of Nigeria, but is
fast gaining ground in other areas of the nation.

These "omo onile" appear at your newly acquired site when construction is about
to commence, and they insist on being paid certain sums of money as a gratuity
for being descendants of the original owners of the land. Refusal to acquiesce
can sometimes lead to frivolous court cases, meant to be of nuisance value, to
threats of violence and sometimes violence. It remains an issue that defiles
solution and property purchasers have had to live with the antics of these
miscreants.

Titles from the government remains the most secure, but available data indicate
that only three percent of the total land in Nigeria has such registrable title.

Finally, it is always advisable that as soon as a property is bought the
perfection of title in your name should be commenced and concluded soonest.

It is very important that as much as possible a thorough due diligence of
facilities provided in a property are undertaken before payment is effected.
Water supply, electric sockets, switches, roof, kitchen cabinets should all be
carefully checked out.

There have been experiences of cases where sockets, switches and electrical
fittings were installed, but no wiring in the conduit pipes.

Ensure that the vendor has approved building plans and tax clearance
certificates, among others. As small as these issues may seem they can become
very frustrating matters when trying to perfect title in the name of the buyer.

Also check that the property does not flood during the rainy season - a very
common problem in Lagos Island and many other parts other parts of Nigeria.

If there are any renovations or modifications promised by the vendor to
facilitate the sale, these must be properly documented and agreements reached on
enforcing/implementing them before payment is made.

It is usually doubly difficult to get vendors to fulfill their obligations to a
buyer once payment has been fully made.

The only recourse is legal and as the Nigerian experience has highlighted, it is
usually a long, torturous route.

In the process of buying a property, it may turn out that the property is
occupied by a paying tenant, the vendor or a relation.

Experience over the years has shown that it is best to insist on vacant
possession simultaneously with payment or have in place very firm enforceable
agreements for vacant possession, if that is to come after the purchase is
concluded.

The reasons are obvious. A buyer could be left with a litigious tenant several
years after purchase of a property.

The best way once again to guarantee that agreements made are kept is that a
certain percentage of the sale price is withheld by the purchaser to be released
only upon vacant possession.

Though it sounds difficult to believe, residents of even the high brow areas of
Nigeria with the highest land and rental values, still provide their own
services.

Public services in Nigeria are non-existent and where they exist at all are very
unreliable.

Therefore in making a purchase of property, one must factor in the cost of a
generator - two these days: a small 5 - 7 KVA, to run during the day and a
larger 25 - 40 KVA to run through the night when all the air conditioners and
other appliances are working.

Boreholes, where they are not already available on the property must be provided
to ensure regular supply of water.

Provisions must be made to employ your own security men, as most likely your
intended purchase is already tucked behind a high fence for the same security
purposes.

Efficient refuse disposal is usually by private arrangement, despite the
promises of the public workers and local government staff.

It is common practice that luxury apartments when let in many parts of Nigeria
are charged separately for provisions of services, such as electricity,
security, refuse and gardening. This figure is sometimes as high as 15 percent
of the rent paid.

One major issue about property acquisition which is coming to fore gradually,
but which has been a major parameter in most of the developed world, is that as
much as possible purchase your home near your office, or your spouses office, or
something that has a correlation to a significant part of your life.

This is because, for instance, commuting in Lagos, and many parts of Nigeria can
be frustrating, with Lagos topping the list. Two to three hours of commute time
on regular days, going up to four to five hours on a rainy day as a result of
traffic, is part and parcel of life in Lagos.

The usual advice is: do not stay in Lagos if you don't have to. Nigeria has
numerous other opportunities outside Lagos, with the attendant good quality life
that we all seek and deserve.

Despite the foregoing, Lagos still accounts for over 60 percent of the economic
activities of Nigeria. It remains difficult to avoid Lagos as much as many
people would love to.

Property values in Nigeria appreciate rapidly, and the reason can be understood
with the following statistics.

Nigeria has a population of about 150 million citizens with over 50 percent of
the population distribution made up of age group 19 - 65 years.

According to the United Nations statistics, less than 20 percent of the
population of people in that age group is adequately housed by their (UN)
standards.

Add to this, the fact that the housing shortfall in Nigeria as a nation is put
very conservatively at 15 million units, made up of various types of
accommodation.

Lagos as a state has an estimated population of 12 - 15 million people with an
additional positive net in flow of at least 800 - 1000 people daily.

These statistics have been provided to highlight the reasons for the acute
housing shortage in Nigeria and the resultant huge demand pressure that is
brought to bear on the available stock of property either for lease or sale.

This pressure causes a rapid rise in values - both rental and capital
particularly in the major commercial cities of Nigeria - Lagos, Abuja and Port
Harcourt. Rental return can also be as high as 10 percent per annum in many
locations.

This rapid rise in values makes property acquisition in Nigeria a viable
investment option. Property capital values are known to sometimes rise as much
as 15 - 20 percent per annum.

The market remains firm despite the much-touted economic crisis and should
remain firm even in the foreseeable future, as there is no plan either by the
government or private sector to drastically tackle the housing shortfall
problem.

The Nigerian read estate market remains firm despite the upheavals caused by the
global economic crisis. The investment opportunities and returns in all sectors
- commercial, industrial and residential remain very attractive.

LOAD-DATE: January 31, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              708 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                   The Times

                           September 6, 1991, Friday

Britain grants biggest loan since Tiananmen

BYLINE: By Catherine Sampson in Peking and Our Foreign Staff

SECTION: Overseas news

LENGTH: 361 words


BRITISH banks have agreed to lend China Pounds 100 million. It is the biggest
loan secured by Peking since the suppression of the pro-democracy campaign in
June 1989.

The money will finance the building of an ethylene plant, the biggest project
covered by th Pounds 300 million concessional finance package offered by the
British government in September 1988 but frozen when sanctions were imposed
after the killings of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square by the
security forces.

The deal, underwritten by a syndicate of nine London-based banks led by the
Midland, was signed in Peking on the last day of John Major's visit to China.
The British embassy in Peking insisted that the timing was merely coincidental.

Restrictions on loans to China were removed last December. The agreement for the
Pounds 100 million loan had been initialled long before Mr Major's visit was
announced.

Britain and other Western countries cut off official loans, high-level
government contacts and military co-operation after the Chinese army opened fire
on unarmed demonstrators in June 1989. The European Community lifted all but the
military embargo last October.

The signing of the loan agreement signals the normalisation of economic
relations in the same way that the prime minister's visit reflected the
normalisation of diplomatic relations. The two events may have been timed to
coincide.

The loan, repayable over 20 years, is at a preferential rate of interest of less
than 5 per cent. It will enable the Chinese authorities to import equipment from
Britain for the construction of the ethylene plant with an annual capacity of
140,000 tonnes in the northwestern region of Xinjiang. The factory is part of a
vast petrochemical project which is partly financed by foreign credit.

Britain's biggest government-backed loan to China last year was for just Pounds
12 million. The Pounds 100 million loan is 100 per cent underwritten by the
Export Credit Guarantee Department. The participating banks, apart from the
Midland, are Barclays, NatWest, Kleinwort, Schroder Wagg, Morgan Grenfell,
Chartered West, Banque Paribas and the HongKong and Shanghai.

LOAD-DATE: September 7, 1991

                              709 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                       Eastern Wake News (North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 29, 2008 Friday

Burr celebrates milestone financing deal with EWA

BYLINE: Denise Sherman, Eastern Wake News, Zebulon, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 580 words


Aug. 29--ZEBULON -- From a dream written on a napkin to a $7.5 million
renovation project, East Wake Academy is on the move.

U.S. Sen. Richard Burr announced last Wednesday USDA Rural Development financing
for a new facility just on the heels of the school opening its senior academy.

The future 25,000 foot facility will house classrooms, a media center and a
library for all of its high school students, said headmaster Brandon Smith.

Smith said the school anticipates increased enrollment and will need the
additional space.

East Wake Academy obtained a $1.8 million low interest loan from U.S.D.A. Rural
Development for the renovation of the Zebulon Civic Center into its senior
academy which opened last month.

That facility was toured by guests after a ceremony -- complete with pageantry
and speeches. Its renovation was actually the reason Burr and USDA state
director John Cooper visited the school.

But at the last minute, the financing for East Wake Academy's second phase came
through. While Burr was there to celebrate the building of facilities, he said
character, commitment and conviction mean more than brick and mortar.

"There is nothing in life you can't achieve if you're willing to commit the time
it takes to succeed," he said. Burr told two stories to hit home his points. He
told of the people of Stoneville, N.C. picking up the remnants of their Main
Street, brick by brick, after a tornado. He said he saw the fabric of a
community at work.

"If one piece elects not to integrate, it makes the community that much weaker,"
he said.

He also told of Helen Keller's response to a reporter who asked her if there was
anything worse than being blind.

Her response: To have her sight, but lose her vision.

Burr said East Wake Academy had not lost its vision.

Smith, who later told Burr his hometown was Stoneville, said EWA has tripled
since 2002 with 940 students currently enrolled in grades K-12.

EWA's graduation rate is 85 percent, compared to the state rate at 69 percent,
said Smith. He also noted that each member of the class of 2008 has been
accepted into a college or university.

John Cooper, state director of USDA, Rural Development, said the government
department makes loans in communities of less than 20,000 and commercial loans
in towns less than 50,000.

Cooper, along with Wake County Sheriff Donnie Harrison, gave personal testaments
to education.

Cooper said he grew up on a tobacco farm in Sampson County and wanted to help
other people develop their gifts. And Harrison, the sheriff of the second
largest county in North Carolina, listed education as one of the ingredients of
his success.

U.S.D.A. Rural Development will provide a $6.5 million bond guarantee to Cape
Fear Farm Credit along with a $1 million community low interest loan for the
construction of the new 25,000-square-foot building.

The event opened with colors presented by the cub scouts from Pack 522, and a
rousing "I'm Proud to be an American," by Angela Millenbaugh, EWA chorus
director.

Contact Denise Sherman at 269-6101, ext. 101, or dsherman@nando.com

To see more of the Eastern Wake News or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.easternwakenews.com/. Copyright (c) 2008, Eastern Wake News, Zebulon,
N.C. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                          New Straits Times (Malaysia)

                                 April 28, 1999

RM490mil loans taken under SCES facilities since 1995

SECTION: Business; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 310 words


THE Export-Import Bank of Malaysia Bhd has approved a total of RM490
million worth of loans under its Supplier Credit Export Services
facilities since the bank's inception in August 1995.

Exim Bank senior manager Engku Husaimi Hazmi said yesterday that
cumulative disbursements made to commercial banks for its Export Credit
Financing since Jan 1 last year amounted to RM6.18 billion.

Approvals under the Buyer Credit and Overseas Investment Credit
facilities were RM1.47 billion of which RM209 million had been approved in
the form of guarantee, Huzaimi said at a seminar on "Towards the
development of Malaysian exporters community" in Kuala Lumpur.

The Supplier Credit Export Services, Export Credit Financing and Buyer
Credit and Overseas Investment Credit facilities are some of Exim Bank's
initiatives to help local companies finance their export activities.

"Through the Buyer Credit and Overseas Investment Credit facilities, the
bank has been able to assist Malaysian companies in exporting and
investing in countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia, China, Namibia, Papua
New Guinea, Cambodia and South Africa," Huzaimi said.

The projects included building construction, telecommunications, highway
construction and export of palm oil machinery, he said.

Meanwhile, Bank Negara director of exchange control department Mohamad
Radzi Kechik said the various policy measures introduced to overcome the
country's economic and financial problems had yielded positive results.

"The business environment has turned favourable, making it easier for
businessmen to conduct operations."

Among the major factors contributing to this favourable environment were
the pegging of of the ringgit which facilitates business planning, the
increased allocation by the Government to various special funds, and lower
interest rates.

                              711 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                            December 22, 2008 Monday

Banks urged to use SBP financial inclusion initiatives

BYLINE: OUR STAFF REPORTER

LENGTH: 1078 words


KARACHI - Deputy Governor State Bank of Pakistan, Yaseen Anwar on Monday
stressed upon all commercial banks, microfinance banks and microfinance
institutions to utilise State Bank's initiatives regarding agricultural,
microfinance and SME financing to create an enabling environment for financial
inclusion of the rural population.

Speaking at Asia Pacific Rural And Agricultural Credit Association's (APRACA)
FinPower Program on Rural Finance held at State Bank of Pakistan in Karachi,
Anwar said that banks should undertake their best efforts to meet the maximum
credit needs of the rural community.

"Innovations in product development and adoption of best practices are the need
of the hour that would assist in developing the rural economy, eradicating
poverty and increasing food security," he added. APRACA is a regional forum for
sharing knowledge of international best practices of the region in agri/rural
finance. State Bank is a member of APRACA.

Highlighting State Bank's initiatives to promote rural finance in the country,
Anwar said that the SBP has formulated a separate Development Finance Group to
synergise all rural finance activities vis agriculture, SME and microfinance. In
addition to this group, other arms of SBP are contributing in aligning its
policies to the initiatives and developments for encouraging the banks to adopt
development finance as a viable business, he added.

He said agriculture lending has received a significant boost as the banks have
met their targets over the past 5 to 6 years and the agri. disbursement has
increased to Rs 212 billion in FY 2007-08 from Rs 39 billion in FY 1999-2000.

Under the new paradigm, SBP has taken several initiatives in the last 7 years
which, inter alia, include the induction of 14 domestic private banks in
agricultural credit scheme, besides the five big banks and two specialized banks
viz. ZTBL & PPCBL, standardization of loan documents and issuance of guidelines
for livestock, fisheries, poultry and horticulture financing.  Further, to
resolve the issue of the farmers for fresh documentation for input loans on each
crop loans, a Revolving Credit Scheme for three-year credit limits with one-time
documentation was introduced. To implement SBP's initiatives at the regional
level, separate Development Finance Support Department and its units have been
established at SBP-BSC.

He said to mitigate the risk of banks and the farming community against losses
caused by natural calamities, the SBP has developed a Crop Loan Insurance
Framework with the help of a Task Force comprising of representatives of banks,
leading insurance companies, the farming community and other stakeholders. Based
on SBP's framework, a mandatory crop loan insurance scheme has been introduced
from Rabi crop 2008-09 for major crops, viz. wheat, cotton, rice, sugarcane and
maize, he added.

"SBP is striving to establish a farmer-friendly market based financial sector in
the country to meet the increasing credit requirements of the agriculture
sector," he added.

Referring to microfinance sector, he said that the SBP has developed a national
strategy to target 3 million microfinance clients by 2010 and 10 million by
2015. Currently, MFBs and MFIs have an outreach of 1.8 million borrowers. SBP
has identified three concurrent steps the industry needs to undergo in order to
fulfil its set goals viz; Sustainable and cost covering operating/business
model; Mobilization of private domestic capital; and building human resource
capacity/systems.

Anwar said in order to develop these critical components of the microfinance
industry, SBP has undertaken several steps, that includes but not limited to,
launching the Financial Inclusion Program (FIP), aimed at eliminating market
failure and improving access to financial services. FIP is a ú50 million program
funded by the UK Department for International Development (DFID), he said and
added it includes a Microfinance Credit Guarantee Facility aimed at providing
incentive to banks / DFIs to channelise funds to MFBs/MFIs for on-lending to low
income segment of the population.

"The facility will provide a credit guarantee for up to 40 percent of funding
provided by banks/DFIs and aims to develop the market and graduate poor
borrowers to mainstream financial service providers," he said.

SBP Deputy Governor said that the Institutional Strengthening Fund is designed
to build capacity of the microfinance sector and is expected to enhance the
potential for growth and create depth in outreach by improving human resource
quality, service delivery and increase service availability to prudential
microfinance clients. The improving Access to Finance Service Fund is designed
to enhance capacity of the microfinance sector and promotes financial literacy
in the country. Besides the above, SBP has issued Branchless Banking guidelines,
which is the regulatory framework to promote banking in

remote/rural areas, he said.

Talking about the SME sector, he said that the sector is confronted with a
number of demand side constraints, including a lack of bookkeeping at SMEs,
missing succession planning, rare strategic objectives or business planning, low
level of financial literacy, unskilled human resources, lack of collateral, etc.

On top of these, there is an issue of availability of formal credit to SMEs
which hinders the progression of smooth growth of this sector. The banks also
consider financing to SMEs and Rural Entrepreneurs (RE) as risky ventures; hence
they are shy of lending to rural sector enterprises. The issues at the bank
level include non-aggressive lending strategies by banks, absence of specific
products offered for SMEs, and a perceived high-risk area by the banks, etc.

He said to motivate banks for lending to SMEs and Rural Enterprises, SBP has
taken several initiatives. He said that SBP has also completed an ADB-funded
project for Strengthening Secured Transaction Framework. The project is aimed at
enhancing SMEs, agri-farmers' and rural entrepreneurs' access to formal source
of finance by establishing a system of charge creation on moveable and immovable
assets of small borrowers in urban and rural areas. Based on the study, the
necessary amendment in the Legal Framework has been suggested to the government.
Rose Cooray, Assistant Governor Central Bank of Sri Lanka and member of APRACA,
also shared the experience of Sri Lanka's rural finance policies & programs with
participants of the programme.

                     The Telegraph-Journal (New Brunswick)

                            June 17, 2009 Wednesday

Understanding relative terminology

BYLINE: DAVID CAMPBELL Economically driven

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 747  words


In the past few months there have been many stories in the media about
government's use of taxpayer funds or the tax system in the name of economic
development. The media has been filled with stories of corporate bailouts,
corporate loans, loan guarantees, tax incentives, etc. The most notable story
has been that of the automobile manufacturing sector "bailout" but there have
been many more across Canada and in New Brunswick.

To clear up confusion, I thought I would provide you with a little primer on how
governments use taxpayer funds to support economic development and offer a few
comments on why, in certain instances, this is necessary.

I would like to clarify the difference between a loan and a loan guarantee. You
might have read in the local media recently about the New Brunswick government
giving a big loan guarantees to a private company while at the same time cutting
education funding. Many of the stories forgot to include the definition of a
loan guarantee or made no effort to distinguish for readers the difference.

A loan guarantee involves the government guaranteeing that a company's line of
credit or some other financial facility is guaranteed by the government in case
of default. The government is not spending a single penny. This is exactly what
the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp. does for virtually every first-time
homebuyer's mortgage.

Occasionally, a company may default and the government may have to honour that
loan guarantee but it is the exception rather than the rule.

Another financial tool the government of New Brunswick uses is something called
a forgivable loan. A forgivable loan is a cash payment directly to a company
that is structured as a loan but the company is not required to pay it back if
they meet certain conditions. Usually these conditions include the creation and
maintenance of a certain number of jobs. It is not really a loan. It is a grant
as long as the company meets its obligations. Think of it as a grant with
protection for the taxpayer investment.

Sometimes governments take part ownership of a company. In these cases, the
government will provide funds to a company in return for an equity stake
(shares). This is quite rare in Canada but the recent case of General Motors and
Chrysler are significant examples.

There are people who believe that under no circumstances should government be
giving taxpayer dollars directly to businesses or offering tax incentives to
encourage business investments. I don't happen to agree with this position for
two main reasons.

First, every U.S. state and Canadian province offers some form of financial
incentives to industry in the name of economic development, as do the vast
majority of municipal governments. As for federal governments in both Canada and
the United States, they transfer billions of dollars each year directly to
companies. I suppose you could still argue New Brunswick should unilaterally
disarm and stop offering any kind of corporate incentives but I think the risk
associated with this would be very high.

I am not supportive of government giving out taxpayer money for just any reason.
Without the right approach, governments could end up propping up firms with bad
business models just to satisfy a local political motive.

For the most part, government incentive programs should only be used to drive
economic growth or productivity and innovation efficiencies. However, in certain
circumstances, government financial support to help out a struggling company may
be justified.

There are huge social costs in Canada and provinces such as New Brunswick need
to generate economic activity to pay for these costs.

A loan guarantee that protects hundreds of jobs will potentially save millions
in tax revenue that would be lost if the company went under.

In addition, for every hundred people who lose their jobs, the taxpayer could
end up paying over a million dollars in employment insurance payments. In
certain cases, it just makes good sense.

These are difficult economic times and governments are tending to be intervening
in the private economy more than they would in better times. We will get through
this recession and hopefully get back to focusing on growing New Brunswick's
economy and addressing our structural challenges. I prefer to have government as
a partner with the business community in that effort.

David Campbell is an economic development consultant in Moncton. He writes a
daily blog, It's the Economy Stupid, at www.davidwcampbell.com.

LOAD-DATE: June 17, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               Publications Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                          November 19, 2014 Wednesday

Nevada: Nevada Rural Housing Authority, Nevada Housing Division, USDA Rural
Development Recognize Lender Partners

LENGTH: 494  words

DATELINE: Carson City


The State of Nevada has issued the following news release:

November 18, 2014

The Nevada Rural Housing Authority (NRHA), Nevada Housing Division (NHD) and the
United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development teamed up to
recognize several business partners at their Lender Appreciation luncheon, held
at The Grove, on November 18.

In honor of Nevada's 150th birthday, the Lender Appreciation Luncheon had a
sesquicentennial theme and lenders were recognized for going the extra mile to
assist their clients. Loan officers also discussed what they were thankful for
and donated items to Food for Thought during the event to assist the hungry and
malnourished children in our community.

The following honorees were recognized at the event:

USDA:


·         Frontier Award: Mann Mortgage

·         Explorer Award: Eagle Home Mortgage

·         Pinnacle Award: Guild Mortgage

NRHA Awards:


·         Rookie of the Year: Roberto Castillo, Greater Nevada Mortgage

·         Battle Born Award: Movement Mortgage

·         Triple Crown Award: Kyle Rush, Guild Mortgage

NHD Awards:

Helping Our Heroes Home Award: Guild Mortgage
    Making the Dream Possible Award: Lisa Fleck, Summit Funding
    Sesqui-Sensational Award: Academy Mortgage

NHD/NRHA Combo Award

·         You Rocked It Trophy: Jorge Montoya, Guild Mortgage

About the Nevada Rural Housing Authority
The Nevada Rural Housing Authority creates hope for the future by providing a
full range of housing and community development programs that help build and
sustain independent communities. They provide rental support, an innovative home
financing program, needs assessments and economic development to Nevada's
fifteen rural counties and the rural portions of Clark and Washoe counties, with
a coverage area including 110,000 square miles. For more information, visit
www.nvrural.org.

About USDA
USDA Rural Development is committed to helping improve the economy and quality
of life in rural America. Their financial programs support such essential public
facilities and services as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics,
emergency service facilities and electric and telephone service. USDA Rural
Development has a $181.1 billion portfolio of loans and will administer $38
billion in loans, loan guarantees and grants through their programs in the
current fiscal year. For more information, visit www.rurdev.usda.gov.

About the Nevada Housing Division

The Nevada Housing Division was created by the Nevada Legislature in 1975, when
it was recognized that a shortage of safe, decent, and sanitary housing existed
throughout the State for low- and moderate-income Nevadans. Their mission is to
improve quality of life by providing affordable housing opportunities. For more
information visit www.housing.nv.gov.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              714 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               The Frontier Star

                            January 12, 2010 Tuesday

Economic Coordination Committee increases sugar prices by Rs. 7 per kilogram

SECTION: Vol. XV No. 12

LENGTH: 610  words


The Economic Coordination Committee of the Cabinet (ECC) met under the
chairmanship of Federal Minister for Finance, Shaukat Tarin at the PM
Secretariat here on Tuesday increased the sugar prices by Rs. 7 to be sold
through USC retail outlets and its new price will be Rs.45 per kg.

According to a press release issued here, the meeting also approved the strategy
designed for ensuring regular supply of major as well as minor crops in order to
sustain food security

It further says the meeting was briefed by Ministry of Industries and Production
on progress on implementation of the National Sugar Policy 2009-10 and decided
to rationalize the price of sugar.

The main elements of the strategy approved by the committee included: Timely
announcement of support price for wheat and intervention/indicative price for
major and minor crops. Ensuring timely availability of farm inputs at affordable
prices with special emphasis on water conservation and its judicious use.
Setting area and production targets of major and minor crops in consultation
with stakeholders.Enhancing farmer's access to modern crop varieties and new
technologies and promoting adoption of good agricultural practices for
production of major and minor crops. Improving marketing systems for various
agricultural commodities. In case of shortage of essential food commodities,
their supply will be ensured by the public and private sectors through imports
and maintenance of buffer stocks.

While discussing the subject of disposal of super basmati rice 2008-09 crop, the
ECC gave approval to the measures for disposal of rice lying in PASSCO godowns:
The ECC also approved the Standardized Security Agreements for hydropower
projects under the Policy for Power Generation 2002. The ECC authorized the
Board of PPIB to approve any project specific amendment in the Standardized
Security Hydropower Agreements required during negotiations provided GOP
obligations or liabilities are not increased.

The ECC approved the recommendations of the Committee on Revival of the Risalpur
Export Processing Zone which include:i. Allowing export of the manufactured
goods from the REPZ as trading items to Afghanistan via land route. Revision of
lease rates/annual ground rent will be decided by Export Processing Zone
Authority, Board of Directors. 30% Export of manufactured goods to tariff area
will be allowed. I view of the acute financial crunch experienced by the
Pakistan Steel Mills, the ECC approved the following Bail Out Package for the
PSM to meet its requirements for working capital and implementing its business
plan: Term loan facility of Rs. 8 billion for 5 years in favour of Pakistan
Steel based on Government of Pakistan Guarantee by Consortium of Banks led by
the NBP.. Running Finance Facility of Rs.2.00 billion, renewable on yearly
basis, in favour of Pakistan Steel Mills based on Government guarantee by
Consortium of Banks led by the National Bank of Pakistan.

While considering the issue of revision of re-lending policy of foreign loans
/credits, the ECC approved that provinces may avail re-lending of the foreign
loans on the same terms and conditions on which loans are signed by the GOP. In
this regard the provinces would be allowed to issue their own bonds.

While considering the issue of passing on the German grant/soft loan to PPAF for
livelihood support and promotion of small community infrastructure project, the
ECC approved relaxation of following terms before signing the Agreement: Passing
on of Euro 14,860,399.40 grant to Project Executing Agency (PPAF) as a grant.
passing on of Euro 16,701,660.86 loan to Project Executing Agency (PPAF) as a
grant.

LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2010 The Frontier Star
                              All Rights Reserved


                              715 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                               The Frontier Star

                            January 12, 2010 Tuesday

ECC increases sugar prices by Rs. 7 per kg

SECTION: Vol. XV No. 12

LENGTH: 622  words


The Economic Coordination Committee of the Cabinet (ECC) met under the
chairmanship of Federal Minister for Finance, Shaukat Tarin at the PM
Secretariat here on Tuesday increased the sugar prices by Rs. 7 to be sold
through USC retail outlets and its new price will be Rs.45 per kg.

sustain food security

on progress on implementation of the National Sugar Policy 2009-10 and decided
to rationalize the price of sugar.

The main elements of the strategy approved by the committee included:

for major and minor crops.      Ensuring timely availability of farm inputs at
affordable prices with special emphasis on water conservation and its judicious
use.      Setting area and production targets of major and minor crops in
consultation with stakeholders.      Enhancing farmer's access to modern crop
varieties and new technologies and promoting adoption of good agricultural
practices for production of major and minor crops.        Improving marketing

i.          Allowing export of the manufactured goods from the REPZ as trading
items to Afghanistan via land route.   Revision of lease rates/annual ground
rent will be decided by Export Processing Zone Authority, Board of Directors.
30% Export of manufactured goods to tariff area will be allowed. I view of the
acute financial crunch experienced by the Pakistan Steel Mills, the ECC approved
the following Bail Out Package for the PSM to meet its requirements for working
capital and implementing its business plan:    Term loan facility of Rs. 8
billion for 5 years in favour of Pakistan Steel based on Government of Pakistan
Guarantee by Consortium of Banks led by the NBP..       Running Finance Facility
of Rs.2.00 billion, renewable on yearly basis, in favour of Pakistan Steel Mills
based on Government guarantee by Consortium of Banks led by the National Bank of
Pakistan.

While considering the issue of revision of re-lending policy of foreign loans
/credits, the ECC approved that provinces may avail re-lending of the foreign
loans on the same terms and conditions on which loans are signed by the GOP. In
this regard the provinces would be allowed to issue their own bonds.

While considering the issue of passing on the German grant/soft loan to PPAF for
livelihood support and promotion of small community infrastructure project, the
ECC approved relaxation of following terms before signing the Agreement:
Passing on of Euro 14,860,399.40 grant to Project Executing Agency (PPAF) as a
grant. passing on of Euro 16,701,660.86 loan to Project Executing Agency (PPAF)
as a grant.

                            East Anglian Daily Times

                             March 9, 2013 Saturday

Private firms receive £2.2m council loans

BYLINE: Joanne Ward

SECTION: ROP

LENGTH: 422 words


THE way that £2.2million of public money has been loaned to private businesses
will be examined by a council task group.

A report to St Edmundsbury Borough Council's overview and scrutiny committee
revealed that hundreds of thousands of pounds had been paid out to cinemas,
leisure centres and golf clubs and not yet been paid back in full.



David Nettleton, who chairs the committee, said: "We are not a bank and members
were concerned about these loans given that we were having to face cutbacks in
Government funding and a freeze on council tax. Therefore should we be lending
out money to other organisations, especially things like a cinema?"

Council documents state that the authority makes loans, which includes a level
of interest, to promote economic growth, enhance sports and leisure facilities
and promote energy efficiency or environmental improvements at council premises.


Among the loans is £150,000 to Abbeycroft Leisure, to carry out improvements at
two council-owned sports centres, repayable over five years.

A total of £120,000 was loaned to City Screen to "help the development" of the
Hatter Street cinema, including improvements to the facade, reorganisation of
the foyer and improving catering facilities.

Christ Church on Moreton Hall received £55,000 - with £30,000 being pledged in
1994 and a further £25,000 in 1998 - while developers of the Suffolk Business
Park, Churchmanor Estates Company, have received £271,393 of a £750,000 loan.

Mr Nettleton said: "As you can see from the report, these loans go back to 1994
and it's been going on for some time. And of course it doesn't fit the treasury
management criteria, which is before the council lends out money it has to have
tight guarantees of the return of the money and what to do if it doesn't come
back. We're trying to get a policy together."

Mr Nettleton said he hoped the six members of the task and finish group, of
which he is one, will meet with finance officers and the finance director in
March ahead of April's cabinet meeting.

Dave Ray, cabinet member for resources for St Edmundsbury, said there are very
few loan requests and they are all assessed to make sure they will help the
local community.

He added: "If it passes that test we want to make sure there is adequate
security for the loan and also that we get a reasonable return from it. We want
to make sure that by using the council tax payers' money in this way, not only
helping the local community but we're also getting a better return for that
money than we would have done otherwise."

                         Erie Times-News (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 25, 2014 Tuesday

Convention Center Authority seeks $3M bridge loan for new hotel

BYLINE: Kevin Flowers, Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 550 words


Feb. 25--The Erie County Convention Center Authority is seeking a $3 million
bank loan to help finance its plans for a new hotel connected to the Bayfront
Convention Center.

The authority's board of directors last week approved soliciting proposals for
what's known as bridge financing related to the project, which also includes a
parking garage.

The money will help the authority take care of "immediate needs" such as
engineering, architectural fees and other design-related costs, said Chuck
Iverson, the authority's director of finance and administration.

The bulk of the project's funding will come from a $25 million state grant and
up to $60 million in bond financing Erie County government has agreed to
guarantee.

The bond financing will be finalized later in the year.

"We'll borrow this money for the short term, and use the funds from the bond to
pay those off," Iverson said.

Iverson said the authority will publicly advertise for bridge financing
proposals later this week.

Iverson said that such bridge financing is not uncommon on projects that involve
funding from the state's Redevelopment Assistance Capital Program, as the
authority's hotel development does.

RACP is a state grant program for economic, cultural or civic improvement
projects that provides reimbursements for costs related to capital improvements.

"This is not atypical at all with an RACP grant involved," Iverson said. "There
always has to be some mechanism for you to pay for your costs before you get the
state (grant) reimbursement."

Erie County Council voted 4-2 on Feb. 11 to guarantee millions of dollars in
long-term financing debt for a new 191-room Courtyard by Marriott hotel that
will be connected to the Convention Center, 1 Sassafras Pier.

The issue sparked weeks of often-bitter community debate about public financing
for hotels.

The debt guarantee, requested by the Convention Center Authority, allows the
authority to use county government's high-grade debt rating to save nearly $20
million in interest costs on its borrowing.

The guarantee would likely only apply to about $35 million, because a $25
million state grant also is being used to help build the hotel.

County government would be at risk for repayment only if the authority defaults
on the hotel bond.

The hotel and parking garage could be open as early as 2016.

County Council signed off after the Convention Center Authority agreed to give
the county $65,000 a year, or an estimated $2 million, in exchange for the loan
guarantee over the life of the 30-year bonds needed for the project.

The Convention Center Authority sought and received a similar long-term debt
guarantee -- for $48 million -- from county government in 2005 for the 200-room
Sheraton Erie Bayfront Hotel on West Dobbins Landing, which is connected to the
Convention Center by an overhead walkway.

Casey Wells, the Convention Center Authority's executive director, has said the
authority needs an additional, connected hotel at the Convention Center to
provide more hotel rooms for conventions, conferences, large meetings and other
events.

KEVIN FLOWERS can be reached at 870-1693 or by e-mail. Follow him on Twitter at
twitter.com/ETNflowers.

___ (c)2014 the Erie Times-News (Erie, Pa.) Visit the Erie Times-News (Erie,
Pa.) at www.GoErie.com Distributed by MCT Information Services
