                              761 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            October 1, 1983 Saturday

Eximbank

BYLINE: DJ

LENGTH: 247 words

DATELINE: Washington DC


WASHINGTON  (DJ) - The board of the Export-Import Bank, meeting on the
 last day of the fiscal year, has approved the establishment of special
 export credit insurance and guarantee facilities totalling $1.5-billion
 (U.S.) for Brazil and $500-million for Mexico.

The Brazilian facility is part of an $11-billion financial package
 being put together by major governments and about 800 commercial banks to
 plug gaps in the country's balance of payments through the end of 1984.

Both facilities are available through Sept. 30, 1984, the Eximbank
 said.

Use of the facilities is contingent upon both countries remaining in
 compliance with the terms of an International Monetary Fund adjustment
 program, upon commercial banks agreeing to make available additional loans
 to Brazil and Mexico, and upon other major governments setting up similar
 facilities, roughly in proportion to their share of the total trade
 involved.

In the case of Mexico alone, use of the facility is also contingent
 upon the signing of certain bilateral and implementing agreements
 connected with that country's debt rescheduling agreement reached last
 June 22.

According to the U.S. Treasury Department, the facilities are designed
 to provide a secure source of financing for U.S. exporters and Brazilian
 and Mexican importers. In addition, the Treasury said, their magnitude
 will help restore the confidence of the international financial community,
 promoting additional commercial bank lending to the countries concerned.

LOAD-DATE: January 24, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       The Oskaloosa Independent (Kansas)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               February 14, 2013

USDA Rural Development highlights 2012 Investments to Build Stronger Rural
Kansas Communities

BYLINE: The Oskaloosa Independent staff

LENGTH: 532  words


USDA Rural Development State Director Patty Clark last week issued a report
highlighting USDA Rural Development's fiscal year 2012 investments in job
creation, businesses, infrastructure and housing for Kan-sans living in rural
communities.

In fiscal year 2012, rural communities throughout Kansas received more than $475
million in financial assistance to finance homeowner-ship, replace aging water
and sewer systems, stimulate business growth and job creation and to enhance
access to healthcare for rural residents as well as expand broadband access.

"USDA Rural Development strives to improve the quality of life for Kansans by
investing in the future of rural Kansas communities," said USDA Rural
Development State Director Patty Clark. "Financing from the federal government
provides rural residents and rural communities with the basic needs of
infrastructure, employment, healthcare and housing."

Through its Community Facilities loan and grant program, Rural Development
provided more than $26 million in financing to communities for purchasing storm
sirens, equipment for electronic medical records, patrol cars, new heating and
cooling units, as well as building and renovating hospitals, nursing homes, and
daycare centers. Ninety percent of the Community Facilities program funding was
for improving rural healthcare centers in the state.

More than 45, 000 rural Kansans in 28 communities were assisted through the
agency's Water and Environmental Program, which provides clean drinking water
and safe, sanitary wastewater disposal. The agency provided $58 million in
financing to communities for installing nearly 300 miles of water and wastewater
lines in rural Kansas, as well as making other water and wastewater system
improvements.

In 2012, Rural Development helped 1, 922 Kansas families purchase safe,
affordable homes by providing $201 million in financing. More than 100 rural
Kansans were provided loans and grants to repair or make accessibility
modifications in order to remain in their own homes.

Through Rural Development's business and cooperative loan, grant and technical
assistance programs, the agency helped 127 rural small business owners improve
their enterprises in 2012. Business and cooperative program funding created or
saved approximately 1, 000 rural Kansas jobs in 2012. Rural Development provided
nearly $35 million to assist rural businesses create ongoing economic
opportunities in rural Kansas that will pay benefits for years to come.

During 2012, Rural Development provided $107 million to eight electric
cooperatives to improve efficiency and modernize rural electric generation and
transmission systems. Nearly $30 million was invested in telecommunication
projects to help expand access to high-speed broadband in rural Kansas.

Additional information on programs available through USDA Rural Development is
available by calling 785-271-2700.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, has an active portfolio of
more than $176 billion in loans and loan guarantees. These programs are designed
to improve the economic stability of rural communities, businesses, residents,
farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in rural America.

                               February 27, 2013

                   Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation

                         1133 Twenty-First Street, N.W.
                                Washington 20036
                            United States of America

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *


COMPANY OVERVIEW

   Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation serves as a secondary market in
agricultural loans such as mortgages for agricultural real estate and rural
housing. Its secondary market offers liquidity and lending capacity to lenders;
offers mortgage loans, rural housing mortgage loans, rural utilities loans and
the guaranteed portions of agricultural and rural development loans. It
purchases loans from agricultural lenders, and sells instruments backed by those
loans. The company also purchases portfolios of newly originated and seasoned
loans, mortgage loans secured by first liens on agricultural real estate, and
fixed- and adjustable rate loans. The company is headquartered in Washington,
the US.

BUSINESS DESCRIPTION

   The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation (Farmer Mac) is a
stockholder-owned and publicly-traded company in the US. Farmer Mac was
established to create secondary market with an aim to provide agricultural real
estate, rural housing mortgage loans and to increase the accessibility of
long-term credit at stable interest rates. It principally serves America's
farmers, ranchers, rural homeowners, businesses and communities. Farmer Mac
employs 53 employees.

   Farmer Mac carries out its secondary market business activities through three
programs namely, Farmer Mac I, Farmer Mac II, and Rural Utilities Loans.

   Under the Farmer Mac I program, the company is principally engaged in buying
agricultural mortgage loans or securities backed by eligible agricultural
mortgage loans. The program serves agricultural and rural residential lenders,
including commercial banks, Farm Credit System institutions, credit unions,
insurance companies and mortgage bankers. Farmer Mac will purchase qualified
loans directly from that lender through the Cash Window, where the sellers
obtain loan credit approvals, lock-in interest rates and deliver the loans
within the rate lock period. To be eligible for the Farmer Mac I program, loans
must meet Farmer Mac's credit underwriting, collateral valuation, documentation
and other specified standards. It offers Farmer Mac Farm and Ranch loans on
monthly, semi-annual or annual payments and with the choices including variable,
adjustable, and fixed rates up to 20 years. The Farmer Mac I Farm and Ranch
products include, Adjustable Rate Mortgage (ARMs) , Variable Rate Mortgages
(VRMs), Fixed Rate Mortgages and Real Estate Revolving Line-of-Credit.

   Through the Farmer Mac II program, Farmer Mac purchases the portions of loans
guaranteed by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) and guarantees securities
backed by those USDA-guaranteed portions (Farmer Mac II Guaranteed Securities).
Under this program interested lenders sell the guaranteed portions of USDA loans
directly to Farmer Mac. Its various eligible loans include, Farm Service
Agency's Farm Ownership, Farm Operating guaranteed loans and the Rural
Development's Business & Industry and Community Facility guaranteed loans. It
offers loan products on annual, semi-annual, quarterly and monthly basis with
the choices including variable, adjustable and fixed rates. In addition, the
company offers Farmer Mac II Guaranteed Securities to lenders in swap
transactions or to other investors for cash. The loans eligible for the Farmer
Mac secondary market include: mortgage loans secured by first liens on
agricultural real estate and rural housing; certain agricultural and rural loans
guaranteed by the USDA and loans to finance electrification and
telecommunications systems in rural areas.

   Under the Rural Utilities program, Farmer Mac is engaged in purchasing
qualified rural utilities loans, or guarantees the timely payment of interest
and principal of securities representing interests in or obligations backed by
pools of such loans.

   The company undertakes ABA/Farmer Mac Alliance program through this program
ABA members have a streamlined approval process for becoming a Farmer Mac
"Seller" and preferred pricing for selected Farmer Mac products. This includes
programs such as Whole Loan Purchase Program, USDA Guarantee Purchase Program.

   Farmer Mac Farm and Ranch ICBA Rates is also one of the programs undertaken
by the Farmer Mac under which they provide farm and ranch loan products.

   The company also provides loan documentation services.

   Recently, Farmer Mac entered into an agreement with Morgan Keegan & Company
under which Morgan Keegan will begin marketing Farmer Mac programs designed
specifically for Morgan Keegan's commercial banking clients that hold
agricultural mortgage loans in their portfolios.

                              765 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                    The Record (Kitchener-Waterloo, Ontario)

                           February 22, 2007 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Forestry sector must leave paper to survive: Ramsay

BYLINE: Canadian Press

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C9

LENGTH: 579  words

DATELINE: TORONTO


Natural Resources Minister David Ramsay has a novel idea to try to revive
Ontario's struggling forestry industry: start getting out of the papermaking
business.

The industry faces a perfect storm of problems -- weak order numbers, high
production and energy costs -- and the world is entering an electronic age in
which paper won't be as sought after as it is today, Ramsay said yesterday.

"There's less demand for paper products -- starting with newsprint, and even
some of the business papers as people record their data more electronically --
and so that means the industry is going to have to adapt,'' he said.

One promising product is a resin made partly from wood waste, which can be used
for production in the auto industry, and is already in the works, Ramsay said.

"That product will be sold to a major parts manufacturer, and that parts
manufacturer will create a component for North American automobiles out of that
material,'' Ramsay said. "So that will be the beginning of what we see, a
transition of forestry moving toward a little more of a chemical-based
industry.''

Ramsay's comments came one day after Abitibi-Consolidated Inc. (TSX:A) announced
the closure of a paper mill in Thunder Bay, Ont., which will result in 353 lost
jobs.

It was another one of dozens of mill closures that have hit the province over
the last few years and after laying off more than 5,000 workers, the industry is
still showing no signs of recovery.

Even the province's $1-billion forest prosperity program, which gives incentives
to the private sector for investment, hasn't been enough to prop up the
multi-billion dollar industry, which employs around 80,000 workers, Ramsay said.

But a spokesperson for the Energy and Paperworkers Union of Canada said the aid
package hasn't been helpful to the industry and while Ramsay has a point about
innovation, the government needs to do more.

"There is some validity in (Ramsay's comments), but that's not the automatic
solution,'' said spokesperson Cecil Makowski.

"(The government's aid package) is an exercise in public relations, really.
One-third of that billion dollars is in loan guarantees -- loan guarantees to an
industry that can't pay its debts now. That's like saying once you get your Visa
maxed out, here's a MasterCard.''

The rest of the funding isn't enough to divvy up between all the businesses that
are in trouble in Ontario, Makowski said.

"You have scores of forest-products facilities that are being impacted. This
isn't a situation where you have one or two or three major manufacturing
facilities like in the auto industry, there's 40-plus communities in northern
Ontario that are reliant on forestry mills.''

Forestry companies are adding -- not cutting -- investments in other provinces
and U.S. states and it's Ontario's policies that are killing business here, said
New Democrat Leader Howard Hampton, who has asked that the legislature be
recalled to address the sector's woes.

"It's not as if this is a dying industry; these companies are making hundreds of
millions of dollars of investments in some places,'' Hampton said.

The province also needs to reduce energy costs for lumber mills in northern
Ontario, he added.

"These mills are surrounded by hydro dams that are generating electricity for a
cost of one to 1.5 cents a kilowatt hour, so . . . the mills and operations in
our part of the province should have an industrial hydro rate that reflects that
fact, not (the current) six or seven cents a kilowatt hour.''

                    The Daily Globe (Worthington, Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 10, 2012 Tuesday

Council may offer loan for hotel

BYLINE: Ryan McGaughey, The Daily Globe, Worthington, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 928 words


July 10--WORTHINGTON -- A bridge loan that would keep construction of a hotel
adjacent to the long-planned Events Center moving forward will be further
considered by the Worthington City Council following its Monday meeting.

A public hearing on the potential offering of a bridge loan of up to $400,000 --
at an interest rate of 7 percent over three years -- will take place during the
council's July 23 meeting. The public meeting on the matter is required by the
state's business subsidy laws.

Council members discussed the possibility for a loan for approximately 20
minutes with Lighthouse Hospitality Group President Don Klain.

Lexington Hotel Development, which plans to construct a 75-room Comfort Suites
Hotel next to the Events Center, is a Lighthouse division.

Brad Chapulis, the city's director of community/economic development, framed the
discussions by telling council members that Lexington is aiming to sell 28
investment shares at $50,000 each -- for a total of $1.4 million -- to reach a
total equity of $2,379,177 required to obtain permanent financing for the hotel.

Sales of the shares began in April, but Chapulis said the company hasn't been as
successful as it had hoped.

"The company has sold 13 shares and nine are in the works ... for a total equity
sold or to be sold of $1.1 million," Chapilis said. "The company is asking for
up to $400,000 in shortfall through the purchase of shares or a bridge loan ...
to avoid a delay in the project."

Since city staff highly recommended the share-purchasing option not be
considered, discussion quickly shifted to a bridge loan and how it might be set
up.

A bridge loan, Chapulis explained in a department memo to council members,
"would be required to be deferred and subordinate lien position in order for the
loan to be considered equity by the lead lenders. Though deferred, the loan
would bear interest for the term of the loan. ... The loan would allow Lexington
to continue to sell the remaining shares without delaying the start of the
project. The monies collected from sold shares would be pledged to pay off the
city loan."

Lexington would be required to make a balloon payment for the balance of the
loan at the end of the loan term. As the loan would be in a subordinate position
to the primary lenders on the real estate, personal guarantees from all the
principal owners of Lexington are necessary.

The company had originally suggested loan terms of 6 percent interest over five
years, but Klain quickly showed a willingness to be flexible.

"Our intention is to get these shares sold as soon as possible," he said in
response to a question from Councilman Mike Kuhle as to the certainty of the
city's bridge loan being paid back.

"Money may not even change hands," Councilman Mike Woll added. "This is just a
guarantee."

Klain said the sales of the hotel shares had been gaining momentum recently and
expressed confidence they would be completed within the next several months. He
added the sales of the shares locally had originally been slow, but have
improved.

"From an outsider's standpoint, if there's not local participation, the question
comes in their mind, 'Why would I invest in Worthington, Minnesota, if people in
Worthington don't want to?'" he said.

Each of the council members expressed a desire to keep the hotel project moving
forward, though Kuhle did express one other concern about the city's offering
the bridge loan.

"I just wonder if we're starting to step over the line when we're starting to
get into competition with other hotels in town," Kuhle said. "I'm struggling
with that one."

Councilman Ron Wood forecast that completion of the hotel next to the Events
Center would translate into greater occupancy rates for motels and hotels
throughout the city.

"It's just an industry pattern you would see out there," he said.

In other business, the council:

--Approved an agreement with Hoisington, Koegler Group Inc. (HKGI), Minneapolis,
to develop a detailed evaluation of existing recreation and athletic facilities
and, among other duties, prepare a draft of a Recreation Facility Master Plan.
The final negotiated cost for the services to be provided is $35,000.

--Approved the final plat for Central Square Addition, which is proposed to be a
two-lot planned unit development on approximately 2.4 acres on the former site
of Central Elementary.

--Approved an agreement with the International Union of Operating Engineers
(IUOE) Local #49 for the years 2012-2014. Negotiations included a mediation
session on May 25.

--Authorized the execution of a Safe and Sober Agreement that allows Worthington
Director of Public Safety Mike Cumiskey to execute an agreement with the
Minnesota Institute of Public Health that awards the Worthington Police
Department up to $1,920 through an Alcohol Compliance Check grant.

--Approved a resolution authorizing Worthington's membership in a Joint Powers
Agreement that would involve the city in a partnership for shared logging of
radio transmissions with Nobles, Lyon, Murray, Pipestone, Redwood and Yellow
Medicine County.

"It is in our best interest to be a member on the Southwest Minnesota Regional
Public Safety Board," Cumiskey wrote in a department memo. "This will allow us
to have some control in our regional communication logging interests. No one
knows our interest/needs better than us; having representation at this level may
prove advantageous in future regional cost-sharing endeavors."

___ (c)2012 The Daily Globe (Worthington, Minn.) Visit The Daily Globe
(Worthington, Minn.) at www.dglobe.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY INFORMATION * * * * * * * * * *
LEGAL STATUS: Equity Issue

EMPLOYEES: 138

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   Echelon International Corporation (Echelon) is a real estate company that
develops, owns, and manages commercial and multi-family residential real estate
(the Real Estate Business). The Real Estate Business includes two segments:
Commercial Real Estate and Multi-Family Residential Real Estate. The Company
also owns and manages a portfolio of financial assets consisting primarily of
leased aircraft and other assets and collateralized financings of commercial
real estate and aircraft (the Leasing and Lending Business). The Leasing and
Lending Business comprises the majority of the Company's third segment,
Investments in Financial Assets. Echelon is withdrawing from the aircraft and
real estate lending business to focus on its core real estate operations. The
Company had revenues of $40.6 million in 1998 compared to $44.2 million in 1997.


   The Real Estate Business

   Echelon owns and manages a portfolio of commercial and multi-family
residential real estate and has additional commercial and multi-family
residential properties under construction or development. Currently, the
majority of the income-producing properties are located in the Tampa Bay area of
Florida. The Company also has offices in Dallas, Texas and Orlando, Florida,
both of which focus on the development and management of multi-family
residential communities in the southeast and southwest United States.

   The Company's owned assets include commercial and multi-family residential
real estate properties. These properties consist of eight operating office
buildings, two operating parking garages, one office building currently under
construction, five industrial and other properties, one income-producing
multi-family residential community, seven multi-family residential communities
currently under development or construction,and seven additional multi-family
residential communities in the Company's pipeline.

   The Leasing and Lending Business

   Echelon is continuing to withdraw from the real estate lending business and
has made no new loans since 1993. The Company does not anticipate originating
any new loans except to facilitate the sale of an existing asset. Echelon's
remaining commercial real estate loan portfolio is secured by properties located
in the western United States. The aggregate loan balance, as of December 31,
1998, was $38.8 million. The final maturities of the loans comprising Echelon's
real estate loan portfolio range from 1999 to 2001.

   At December 31, 1998, Echelon's largest outstanding loan is $23.5 million to
the Marquardt Company (Marquardt). Marquardt is owned by Ferranti PLC, which is
operating under receivership in the United Kingdom. The loan is secured by a
52-acre industrial complex located in California adjacent to the Van Nuys
Airport.Situated on the property are several industrial buildings on short-term
leases of less than one year and several buildings totaling 173,764 square feet
on 16 acres of land leased to Kaiser Marquardt for the manufacturing and testing
of aerospace engines. In addition, Echelon has been assigned Marquardt's lease
with Kaiser Marquardt. Echelon estimates that the potential fair market value of
the industrial complex exceeds the outstanding loan balance.

   Echelon has three loans totaling $15.3 million as of December 31, 1998 to the
two Vine Street partnerships. Each individual loan is secured by an office
building located in the State of Washington. The buildings securing such loans
range in size from 43,000 to 76,000 square feet. The loans are split between two
Vine Street partnerships: Vine Street Investors (VSI) and Vine Street Associates
(VSA). Each partnership guarantees the other partnership's loans. VSI is the
borrower of the Capitol View I and II loans,while VSA provides the guarantees.
VSA is the borrower of the Town Square VI loan, while VSI provides the
guarantee. The guarantees are secured with second liens and assignment of leases
on the other partnership's security. All three buildings are leased to the State
of Washington.

   In addition, Echelon owns and manages a portfolio of leveraged, direct
finance and operating leases of aircraft and other equipment and one
collateralized loan secured by aircraft. As of December 31, 1998, Echelon's
portfolio includes two direct finance leases. The first lease was obtained
through the July 31, 1998 dissolution of the Progress Potomac Capital Ventures
joint venture between Echelon and Potomac Capital Corporation and is for a 1973
DC10-30 leased to Continental Airlines, Inc. (Continental).

   The second direct finance lease is for a 1984 B737-300 leased to Southwest
Airlines Company (Southwest) which was originally scheduled to mature in June
2004. In November 1998,Echelon executed an extension on the direct finance
lease, which extends the maturity of the lease through June 2008 and adjusts the
monthly rental payments, beginning in June 2004. Subsequently, the lease was
utilized as collateral for a $13 million loan maturing in June 2008. Echelon has
one operating lease for a 1981 B727-200 ADV aircraft on lease to Air Micronesia,
Inc. (a subsidiary of Continental), which had an original lease expiration of
December 31, 1998. The maturity of the lease was extended to October 31, 2000.

   Echelon has withdrawn from the aircraft lending business and has one
remaining aircraft loan, which matures December 31, 1999. The aircraft loan is
to American Finance Group with an outstanding balance at December 31, 1998 of
$.2 million %. The loan is secured by three 1978-79 B737-2H4 aircraft which are
leased to Southwest until December 1999.

* * * * * * * * * * EVENTS * * * * * * * * * *


Piedmont Electric Announces Community Solar Program

   Apr 01, 2016

   Piedmont Electric Membership Corporation, a not-for-profit electric
cooperative headquartered in Hillsborough recently announced a new Community
Solar program as part of a continued commitment to renewable energy. This
program provides a lower cost, and lower risk, way for Piedmont Electric members
to get involved in solar power. In fact, community solar programs are one of the
few ways that renters can invest in solar panels.The challenge with traditional,
home mounted solar panels is that they can be expensive to install and it can
potentially take years to see a return on investment in the form of lower power
bills. Community solar projects remove this risk by allowing members to
subscribe to the output of solar panels from a solar farm owned and operated by
a separate provider, in this case Piedmont Electric. The energy generated by
these solar panels goes directly to the grid, while the member who subscribes to
the panels sees all solar generation as a solar energy credit on their monthly
power bill.Piedmont Electric recently constructed solar fields at their Roxboro
and Caswell County offices. The fields have more than 1,800 panels which can
generate up to 3,000 kilowatt hours of electricity each day, enough to power 70
average American homes. Participants in the Community Solar program must be
current Piedmont Electric members. Each member will be allowed to subscribe to
up to 15 solar panels for $2.50 per month, per panel.


Solar projects in Roxboro and Caswell: Piedmont Electric Membership Corporation

   Jan 15, 2016

   At Piedmont Electric, solar power can be responsibly incorporated as an
energy source. That's why the company constructed a solar farm to benefit
cooperative members and community. In December, construction of two solar fields
was completed at Roxboro and Caswell offices. Hannah Solar out of Atlanta,
Georgia helped with the installation of the solar photovoltaic (PV) panels.
Altogether, these solar fields will produce 500kW of power at a competitive
cost.


Planned Outage at Baynes Substation

   Feb 02, 2015

   Piedmont Electric will be having a planned outage at Baynes Substation this
Wednesday, February 4, 2015, at 2:00 PM. This outage will impact those in
Caswell County; in and around Hwy 86 and Hwy 49 areas. The outage should be
around 5 minutes barring no unforeseen incidents. We apologize for any
inconvenience this maintenance outage causes you. Thank you for your
understanding while your electric cooperative performs this necessary substation
work.


USDA Reaches Goal To Fund $250m In Smart Grid Improvements

   Sep 07, 2012

   The U.S. Development of Agriculture (USDA) reached its $250m goal to finance
smart grid technologies to help modernize nation's electric system. USDA also
announced nine rural electric cooperatives and utilities in 10 states including
North Carolina will receive loan guarantees to make improvements to generation
and transmission facilities and implement smart grid technologies.With the
announcement of more than $27m in smart grid investments, USDA has met President
Obama's goal and has further enabled rural utilities to make efficiency
improvements to the electric grid that will help consumers lower their electric
bills by reducing energy use in homes and businesses.Tom Vilsack, secretary at
USDA, said, Grid modernization and deployment of 'smart grid' technology will
increase the reliability and efficiency of electric power generation. Providing
reliable, affordable electrical service contributes to stronger rural economies
and is the backbone for a prosperous rural America. These loans will help ensure
that rural areas can retain existing businesses, support new ones and have
reliable, up-to-date infrastructure. The administration has outlined a framework
for a modernized electric system that will benefit all Americans. This framework
lays out a number of public and private initiatives, including a goal of $250m
in loans for smart-grid technology deployment as part of the USDA's Rural
Utility Service, which is focused on upgrading the electric grid in rural
America. This $250m investment in loan funds for smart grid technologies means
infrastructure investment at virtually no cost to the taxpayer. These
technologies will facilitate the integration of renewable sources of electricity
into the grid, help avoid blackouts and restore power quicker when outages
occur, and reduce the need for new power plants. North Carolina's Piedmont
Electric Membership Corporation received a $30m guaranteed loan from USDA to
extend its system by 52 miles and help provide service to about 1,000 new member
consumers. The cooperative will also increase capacity for 100 current consumers
and improve the reliability of about 40 miles of line. The cooperative installed
a new automated meter system (AMI) with funds from a previous loan and will
invest approximately $150,000 of the funds from this new loan on new AMI meters
for the 1,000 new member consumers. USDA also announced that two other
cooperatives in North Carolina will receive loan guarantees. Brunswick Electric
Membership Corporation will receive a $21.5m loan to build and improve 220 miles
of distribution line and make other system improvements. Edgecombe-Martin County
Electric Membership Corporation will receive a $6.4m loan. The firm will use
about $1m of the loan to install automatic meters (AMIs). The following is a
list of rural utilities that will receive USDA funding, which is contingent upon
the recipient meeting the terms of the loan agreement. Tri-State Generation and
Transmission Association, Inc. will receive $140.5m loan to build 50 miles of
transmission line and make upgrades to the existing generation and transmission
facilities in Colorado, Nebraska, New Mexico and Wyoming. The loan amount
includes $21.8m in smart grid projects and $808,780 in environmental
improvements. The Ark Valley Electric Cooperative Association, Inc. will receive
$6.13m loan to build and improve 355 miles of distribution line and make other
system improvements in Kansa. The loan amount includes $2.01m in smart grid
projects. Stearns Cooperative Electric Association will receive $23.6m loan to
improve 147 miles of distribution line and make other system improvements in
Minnesota. The loan amount includes $974,085 in smart grid projects. Agralite
Electric Cooperative will receive $5.2m loan to build and improve 61 miles of
distribution line and make other system improvements in Minnesota. The loan
amount includes $180,968 in smart grid projects. Northeast Missouri Electric
Power Cooperative will receive $30.1m loan to build and improve 24 miles of
transmission line, build three new substations and make other improvements in
Missouri and Iowa. The loan amount includes $500,000 in smart grid projects.
Edgecombe-Martin County Electric Membership Corporation will receive $6.4m loan
to build and improve 310 miles of distribution line and two miles of
transmission line and make other system improvements in North Carolina. The loan
amount includes $1.1m in smart grid projects. Piedmont Electric Membership
Corporation will receive $30m loan to build and improve 108 miles of
distribution line and five miles of transmission line and make other system
improvements in North Carolina. Brunswick Electric Membership Corporation will
receive $21.5m loan to build and improve 220 miles of distribution line and make
other system improvements in North Carolina. Chippewa Valley Electric
Cooperative will receive $6m loan to build and improve 88 miles of distribution
line and make other system improvements in Wisconsin. The loan amount includes
$255,833 in smart grid projects. The $269m in loan guarantees announced are
provided by USDA Rural Development's Rural Utilities Service (RUS). The funding
helps electric utilities upgrade, expand, maintain and replace rural America's
electric infrastructure. USDA Rural Development also funds energy conservation
and renewable energy projects. USDA, through its rural development mission area,
administers and manages housing, business and community infrastructure programs
through a national network of state and local offices. Rural Development has an
active portfolio of more than $172 billion in loans and loan guarantees. These
programs are designed to improve the economic stability of rural communities,
businesses, residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in
rural America.


Carolina Solar Energy Partners Piedmont Electric To Construct 240kW Timberlake
Solar Farm In North Carolina, US

   Jun 12, 2012

   Carolina Solar Energy, LLC partnered with Piedmont Electric Membership
Cooperative (Piedmont Electric) to design, finance, construct, permit and
commission a 240kW dc PV generator to be located on three acres of land in
Timberlake North Carolina, US. The solar farm will sell bundled energy, capacity
and renewable energy certificates to the Piedmont Electric's distribution grid
under a 10 year power purchase agreement.The system is a fixed tilt ground mount
design will use 1008 Schuco and Yingli 240 W polycrystalline modules and
generate approximately 360,000kWh the first year. The estimated annual power
production will be equivalent to the annual energy needed to power 33 average US
homes and will offset approximately 240 metric tons of CO2 released by current
fossil fuel plants.The Timberlake solar farm is expected to be completed and
commissioned in August 2012.


Piedmont EMC Selects Hunt Technologies To Provide TS2 AMI System

   Aug 14, 2006

   Piedmont Electric Membership Corporation (Piedmont EMC) selected Hunt
Technologies to provide a two-way advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) system
for its entire service territory.Piedmont EMC plans to deploy Hunt
Technologies's TS2 AMI system to 30,000 meters over the next three years. The
utility's service territory covers parts of six counties and includes a mix of
rural, suburban and urban areas. TS2 utilizes a power line carrier-based
technology to maintain continuous two-way communication with each meter. In
addition to reporting daily power usage, TS2 provides advanced functionality,
such as remote programmable time-based rate structures, outage detection, load
control and remote service disconnect.Jared Goodnite, system engineer at
Piedmont EMC, said, We like the way the system integrates into our existing
operation. The technology is continuously communicating with each meter, so
outage detection doesn't require someone polling the system, and the system
interfaces with our outage management software. Piedmont EMC plans to retrofit
the majority of its existing meter stock with TS2 modules. The utility also
opted to use Hunt Technologies's managed services package for data hosting. This
will allow the utility to access meter data anytime, anywhere there is an
internet connection, without having to manage software upgrades, licensing or
servers.

                     The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)

                             May 20, 2010 Thursday

Loans available to boost city

BYLINE: By STEVE SNYDER Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; News

LENGTH: 337 words


A second volley has been fired by the Lebanon Valley Economic Development Corp.
in an attempt to help revitalize the city of Lebanon.

LVEDC President Charles Blankenship announced Tuesday that the Lebanon Urban
Revitalization Enterprise loan guarantee program will begin accepting applicants
next week. Applications can be made through the website www.lvedc.org next week.

"We will guarantee 25 percent of a bank loan," Blankenship said. "You can use
the money for acquisition of deteriorated or unsafe business properties in the
city."

Other uses covered by the program include new construction, renovation of
existing buildings and demolition.

The minimum loan amount is $50,000.

"We have $500,000 committed," Blankenship said, with another $200,000
anticipated over the next two years.

"That $700,000 should leverage at least $2.8 million," Blankenship said.

Combined with $2.5 million in federal Recovery Zone bonds now available after
county commissioners declared the city a Recovery Zone last week, "There is now
$5.3 million available for investment in the city to help the city reach
economic sustainability," Blankenship said. "That money was not there at the
start of the summit."

In late March, LVEDC sponsored a summit for city and community leaders to
brainstorm ways to produce $1 million in revenue for the city within two years.

"We have to work quickly," Blankenship said. "There's not a lot of time."

Blankenship will be distributing information about LURE to area banks this week.

The city has access to $1.5 million in low-interest Facility Bonds that will be
available to private developers and $1 million in low-interest municipal
Redevelopment Bonds, Blankenship told the commissioners last week. Financing for
the bonds must be arranged by Jan. 1.

Mayor Sherry Capello said she hopes the bonds will be used for a large downtown
project or a construction project along Schneider Drive's business park.

For more information about the LURE program, call LVEDC at 274-3180.

stevesnyder@ldnews.com; 272-5611, ext. 152

                              771 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                             The New Times (Kigali)

                                August 25, 2014

BDF Takes Services to Rural Areas

BYLINE: Kenneth Agutamba

LENGTH: 907 words


A call that started at the 2012 national dialogue (Umushyikirano) is finally
yielding results with Business Development Fund (BDF) set to have a branch in
all districts across the country.

In 2012, a participant attending the annual National Dialogue raised a concern
that BDF was too centralised that it lacked a presence in the countryside,
making it hard for rural folks to access its services.

The call was taken up by the National Leaders' Retreat, last year, during which
officials agreed that the country's only guarantee fund should be decentralised.

"We have seven branches already in operation in seven districts," Innocent
Burindi, the BRD chief executive, said.

In an understanding between BDF and Rwanda Development Board (RDB), the Fund
would take over the 30 Business Development Centres (BDCs) located at the
district level.

The pilot phase, aimed at testing how the new decentralised system would work,
was done with BDCs located in the Western Province districts of Ngororero,
Nyabihu, Rubavu, Rutsiro, Karongi, Nyamasheke and Rusizi.

"Now we expect to open 10 more to make 17, the total number of our district
branches, by the end of the year," Burindi said.

The 10 districts set to have BDF branches include Kayonza, Gatsibo, Rulindo,
Nyanza, Rwamagana, Ngoma, Nyagatare, Gicumbi, Huye and Nyamagabe.

BDF pledged to use the facilities to enable rural people access financial
services, extend business development services and help at least 7,000 small
entrepreneurs to obtain credit by the end of June 2015.

BDC facelift

BDCs were formed in 2011 on a public-private partnership (PPP) model in which
government, represented by RDB, retained ownership of the centres' assets but
with the private operators assuming responsibility for operational costs.

Before the takeover, the centres were being managed by four private operators
whose management contracts have since expired, Burindi said.

With the management overhaul involved, BDF will be hiring to fill up the 30
district branches. The Fund's chief executive told The New Times that they need
at least 120 people to fill up various positions, including that of station
managers and coordinators.

BDCs taught people how to start and grow businesses with ethical values as well
as learn basic ICT skills such as opening e-mail accounts and using the Internet
to access market information.

BDF will take over that role and introduce more services such as equipping
aspiring entrepreneurs with business development skills like planning and
budgeting but at a cost that will vary from district to district.

"This is aimed at reducing bad business cases that have been going to banks
ending up being rejected," Burindi said.

The idea is that with well developed business proposals, BDF can help introduce
clients to partnering banks with less chances of rejection.

Each district branch will be run by a team of four persons.

Broad menu

BDF also revealed that it will be broadening its services to offer Rwandans an
array of products in a bid to ease and increase financial access for SMEs.

The guarantee fund has been divided into four categories, such as the
agriculture guarantee fund targeting productive projects in the agricultural
value chain, SME guarantee fund aiming at guaranteeing loans issued by
participating financial institutions, and women guarantee fund aimed at
promoting women and retrenched civil servants' guarantee fund.

The New Times understands that at least 2,006 loans have been guaranteed for up
to 75 per cent as of June 2014, worth Rwf23 billion, and helping stimulate bank
loans worth Rwf60 billion.

The maximum amount guaranteed by BDF is limited to Rwf500 million per SME
guaranteed for up to 10 years.

BDF has added more products, including a grants fund, Sacco refinancing and a
quasi equity fund.

The $10 million grant is called the Second Rural Investment Facility (RIF2)
availed by the Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources.

Officials say it's aimed at providing incentives for both financial institutions
and for entrepreneurs to make productive investments in agriculture.

About 3,111 entrepreneurs have received grants worth Rwf1.4 billion as of June
2014. Grant beneficiaries receive a certain portion of an investment loan taken
to fund projects that represent investments along the agricultural value chain.

According to Trade and Industry minister Francois Kanimba, Saccos have a
liquidity problem which is mainly caused by the nature of their deposits.

Depositors save money only to withdraw shortly, affecting operations.

"So our refinancing product is basically to address that problem by ensuring
that Saccos, which are the closest to most citizens, stay with liquid," says
Burindi.

Under Quasi Equity funding, BDF will be buying stakes into what they deem to be
good projects that can't find funding from banks or struggling to repay an
expensive bank loan, in which case they would help buy out the debt and give the
distressed firm relief to recover under a flexible repayment arrangement.

BDF has already invested more than Rwf436 million in at least 17 SMEs.

The cost implication of decentralising BDF is an annual budget of Rwf7.2 billion
each year for the next five years up to 2019. Burindi says government has
committed to provide the money.

Mary Nyirakadari, a member of a women's handicraft association in Ngoma
District, said she hopes to benefit from the district branches because many of
their ideas have stalled because of financial hardships.

LOAD-DATE: August 26, 2014

                          New Straits Times (Malaysia)

                           December 3, 2014 Wednesday

PUNB allocates RM300m for loans, financing

BYLINE: Cheryl Yvonne Achu

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 260 words


SHAH ALAM: Perbadanan Usahawan Nasional Bhd (PUNB) plans to disburse more than
RM300 million worth of loans and financing to Bumiputera companies and
businesses next year, compared with RM290 million this year.

Chief executive officer Datuk Dzulkifli Fadzilah said the allocation is in line
with PUNB's goals to enhance the skills of the Bumiputera entrepreneurial and
business communities by offering programming and financial assistance to enhance
Bumiputera ventures.

"This is also based on the growing number of entrepreneurs, especially among the
younger generation and we are prepared to provide loans to those who have
business projects and quality products for expansion," he said at a press
conference after the signing ceremony between PUNB and Bank Muamalat Malaysia
Bhd, here, yesterday.

Dzulkifli said as of October, 80 per cent of RM290 million had been disbursed to
the small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the retail and wholesale sectors.

The partnership pact was signed by Dzulkifli on behalf of PUNB, while Bank
Muamalat was represented by chief executive officer Datuk Mohd Redza Shah Abdul
Wahid.

The collaboration with Bank Muamalat is to support the development of
entrepreneurs, especially SMEs in the country, where it aims to establish a
Kafalah guarantee scheme.

Under the scheme, PUNB will provide financial guarantee to Bank Muamalat in
terms of advances, credit facilities and financing to established SMEs.

The strategic tie-up is in line with the government's aspiration of seeing more
credit opportunities available for SMEs.

                              773 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Pioneer (India)

                            August 28, 2010 Saturday

Role of banks crucial in development of State: CM

LENGTH: 523  words

DATELINE: Bhopal


Bhopal, Aug. 28 -- Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan on Friday described the
role of banks in the development of the State as crucial and urged them to
provide credit facilities at lower interest rates to farmers, small
entrepreneurs, artisans and those engaged in service sector. He also exhorted
them to help fillip the rural housing initiative of the State Government.

The Chief Minister further asked banks to take steps for opening a bank branch
for 1,000 population in rural areas as against the current trend of establishing
branches for 2,000 population.

Addressing the 140th meeting of State level bankers' committee, the Chief
Minister termed prosperity and development as top priorities of the State
Government and urged for farmers to be provided loans at lower interest rates to
ensure that agriculture remains a profitable proposition.

Small scale industrial units also need maximum credit facilities. Small
entrepreneurs should get loans on lower interest rates. He informed the bankers
about State Government initiative for upgrading the skills of artisans
associated with micro enterprises and in the service sector; he added and called
for banks to extend support to improve their business.

He said that the Welfare Government can play a meaningful role by ensuring
economic empowerment of these sections.

Highlighting the State Government initiative guaranteeing educational loans to
encourage higher education of talented students, he said the State Government
will stand guarantee for loans to meritorious students.

Urging banks to improve credit deposit ratio from 60 per cent and above in
predominantly tribal districts, Chouhan said that that economic empowerment of
tribal community is a must to fulfill the development agenda.

He said that nationalised and private banks should support the task of issuing
Kisan Credit Cards. He said that the beneficiary farmers of loan waivers, who
are eligible for Kisan Credit Card, should also be provided the cards.

Chouhan said that the farmers involved in nurseries are not getting benefits of
Kisan Credit Cards. In view of investment in horticulture sector and its
expansion, the farmers growing fruit bearing plants should also get these
benefits.

He said that the district level bank branches must include special facilitation
counters for small industrial units complying with the Reserve Bank of India
directives.

The Chief Minster informed that bankers that 1.5 lakh rural housing units would
be constructed under the Mukhya Mantri Gramin Awas Yojana each year and sought
cooperation of banks to provide credit facilities to the prospective
beneficiaries.

Central Bank of India CMD S Sridhar, chairing the meeting said that out of eight
districts with low C:D ratio, two districts-Alirajpur and Dindori have already
achieved the minimum prescribed C:D ratio level of 40 per cent and in the
remaining districts, necessary steps have been initiated by SLBC to improve the
position. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Pioneer. For any
query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please
contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                              774 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                        Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)

                     November 15, 2002 Friday Final Edition

Feds won't back pipeline loan: Alternatives available, Dhaliwal tells
aboriginals

SOURCE: Calgary Herald

BYLINE: Scott Haggett

SECTION: Business; Pg. D1 / FRONT

LENGTH: 678 words

Federal Natural Resources Minister Herb Dhaliwal said a native group that wants
to own a piece of the planned $3-billion Mackenzie Valley natural gas pipeline
may not need the government's financial support -- only to have the claim
disputed by a key player in the pipeline group.

Speaking to reporters from India, where he's leading a trade mission, Dhaliwal
said the government's position is not to offer the Aboriginal Pipeline Group the
$70 million in loan guarantees that it's seeking to fund its share of design
work for the line.

The minister said the group has other options that don't require government
backing.

"There are other proposals that I'm aware of," Dhaliwal said.

"The APG could fund this through buying a share once the project is completed
and, therefore, it should be easier to get private funding for it. That's one of
the options I think they may be considering, depending on whether the producers
build the pipeline themselves or whether it's built by a private company."

Nellie Cournoyea, former chair of the Aboriginal Pipeline Group and still an
executive member, said the group isn't considering any other proposals -- and
it's still counting on the government's backing for loan guarantees.

"I really don't know what the heck (Dhaliwal) is talking about," Cournoyea said
from Inuvik.

"It's very difficult when a minister shoots from the hip. We've never had a
meeting with him and he hasn't discussed these issues with us."

Cournoyea said the Aboriginal Pipeline Group isn't interested in buying into a
pipeline once it's built.

The group wants to be included in the design and construction of the line to
ensure participation -- and economic benefits -- for the communities along the
pipeline's 1,350-kilometre route from the gas fields of the Mackenzie Delta to
northern Alberta.

"It's not just about ownership, it's about true, meaningful involvement as we go
through the regulatory process," she said.

On his conference call, Dhaliwal said he recognizes the aboriginal pipeline
group will play an important role in the development of the pipeline.

However, he's still waiting for a report from Roland Priddle, a former head of
the National Energy Board, who's negotiating with the group over the loan
guarantees.

"We have appointed Mr. Priddle, who's talking to the parties and will report
back," he said. "The policy of the government of Canada is that we do not fund
pipelines, nor do we provide loan guarantees, but I will be very interested to
see what Mr. Priddle has to say."

Dhaliwal was a leading voice against subsidies for an Alaska Highway natural gas
pipeline that were included in an energy bill from the U.S. Senate. That bill
died Wednesday after the Senate and the House of Representative were unable to
agree on it.

Imperial Oil Ltd., the leader of a group of producers including Shell Canada
Ltd. ConocoPhillips and ExxonMobil Canada that are driving the pipeline
proposal, says it also wants to ensure the group has a role in the line.

"We have made it clear to Mr. Priddle and others in the federal government that
aboriginal support for the pipeline is essential if this project is to go
ahead," said Imperial spokesman Hart Searle. "We are very much interested in
seeing this issue resolved."

The group is moving to unlock gas reserves in the Mackenzie Delta that were
first discovered in the 1970s.

However, with gas prices on the rise and reserves in southern Canada declining,
the consortium believes the massive pipeline could be profitable. In fact, the
group is now considering beefing up the capacity of the line to handle as much
as 1.9 billion cubic feet (bcf) of gas a day from the 800 million cubic feet to
1.2 bcf per day initially proposed.

Searle said it was likely the line would be constructed to handle 1.2 bcf per
day but would be designed to be quickly expanded as new gas supplies are found
in the area.

"Our expectation is that there will be more gas available beyond the anchor
volumes of the four companies," he said.

haggetts@theherald.southam.ca

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2002

                                 The Bond Buyer

IRS to Audit Some Bonds With LOCs
Federal Home Loan Guarantees Queried

                           December 3, 2002, Tuesday

By Susanna Duff

DATELINE: WASHINGTON



The Internal Revenue Service plans to audit about 30 industrial revenue bond
deals that it says are double-dipping into federal benefits -- but it will give
issuers a sliver of time to come forward first, a top enforcement official said
yesterday.

The audits will be launched because the IRS believes that tax-exempt industrial
revenue bond issues that are backed by standby letters of credit provided by
Federal Home Loan Banks constitute an illegal federal guarantee. Under the tax
code, a non-housing bond issue that carries a federal guarantee cannot also
qualify for tax-exempt status. "We are pretty comfortable our position is going
to be adverse on these cases," said Mark Scott, the IRS' national director for
tax-exempt bonds.

The IRS has audited at least one transaction, he said. Most of the bond issues
in question appear to be small-issue manufacturing facilities, Scott said. The
IRS will give the issuers "a couple of months" to reach settlements with the
agency before it launches the audits.

"We'd like to get them resolved in the easiest and friendliest way possible,"
Scott said.

The 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks are federally chartered but are owned by
their members, which are mostly commercial banks and savings and loan
institutions. Some have extended their practice of providing standby letters of
credit that are used to back housing bonds to other types of economic
development bonds. All of the non-housing bonds issued by the Chicago Federal
Home Loan Banks are designed to benefit low-income community investment
developments, said a bank spokesman who refused to discuss the IRS
investigations.

The IRS based its decision to move forward with its investigation because of
several incidences in the past 18 months where the letters of credit were used
to back non-housing bonds, Scott said. When the agency learned about the
practice, it approached the National Association of Bond Lawyers because the
group earlier had asked the IRS to consult with it before launching a new class
of audits. But the association decided not to advise the IRS when it realized
this summer an issuer had requested a private letter ruling, said Bill Larsen,
NABL's director of governmental affairs. That letter was withdrawn when the
IRS's chief counsel tentatively indicated there was a problem.

In September, the IRS issued a preliminary determination that interest on a $5.3
million industrial revenue bond issue sold by the Illinois Development Finance
Authority is not exempt from federal income taxes because the deal used a
standby letter of credit from the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago. Lawyers for
the IDFA declined to comment.

In addition, the issue also has caught the eye of Congress. A bill introduced in
October by House Ways and Means Oversight subcommittee chairman Rep. Amory
Houghton Jr., R- NY, would allow future bonds backed by letters of credit for
federal home loan banks to be treated as tax-exempt bonds. The bill would not
apply retroactively to the 30 transactions pending an IRS investigation.

"We expect and hope it will be reintroduced" in the 108th Congress when it
convenes on Jan. 7, said the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago spokesman.

Scott has assigned a staffer in the IRS outreach and education office to contact
the Federal Home Loan Bank and issuers. "We are going to encourage those issuers
to come in voluntarily and resolve the problems so we don't have to open those
examinations," Scott said.

If they do not come forward, the IRS could try to recover the amount the issuer
benefited from the actual federal subsidies, Scott said.

The bond market likely will put a hold on tax-exempt bonds backed by federal
home loan banks, said Mitchell Rapaport, a tax lawyer with Nixon Peabody here.

"Until this matter gets resolved, I would expect the bond market is going to
treat these as potentially taxable," Rapaport said. "It would seem extremely
difficult for a transaction with this guarantee to go forward until this matter
is resolved."

Copyright c 2002 Thomson Media. All Rights Reserved. http://www.bondbuyer.com

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 685 words

LOAD-DATE: December 2, 2002

                                US Official News

                            February 27, 2015 Friday

New Jersey: GROWTH OF SMALL BUSINESS REMAINS TOP PRIORITY OF STATE

LENGTH: 683  words

DATELINE: Trenton


Department of Economic Development Authority, The State of New Jersey has issued
the following news release:

From a husband-and-wife-owned bed and breakfast in West Cape May to a fast
growing manufacturer in Riverdale, hundreds of small businesses across the State
took advantage of low-cost lending and recovery programs offered by the New
Jersey Economic Development Authority (EDA) in 2014.  These companies, which
benefited from a total of $92 million in financing, expect to create more than
1,170 new jobs.

"The vitality of New Jersey's small business community is intrinsically linked
to the growth of the State's economy," said Tim Lizura, EDA President and COO.
"Through our collaboration with banks and other local, state and federal
partners, the EDA has been able to increase access to capital for small
businesses that want to rebuild, maintain or expand their operations in the
State."

One of the EDA's longest-standing programs for small business is the New Jersey
Business Growth Fund, an exclusive partnership with PNC Bank. Through this
program, eligible small businesses can take advantage of PNC Bank loans of up to
$3 million with a 25 percent or 50 percent EDA guarantee. Funding can be used
for machinery and equipment or real estate. Since the program's inception in
2004, more than 350 projects have been assisted, representing approximately $170
million in loans and $50 million in EDA guarantees.  Today's Board action
extends the partnership for another year.

In 2014, Filan and Conner Plumbing utilized the program to purchase a property
in Berlin for its plumbing and bathroom remodeling business; Tony's Freehold
Grill, a family-owned railcar diner, was able to purchase its location in
downtown Freehold; and metal hose assembly manufacturer Flexline acquired a
building for its operations in Kenilworth.

In addition to the New Jersey Business Growth Fund, the EDA partners with over
40 banks to help lower the cost of borrowing for small businesses. Banks that
have been approved by the EDA for Premier Lender status benefit from faster
turnaround and reduced risk.  The streamlined process involves the EDA approving
finance applications in as early as three to five business days, the result of
which speeds the flow of capital to businesses.  The EDA can participate in up
to 50 percent of a bank loan for fixed assets (up to $2 million) or working
capital (up to $750,000); the maximum guarantee for fixed assets and working
capital is $1.5 million.

Riverdale-based EVS Metal, Inc. is a precision sheet metal fabricator and one of
the fastest growing manufacturing companies in the United States. In addition to
its metal fabrication service, EVS provides machining, finishing, engineering,
logistic and integration services. The company received a loan from JP Morgan
Chase that included an EDA participation to support its operations.

"Fueled by a commitment to service, quality and solutions, EVS Metal is proud to
be recognized for its world class manufacturing processes," said Scott
Berkowitz, President, EVS Metal.  "Our business was launched in New Jersey 20
years ago, and we're thankful for the support of the EDA as we continue to
expand and grow in the State."

Other businesses that benefited last year include Tipico Products Co., a
wholesaler utilizing a TD Bank loan that included an EDA participation to expand
to a larger facility in Lakewood; Custom Labels, Inc., a printing company that
received a loan from Two River Community Bank that included an EDA participation
to acquire a new property in Fairfield; and, Acupuncture & Chiropractic Healing
Arts, which used a Roma Bank loan that included an EDA participation to support
its continued operations in Pennington.

In addition to partnerships with commercial lenders, the EDA provides
below-market rate direct loans that can be used for fixed assets or working
capital.  Eligible businesses can apply for up to $2 million for fixed assets,
or up to $750,000 for working capital.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: February 28, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                            Aberdeen Evening Express

                            March 23, 2016 Wednesday

UK Government's £86m boost for city development

BYLINE: Peter Davidson

SECTION: NEWS; OTHER; Others; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 199 words


THE UK Government has announced an £86 million investment for a major
development in the North-east.

Lord Dunlop, the UK Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Scotland
Office, visited Aberdeen to make the announcement regarding the Countesswells
site, where Stewart Milne Homes will be the primary developers.

The development will see more than 3,000 homes built, with 750 being affordable.
There will also be two new primary schools, a secondary school, a health
facility and retail units.

Lord Dunlop said: "The UK Government is providing an £86m loan guarantee that
really unlocks £800m of commercial investment in a very exciting housing
development.

"Every time I come to the North-east I hear the same story that there is a
shortage of affordable housing and this deal absolutely addresses that key
requirement."

John Slater, group managing director at Stewart Milne Homes, said: "We are
delighted that, through HM Treasury, we have been successful in securing a
guarantee to support the delivery of Countesswells.

"It is a critical project for the city over the next 15 years, delivering much
needed homes and community facilities that in turn will compliment Aberdeen's
economic growth."

LOAD-DATE: March 23, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Investing:Stuart MacGregor, Lord Dunlop and John Slater.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                WMI Company News

                            October 19, 2012 Friday

Madison Community Hospital secures funding for new hospital in South Dakota

LENGTH: 104 words


Located near a highway bypass in Madison, the one-storey building will
accommodate 22 licensed inpatient beds, ancillary medical services, support
services and medical clinic among other amenities. The new hospital will be an
energy efficient structure that will be built to meet health care codes.

The USDA has awarded funds from under its Community Facilities Direct Loan
Program. The hospital has also secured $10 million Rural Development Guarantee
from AgStar, $1.3 million loan from Heartland Consumer Power District, $300,000
loan from Sioux Valley Energy, and $480,000 loan from Sioux Valley Energy's
Revolving Loan Fund.


LOAD-DATE: October 19, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              782 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                  Guardian.com

                             October 3, 2011 Monday

George Osborne admits key policy runs into the ground

BYLINE: Phillip Inmanguardian.co.uk

LENGTH: 621 words

ABSTRACT

The chancellor wants to ease credit to small businesses but is vague about how
to do it

FULL TEXT

George Osborne has admitted one of his key plans has run into the ground with
the announcement that he is looking into ways to get money directly to companies
through a form of credit easing.

Project Merlin, the multi-billion pound deal with the banks to spur increased
lending, especially to small and medium-sized companies, was a central plank of
government policy until today when the chancellor effectively told the Tory
party conference it was not working and he needed a Plan B.

For several months, Bank of England data has shown lending remains at rock
bottom levels and business surveys reveal a level of desperation among small
businesses for short term loans not seen since the worst of the crisis.

Osborne was vague about what the Treasury may eventually put in place, though it
was clear the Treasury and not the Bank of England would supply the funds.

He said: "I have set the Treasury to work on ways to inject money directly into
parts of the economy that need it such as small business."It is known as credit
easing. It is another form of monetary activism," he said. "It is similar to the
national loan guarantee scheme we talked about in opposition."

As far as most economists are concerned credit easing bears little resemblance
to the national loan guarantee, which is an attempt to underwrite bank loans,
with the government taking on some of the risk.

David Cameron announced it in 2008 and said it would guarantee loans for a
commercial insurance fee, passed on by the banks, that would "properly protect
the taxpayer".

The scheme would be chaired by someone appointed by the Chancellor with the
agreement of the Governor of the Bank of England.

Cameron said at the time: "This is not a new spending programme financed by more
borrowing. It is like the secured guarantees for a fee that the Bank of England
has already put in place for inter-bank lending, which we supported."

As a policy, it won few friends internationally because the pitfalls of
overriding current bank lending practices were many and fraught with serious
risks. The US central bank chief Ben Bernanke set what the economist community
believe is credit easing in 2009.

He divided them into three groups: lending to financial institutions, providing
liquidity to key credit markets, and purchasing longer-term securities.

He saw it as the job of the central bank and not the Treasury to undertake these
background activities, which "ease" conditions and do not, like a loan guarantee
scheme, involve direct loans to companies by the government.

Bernanke said, in the Fed's traditional role as lender of last resort, it should
ensure that healthy financial institutions have access to sufficient short-term
credit, particularly during times of financial stress.

These lending facilities dramatically affected both the composition and size of
the Fed's balance sheet.

It is debatable whether they greatly influenced the path of the US economy,
which has struggled with more fundamental issues such as the huge property price
bubble overhang.

It is probably true Wall Street's collection of ailing banks would probably be
bust without Bernanke's credit easing in place, but the flow through to ordinary
businesses has been lacking on main street as much as in the UK.

Credit easing, then, is a background activity that aids banks and their lending
activities. It is not a plan for direct loans to companies on the point of going
bankrupt for the lack of an affordable overdraft.

As in the US, lending is a problem, in both its available and high cost. It is
not clear the government can do much more than support its existing banks to
increase lending.

LOAD-DATE: October 3, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              785 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                               dailyrecord.co.uk

                        April 1, 2016 Friday 2:50 PM GMT

Stewart Milne Group secures £86m government guarantee for Aberdeen development;

Housebuilder said the £86m government facility secured by its Countesswells
Development Ltd subsidiary will allow the group to begin work on the proposed
3,000 home development

BYLINE: By Scott McCulloch

SECTION: BUSINESS,COMPANY RESULTS & FORECASTS

LENGTH: 523 words


Housebuilder Stewart Milne Group has secured an £86 million UK Government-backed
loan guarantee to fund first phase development of its Countesswells development
in Aberdeen.

The Aberdeen-based housebuilder said it will start work on the development in
April despite "challenging trading conditions in the North East Scotland Market"
as a result of the oil price slump.

The group notes in accounts now filed with Companies House: "In March 2016, the
Infrastructure and Projects Authority (part of HM Treasury) confirmed a UK
Guarantee to the value of £86 million enabling Stewart Milne Group to raise
funds from Lloyds Banking Group and deliver this significant project."

Adding: "The £1bn Countesswells development is a landmark project for our
business and one that we have been working to bring to market for many years.

"We are excited to announce that we will start work on the first phase of this
prestigious new community in April this year."

Stewart Milne Group secured planning consent in 2014 for a 3,000 home, 15 year
development at Countesswells, Aberdeen.

The group notes in full-year accounts, trading conditions in the North East
deteriorated since the June 2015 year-end, though other markets "continue to
show signs of growth as the general UK economy continues to improve".

The announcement on the government funding deal was included in the group's
audited accounts covering the 2015 year to June 30.

Stewart Milne Group said it recently entered into a three year funding facility
with Bank of Scotland which is due to expire on October 31, 2018.

The group adds it is "currently engaged in a collaborative and joint process to
review the repayment profile within the facility with a view to securing land
opportunities and allowing the group to meet its business growth objectives".

"It is anticipated that this process will be concluded by June 2016."

The group notes net debt at the 2015 year end stood at £201 million, up from
£193.8 million in 2014.

Stewart Milne Group reports pre-tax profits for the 2015 year rose to £4.99
million (2014: £3.01 million) and turnover rose 20 per cent to £252.6 million.

However profit figures in the 2014 year had included £1.8 million in one-off
restructuring and wind-down costs.

On a operating level, profits were down 16 per cent to £11.78 million in the
2015 year, down from £14.07 million in 2014 as gross margin dipped three per
cent to 21 per cent.

The group said it built 87 more homes in 2015 for a total of 809 units.

The group notes interest payments on loans and overdrafts were £1.6 million
lower on the prior year to £9.01 million (2014: £10.6 million).

Post year-end Stewart Milne Group also sold a number of non-core asset,
"primarily the sale of its shared equity debtors" with a total book value of
£24.6 million, which were sold for an "initial consideration of £11.3 million".

Additional payments from the asset sale may also be payable, "depending on
future redemption amounts through to 2024".

The group notes: "Current year trading remains positive in Central Scotland and
North West England and we remain optimistic about the Aberdeen market despite
some challenging conditions."

LOAD-DATE: April 1, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication

JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDAR

                            Aberdeen Evening Express

                            March 23, 2016 Wednesday

UK Government's £86m boost for city development

BYLINE: Peter Davidson

SECTION: NEWS; OTHER; Others; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 200 words


THE UK government has announced an £86 million investment for a major
development in the North-east.

Lord Dunlop, the UK Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Scotland
Office, visited Aberdeen to make the announcement regarding the Countesswells
site, where Stewart Milne Homes will be the primary developers.

The development will see more than 3,000 homes built, with 750 being affordable.
There will also be two new primary schools, a secondary school, a health
facility and retail units.

Lord Dunlop said: "The UK government is providing an £86m loan guarantee that
really unlocks £800m worth of commercial investment in a very exciting housing
development.

"Every time I come to the North-east I hear the same story that there is a
shortage of affordable housing and this deal absolutely addresses that key
requirement."

John Slater, group managing director at Stewart Milne Homes, said: "We are
delighted that, through HM Treasury, we have been successful in securing a
guarantee to support the delivery of Countesswells.

"It is a critical project for the city over the next 15 years, delivering much
needed homes and community facilities that in turn will compliment Aberdeen's
economic growth."
