                          The West Australian (Perth)

                             May 22, 2004 Saturday
                                     METRO

Don't borrow in haste

BYLINE: NATASHA GRANATH

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 736 words


Securing a home loan can cost thousands of dollars in unnecessary payments
unless you get the right information - but this might require investing a little
time and money.

State president of the Mortgage Industry Association Australia Murray Sebbes
said the best advice for homebuyers was to get as much information as possible
from experts before signing an offer.

He advises that they consult an MIAA accredited mortgage broker for an
assessment of their capacity to borrow before approaching a lender.

"Brokers are happy to sit down with you and work out a process to see what you
can afford," he said.

"Check out your eligibility for the First Home Owners Grant at the Office of
State Revenue website and importantly, get an understanding of additional costs.
There's lots of hidden costs from stamp duty to conveyancing fees, and you might
think you have a tidy deposit but those costs chip away at that."

Mr Sebbes said new products were available for parents to help their children
enter the increasingly impenetrable home loan market without putting their house
on the line.

"There are two products from St George and the Commonwealth Bank, which are
great because they limit the amount of the parents' guarantee," he said.
"Instead of putting the whole house on the line, they can guarantee only, say,
$20,000.

"The reality is that the kids could have an accident or could get retrenched,
or, as in most cases, their spending patterns get out of hand with credit cards
and so on."

For those buying a second house or an investment, the same rules applied.

"They should sit down with an MIAA broker and work out their capacity to lend
and, particularly for an investment property, they should talk with their
accountant, because there are a lot of traps and tips on the taxation side," he
said.

"Get a pre-approval so you know where you stand and you still should make your
offer subject to finance. Also, be wary of products with features you pay for
that you are not going to use."

Mr Sebbes said the retirement and downscaling sector was an emerging market and
there were many new facilities catering for the ageing population.

Mortgage Choice national corporate affairs manager Warren O'Rourke said seniors
had options in retirement thanks to products released last year.

They meant the retiree could do renovations, take an overseas holiday, upgrade a
car or help out family members financially. The Senior Access Home Loan released
by St George last year allowed seniors to access equity in their home.

"There is a whole generation in the community who have retired and no longer
have regular income to supplement their lifestyle and who never would have
thought of tapping into and accessing the equity in

their home," Mr O'Rourke said.

Sarah Curthoys, principal of Curthoys and Co Solicitors, said one of the
mistakes West Australians made was relying too heavily on settlement agents.

"Their primary job is to arrange the transfer of land and iron out fees and
taxes and for them, settlement is seen as a transaction, whereas a lawyer does
more of a due diligence on the property," Ms Curthoys said.

"This might involve going to the council to make sure improvements on the
property have been approved - the worst-case scenario is that the council issues
a demolition order."

She said it was worth investigating the property thoroughly before signing an
offer and acceptance.

"For a house, check with the council, and for a unit or apartment in a complex,
examine the strata minutes before you buy," she said.

"The law says "caveat emptor' - buyer beware - so once you've moved in and
discovered all those problems, you can't go back."

QUESTIONS TO ASK WHEN CHOOSING A LOAN

What are the monthly fees and charges?

Can I switch from a variable to a fixed rate?

How quickly can I organise to fix the interest rate of my loan?

Can I get pre-approval and how long does it take?

Can I use more than one property as security for my loan?

Is the loan portable?

Can I make extra repayments?

Can I pay out my home loan at any time?

How do I make my repayments?

Can direct debits be set up from the home loan account?

What is direct salary crediting and how do I establish it?

Can I access a redraw facility?

SHOPPING FOR A HOME LOAN ON THE NET

www.infochoice.com.au

www.housing.wa.gov/key/home.htm

www.wizard.com.au

www.mortgagechoice.com.au

www.aussiehomeloans.com.au

www.rams.com.au

www.mortgageaustralia.com.au

www.yourmortgage.com.au

www.echoice.com.au

LOAD-DATE: May 24, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Progressive Media - Company News

                           September 10, 2012 Monday

US Agriculture Department to provides $27m in loan guarantees to deploy smart
grid technologies

SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Industry Updates

LENGTH: 108 words



HIGHLIGHT: The US Agriculture Department announced $27m in loan guarantees to
nine rural electric cooperatives and utilities in 10 states to improve
generation and transmission facilities and implement smart grid technologies.


This marks the reaching the goal of investing $250m in smart grid technologies,
in the government's efforts to modernize the nation's electric system.

Commenting on the investments Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack remarked that
modernization of the grid and deployment of smart grid technologies will the
electricity systems reliability and efficiency.

"Providing reliable, affordable electrical service contributes to stronger rural
economies and is the backbone for a prosperous rural America.

"These loans will help ensure that rural areas can retain existing businesses,
support new ones and have reliable, up-to-date infrastructure," said Vilsack.

                                December 8, 2016

                              The Chiba Bank, Ltd.

                                1-2 Chiba-Minato
                                 Chiba 260-8720
                                     Japan

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

COMPANY OVERVIEW


   The Chiba Bank, Ltd (Chiba Bank) is a regional bank operating primarily in
Chiba Prefecture in Japan. The bank provides retail banking, securities,
consumer lending, leasing and various other financial products and services. It
offers a wide range of deposit products, which include current deposits, saving
deposits, ordinary deposits, time deposits and negotiable certificates of
deposits. The bank is also involved in management and collection of claims,
housing-loan guarantees, collateral appraisal services, securities and credit
card businesses. The bank operates through comprising network of branches,
sub-branches and virtual branches. The bank also operates branches in
international financial centers of New York, Hong Kong and London; and
representative offices in Shanghai and Singapore. Chiba Bank is headquartered in
Chiba-Shi, Japan.


BUSINESS DESCRIPTION:



Chiba Bank is a banking and financial solutions provider based in Japan. The
bank provides retail banking, securities, consumer lending, leasing and various
other financial products and services to individual and corporate customers. The
bank operated through 177 offices comprising 156 branches, 19 sub-branches and
two virtual branches as on March 31, 2014.

It also had 41,197 off-branch ATM locations comprising 12,915 E-net ATM
locations at convenience stores, 10,149 Lawson ATM locations at convenience
stores, and 17,866 ATM locations jointly with Seven Bank, Ltd.; and three money
exchange counters, as on March 31, 2014. Furthermore, the bank operates branches
in international financial centers of New York, Hong Kong, and London; and two
representative offices in Shanghai and Singapore.

Chiba Bank accepts various deposit products and originates various types of
loans such as corporate loans and housing loans. The various other services
offered by the bank include management and collection of claims, outsourcing of
operational business and accounting, general administration, and temporary staff
services. In addition, the bank provides housing-loan guarantees and fee
collection services; credit card and credit guarantee services; and also offers
information services and surveys, and consulting services. It also operates
three consulting plazas specializing in providing customers with proposals
involving a diverse range of financial products.

In addition to clients from mainstream sectors, Chiba Bank specifically caters
to customers in various growing business sectors such as medical and nursing
services, agriculture, tourism, environment, social infrastructure and
international business. It also participates in various activities such as The
Chibagin Marche, food exhibition and business conference and Shanghai Business
Community Seminar. The bank also holds business alliances with various renowned
international banks including Bangkok Bank PCL, Bank of Communications, PT Bank
CIMB Niaga Tbk and Standard Chartered Bank.

The bank provides products and services through its subsidiaries such as
Chibagin JCB Card Co.,Ltd., Chibagin Guarantee Co.,Ltd., Chibagin Securities
Co.,Ltd., Chibagin Leasing Co.,Ltd., Chibagin Capital Co.,Ltd., Chibagin Asset
Management Co.,Ltd., Sobu Co., Ltd. and Chibagin Research Institute,Ltd.
Chibagin Guarantee Co.,Ltd. offers housing-loan guarantees and fee collection
services. Chibagin JCB Card Co., Ltd. carries out credit card and credit
guarantee business. Chibagin Research Institute,Ltd. provides information
services and surveys, and consulting services. Chibagin Capital Co.,Ltd. focuses
on issuing of IPOs and related advisory services. Sobu Co., Ltd. is involved in
rental and maintenance of the bank's office buildings and welfare facilities and
purchase and sale of supplies and consumer goods.

                        Greensburg Daily News (Indiana)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 23, 2009 Monday

Westport Fire Moves Into New Home

BYLINE: Elizabeth Bailey, Greensburg Daily News, Ind.

SECTION: LIFESTYLE

LENGTH: 451 words


Mar. 23--After serving the people of Westport and its surrounding area for 50
years, the Westport Volunteer Fire Department dedicated its new station
Saturday.

Chief Jay Maddux explained the department had called its Mulberry Street station
its home since its incorporation in 1959. Having expanded the facility a couple
of times, he said, the newer and larger trucks showed the community the time had
come for a larger station.

The property was sold to the department at a reduced rate a couple years ago,
Maddux said. From there, the volunteer firefighters secured a loan from
MainSource Bank, guaranteed by USDA Rural Development. The town of Westport,
Maddux explained, is not well positioned for grant funding, however the
guarantee from Rural Development enabled the department to receive a good rate
on the loan. In addition, community support gives the department confidence the
loan will be repaid.

JHS Construction and Fuel began construction more than a year ago, and the
firefighters relocated about four months ago. Don Louden completed the heating
and cooling systems, the Decatur County Community Foundation approved a grant
for the department enabling the purchase of a generator, Decatur County REMC
funded equipment and Myers Paving, Inc., as well as A&B Concrete played a roll
in completing the new facility.

Maddux said the new station is better organized and offers the volunteer force
room to expand as needed. The 28-member department covers an 80.4-square-mile
area crossing the Decatur and Jennings County line, but it is the members of its
Westport community that Maddux credits with the department's success.

"Without community support, this wouldn't have been possible," he said.

The department conducted a fundraising drive with a good response. The township
trustees also enabled the project to progress. Having made 303 runs last year
and 83 already in 2009, the Westport firefighters stay busy, and the new station
will enable them to continue doing the work they do, Maddux said.

The community came out, Saturday, to show its support for the volunteer
firefighters, and the town was rewarded with hamburgers, hot dogs, chili, chips,
cake and punch. With its new station, the department hopes to continue serving
the community long into the future.

To see more of the Greensburg Daily News or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.greensburgdailynews.com/. Copyright (c) 2009, Greensburg Daily News,
Ind. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                      The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)

                      April 9, 1992, Thursday, 1* EDITION

Deficit or no, public trough's still open .

BYLINE: JUDY LINDSAY; VANSUN

SECTION: BUSINESS; JUDY LINDSAY; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 617 words


SOME $ 470 million in government loans and loan guarantees to more than 3,600
businesses. Makes you wonder about the business sector's sincerity on the
deficit issue, doesn't it?

With one hand business scoops up the bucks and with the other it shakes a finger
at government for over-spending.

The figures above don't include the "student venture loans" which saw students
buying cattle, fattening them up over summer and selling them off. Although it's
good to see young people taking such a down-to-earth approach to business, the
students are also learning to sup at the public trough.

This lesson in dependency was brought to them by the Social Credit government.

Finance Minister Glen Clark suggests the amount (a total of $ 1 billion
including student loans, mortgage assistance guarantees, and so on) is
symptomatic of the poor economy.

Maybe so. But the numbers also reveal the extent of the business community's
unhealthy dependence on government financial assistance.

Business would be sharper and more competitive if that door were closed to it.
Consider: Ten years ago the federal and some provincial governments gave $ 500
million towards the upgrading of small, old eastern Canadian pulp mills instead
of letting them die.

Today those inefficient mills are a terrible drag on the industry and are being
shut down. Had government not behaved like an indulgent parent with an infinite
bank account, the companies probably would have closed the mills and built
bigger and better ones that would be competitive today.

Of course Clark would not criticize the Socred lending activity. For one thing,
B.C. Enterprise Corporation made some of the loans, such as $ 70 million to
Fibreco to help build a pulp mill in Fort St. John. BCEC is the successor to the
B.C. Development Corp., a creation of Clark's political ancestors, the New
Democratic Party government of 1973-75.

For another, the current NDP government is itching to funnel money to industry,
as the creation of the $ 100-million B.C. Endowment Fund shows.

Although it may tidy up all the different pots of money, this government won't
get out of the loans, grants, guarantees and investment business - they are a
clutch of magic wands to a bunch of reckless fairy godmothers.

*

That strange proposal from three American senators and a congressman for a
compromise solution to the softwood lumber dispute arose more out of domestic
political needs than out of any sincere attempt to resolve the matter.

The four are all from northwest states where the forest industry worked hard to
get the federal government to restrict log exports so that the companies would
have fibre supplies and residents would continue to have jobs.

However, the Coalition for Fair Lumber Imports, the largely southeast-based
lobby group trying to get a countervail duty applied to Canadian lumber, has put
that restriction at risk by attacking a similar restriction in B.C.

The four, who had been very cosy with the coalition, obviously were made to see
that the northwest's interests and those of the coalition were not one and the
same. The fact that three of the four politicians are going to the voters this
fall may have been a factor.

A few weeks ago, in an effort to mollify the northwest's anxiety, the coalition
issued a press release arguing at length on why the U.S. log export restrictions
were different from the B.C. restrictions and therefore safe.

Apparently the folks in the northwest were not convinced. So the senators and
congressman proposed something Canada couldn't take seriously but which served
to put some distance between them and the coalition. It was for domestic
consumption only.


LOAD-DATE: April 9, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)

                       March 8, 2002 Friday Final Edition

Canada needs to bribe automakers: CAW: It's the only way to attract new assembly
work in post-auto-pact era, union chief says

SOURCE: CP

BYLINE: STEVE ERWIN

SECTION: Business; Pg. C3

LENGTH: 560 words

DATELINE: TORONTO

Canada will have to "bribe" automakers to attract new assembly work in the
post-auto-pact era, says the head of the country's largest private-sector union.

Without a replacement for the defunct Canada-U.S. auto pact - which until last
year required North American automakers to build as many cars in Canada as they
sold to avoid stiff import duties - governments must put up loan guarantees or
grants to compete for new investment with American states, Canadian Auto Workers
president Buzz Hargrove said.

"Once you give up on the auto pact, and those kinds of rules are no longer
necessary and we just rely on the good will of corporations, you've only got one
thing left - and that's to bribe them," Hargrove said yesterday at a Canadian
Urban Institute debate in Toronto.

"This is a game the companies play, whether we like it or not."

Hargrove said plants are being constructed for Honda in Alabama and Nissan in
Mississippi because those states offered hundreds of millions of dollars in
loans and grants. Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi and Ohio are in a bidding war
for a new Hyundai factory.

In exchange for the funds, the automakers commit to keeping the factories
running for a decade or more, Hargrove said.

"The investment is an initial investment that's paid back 10 times over in terms
of the community and taxes and services," Hargrove said after his debate on the
auto industry's future with analyst Dennis DesRosiers.

"In some cases, it's justifiable and a good investment if you've got long-term
job commitments."

Hargrove recently lobbied Ottawa to help finance the design and building of a
new van for a DaimlerChrysler plant in Windsor, Ont., which he said could cost
the automaker about $430 million.

Yesterday, he suggested the Ontario government could offer $200 million in loan
guarantees to bring the new vehicle to the Pillette plant, where commercial van
production is scheduled to cease next year.

Hargrove's comments come as the CAW's membership at Canadian assembly plants is
dwindling. General Motors's Sainte-Therese facility is slated to close this fall
and a Ford truck plant in Oakville, Ont., is to close by 2004.

DesRosiers said those cuts are colouring the view of the union, whose membership
at assembly plants is falling while the total non-union workforce for Toyota and
Honda plants in Ontario has swelled to 8,000 and stands to increase in coming
years.

"Toyota alone could offset all other production losses," DesRosiers said.

Hargrove countered that Toyota and Honda lack significant parts operations in
Canada and Mitsubishi's plans to open a national network of dealerships without
any manufacturing here demonstrates a weak commitment to the Canadian economy by
overseas-based manufacturers.

"If we're buying cars that are built in Japan or South Korea, we're taking jobs
out of this country," he said.

DesRosiers said Hargrove is stuck in decades-old thinking that emphasizes
assembly-line work when Canada should instead be looking to be a leader in
emerging auto technologies, such as cleaner engines, research and development.

"We need a 2020 vision, not a 1965 vision," DesRosiers said. "In the past, we
said we wanted these GM, Ford and Chrysler jobs and we wanted these assembly
jobs and we wanted these stamping jobs. Maybe that isn't where we want to be."

LOAD-DATE: March 8, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                US Official News

                            August 11, 2016 Thursday

Washington: Heitkamp Announces Federal Funding to Expand Health Care Services in
Rugby

LENGTH: 209  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the Senator Heidi Heitkamp has issued the following news
release:



 U.S. Senator Heidi Heitkamp, Ranking Member of the Senate Subcommittee on Rural
Development and Energy, announced $112,000 in federal funding for the Heart of
America Medical Center in Rugby to renovate existing space within the hospital
into a cancer care center.





 "Quality cancer care is critical in every region of North Dakota," said
Heitkamp. "By improving and growing rural hospitals across our state, we can
help provide excellent care folks in remote communities count on when they need
it most. Today's federal support for the expansion of cancer care treatment
facilities in Rugby will help boost access to critical health services families
in the region can depend on for years to come."



 These federal funds are made available through the U.S. Department of
Agriculture Rural Development's Community Facilities Program. The program
supports important rural community facilities, like hospitals, through federal
grants, loans, and guarantees that improve the quality of life and provide
needed services that allow small towns to thrive.

                             National Mortgage News

                                 March 27, 1995

Easier for Lenders to Use Title One

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 284 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The Department of Housing and Urban Development has published regulations making
it easier for lenders to use the Title One property improvement and manufactured
housing home loan guarantee programs.

HUD leaders hope that easing the lender approval regulations will enable home
improvement lenders to serve more homeowners in central cities and underserved
communities.

The new regulations allow a broader range of financial institutions to
participate in the Title One program.  For instance, charitable organizations,
nonprofit associations and pension funds will be allowed to buy Title One home
improvement loans.

Previously, investors who purchased Title One loans were required to maintain
the staff and facilities needed for loan origination.  HUD has eliminated this
requirement.

HUD hopes the change will increase the amount of capital available to fund Title
One property improvement loans guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration.
Of FHA Title One borrowers, 64% have incomes below area median.

The new regulations are scheduled to take effect on April 13.  The final rule
was published in the March 14 edition of the Federal Register. The reg also
applies to lenders who participate in the manufactured housing loan guarantee
program.

Also, Fannie Mae began purchasing Title One loans from a limited number of
lenders on March 1 under an initial $ 100 million commitment to the program.

In FY 1994, the FHA insured 72,000 Title One property improvement loans with a
balance of $ 806 million.  In budget documents released in February, the
Administration said it anticipates that volume will grow to almost $ 1.2 billion
in FY 1995 and $ 1.4 billion in fiscal 1996.

                              820 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 14, 1980, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. TREASURY'S 'BACK-DOOR' BANK

BYLINE: By EDWARD COWAN

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1879 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


In terms of the funds that move through its ledgers, it is one of the largest
financial institutions in the United States. But surely, dollar-for-dollar, it
is the least visible. It is not listed in the District of Columbia white pages,
the Congressional Directory or standard guides to the capital. You can't even
see it, unless you stand in front of the statue of Albert Gallatin at the north
end of the Treasury building and then look up over his left shoulder to a
third-floor window framed with gold drapes.

There, in room 3124, is the office of Roland H. Cooke, the secretary and
managing officer of an agency of the Government known as the Federal Financing
Bank. For Mr. Cook, it is a part-time job.  He is also a senior Treasury
debt-management officer, director of market analysis and agency finance. Mr.
Cook runs the Federal Financing Bank without ever handling cash. He does
business only with other Federal agencies, foreign governments and private
institutions.

Inside Room 3124, the atmosphere is utterly calm. An oil painting of Jay Cooke,
the Civil War financier, by William M. Chase, dominates the room, imparting a
tone of elegance and civility. Mr. Cook chats amiably and with seeming openness,
despite his reputation in the Treasury as a crusty, cantankerous fellow who
keeps his books close to his vest.

Mr. Cook, however, sits at the eye of a gathering storm.  Figuratively, Mr.
Cook's office is the notorious ''back door'' to the Treasury, the avenue for
prying money out of the Government without going through the Congressional
appropriations process.

What the Federal Financing Bank does is simple: it borrows money from the
Treasury and uses the funds to finance a score of programs run by other
agencies. They include such diverse enterprises as the sale of weapons to
foreign countries, construction of rural electric generating facilities and
providing working capital for new health maintenance organizations.

This is what Congress intended. It created the bank in 1973 to centralize what
had been the separate, uncoordinated and often overlapping trips to the capital
markets of various Federal agencies. The agencies would borrow money for direct
loans to their constituents, for example, loans by the Farmers Home
Administration for rural housing.

Federal agencies also offer their constituents loan guarantees that carry the
full faith and credit of the United States. Thus, the Defense Department gives
munitions customers such as South Korea, Israel, Jordan and Colombia loan
guarantees and the Department of Transportation guarantees loans to railroads
for roadbed improvement.

Traditionally, Congress viewed the guarantees as a way to harness private
capital to Federal purposes. But with the Federal Financing Bank lending
directly to the guarantee-bearing customers, and with the bank obtaining its
funds from the Treasury, the guarantee is now seen as a ''back door'' raid on
the Treasury.

Worse, in the eyes of some critics, the bank's loans to guarantee holders are
''off-budget'' transactions. They amount to direct Federal loans but do not add
to the budget total or the deficit, because the bank, by statute, is an
off-budget agency.

The critics also object to the way the bank's operations can reduce agency
budget expenditures, as they are now counted. The bank funnels money to the
agencies by ''buying'' their loans - the i.o.u.'s they hold - in much the way a
factoring company buys accounts receivable.

When the Financing Bank buys an agency loan, the agency's net budget outlays are
reduced. This is a convention, that the sale of an asset is an offset against
spending. By now, selling assets such as Federally insured mortgages to private
investors is a hoary device for shrinking the nominal size of the Federal
budget.

Still another criticism of guarantees, but not of the bank, is that they usually
are not subject to regular scrutiny through the Congressional appropriations and
budget processes.

Concern about how the Federal Financing Bank operates is part of a larger
dispute over whether the entire Federal credit system of loans and loan
guarantees is adequately disciplined. Robert Reischauer, deputy director of the
the Congressional Budget Office, has testified that for the years 1976-79, loans
and loan guarantees grew at a faster rate than Federal spending.

''Most of the growth in Federal credit programs has occurred outside any
Congressional control process or mechanism for allocating resources,'' Mr.
Reischauer, an economist, told a Senate Budget subcommittee in June.

Whether an agency's direct loans are on or off the budget is determined by
Congress in the enabling legislation, and with loan guarantees supported by the
full faith and credit of the Government, the guaranteed debt is almost as good
as the Treasury's own obligations in the eyes of the financial community.

Both the Carter Administration and members of Congress have made proposals to
tighten discipline over Federal credit, especially offbudget loans. The Congress
included overall ceilings on direct loans and guarantees in the first budget
resolution for fiscal 1981, which begins Oct. 1.

In addition, a bill sponsored by Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of
Illinois, would make direct loans and loan guarantees subject to the
appropriations process. Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin,
chairman of the Banking Committee and a longtime advocate of a comprehensive
Federal budget for credit, has said he will introduce legislation to pull the
Federal Financing Bank into the budget in two ways. His legislation would
require that guaranteed loans financed by the bank be counted in the budget as
loans by the agencies; and it would discontinue the practice of reducing the
agencies' stated loan outlays by the amount of their sales of loan assets to the
Financing Bank.

President Carter's 1981 budget proposed that Congress write loan and guarantee
limits for some agencies into the annual appropriations. According to the Office
of Management and Budget, the House Appropriations Committee adopted 61 of the
69 such limits proposed by the President (although not always for the identical
dollar amount).

As Roland Cook and others see it, there are fine ironies in the blame now heaped
on the Federal Financing Bank.  ''We wanted to get the total amount of financing
identified in one lump sum so people would know what's going on,'' said Paul A.
Volcker, then Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs and the
Administration's chief witness in hearings on Capitol Hill.  Mr. Volcker is now
chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

''We got the efficiency,'' Mr. Volcker said. ''We didn't get the control.'' In
part that may have been because the Congress, responding to interest groups that
feared the Federal credit spigot would be shut off, was persuaded to delete
language that would have given the Treasury authority to approve in advance the
issuance of guarantees and require that they be placed with the Financing Bank.

The fear, Mr. Cook recalled, was ''that somehow we would be too much of a
czar.'' In fact, he said, the last thing the Treasury wanted was to take on the
onerous task of rationing credit among the agencies.

The ''backdoor'' charge against the Financing Bank may have grown out of a
change in policy. Mr. Volcker's successor as Under Secretary, Jack Bennett, felt
that instead of selling its own obligations, the Financing Bank should borrow
from the Treasury, letting the Treasury raise the money. That meant still fewer
trips by the Government to the capital markets and a lower cost of money.

The Financing Bank pays the Treasury one-eighth of a percentage point more than
the Treasury's cost of money and charges its customers the same rate. Presumably
that is less than they would pay if they placed their own obligations.

Mr. Volcker said he was disappointed that the Financing Bank turned to borrowing
from the Treasury. ''It didn't bring it into the public focus I was looking
for,'' he said.

The Financing Bank's success gives rise to the question of whether it is not
simply a neutral, accommodating financial intermediary, but a force for Federal
credit expansion. ''Did the ease of financing by the F.F.B. stimulate more than
we bargained for?'' asks Mr. Volcker.

Mr. Cook says the root of the problem is not in the Financing Bank but in the
decisions by Congress to authorize loans and guarantees for a multiplicity of
programs. ''We'd like to see better control of the guarantee-giving function by
Congress,'' he said.

Mr. Cook, who acknowledges that he never turns an agency down (he is not
supposed to), argues that without a Financing Bank the various programs would
raise no less money. ''They'll be financed,'' he says. ''They're Federal
credit.''

Might some programs experience more difficulty? Might they not have to scale
back?  Mr. Roland replied that a higher cost of money might cut into program
size somewhat, but the programs would be financed anyway.  ''There would have
been a series of Federal financing banks,'' he asserted.

The Treasury Department's deeply imbedded belief in the Financing Bank as an
efficient intermediary and the conflicting view that it invites special
interests to raid the Treasury by the back door was illustrated recently in an
exchange of correspondence between the Treasury Deputy Secretary, Robert
Carswell, and Senator Proxmire.

Mr. Carswell wrote first, arguing that if Congress had not forbidden the
purchase of Government-guaranteed Chrysler debt by the Financing Bank, the auto
company could have saved more than $26 million in interest and $2 million in
underwriters' fees in its July 30 sale of $300 million of debt. Mr. Carswell
added that ''we remain convinced that the Federal Financing Bank should be
authorized'' to buy the guaranteed Chrysler debt if that would mean
''substantial savings to Chrysler.''

Senator Proxmire, in a tart reply, noted that both the House and Senate Chrysler
bills included the prohibition. The intent, he said, was ''to prevent the
guaranteed loans from being converted to direct loans off-budget.''

The Banking Committee chairman then challenged the Administration to try a
front-door approach, and he hinted that Congress would slam that door in the
President's face. He suggested that the Administration seek direct-loan
authority in place of the remaining $700 million of guarantee authority Chrysler
has not used.

''Should you choose to go this route,'' he told Mr. Carswell, the Banking
Committee would ''consider the issue on its merits, and I assume that the
Appropriations Committee would follow suit.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1980 The New York Times Company


                              821 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            April 18, 2009 Saturday

Quebec gives Abitibi $100-million 'shot in the arm'

BYLINE: BERTRAND MAROTTE AND PAUL WALDIE

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: CANADIAN; PULP AND PAPER; Pg. B6

LENGTH: 522 words

DATELINE: MONTREAL and TORONTO


A loan guarantee of up to $100-million (U.S.) from the Quebec government is a
welcome vote of confidence in AbitibiBowater Inc. ABH-T and helps reassure
job-dependent communities in the province that suppliers will continue to be
paid, court was told yesterday.

"That is a tremendous shot in the arm for us," Sean Dunphy, the head of the
legal team guiding the debt-laden newsprint giant through bankruptcy protection
proceedings in Canada, told Mr. Justice Clément Gascon of Quebec Superior Court.

Montreal-based AbitibiBowater - the world's biggest producer of newsprint - was
also in Delaware court yesterday, after filing for Chapter 11 protection for its
U.S. operations on Thursday.

The Quebec offer of financial aid yesterday came a day after Ottawa said it
cannot provide loan guarantees because they would be a commercial advantage to
Canadian producers and would aggravate the softwood lumber dispute with U.S.
firms.

Revenue Minister Jean-Pierre Blackburn, who has two AbitibiBowater facilities in
his riding, said yesterday that Ottawa can only offer help through Export
Development Canada.

Industry Minister Tony Clement has refused to wade into the matter.
"AbitibiBowater's actions represent an internal business decision and it would
be inappropriate for the government to comment further during these
arrangements," Industry Canada said.

AbitibiBowater, which employs 15,800 people worldwide - 11,300 of them in
Canada, including 7,500 in Quebec - is preparing for what will likely be a long,
complex financial restructuring aimed at drastically reducing its massive debt
of more than $6-billion (U.S.).

Mr. Dunphy told the court yesterday that the goal is to get through the
restructuring with "as little collateral damage as can be managed" to employees,
suppliers, customers and other stakeholders.

The 2007 merger of Abitibi-Consolidated with U.S. forestry giant Bowater has
been successful, he said. The merged company is a stronger entity than if the
two had remained separate, he told the court.

But the balance sheet is in dire need of repair, he said.

In a research report yesterday, analysts Sean Steuart and Graham Meagher of TD
Securities Inc. said AbitibiBowater will likely close several of its Canadian
mills as part of the restructuring.

"We believe that this company will eventually re-emerge as a smaller, leaner
company with a more concentrated capacity base focused around the company's best
assets in the U.S. Southeast," they wrote.

Protection from its creditors might in fact make it easier for AbitibiBowater to
close some of its higher-cost mills in Canada, they said.

The company also filed a list of creditors in U.S. bankruptcy court in
Wilmington, Del., yesterday. The list ran more than 2,500 pages and contained
more than 60,000 creditors. The creditors ranged from large newspapers including
The Globe and Mail, Toronto Star, New York Times and Wall Street Journal to
smaller publications such as the Kenora Daily Miner & News.

It is not clear how much any of the creditors are owed or why they were included
on the list.

With files from reporter

Daniel Leblanc in Ottawa

LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              822 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                 The Bond Buyer

                           December 3, 2014 Wednesday

HUD Seeks Buyer for Austin-Area Medical Center After Default

BYLINE: Richard Williamson

SECTION: REGIONAL NEWS Vol. 1 No. 34220

LENGTH: 360  words


DALLASÂ - The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development is seeking a
buyer for Lakeway Regional Medical Center after the two-year-old suburban Austin
hospital defaulted on a $164 million mortgage loan that carried a federal
guarantee.

The loan guarantee, announced in 2010, was the largest the federal agency had
ever provided for a for-profit healthcare facility, according to the Austin
American-Statesman.

HUD officials called the default "an exceedingly rare" event, according to the
Statesman. The agency took over the hospital in October.

HUD' 2010 loan guarantee was expected to save the hospital $91.2 million in
interest. Investors' HUD application said that Lakeway lacked a hospital, making
the residential area around Lake Travis west of Austin medically "underserved."

Investors cited a study showing the hospital would provide access to a primary
service area with an estimated 243,000 residents by 2016. The 100-bed hospital,
which cost $210 million, was also marketed as an economic engine to spur retail
and other development.

Just months after opening in April 2012, Lakeway Regional suffered cash
shortages. In August 2013, the hospital missed its first mortgage payment and
landed in default, HUD officials said. After that, the loan changed hands to
Greystone Servicing Corp. Inc. In September, HUD took over from Greystone.

On Sept. 17, HUD paid Greystone $154.6 million, 90% of the amount owed,
according to the Statesman. The other 10% will be paid when HUD receives all of
the ownership documents, officials told the paper.

Since 1968, the Federal Housing Administration, an agency operating under HUD,
has insured 358 mortgages to hospitals throughout the nation, 45 within the past
five years.

Moody's Investors Service cited the planned hospital as a factor in upgrading
the city of Lakewood to Aa3 from A1 on April 7, 2010.

Lakeway is about 15 miles northwest of Austin on the shores of Lake Travis, with
a small but affluent population of about 11,200. Traditionally a lake home
community with higher-end homes, the city's assessed value increased to $2.74
billion in 2010 and averaged 16.3% annual growth over the previous five years.

URL: http://www.bondbuyer.com

LOAD-DATE: December 2, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: BONDBUYER_NEWS

                            December 1, 2014 Monday

HUD Seeks Buyer for Austin-Area Medical Center After Default

BYLINE: Richard Williamson

SECTION: REGIONAL NEWS Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 360  words


DALLASÂ - The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development is seeking a
buyer for Lakeway Regional Medical Center after the two-year-old suburban Austin
hospital defaulted on a $164 million mortgage loan that carried a federal
guarantee.

The loan guarantee, announced in 2010, was the largest the federal agency had
ever provided for a for-profit healthcare facility, according to the Austin
American-Statesman.

HUD officials called the default "an exceedingly rare" event, according to the
Statesman. The agency took over the hospital in October.

HUD' 2010 loan guarantee was expected to save the hospital $91.2 million in
interest. Investors' HUD application said that Lakeway lacked a hospital, making
the residential area around Lake Travis west of Austin medically "underserved."

Investors cited a study showing the hospital would provide access to a primary
service area with an estimated 243,000 residents by 2016. The 100-bed hospital,
which cost $210 million, was also marketed as an economic engine to spur retail
and other development.

Just months after opening in April 2012, Lakeway Regional suffered cash
shortages. In August 2013, the hospital missed its first mortgage payment and
landed in default, HUD officials said. After that, the loan changed hands to
Greystone Servicing Corp. Inc. In September, HUD took over from Greystone.

On Sept. 17, HUD paid Greystone $154.6 million, 90% of the amount owed,
according to the Statesman. The other 10% will be paid when HUD receives all of
the ownership documents, officials told the paper.

Since 1968, the Federal Housing Administration, an agency operating under HUD,
has insured 358 mortgages to hospitals throughout the nation, 45 within the past
five years.

Moody's Investors Service cited the planned hospital as a factor in upgrading
the city of Lakewood to Aa3 from A1 on April 7, 2010.

Lakeway is about 15 miles northwest of Austin on the shores of Lake Travis, with
a small but affluent population of about 11,200. Traditionally a lake home
community with higher-end homes, the city's assessed value increased to $2.74
billion in 2010 and averaged 16.3% annual growth over the previous five years.

                                US Official News

                              March 7, 2014 Friday

Washington: BROWNFIELD REDEVELOPMENT AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT INNOVATIVE
FINANCING ACT OF 2014

LENGTH: 767  words

DATELINE: Washington


United States Congress has issued the following proceedings and debate details:


HON. JANICE HAHN

of california

in the house of representatives

Thursday, March 6, 2014

Ms. HAHN. Mr. Speaker, today, I introduced the ``Brownfield
Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing Act of
2014,'' legislation that will help redevelop large brownfield
redevelopment projects that have the potential to create jobs, provide
affordable housing opportunities and transform regional economies.


 Across the country, from Baltimore to Los Angeles, there are large
redevelopment sites that communities have identified as the economic
development futures of their regions. Older manufacturing sites,
retired steel mills, automotive legacy sites and landfills within
communities are in need of transformation.
 These sites, known as brownfields, are untapped resources that, when
environmentally remediated and redeveloped, will address tax base
shortfalls, provide affordable housing, create jobs, attract new
businesses as well as unify communities with planned sustainable
development that will meet the needs of a changing economy and a
growing population.
 For instance, in my district, the city of Carson provides a shining
example of how large brownfield properties can be redeveloped and
transformed into successful redevelopment projects.
 In 2003, using $90 million of redevelopment funding, Carson invested
in the cleanup of an 160 acre site along the 405. Immediately, the
private sector matched the city's funding and the project moved forward
with the cleanup of the site.
 The project, called The Boulevards, is set to finish construction in
2016, and will have two hotels, retail space, affordable housing,
office buildings, restaurants and movie theatres that will raise an
estimated $107 million in property tax revenues over the next 30 years.
 The Boulevards is a great investment for Carson and for the region
and will ultimately end up paying for itself. What's changed for
Carson, like most communities, is that they do not have another $90
million dollars to quickly redevelop their other large brownfield
projects.
 Unfortunately, there is no current federal funding or financing
mechanism to support and leverage local and private sector resources to
move large brownfield redevelopment sites forward.
 While Title I of the 1949 Housing Authority Act used to provide a
line of federal credit to local communities to undertake major
redevelopment projects during the 1970's, this was later replaced with
the current Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program
administered by HUD. And CDBG funds are currently stretched too thin to
be able to adequately address the needs of large scale redevelopment
projects.
 Additionally, private lenders are hesitant to loan money for these
projects since the extensive remediation and clean up of these sites
means investors aren't going to begin seeing returns for possibly a
decade or longer.
 That's why I have introduced the The Brownfield Redevelopment and
Economic Development Innovative Financing Act of 2014. This bill
creates a pilot program that re-establishes a partnership with
communities by providing the HUD Secretary the authority to guarantee
the repayment of principal and interest on loans made by lenders to
local governments for large brownfield redevelopment projects.
 By providing a federally backed loan guarantee for brownfield
redevelopment, this will eliminate traditional lending risk and thus
attract private resources for projects that otherwise wouldn't have
received funding. At the same time, this bill grants local governments
enough time to remediate and develop their properties so they won't
need to begin making loan repayments until they start receiving
revenue.
 These tools will provide communities with the ability to make an
immediate and long term economic impact on their region and will be the
drivers that help move our national economy forward.
 That is why this bill is supported by public and private stakeholders
alike, including, Weston Solutions, CH2M Hill, Parsons Brinckerhoff,
the American Council of Engineering Companies, Smart Growth America,
the U.S. Conference of Mayors, the National League of Cities, the
National Brownfield Association, the League of California Cities, the
California State Association of Counties, and the city of Carson,
California.
 By providing a platform for partnerships and innovative financing
tools, we will finally arm communities with the necessary tools to
fully plan, invest and develop their futures.

For more information please visit: http://beta.congress.gov

LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited

                           Sherbrooke Record (Quebec)

                           August 29, 2007 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

Breaking into the US?; Milan's Usinex gets dough

BYLINE: The Record

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 298  words

DATELINE: SHERBROOKE


SHERBROOKE - Maison Usinex inc., which rose from the ashes after a fire in
December 2006 destroyed the prefabricated homes factory in Milan, has just
received a $250,000 loan guarantee from the provincial government.

The announcement was made Tuesday by M[#x17d]gantic-Compton Liberal MNA Johanne
Gonthier on behalf of industry minister Raymond Bachand.

The financial aid package will be part of a $3.6 million development project
that will help the plant increase its production capacity by acquiring new
hi-tech equipment. The expansion will allow the creation of 15 news jobs that
will be added to 65 existing ones.

For several years the Quebec enterprise has grown considerably and it is now
looking at penetrating the American market which will bring spinoffs to Quebec,
Gonthier said in a statement.

"Small and medium sized industries are the motor of our economy and the
government takes their economic growth to heart," stated Gonthier. "That why we
are happy to support Maison Usinex, an enterprise with a promising future."

The plant, in the tiny border community of Milan, builds single family, duplexes
and small apartment buildings, which are delivered in modular units that are
assembled on site. It sells some 125 units a year throughout the province.

The government notes the Estrie region is the only one in Quebec with an
industrial niche that includes sawmills and industries that specialize in
composite materials. For that reason, the region was recognized under the
d'Action concert[#x17d]e de coop[#x17d]ration r[#x17d]gionale de
d[#x17d]veloppement (ACCORD) program that recognizes innovation in certain
sectors of industry.

By qualifying under the ACCORD program, Usinex and other industries can profit
from loan guarantees which aim to help specialized industries increase
productivity and create jobs.

LOAD-DATE: August 29, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              827 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                              April 3, 2006 Monday
                                  All Editions

Workshops focus on energy projects

SECTION: Pg. A7

LENGTH: 613 words

DATELINE: FREEPORT


Community Energy Partners LLC will hold workshops for Maine farmers and rural
small-business owners eligible for up to $750,000 in federal funding to purchase
renewable energy systems or make energy-efficiency improvements in their
businesses.

Known as the Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Improvements Guarantee
Program, the funding comes under Section 9006 of the 2002 Farm Bill. It provides
financial assistance to foster economic development and growth in rural areas.

"The 9006 program is a great opportunity for Maine farmers and small-business
owners to reduce their electricity costs at a time of record-high prices," said
Sue Jones, who is in the process of creating Community Energy Partners after
working as an attorney and lobbyist for the Natural Resources Council of Maine
for eight years.

This year the 9006 program is making available more than $187 million
nationally, with more than $11.385 million for competitive grants and $176.5
million for guaranteed loans. Individual projects are eligible for up to
$750,000 per year in combined renewable and efficiency funding. In 2005, more
than half the total grant funding (more than $11 million) went to wind-energy
projects, with nearly all of it going to large wind projects of 1 megawatt or
greater.

"With strong wind resources located in many rural and farming areas in Maine,
the 9006 program can provide the seed money for farmers to harvest wind, Maine's
newest and most profitable crop," said Jones.

In 2005, 85 wind projects were funded. The vast majority of funding was at the
$250,000 level, but 5 projects were funded at the maximum level of $500,000 for
a renewable project. For the first time in 2005, the USDA made two loan
guarantees of $10.1 million for each of two projects for a total of $20.2
million.

In 2004, Gold Top Farms of Knox received $4,462 for efficiency improvements to
its dairy barn. By installing three fans, Gold Top Farms expects to save more
than $8,000 annually, contributing directly to the farm's profit. Gold Top Farms
combined federal funding with the PUC's Efficiency Maine state funding to put
together its proposal. In 2005, Windham Millwork Inc. received a 9006 grant.

Qualifying projects have included installation of wood-fired and biomass
furnaces, geothermal energy systems, and manure processing and drying equipment,
construction of a biodiesel plant, grain dryer and kiln systems and solar PV
pumping systems, as well as the installation of energy-efficient equipment in
barns, office facilities, warehouses and restaurants, among other projects.

The workshops will be led by Jones and John Sheehan from USDA's Bangor office.

The agenda for the workshops includes an introduction and overview of the 9006
program by John Sheehan, a video presentation that highlights successful farmer-
and small-business-owned renewable and efficiency projects in the Northeast, and
a presentation by Jones on how to put together a qualifying project, potential
business models and two case studies of projects that have received 9006
funding.

The workshops are free and will be held Thursday, April 6, at the Eastern Maine
Development Corp. in Bangor, and Friday, April 7, at the Holiday Inn Ground
Round in Augusta. Registration will be held from 8:30 to 9 a.m.; the workshops
will be held from 9 to 11:00 a.m. For more information and to register, please
e-mail renewable@suscom-maine.net, or call 221-5639 or 865-0042.

"Maine farmers and rural small businesses who are looking for ways to reduce
high energy costs should attend one of these one-stop-shopping workshops," said
Jones. "Our goal is to give them the information and tools they need to be
successful recipients in 2006."

LOAD-DATE: April 3, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2006 Bangor Daily News


                              828 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                             El Paso Times (Texas)

                            February 28, 2010 Sunday

SBA chief hopes for stimulus cash boost

BYLINE: By Vic Kolenc / El Paso Times

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 712 words


EL PASO -- Yolanda Garcia Olivarez, the new regional administrator for the Small
Business Administration, says she hopes Congress provides more stimulus money to
further boost small-business lending.

She also said it appears El Paso small businesses are getting an appropriate
share of contracts in the $6 billion expansion at Fort Bliss.

Olivarez, 56, a former banker in her native Corpus Christi, became regional SBA
director in August.

She oversees 11 SBA offices with about 100 employees in Texas, New Mexico,
Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana, including an El Paso office with eight
employees.

She was in El Paso last week to learn about the community and hear from business
people and others.

"Fifty percent of the people that live in the United States either work for a
small business or own a small business, and this community gets that," Olivarez
said.

The El Paso chambers of commerce and El Paso bankers are providing support for
small businesses, she said. That impressed her, Olivarez said.

The SBA used $500 million in stimulus money to remove borrowers' fees and expand
its loan guarantee to 90 percent for its largest loan programs last year and
early this year.

That boosted SBA-backed lending in El Paso and across the nation, but the money
is now exhausted, Olivarez said.

A bill is to be introduced in Congress to provide more stimulus money for the
the SBA-backed loan features.

SBA fees on a $1 million loan can add up to about $35,000, and that is a real
problem for small businesses, Olivarez said. So waiving those fees shows "this
administration believes in small business," she said.

Yolanda Diaz, owner and president of Mirador Enterprises, a small El Paso
company that does facilities maintenance and construction work, said she would
like to see the waivers and expanded loan guarantees continue. But, she said,
she would also like to see the federal government package contracts differently
at Fort Bliss so more El Paso small businesses could bid on them.

Diaz said that her company has contracts at Fort Bliss but that many other small
El Paso companies are having difficulty getting contracts.

Diaz told Olivarez about her concerns at a luncheon last week.

"I know she has no power (over the contracting), but I would like her to
persuade the government to break contracts into smaller chunks so companies can
bid on them," Diaz said.

Some contracts could be kept exclusive for El Paso businesses and not put out to
the region and nation for bids, she said.

Olivarez said, "My challenge to folks that say they're not getting that business
is they need to contact" the El Paso Small Business Development Center and the
El Paso chambers and "find out what piece of the puzzle they're missing so they
can do that. ? One thing small businesses have to realize is they have to market
themselves to the right folks, and to have that special business plan."

Small companies often cannot meet government project bonding requirements. But
the SBA recently expanded its surety-bond-guarantee program to allow small
businesses to get bonding for up to $5 million, expanded from the previous $2
million cap, Olivarez said.

Diaz said she was impressed with Olivarez's banking background and her interest
in El Paso.

"I knew her heart was really there. It looks like she is really interested in El
Paso and what is happening here," Diaz said.

Olivarez worked in banking for more than 30 years, including the past 16 as
senior vice president for commercial banking at Wells Fargo Bank in Corpus
Christi.

She took the job as regional director because President Barack Obama impressed
her, she said, and "I wanted to help the country and help serve under his
leadership."

Vic Kolenc may be reached at vkolenc@elpasotimes.com;546-6421

For information: www.sba.gov.



Web chat

     ·    What: How small-business owners can get government contracts and
          obtain bonding is the topic of a Small Business Administration Web
          chat this week.Who: Karen Hontz, of the U.S. Office of Government
          Contracting and Business Development, and Pam Swilling, of the SBA's
          Office of Surety Guarantees, will take questions for one hour.When:
          Thursday, 11 a.m.How: You can join the chat at www.sba.gov, and click
          Online Business Chat. People can post questions before the chat at
          http://web.sba.gov/livemeeting/Mar10.

                              830 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                            The Daily Star (Lebanon)

                            June 22, 2011 Wednesday

Egyptian T-Bill yields at 2008 high on aid concern: Arab credit

BYLINE: Ahmed A. Namatalla And Alaa Shahine

LENGTH: 1104 words


Investors in Egyptian treasury-bill auctions are demanding the highest yields
since 2008 on concern international aid pledges won't arrive on time, hurting
the government's efforts to finance the widening budget deficit.

The U.S. and the International Monetary Fund are among donors that promised
about $17.5 billion in loans, credit guarantees, debt relief and investments
after a popular revolt ended the 30-year rule of former President Hosni Mubarak.
So far, Saudi Arabia has provided $500 million in budget support.

Egypt raised less than planned in the past nine auctions of one-year notes and
canceled 16 billion Egyptian pounds ($2.7 billion) in debt sales since Jan. 25
as investors demanded higher yields. Rates on one-year notes soared 232 basis
points this year to 12.98 percent, the highest level since November 2008. The
yields are about 12 percentage points above Bahrain's and compare with 0.16
percent on one-year Treasury bills.

"The track we're on is unsustainable," said Moustafa Assal, the head of
fixed-income at Beltone Financial, a Cairo-based investment bank with $4.2
billion assets under management. "We're reaching the limits of the banking
system's ability to fund the government, which is why it's critical that the aid
arrives soon. Otherwise, we're not far from seeing our yields jump just like
they did in Greece."

Egypt is rated Ba3, three levels below investment grade and four above Greece,
by Moody's Investors Service. The most populous Arab country accumulated $147
billion in debt at the end of 2010, according to the Ministry of Finance.

The IMF said in April that Egypt's economic growth may ease to 1 percent this
year, the slowest pace since 1992. The government projects the budget shortfall
may reach 11 percent of gross domestic product compared with about 10 percent
this year.

U.S. President Barack Obama pledged $1 billion in loan guarantees last month to
finance infrastructure projects and job creation and $1 billion in debt
forgiveness to a "democratic Egypt" to be used "to foster growth and
entrepreneurship." Obama also said the Overseas Private Investment Corp., the
U.S. government's development finance institution, will soon set up a $2 billion
facility to support private investment across the region.

Finance Minister Samir Radwan said he would take advantage of the debt guarantee
to sell $1 billion in five-year eurobonds by year-end. Egypt has a similar bond
maturing next month. The U.S. hasn't said when it would forgive the debt.

The U.S. government has been working with Egyptian authorities to support the
country's democracy, including by rallying the international financial
institutions and international community to provide key economic support, said
an administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The yield on Egypt's 8.75 percent $1 billion bond maturing in July surged 345
basis points this year to 3.60 percent yesterday.

The IMF will lend Egypt $3 billion over the next year, Radwan said June 5. No
conditions or disbursement schedules have been issued for $4 billion from Saudi
Arabia, a combined $4 billion of loans offered by the African Development Bank
and Islamic Development Bank or the $40 billion the Group of Eight committed to
North Africa, including Egypt and Tunisia.

World Bank President Robert Zoellick last month said the agency plans to provide
as much as $4.5 billion to Egypt. Details of the financing haven't been
announced and still have to go to the board for approval. A World Bank official
had no immediate comment.

The international community's pledges also include $2.5 billion from Jeddah,
Saudi Arabia-based Islamic Development Bank, of which Egypt is a 7.1 percent
shareholder. The lender said today it will provide Egypt with the funds over
three years.

"So far, there seems to be a preference for longer term development projects or
debt relief rather than short-term budget support," said Dubai-based Simon
Williams, the chief Middle East economist at HSBC Holdings Plc. "That may be
good for growth in due course, but it won't address immediate financing needs."
The IMF funds will only cover 10 percent of the deficit the Finance Ministry is
expecting over the next year, he said.

The government has sought $9.5 billion in budget support from international
sources, according to a document on the Finance Ministry's website detailing the
government's plan for the fiscal year that starts next month.

"You add up the aid pledges and they are actually more than what Egypt needs,"
said Richard Fox, the London-based head of Middle East and North Africa
Sovereign Ratings at Fitch Ratings. "I don't have any major concerns" about aid
coming in, "provided the government sticks to its fiscal plans."

Following Obama's pledge, the yield on Egypt's 5.75 percent 10-year dollar bond
due in April 2020 dropped as much as 62 basis points to 5.57 percent June 6. The
rate was at 5.72 percent at 12:22 p.m. in Cairo after soaring to as much as 7.07
percent Jan. 31 amid the protests.

The cost of insuring the nation's government debt for five years through
credit-default swaps has tumbled 139 basis points to 303 today from its high on
Jan. 31, according to data provider CMA, which is owned by CME Group Inc. and
compiles prices quoted by dealers in the privately negotiated market.

Egypt, where 76 percent of the debt is made up of local currency obligations
that are rolled over through bill and bond auctions, reversed course on a plan
announced last year to extend debt maturities after Mubarak was ousted in
February. Egypt hasn't sold Treasury bonds since the start of the uprising in
January. Local banks have increased purchases of bills after foreign investors
trimmed their holdings of the country's securities by $4.9 billion in the first
quarter, central bank data show.

The annual financing needs of the government are the equivalent of about 11.7
percent of banking assets or 16 percent of total deposits, Nondas Nicolaides, a
senior analyst at Moody's Investors Service in Limassol, Cyprus, said in an
emailed answer to questions.

Local government debt can be absorbed by banks for at least two years, "assuming
there is a smooth transition to an officially elected functioning government in
the immediate future," if deposits don't decline significantly and "given that
banks will have at least half of the government debt redemptions that are likely
to roll over," he said.

Egypt will hold presidential elections this year to elect what could be the
first civilian leader since the military took power in a 1952 coup, according to
surveys from organizations including Washington-based Pew Research Center.

LOAD-DATE: June 22, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                The Irish Times

                            November 23, 2012 Friday

Bond successes no guarantee for Ireland Inc

BYLINE: CIARáN HANCOCK

SECTION: FINANCE; Back page; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 379 words


One More Thing:Bord Gáis has tapped the bond markets for EUR 500 million,
becoming the latest arm of the State to successfully access funds recently.

Remarkably, it was 13 times oversubscribed and the coupon was a competitive
3.625 per cent.

This follows similar successful auctions of late by the National Treasury
Management Agency and ESB.

Accounts just released for a subsidiary of the Dublin Airport Authority show
that it, too, has had some joy with bonds.

DAA Finance plc repurchased EUR 50.35 million worth of bonds last year from a
EUR 600 million loan note due in 2018, netting a EUR 5 million profit.

DAA Finance also drew down a EUR 260 million loan from the European Investment
Bank at a knockdown rate of 2.175 per cent to replace a EUR 250 million facility
that matured last year and carried a coupon of 6.15 per cent.

Of course, successful corporate bond offerings are no guarantee that Ireland
will be able to exit the bailout programme.

For a start, the State needs to raise a multiple of the sums generated by Bord
Gáis and ESB   EUR 15 billion-plus a year.

However, they are encouraging.

Both are profitable, solid businesses, with good cash flows and strong track
records.

Such fundamentals should always prove attractive to the investment community.

Before the crash, investors took added comfort from the fact that there was an
implied guarantee from the State. It was a handy insurance policy.

That all changed when the economy crashed and the Government was forced to pump
billions into insolvent banks.

Lending to Ireland Inc became a major risk and the interest rate rising to an
unsustainable level, hence the Troika bailout.

The fundraisings by Bord Gáis and ESB indicate a more benign view of Ireland
now.

On a brief trip to Ireland at the end of last month, German finance minister
Wolfgang Schäuble stated confidently that Ireland was on track to re-enter the
markets next year and exit the bailout programme.

Here s hoping he s right but there s still a long journey to travel in that
respect.

Our prospects hinge every bit as much on resolving the intractable euro zone
financial crisis and on global economic growth being generated to fuel our
exports and sustain inward investment and job creation.

Unfortunately, these factors are largely outside our control.

LOAD-DATE: November 22, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                         Bayside Advertiser (Australia)

                             August 31, 2009 Monday
                                 1 - SB Edition

Council backs club

BYLINE: Bowling| Jon Andrews

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 230  words


BRIGHTON Bowling Club's new international-standard Dendy Park project has been
given a loan guarantee lifeline by Bayside Council.

Though work on the $5 million complex is nearly complete, the club has been
granted a $200,000 assurance to cover unexpected late land tax and substation
work bills.

Club president Ken Armstrong said they needed the fiscal backing to get a bank
loan, and they had asked the council for help as the complex was on its land.

Mr Armstrong said the club wasn't having financial problems.

Mayor James Long said the council would back the project to the tune of $200,000
over five years.

If the club won an upcoming appeal to the State Government regarding a whopping
$250,000 land tax bill, that surety would be dropped to $50,000, he said.

``Council's loan guarantee will enable a development that is almost complete to
be finished and utilised,'' Cr Long said.

The council wants better access for non-members, he said.

Dendy Park Association spokesman Michael Nugent said there was a ``level of
community anger'' about the project and council's support for it.

The club is leasing the land from the council for 30 years, before reverting it
to public ownership in 2035.

It sold its previous home for more than $6 million in 2005 to help fund the new
venture.

Mr Armstrong said it would be the best facility in Australia for lawn bowls and
would attract world events.

                                    Scotsman

                           September 13, 2016 Tuesday

Gillian Donald: Social investment goes mainstream

BYLINE: Gillian Donald

LENGTH: 614  words


Most of us are familiar with enterprise investment schemes and the tax
incentives they offer to private investors.

Created to encourage investment in unlisted and potentially riskier ventures in
the UK, until recently the qualifying conditions meant that entrepreneurial
activity had to be for commercial purposes. This changed last year when social
enterprises were given the same opportunities through the social investment tax
relief provisions.

Social enterprises can be defined as commercial businesses whose main purpose is
to return benefit to their community. This might be in provision of services -
such as a café providing training and/or employment for young people. It could
equally be in provision of facilities - such as a community nursery, providing a
local, financially accessible care facility which helps both the children and
their parents.

Traditionally, commercial businesses would do this by donating money, goods or
services to their communities. Larger businesses might even set up their own
charities to make donations. The alternative route was through charities -
government policy was to make "top-down" funding available to charities, which
obviously influenced organisations to take charitable status.

However, the opportunities presented by charitable status also brought
constraints. One of the main ones being that charity directors are essentially
voluntary and not many unpaid board members would be willing to take on a bank
loan which, for an SME, typically comes with a requirement for personal
guarantees from the directors. This has resulted in a general aversion to
borrowing within the charity sector. And as we know, borrowing to fund business
development is an essential aspect of most commercial entities.

The difference now is that a generation of social entrepreneurs has grown up
without the "top-down" grant funding available throughout the 1990s, so there is
much less of an incentive to obtain charitable status. They don't have the cash
reserves to fund investment but these emerging business leaders want to effect
the same changes and are more accepting of the need for risk capital to achieve
social objectives.

At the same time, the new tax breaks have opened up finance opportunities to
social enterprises, which now have opportunities to access finance on a level
playing field with the rest of the commercial sector - free from the personal
guarantees required by the banks, and the constraints of charitable status. The
government policy changes are set to enable a step change in growth in this
sector.

The market is already responding to this opportunity with one local community
development finance organisation taking the lead on this - award-winning Social
Investment Scotland has created Scotland's first bespoke qualifying social
investment fund - SIS Community Capital. Fully subscribed on opening, it matches
individual investors with social enterprises and ensures both the investors and
the enterprises meet qualifying criteria and carries out the due diligence to
confirm the enterprises are expected to be able to repay the finance. Then the
funding is given and the social enterprise is expected to deliver to the same
standards as a commercial entity, making a profit and returning the agreed value
to the investors.

Social enterprises are usually micro-businesses and are a tiny part of our
economy. But government policy changes and how the market is responding mean we
expect to see significant and sustained growth in social enterprise in the
medium term.

o Gillian Donald is a partner at accountant and business adviser
{http://www.scott-moncrieff.com | Scott-Moncrieff | Link to Scott-Moncrieff
website}

LOAD-DATE: September 13, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: SWTS


                       Copyright 2016 Johnston Press Plc
                              All Rights Reserved


                              835 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                    Scotsman

                           September 13, 2016 Tuesday

Gillian Donald: Social investment goes mainstream

BYLINE: Gillian Donald

LENGTH: 614  words


Most of us are familiar with enterprise investment schemes and the tax
incentives they offer to private investors.

Created to encourage investment in unlisted and potentially riskier ventures in
the UK, until recently the qualifying conditions meant that entrepreneurial
activity had to be for commercial purposes. This changed last year when social
enterprises were given the same opportunities through the social investment tax
relief provisions.

Social enterprises can be defined as commercial businesses whose main purpose is
to return benefit to their community. This might be in provision of services -
such as a café providing training and/or employment for young people. It could
equally be in provision of facilities - such as a community nursery, providing a
local, financially accessible care facility which helps both the children and
their parents.

Traditionally, commercial businesses would do this by donating money, goods or
services to their communities. Larger businesses might even set up their own
charities to make donations. The alternative route was through charities -
government policy was to make "top-down" funding available to charities, which
obviously influenced organisations to take charitable status.

However, the opportunities presented by charitable status also brought
constraints. One of the main ones being that charity directors are essentially
voluntary and not many unpaid board members would be willing to take on a bank
loan which, for an SME, typically comes with a requirement for personal
guarantees from the directors. This has resulted in a general aversion to
borrowing within the charity sector. And as we know, borrowing to fund business
development is an essential aspect of most commercial entities.

The difference now is that a generation of social entrepreneurs has grown up
without the "top-down" grant funding available throughout the 1990s, so there is
much less of an incentive to obtain charitable status. They don't have the cash
reserves to fund investment but these emerging business leaders want to effect
the same changes and are more accepting of the need for risk capital to achieve
social objectives.

At the same time, the new tax breaks have opened up finance opportunities to
social enterprises, which now have opportunities to access finance on a level
playing field with the rest of the commercial sector - free from the personal
guarantees required by the banks, and the constraints of charitable status. The
government policy changes are set to enable a step change in growth in this
sector.

The market is already responding to this opportunity with one local community
development finance organisation taking the lead on this - award-winning Social
Investment Scotland has created Scotland's first bespoke qualifying social
investment fund - SIS Community Capital. Fully subscribed on opening, it matches
individual investors with social enterprises and ensures both the investors and
the enterprises meet qualifying criteria and carries out the due diligence to
confirm the enterprises are expected to be able to repay the finance. Then the
funding is given and the social enterprise is expected to deliver to the same
standards as a commercial entity, making a profit and returning the agreed value
to the investors.

Social enterprises are usually micro-businesses and are a tiny part of our
economy. But government policy changes and how the market is responding mean we
expect to see significant and sustained growth in social enterprise in the
medium term.

o Gillian Donald is a partner at accountant and business adviser
{http://www.scott-moncrieff.com | Scott-Moncrieff | Link to Scott-Moncrieff
website}
