                              882 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                           The Sunday Times (London)

                              March 2, 2014 Sunday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

King denies destabilising Rangers

BYLINE: Mark Walker; John Fallon

SECTION: SPORT; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 668 words


DAVE KING has cranked up the pressure on the Rangers board even further by
dissecting their response to his explosive intervention last week, where he
urged supporters to withold seasonticket money and accused the board of
insulting the fans.

The South African-based former director and investor dramatically catapulted
himself back into the battle for Rangers' future last week with a calculated
call-to-arms to supporters increasingly irritated by the current board. The
catalyst was a £1.5m loan to help with the club's running costs, secured against
two of Rangers' properties, with King's plan for fans to ring-fence
season-ticket cash until conditions were met.

After supporters groups backed King, chief executive Graham Wallace hit back
with his own statement pleading to be allowed to complete his 120-day review of
the turmoil at the club and insisting King was destabilising the club.

King responded last night: "It is inspiring to see how the Rangers community
continues to unite and put the club first in times of need. This will guarantee
a positive outcome at this watershed moment in our club's history. I will now
make it a priority to travel to Scotland to meet with fan representatives to
ensure that appropriate legal structures are discussed and implemented for both
season-ticket payments and the creation of a substantial fund to secure an
influential equity stake in the club for fans. Unfortunately, I can only express
bemusement at the board's response to myself and the fans."

"  King picked holes in Wallace's response and said claims he was undermining
the club were "an insult to fans who have nothing other than the club's interest
at heart." He went on to suggest that it was "quite possible that Charles Green
is still de facto controlling the club" after Wallace had blamed the previous
regime. He also stated: "The board correctly argues that season-ticket monies
are normally part of sound working capital management. Again, it is what is not
said that is key. These are not normal times. Normally, there would be
sufficient facilities in place to support the club once the season-ticket money
is used up. Despite multiple requests, the board is either unwilling or unable
to provide such confirmation. This is particularly important given that this
board falsely assured fans that there were sufficient funds to meet the club''s
commitments to the end of the season."

On the loan from shareholders Laxey Partners and Sandy Easdale, secured against
the Albion car park and Edminston House facilities near Ibrox, King said:"It is
insightful of the board's mindset that it is willing to borrow money from a
preferred shareholder at a rate of interest that reflects a high risk to the
investor. In doing so the board has finally confirmed its true view on the
parlous state of the club's finances. What is incomprehensible however is that
it then eliminated the risk to this investor by providing club assets as
security while still paying the high-risk rate."

Dundee United captain Gavin Gunning has revealed the renewed concerns
surrounding finances at Rangers could dissuade him from moving to Ibrox in the
summer. Out of contract in May, the in-demand Tangerines captain has been free
to negotiate with other clubs since January 1, but Rangers had appeared to be
his likely destination. Gunning has received a hostile reception at Ibrox during
his four years in Scotland, especially after scoring there in 2012, but has no
qualms about becoming only the second Irish-born Catholic to join the Glasgow
giants. Last week's news, however, that the club required a £1.5m loan to
guarantee their viability until the end of the season, alarmed the Dubliner.

"I've a young family now and can't afford to be putting them at risk," he said.
"It just wouldn't be fair to sign and then, down the road, be asked to take pay
cuts. I need stability. I'm not completely ruling out Rangers but neither am I
confirming that I'll definitely be leaving Dundee United. I've some big
decisions to make."

                              884 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                       Sarasota Herald Tribune (Florida)

                             June 15, 2010 Tuesday

Worcester woos airplane company // Lake Aerospace could add 130 jobs

BYLINE: Danielle M. Horn

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. B8

LENGTH: 566 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


WORCESTER - City officials are working to attract an amphibious plane company to
the airport, expecting that it would create 130 jobs over three years.

The City Council tonight will receive City Manager Michael V. O'Brien's
recommendation to approve a $1 million U.S. Department of Housing and Urban
Development Section 108 Loan Guarantee, which would help the Delaware-based Lake
Aerospace LLC fund a proposed $7.3 million project at 10 Coppage Drive. The
council is expected to refer the proposal to its Standing Committee on Economic
Development.

Timothy J. McGourthy, director of economic development, said the loan guarantee
is only one portion of the financing Lake Aerospace is seeking as it looks to
open a facility for the production, sales, and service of Lake Amphibians, the
only Federal Aviation Administration-certified single-engine amphibious aircraft
in the world. The planes, which come in civilian and military models, are
designed to operate smoothly and efficiently on both land and water.

The location in the Worcester Airport Industrial Research Park, which has been
vacant for almost a year, would serve as the company's national and
international headquarters.

"This is something that will help both the airport and the economy at large,"
Mr. McGourthy said. "There is a lot of interest in this company from entities
looking to buy their aircraft."

To date, according to city officials, Lake Aerospace has received letters of
interest from an international United Nations-affiliated agency for 50 to 100
military aircraft over three years, a U.S. police agency for two military
aircraft, and an aircraft distributor for 25 civilian aircraft over three years.
Lake Aerospace has also received expressions of interest from U.S. and foreign
government agencies for more than 200 military aircraft.

The 100 jobs estimated to be created in the first two years of operation would
come with hourly wages ranging from $11 to $25.50, city officials said. An
additional 30 jobs are expected to be created in the third year.

Lake Aerospace last year started the process of acquiring the assets of Revo
Inc., a Florida corporation that for 50 years produced Lake Amphibians. Run by
principals Larry Gould and Antonio Valdez, Lake Aerospace is incorporated in
Delaware and has not yet filed papers with the Massachusetts secretary of state.

Mr. Gould, the company's president, said the company has not yet ruled out
setting up shop elsewhere.

"Florida is still in the running if things fall through," said Mr. Gould, a
former Natick resident. "But we're very excited about the prospect of coming to
Massachusetts. We'd be proud to help revitalize the airport."

Lake Aerospace intends on finalizing all of its funding sources by the middle of
August. The company intends to invest $1 million of its own money to fund the
project, and is working to secure loans from different sources. Included in the
financing would be the $1 million loan guarantee Mr. McGourthy hopes the City
Council will support.

HUD loan guarantees allow cities to leverage their community development block
grants against the amount a private business or corporation borrows.
Essentially, the city would be vouching for Lake Aerospace and using its
borrowing power to help the company get credit.

"Really, our action is setting the stage for their purchase and development of
the overall company and project," Mr. McGourthy said.

LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: WORCESTER - City officials are working to attract an amphibious plane
company to the airport, expecting that it would create 130 jobs over three
years.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2010 Sarasota Herald-Tribune Co.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              885 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                 Republican & Herald (Pottsville, Pennsylvania)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                              May 22, 2015 Friday

Butler supervisors vote to back sewer authority refinancing

BYLINE: John E. Usalis, Republican & Herald, Pottsville, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 714 words


May 22--FOUNTAIN SPRINGS -- The Butler Township supervisors approved an
ordinance to have the township back the refinancing of a Butler Township Sewer
Authority loan with a lower interest rate.

The conditional approval at Tuesday's meeting was made after attorney Peter T.
Edelman of the law firm of Stevens & Lee, Reading, who is working with the
authority on the refinancing action, presented specifics.

"I've received some phone calls over the past week regarding requests by the
authority for the township to act as the guarantor on refinancing a loan for
their sewer facility to save some money," township solicitor Christopher
Riedlinger said.

Edelman said the sewer authority board met Monday and heard a presentation by
Scott Kramer, financial adviser with RBC Capital Markets, explaining
opportunities to refinance indebtedness.

"The debt goes back to 2005, but because of today's low interest rates, the
authority has the opportunity to refinance that debt, lower the interest rate
and save over $200,000," Edelman said. "The original debt was guaranteed by the
township, so as part of this refinancing, we're requesting the township on
behalf of the authority to consider enacting an ordinance that will authorize a
guarantee agreement to support this debt like it did for the original 2005
debt."

The original loan in 2005 was about $6.5 million, with the current principal at
about $5 million after 10 years. Edelman said the current loan rate is 6.5
percent, and the refinancing will bring that down to 3 to 3.5 percent over the
remaining 15 years.

Riedlinger said that although this is refinancing an existing loan, the state
Department of Community and Economic Development treats it as a new loan,
requiring the township to repeat the same steps as had been done in 2005.

"So, you're looking for the township to guarantee the new loan, but they've
already guaranteed the old loan, so it's nothing new," Reidlinger said.

"Correct, and it's a benefit to the township as well because it reduces the
township's ultimate obligation by that amount," Edelman explained.

"And I assume it is also a benefit to the ratepayers in Butler Township, because
with lower interest rates, there may not be a need for higher user fees at some
point in the future," Riedlinger said, to which Edelman agreed.

Supervisors Chairman David Kessler asked if the authority has paperwork in place
to move forward. Edelman said the ordinance has been advertised as required by
the provisions in the Local Government Unit Debt Act.

"The ordinance is pretty straightforward and follows the requirements of
Pennsylvania state law where it comes to guarantee agreements," Edelman said.
"We can move forward tonight and enact the ordinance, and then we would file
everything with the state as required by DCED."

"One of the things I would be most concerned about on behalf of the township is
that the appropriate steps are taken to get DCED to consider this
'self-liquidating debt,' so it's excluded from the township's borrowing base,"
Riedlinger said.

Riedlinger explained that the township has a limit on how much it can borrow. He
said the township has two existing loans on purchase of capital equipment, and
in those cases the township has not exceeded its debt limit.

"But this loan, if it wasn't excluded from your debt limit, would exceed your
debt limit and you wouldn't be able to borrow any money for something you might
need," Riedlinger said. "The current guarantee that you made is excluded from
your borrowing base."

Edelman replied that a new self-liquidating report would need to be filed with
DCED, and that it is in the process of being completed by Entech Engineering,
the authority's consulting engineer.

Kessler asked about the costs involved, with Edelman explaining that expenses
will be paid through the sewer authority, including the time and expense that
Riedlinger would have in reviewing documents and other work.

In other business, the supervisors approved a request from Friendship Fire
Company, Englewood, to close Pine and Spring streets near the fire company for
the annual block party, which will be held until Monday.

___ (c)2015 the Republican & Herald (Pottsville, Pa.) Visit the Republican &
Herald (Pottsville, Pa.) at republicanherald.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                                Daily Times (PK)

                          September 24, 2011 Saturday

SBP committed to making banking services easy to access

LENGTH: 585 words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, Sept. 24 -- The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) is committed to using all
the possible means to make the banking services accessible to all segments of
the society.

Managing Director, SBP Banking Services Corporation, Qasim Nawaz at the two-day
banking exhibition at Gujranwala on Friday highlighted various initiatives taken
or being taken by the SBP to facilitate the underserved sectors of the economy
in the field of agriculture, SME and microfinance.

The ongoing review of policy and regulatory environment is to promote SME,
agriculture and micro finance as a viable and mainstream business activity for
banking industry.

SBP is also undertaking review of the existing Prudential Regulations for SME
Financing, to develop and separate PRs for "Small Enterprises" & "Medium
Enterprises. When implemented, this exercise would facilitate small enterprises'
access to bank credit and consequently raise their share in banks' loans).

Introduction of Credit Guarantee Scheme for Small & Rural Enterprises (CGS) to
share credit risk with banks (upto 40%) with the objective of increasing banks'
lending in neglected sectors/areas. Around 2,000 accounts have been issued
guarantee under CGS. An amount of Rs 925 million has been disbursed to small and
rural enterprises under CGS and SBP shares risk worth Rs 392.5 million with
commercial banks for their lending to this sector.

Introduction of Microfinance Credit Guarantee Facility for resolving liquidity
problems for microfinance banks/microfinance institutions. Ten MFBs/MFIs have
been provided funding facilities worth Rs 2.8 billion under the scheme by banks.

SBP BSC has provided guarantee cover of Rs 805 million for the lending by
commercial banks to MFB/MFIs.

Whereas introduction of refinance scheme for modernisation of SMEs, introduction
of refinance scheme for agriculture produce storage construction, crash training
programme for the SME and agriculture credit officers of banks. Special capacity
building programmes for MFBs/MFIs and Islamic banks are also in the pipeline,
launch of eCIB for MFIs to assess the credit worthiness and to avoid
over-indebtedness of small borrowers, establishment of SME, agri and
microfinance focus groups at BSC field offices across the country to strengthen
the consultative mechanism in policy formulation and implementation, initiation
of surveys and studies of different regions (furniture industry and rice husking
industry surveys of Gujranwala region are planned this year), development of
linkages with all the key stakeholders both at country level as well as the
district/region level to adopt a collaborative strategy to help/facilitate the
entrepreneurs and rural communities in accessing financial services from banks,
organising SME, micro, agri and Islamic seminars, workshops, exhibitions and
fairs in cities and rural areas in collaboration with banks, SMEDA, and
provincial agricultural, livestock departments to create awareness amongst the
stakeholders at grassroots level about financial services.

These studies will enable banks and SBP to make their policies, initiatives and
products more responsive to the market needs.

Qasim Nawaz expressed hope that the banking exhibition at Gujranwala would go a
long way in improving access to finance for the lower segment of the borrowers
of the region. Published by HT Syndication with permission from Daily Times. For
any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please
contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                         TendersInfo - Project Notices

                              May 16, 2014 Friday

Business Formation and Retention Revolving Loan Program

LENGTH: 394  words


Project Start : 6/1/2012
Project End : 12/31/2015
Project Number : OP121
Status : Active
Phase : Execution
Project Cost : $100,000
Department : Police, Public Works
Location : United States
Project Description
On a number of occasions the Redevelopment Authority has discussed the potential
benefits of creating a revolving loan program to assist with business formation
and retention in State College.

Revolving loan programs are frequently found in the tool box used by
redevelopment authorities that operate business assistance programs. Communities
of all sizes (e.g., Pittsburgh, Hermitage and Lock Haven) across the state
operate revolving loan funds for business development activities ranging from
brownfield reclamation to sustainable agricultural projects to advanced
technology programs to manufacturing facilities to service and retail business
development. From the revolving loan programs staff reviewed, it appeared that
those tied to manufacturing businesses were the most common. The CDICC and
SEDA-COG both operate revolving loan funds that focus mainly on manufacturing,
although other types of businesses are eligible. The program would be a
partnership of local lending institutions, the State College Redevelopment
Authority, and Downtown State College. The SBDC and CDICC would also be involved
in the program, lending their expertise as needed. We will particularly benefit
from the involvement of these organizations in the area of business plan
preparation. In discussions with our potential partners, we have looked at two
approaches    a loan guarantee approach and/or a gap financing approach. It
appears from review of revolving loan programs in other communities, the gap
financing approach is more common. In either case, the program would be
structured as a matching program where the level of public funding committed to
the program would match the level of funding committed by local banks in the
partnership. The specific details of the program have not been finalized.
However, the following program elements are common in revolving loan programs:
Project completion date : 2015-12-31 12:00:00
Major organization : BOROUGH OF STATE COLLEGE

Address : 243 South Allen Street,
State College, PA 16801-4806
United States

Country :United StatesCopyright © Euclid Infotech Pvt. Ltd. Provided by
SyndiGate Media Inc. (Syndigate.info).

                         TendersInfo - Project Notices

                             April 12, 2013 Friday

Libya-Jafara Co. for Food Production Project

LENGTH: 501  words


Project Start (Estimated) : 2013
Project End  (Estimated) : 2014
Project ID :     9441
Fiscal year :     2013
Status :     Active
Guarantee holder :     Inter MIMS Investment Limited
Investor country :     Mauritius
Host country :   Libya
Environmental category :     B
Sector :     Manufacturing
Date SPG disclosed :     July 06, 2012
Project Board date :     July 23, 2012
Gross exposure :      $9.8 million
Project type :     SIP
Strategic priority area :     South-South
Conflict Affected
Summaries of proposed guarantees are provided prior to Board consideration and
before final contract signing, and they are therefore subject to change. Project
briefs are disclosed after Board consideration and contract signing and reflect
the terms of the project at the time of contract signature. Environmental and
Social Review Summaries are provided for projects assigned an Environmental
Assessment Category of A or B.


This summary covers a shareholder loan from Inter MIMS Investment Limited of
Mauritius to Jafara Group Limited in Libya. The investor has applied for a MIGA
guarantee of up to $10 million for a period of up to 10 years against the risks
of transfer restriction, expropriation, and war and civil disturbance.
Jafara is a company involved in the production, bottling, and distribution of
drinking water and juice products in Libya. The company is now the fourth
largest manufacturer of juices in the Libyan market and has established two
Tetra Pak juice lines, a polyethylene terephthalate (PET) mineral water
production line, and canned fruit juices/sodas. Inter MIMS   shareholder loan
will support the expansion of Jafara  s production capacity. Planned
improvements include the construction of an additional warehouse, the purchase
of equipment for glass bottling, and a new air conditioning system for the
entire factory.
Environmental Categorization
The project is a category B under MIGA  s Policy on Social and Environmental
Sustainability as it has potentially limited adverse social or environmental
impacts. Key potential impacts include community and workers   health and safety
and pollution mitigation. The potential impacts are largely reversible and
readily addressed through mitigation measures. The company has provided a Social
and Environmental Assessment Report in line with MIGA  s Performance Standards.

Development Impact
The project  s key development impacts include the addition of new permanent
jobs, (158 staff employed by the project in total), taxes paid to the government
after the expiration of the tax holiday, and significant local sourcing. Inputs
sourced in the local market include sugar, pre-forms, caps, cartons, stretch
folio, pallets, and glue. The company estimates that it spends   6.5 million
yearly in the purchase of local goods and services. In addition, Jafara provides
free water and juice to local hospitals and schools.

This project will also have an important catalyzing effect for foreign di

country :Mauritius
Ltd.

                              889 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                This Day (Lagos)

                                October 30, 2012

FCMB, Citibank Sign U.S.$20 Million Loan Deal to Boost Lending

BYLINE: Obinna Chima

LENGTH: 460 words


First City Monument Bank Plc (FCMB) has secured a $20 million, three-year term
loan from Citigroup Global Markets Limited (Citi), to support Small and Medium
Enterprises (SMEs) customers of FCMB.

A statement from Citibank Nigeria Monday explained that the facility was
supported through a partial guarantee from the Overseas Private Investment
Corporation (OPIC) and would be channelled towards lending to SME customers of
FCMB that had been identified.

It further described the deal as a "pioneering OPIC SME Loan Guaranty Facility
in Nigeria and will provide significant employment opportunities within the SME
sector of the economy."

OPIC is an agency of the United States government that mobilises private capital
to help solve critical developmental challenges and catalyse revenues, jobs and
growth opportunities in emerging markets. OPIC achieves its mission by providing
financing and political risk insurance.

Citibank acted as the Sole Arranger and Facility Agent on the deal.

Group Managing Director/Chief Executive Officer, FCMB, Mr. Ladi Balogun, was
quoted to have described the transaction as an innovative collaboration between
Citi and FCMB.

Balogun said: "By implication of the size of the loan, we will be deploying it
towards the SME segment of our customer base. Most importantly, this is an
indication of the growing confidence the international community has in the
Nigerian financial sector following the reforms initiated by the Central Bank of
Nigeria.

"No doubt the sector's risk rating and the country's sovereign rating will
continue to improve to the benefit of the financial sector and the economy at
large. We will be applying these funds towards our underserved SMEs.

"This underserved sector, is absolutely critical to growth and employment in our
economy, will benefit from greater access to competitively priced funds such as
this. FCMB is pleased not only to have received these funds but also to continue
its supportive role in the growth and development of SMEs in Nigeria," he added.

On his part, Executive Director/ Corporate Bank Head for Citi Nigeria, Omar
Hafeez, said the structure of the deal demonstrates Citi's singular focus on
delivering client solutions.

According to Hafeez, the transaction would not only help FCMB to diversify and
strengthen its funding base, but also directly impact on the Nigerian economy.

Citibank's outgoing Managing Director, Mr. Emeka Emuwa, who was also present at
the event, reflected on Citi's long-standing relationship with FCMB and
commended the entire team on a successful outcome.

FCMB, a full service banking group, recently completed the acquisition of former
FinBank. On the other hand, Citi has approximately 200 million customer accounts
and does business in more than 140 countries.

LOAD-DATE: October 30, 2012

                              890 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                      June 4, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Deal in works to save mill, Kapuskasing mayor says

BYLINE: By Rick Haliechuk Toronto Star

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C2

LENGTH: 393 words


A deal to save 1,200 jobs at a pulp and paper mill in Kapuskasing is in the
works, says the mayor of the Northern Ontario town.

Ted Jewell announced yesterday that employees of Spruce Falls Power and Paper
Corp. and other town residents have pledged $ 13.1 million toward the upgrading
of the mill.

"The people have shown their intent to grab hold of their destiny," Jewell said
in a telephone interview.

The paper mill is jointly owned by Kimberly-Clark Corp. of Dallas and The New
York Times Co.

They've offered to transfer ownership of the plant to the employees at no
charge, but the employees would have to find the money necessary to upgrade and
modernize the facility.

Kimberly-Clark and The New York Times also want to sell their Smoky Falls
electrical generating station, 80 kilometres from the paper mill.

The offer to the employees expires June 30 and is contingent on Ontario Hydro
acquiring the power plant for $ 133.6 million.

Hydro agreed to buy the facility in 1989, provided the power plant received
environmental assessment approval from the provincial government, which is still
pending.

Jewell said his community's business plan for the paper mill will be put to the
Ontario government on Thursday.

The community is hoping to receive grants, loans and loan guarantees from
Queen's Park and Ottawa of as much as $ 70 million toward the modernization
costs.

Jewell said he's confident the NDP government will do the right thing.

He said that 1,198 employees of Spruce Falls have written letters, indicating a
willingness to contribute a total of just over $ 8 million toward the deal;
another 750 residents of Kapuskasing and the area have agreed to plunk down a
total of just over $ 5 million.

Asked how a community of only 10,834 people could find a total of $ 13.1 million
among them, Jewell replied: "Not now and not in the past has Kapuskasing been a
poor community; the wages here have traditionally been good."

A spokesperson for Ontario Hydro said there was nothing new to announce from
Hydro's point of view. Hydro is still waiting for environmental assessment
approval from the government, he said.

Kimberly-Clark chairman Darwin Smith said yesterday if no deal is reached by
June 30, his firm will begin issuing layoff notices to 1,200 of the 1,450
employees now working at Spruce Falls.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                The Toronto Star

                      June 4, 1991, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Deal in works to save mill, Kapuskasing mayor says

BYLINE: By Rick Haliechuk Toronto Star

SECTION: BUSINESS TODAY; Pg. C2

LENGTH: 400 words


   A deal to save 1,200 jobs at a pulp and paper mill in Kapuskasing is in the

                              Daily The Pak Banker

                              May 3, 2016 Tuesday

New facility to be able to generate up to US$800 million in concessional loans

LENGTH: 194 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 WASHINGTON: Under a package, new facility will be able to generate up to US$800
million in concessional loans in the next year. Eight nations and the European
Commission pledged a package of more than US$1 billion to a World Bank-led
financing initiative in support of Syrian refugees and host communities in
Jordan and Lebanon, as well as recovery and reconstruction across the region.





 The package includes-- US$141 million in grants, US$1 billion in soft loans and
US$500 million in guarantees. Japan, France, the United Kingdom, the United
States, Germany, Canada, the Netherlands, Norway and the European Commission
each pledged their initial financial contributions to the New Financing
Initiative to Support the Middle East and North Africa Region.



 The pledging occurred at a ministerial conference co-chaired by the President
of the World Bank Group, the Secretary General of the United Nations and the
President of the Islamic Development Bank Group. The conference brought together
ministers from G7, Gulf Cooperation Council, European and MENA countries, as
well as the heads of various multilateral development banks and international
organizations.

                               Right Vision News

                            July 17, 2013 Wednesday

Pakistan: KPK Govt announces mega projects for youth

LENGTH: 645 words

DATELINE: PESHAWAR


PESHAWAR, July 17 -- The Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) government has planned seven
development schemes for motivation and uplift of youth by focusing on
construction of district youth centres, stipend for jobless and launching of
skill development programme to make best use of their potential.

To provide career counselling and recreational facilities to youth, the Pakistan
Tahirk-e-Insaf led government has decided to construct District Youth Centers
(DYC) at divisional headquarters through community driven development
initiatives for organising sports events, youth mobilization, awareness
campaigns.

An official of Finance Department Monday said that Youth Marakaz will be
established in the existing government buildings on patterns of universities and
colleges to fully tap their hidden talent. He said work on these projects would
be initiated in current fiscal year costing Rs 70 million.

He said a stipend for unemployed youth scheme is also being initiated under
which Rs 2,000 per month would be provided to the fresh masters degree holders
of 2013-14, adding Rs 500 million has been allocated in the budget for this
purpose.

In addition to establishment of Technology Up-gradation and Skill Development
Company (TUSDEC) costing Rs 150 million, he said the government has planned to
launch Youth Skill Development (YSDP) Programme under which the government will
bear the training charges as well provide stipend to students aged 18-25, who
undergoes technical training.

Youth Challenge Fund (YCF) is also being established to encourage local
entrepreneurship in the province with Rs 2 million seed money for 50 top
business proposals prepared by young business planning youth that would be
assessed through a transparent system of competition, adding Rs 120 million has
been allocated in the budget.

The government will initiate sports facilities for youth to promote healthy
co-curricular activities in the province.Under this scheme, he said, sports
equipment/items would be provided to high schools with playground facility with
allocation of Rs 100 million for current fiscal year in the budget.

Khud Kifalat interest free scheme is also being initiated in KP according to
which an interest free loan of Rs 50,000 to 200,000 will be provided to bonafide
residents of this province in the age range of 18 to 50 years.

He said the loan shall be secured through personal guarantee by two guarantors
and Rs 2.7 billion has been allocated for this purpose during 2013-14.

Madrasa interest free micro finance credit scheme has been planned under which
an interest free loan of Rs 25,000 to 50,000 shall be extended to Madaris in 12
backward districts to be selected on the basis of credible survey and a sum of
Rs 1 billion has been allocated for this purpose during 2013-14.

Ranrra solar energy initiative loan is also being launched under which a loan
upto Rs 30 million on 7% markup for a period of 6 years with 1 year grace period
shall be granted to bonafide residents of KP, upto 60 years age for the
establishment of employment oriented businesses in the province with debt-equity
ratio of 60:40.

The loan shall be recovered in quarterly instalments and Rs 300 million has been
allocated for this purpose in the budget.

Under the Community Driven Local Development programme, he said a policy and
governance framework for community driven local development is being adopted by
the government of KP under which funds would be directly transferred to the
village based organisations/councils that would be monitored through strict
system of performance audit.

The EU has allocated Rs 1 billion and counterpart funds of Rs 500 million shall
be provided by government of KP

                                Matlock Mercury

                                October 3, 2007

Village store calls for aid

LENGTH: 337  words


A VILLAGE store which is owned by the community is appealing for people to help
secure its long-term future.

Winster Village Shop was bought by the village in 2005, but it was known that
the building's structure needed significant investment.

The shop's management needs to find £80,000 from grants, loans and donations in
order to fund scheduled improvements including a new stock room and kitchen.

Chairman of the Winster Village Shop Association, David Mitchell, said: "The
main problems with the shop are that there are no staff facilities other than a
condemned outside loo, the warehouse is very damp, the electrics need rewiring
and the ceiling is collapsing.

"If we are to compete with Sainsbury in Matlock, or rather survive alongside, we
have to differentiate ourselves with more fresh product, local product and
additional services to suit residents and tourists alike.

"The work will be done in three phases to ensure that one way or another the
shop will continue trading to meet the needs of the community.

"We have a grant of £20,000 and are actively seeking more grants, loans and
donations from the country at large, local businesses and local residents.

"We will gain, in simple terms, a larger, well-fitted shop with excellent
support facilities that can trade successfully in Winster without further
investment for the foreseeable future."

The shop is a company limited by guarantee, meaning every resident of Winster
and Elton over the age of 18 is an owner of the shop and has a vote at its AGM.

Work has already begun on the first phase of improvements, involving the
demolition and rebuilding of a warehouse with staff facilities and a prep
kitchen.

Later phases will see refitting of ceilings, and installation of new equipment
and electrics.

It is hoped the works and increased floor space could also create a further two
part time jobs for local people.

Future profits of the shop will be distributed for the good of the community.

If you can help to support the project, contact David Mitchell on 01629 650220.

LOAD-DATE: October 3, 2007

                              897 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                        The Legal Ledger (St. Paul, MN)

                                 March 2, 2009

Washington aims to boost business investment by sweetening terms on SBA lending
programs

BYLINE: Mark Anderson

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 902  words


The giant economic-stimulus legislation that became law Feb. 17 included among
its imposing allocations for highways, renewable energy and schools a $730
million pool aimed at boosting investments in the nation's small businesses.

That provision, a small piece of the overall $789 billion package, will make it
cheaper and less risky for business owners and banks to take part in Small
Business Administration (SBA) loan programs, which have driven much of the
nation's small business investment in recent years.

The SBA initiative will lower borrower fees and increase the portion of each
loan that the government guarantees. It also provides a new temporary loan fund
to help current SBA borrowers stay on top their payments at a time when their
receipts are probably declining.

Those new tools should add fuel to a Minnesota market that slowed dramatically
in the past 15 months, according to two of the top community bank SBA lenders in
the state.

One of the biggest contributors to the slump here was the loss of wealth that
most would-be borrowers experienced - whether through erosion in their home
equity values or losses in 401(k)s and other savings. Those provided much of the
collateral that enabled lenders to underwrite small business loans.

"In the past, those personal assets gave us comfort, but those numbers are down
now," said Kim Storey, a senior vice president and SBA manager at Highland Bank.
In that situation, "the new higher loan guarantees [raised to 90 percent from
75-80 percent in the past] will gives us some added comfort" and make more loans
possible, she said.

The other major SBA initiative in the package is a promise to temporarily reduce
or eliminate fees that borrowers pay when they obtain a loan. Those fees range
now from 1 percent of the loan amount on small credits up to 3.75 percent on a
portion of loans greater than $1 million. Such existing fee structures add more
than $28,000 to the cost of a $1 million loan.

"Those could be wrapped into the loan payments, but they're still pretty
significant costs," and contributed to the slowdown in borrowing in these tight
times, said John Kimball, senior vice president at Park Midway Bank in St. Paul.
"Lowering those fees will help customers. "

The new fee structure hasn't been finalized yet, so lenders and borrowers aren't
sure of the savings. But Edward Daum, director of the Minnesota district, said
the agency has expedited a process that normally takes months to run through
industry and agency reviews, and he said the SBA will finalize the program soon,
getting those better terms out to borrowers quickly.

The SBA component of the stimulus also provided $255 million for small
"stabilization" loans so that current borrowers could keep making their loan
payments; it added $30 million to expand a micro-lending program for very small
startup businesses; and it created a new opportunity to refinance loans for
fixed assets to help owners expand current projects.

Small business lending markets, like every other credit market, slowed
dramatically in the past 15 months, declining by 60 percent nationally during
the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, and agency representatives said the
slump continued this year.

The value of Minnesota SBA loans in fiscal 2008 dropped by 12 percent in fiscal
2008, but even that was well above national trends.

One reason national activity dropped so much faster was that big, non-bank
lenders dominate many state markets, but not Minnesota. Those lenders obtain
funds by securitizing their loans and selling them to large investors. But like
most secondary loan markets, demand for SBA loan pools also dried up last year,
leaving those large lenders with little cash to lend after early in 2008.

The stimulus package included a small investment in strengthening the secondary
market for SBA 504 or real estate loans, and the Treasury department is working
on a plan to boost the rest of the secondary market with investments from the
Term Asset-backed Securities Loan Facility, or TALF.

In Minnesota, the remedies will come primarily through the fee and guarantee
enhancements, but those steps should deliver another boost by restoring
confidence among lenders and borrowers, Kimball and Storey agreed.

"The package gives a clear demonstration that this administration supports the
SBA program, and that's something we haven't had for a while," Kimball said.
"This is definitely building bankers' confidence in the SBA. "

And it should have a similar effect on borrowers, Storey believes: "There's a
perception in the business community that there's a hump to get over in the
economy, and I think the stimulus package will help us get there. "

Both lenders expect all those factors to translate into an alright year for
their SBA shops.

"We think we'll book more loans this year than last year," when Highland
originated almost $2 million in SBA loans, Storey said. "There's some slowdown
in demand, but that doesn't include everybody. We have existing customers who
are looking at expansions, and we're looking at three or four that should close
in the first quarter. "

"We're cautiously optimistic," Kimball said about Park Midway's SBA prospects
this year. He added that the 504 program has been busy, filling a gap left by
weakness in the conventional commercial real estate market.

"We think we'll be steady" with last year, when Park Midway originated more than
$12 million in SBA loans.

LOAD-DATE: March 3, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Government activity

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2009 Dolan Media Newswires
                              All Rights Reserved


                              898 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                      Finance & Commerce (Minneapolis, MN)

                            February 27, 2009 Friday

Stimulus: Government efforts include $730 million to boost small business
investment

BYLINE: Mark Anderson

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 907  words


The giant economic-stimulus legislation that became law Feb. 17 included among
its imposing allocations for highways, renewable energy and schools a $730
million pool aimed at boosting investments in the nation's small businesses.

That provision, a small piece of the overall $789 billion package, will make it

loan that the government guarantees. It also provides a new temporary loan fund

receipts are probably declining.

And it should have a similar effect on borrowers, Storey believes: "There's a
perception in the business community that there's a hump to get over in the
economy, and I think the stimulus package will help us get there. "

Both lenders expect all those factors to translate into an alright year for
their SBA shops.

"We think we'll book more loans this year than last year," when Highland
originated almost $2 million in SBA loans, Storey said.   "There's some slowdown
in demand, but that doesn't include everybody. We have existing customers who
are looking at expansions, and we're looking at three or four that should close
in the first quarter. "

"We're cautiously optimistic," Kimball said about Park Midway's SBA prospects
this year.   He added that the 504 program has been busy, filling a gap left by
weakness in the conventional commercial real estate market.

"We think we'll be steady" with last year, when Park Midway originated more than
$12 million in SBA loans.

LOAD-DATE: March 3, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Financing

                               Right Vision News

                             August 6, 2012 Monday

Pakistan: On a turn in fate and lives

LENGTH: 598 words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, Aug. 6 -- For 23-year-old Fouzia Mai, life had held little dreams
except a domestic routine at her village Aziz Abad, Fazilpur, District Rajanpur,
where she resides with her parents and younger siblings.

But the devastating floods of 2010 changed all that in a flash. Her family lost
everything, including a roof over their heads. With her father being the sole
bread earner of the family - he works for a goods forwarding agency - Fouzia's
family found themselves in a bleak situation.

The natural calamity that struck the region in the year 2010 had a deep and
profound impact on the lives of thousands of people across the country; however,
Fouzia was determined to fight the odds. "Since my father did not have any
technical qualification to earn a livelihood, I decided that it was up to me to
earn a living for the family," she says.

With only middle school education, Fouzia was wise enough to understand the
corporate world would not be kind on her. Knowing the art of embroidery, she
utilised this skill to lend a helping hand to her family.

But even the smallest and most basic of business needs money. A neighbour told
her about the Khushhalibank Micro loan facility. "I took a loan of Rs15,000 from
the bank on August 1, 2011. This was a monthly installment based loan with group
guarantee and now, one year forward, I am in the second loan cycle," she says.

With the help of this facility, Fouzia was able to purchase a sewing machine and
unstitched cloth to start her own stitching business. The young girl who used to
earn a meager Rs3,000-Rs3,500 per month from her stitching was suddenly seeing a
potential to grow.

She found that there was demand for her embroidery from her neighbouring
localities and the local people were willing to pay for her designs. "I operate
from home on my sewing machine and I make approximately six to seven pieces of
clothes every month," she says.

Fouzia has been able to make around Rs30,000 per month in the very first loan
cycle, which speaks volumes for her hard work and commitment.

Having successfully initiated her own venture she is not only financially able
to support her parents but her siblings are also now enrolled in proper schools.
She also plans to further pursue her education following the success of her
business so she can climb the ladder of success with the help of further
education.

Having done well so far has made Fouzia ambitious. Now she is looking to
purchase or rent new machines after which she would employ a few women to help
her with stitching work and embroidery.

Her aim is to be able to make a name for herself in Pakistan through her
embroidery work and also introduce it in the international markets. Furthermore,
she plans to open up a training center for women of her community who can come
in and learn the art of stitching and embroidery.

"Through honing their skills they would be able to embark upon the road to
self-sufficiency. The community involvement would engage young girls of my
locality that would enable them to become empowered through learning the skill,"
she says.

Moreover, Fouzia would earn additional revenue from running these community
centers and the productivity of her work would also increase significantly. "I
hope I can be a role model for other girls who lost everything in natural
calamities like I did. This one year has been like a dream come true for me,"
she concludes Published by HT Syndication with permission from Right Vision
News. For any query with respect to this article or any other content
requirement, please contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

LOAD-DATE: August 21, 2012

                              900 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              The Financial Daily

                             October 2, 2015 Friday

Banks have started Value Chain schemes

BYLINE: Mohammed Arifeen

LENGTH: 1322  words


Value Chain Contract Farmer Financing schemes are broadly defined as binding
arrangements between banks and agri. value chain actors including producers,
processors, aggregators, traders through which a farmer or group of farmers
ensures supply of agricultural products to individual firms. It replaces the
traditional collateral requirements with trade agreements by facilitating
coordinated commercial relations between value chain actors.

Agricultural value chain finance permits lending institutions such as banks to
diversify their investment portfolio. In essence, agricultural value chain
financing acts as a catalyst for driving economic growth in rural areas. It
helps to increase household incomes for a large proportion of the population,
and results in poverty reduction and guaranteed food security. It helps women,
who account for the major part of production but who often do not own the
traditional collateral (land) on which banks tend to rely, to raise finance on
the back of their ability to supply into a value chain.

The State Bank of Pakistan has introduced a 'Value-Chain Contract Farmer
financing' scheme to build liaison between banks and small farmers who have no
access to formal financing. The SBP circulated among banks elaborate guidelines
about what the scheme is all about and how it has to be implemented. Bankers say
the scheme is, by and large, practical. Under this scheme, farmers can avail
themselves of bank financing using processors' guarantees. In return, they will
make sure that the processors or buyers get the required quantity of a crop or
any other agricultural produce.

State Bank of Pakistan on amended the guidelines for value chain contract farmer
financing. According to SBP AC and MFD Circular Letter No 01 0f 2015 issued on
January 2, 2014, in order to encourage banks to lend to individual farmers,
"corporate guarantee" has been added to the eligible securities/collateral
(under section 4.8) of the value chain contract farmer financing guidelines.

Successful adoption of the guidelines will improve depth and spectrum of
agri-financing to escalate rural household incomes and economic growth of the
country.SBP has advised banks to use the guidelines for developing their own
products for providing credit to contract farmers particularly to those who lack
collateral to offer to the bank.

It has issued Guidelines on Value Chain Contract Farmer Financing to encourage
banks to extend credit to small and marginalized farmers by leveraging on the
strengths of interrelationships that exist in the agriculture value chain. These
guidelines will serve as a basis for banks to develop mutually beneficial
relationship between the banks, farmers and the value-chain agent.

To bring more clarity in the related instructions, a few amendments have also
been made to section 4.8 of the guidelines. As per new guidelines on
securities/collateral (Section 4.8): Under contract financing scheme, banks may
provide unsecured financing up to a maximum of Rs 1,000,000 to individual farmer
as per prudential regulation No R4 of agriculture financing.

In case, a bank intends to secure its financing facility to farmer, it may
obtain security/collateral from a lead firm who can be a processor, input
supplier, stockiest, marketing company, trader, exporter, etc. The same
security/collateral may also be used by banks for securing their marketing loan
provided to the lead firm for meeting their short terms/seasonal financing
requirement.

The introduction of value chain contract farmer financing scheme will enable
farmers to avail financing from banks backed by processor's guarantee and in
return buyers/processors may get assurance of getting required quantity and
quality of agricultural produce. The guidelines have introduced five instruments
including Trader Credit, Input Supplier Credit, Marketing Company Credit, Lead
Firm Credit and Arthi or Intermediary, besides identifying roles  and
responsibilities of stakeholders, financing mechanism, eligibility criteria,
types of financing, loan limits, security  and  collateral, insurance and loan
monitoring mechanism.

Small farmers with up to 5 acre land holding constitute 65 percent or 5.4
million as against 8.3 million farm households in the country. Therefore, SBP,
in line with government's efforts to promote access to finance to small farmers,
is working on a number of initiatives that include credit guarantee scheme for
small  and  marginalized farmers, crop  and  livestock insurance and warehouse
receipt financing.

After the launch of agricultural valuechain financing last October, banks have
begun using this tool to boost their risk-mitigated lending to the agriculture
sector. The bulk of value-chain financing is used in crop-growing and animal
farming, as it is easier for banks classify value-chain partners and commodity
or input suppliers who act as guarantors for the farmers.

Although banks are encouraged to make long-term loans, they are currently
focused on making short-term loans. Such loans get repaid in installments as and
when the growers sell their crops. Bankers say these are making the value chain
financing attractive for them and this is why commercial and microfinance banks
are using it actively.

They are using value-chain financing in lending operations such as trader
credit, input supplier credit, marketing company credit and lead firm credit
Value chain financing has not grown fast and is creating lot of problems.
Bankers say obtaining the right information about farmers through VCPs or
suppliers is not that easy. It is anticipated that the guideline would benefit
farmers in terms of enhanced productivity in variety of ways such as availing
quality input facilities, adopting new technologies, insurance coverage for
crop/non-crop activities and most importantly assurance of buyer in advance.

Many sugar and tobacco mills and a number of companies like Rafhan Maize,
Nestle, Engro Foods, Shan Foods, National Foods and Lays etc currently provide
inputs and transportation facilities to selected farmers who, in return, sell
their respective produce (tobacco, sugar, maize, wheat, rice or potatoes etc) to
them. Under the value chain financing, banks are participating in such
activities as financiers or cofinanciers.

According to the SBP, the value chain financing was one of several factors that
lead to a phenomenal 38 percent year-over-year growth in gross agricultural
lending in fiscal year 2015. Bankers say they can use the valuechain financing
scheme in four main categories of lending operations i.e. trader credit, input
supplier credit, marketing company credit and lead firm credit.

The scheme has also laid down a procedure for banks to benefit from the
centuries-old institution of Arthi, or intermediary. Banks can establish
contacts with the Arthi and use his services to identify a genuine borrower,
correctly assess his borrowing need, ensure proper utilisation of loan and
facilitate and manage the borrower's cash-flow by binding him to sell his
produce through the Arthi.

The value chain financial scheme also envisages a system for banks to use an
arthi, or an intermediary for advancing value-chain loans. Banks are allowed to
use the services of the arthis and to identify genuine borrowers, correctly
assess their borrowing needs, ensure proper utilisation of the loans, and
facilitate and manage the borrowers' cash flows by binding them to sell their
produce through the arthis.

But bankers say establishing contacts with reputable arthis has proved more
difficult. The value chain finance scheme is ideal for arthis because they can
earn profits by selling the growers' agricultural produce without lending any
money to them (as this job has now taken over by a bank).

It is seen reputable arthis are not showing much interest in the scheme,
particularly in Sindh, whereas those whose credentials are not well-established
are eager to do business with banks.

LOAD-DATE: October 2, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                    November 1, 2001 Thursday, Final Edition

SCHOOL REPAIRS, SAFETY AT STAKE IN QUESTION 4;
Schools lacking facilities for essential programs may also get money from the
state's revolving loan fund.

BYLINE: TESS NACELEWICZ Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL & STATE; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 605 words


Voters who want safe, healthy schools for Maine's schoolchildren should support
a $15 million state borrowing request that would help finance repairs and
improvements to public school buildings, according to the chairwoman of the
State Board of Education.

Question 4 on the state ballot Tuesday is a $15 million bond issue for the
state's revolving renovation loan fund. Money from the fund goes to local
municipalities to repair and renovate school buildings, particularly those with
problems relating to health and safety.

Schools that lack facilities for essential programs also may get money from the
fund for such projects as adding science labs, said the board chairwoman, Jean
Gulliver.

"It certainly touches a lot of communities and addresses a great number of
needs," Gulliver said of the fund.

She said about 170 school buildings statewide have been helped by the fund,
which the state started three years ago to assist communities in renovating
school buildings in disrepair. Prior to that time, communities could only get
state funding when they constructed new schools, Gulliver said.

"We didn't really have a vehicle to address renovation needs," she said.

The Legislature in previous years dedicated $70 million from the state surplus
to the fund, but that money has either been spent or is already dedicated to
specific school projects, so more is needed, Gulliver said.

"If we're going to continue with this program that's been tremendously
successful, we need to continue this funding," Gulliver said. "I think the
important thing to remember is that this money is broadly used around the state
and it helps local communities with costs that are otherwise going to be borne
entirely locally."

Portland is one of the districts that may benefit from the fund, said state Rep.
Glenn Cummings, D-Portland.

The Portland School Department is already planning to apply to the fund to help
pay for the site work for a modular village of classrooms it proposes building
on Munjoy Hill to house some displaced Jack Elementary School students. That
school was permanently closed in August because of a toxic mold, and its nearly
300 students are attending school in a converted office building.

Cummings said some of Portland's 11 other elementary schools, which are aging
and need repair or renovation, also may qualify for money from the fund.
Cummings stressed there's no guarantee that Portland will get a share of the
money if voters approve this bond issue, because schools have to meet specific
state criteria to qualify for the loans. However, he said, "the larger the pot,
the more likely that Portland can benefit."

State Board of Education member James Rier said the fund monies initially went
to schools with health and safety problems, but as the backlog of such schools
has shrunk, money can now go to schools that need to address learning space
upgrades.

Gulliver said that local communities must provide matching funds for the loans.
The repayment requirements for the loans depend on the level of other state aid
a school district receives, she said.

In addition to the $15 million bond issue Maine voters are being asked to
approve this Election Day, there will be another $15 million bonding request to
voters next November to finance the fund, Rier said.

If approved, that would bring the total state monies committed to the fund to
$100 million, a figure that was recommended by the governor's School Facilities
Commission. Rier was chairman of that panel.

Staff Writer Tess Nacelewicz can be contacted at 791-6367 or at:

tnacelewicz@pressherald.com

LOAD-DATE: November 1, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Election 2001: State Referendum

                 Copyright 2001 Blethen Maine Newspapers, Inc.


                              904 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                         Spokesman Review (Spokane, WA)

                             May 20, 2004 Thursday
                                 Idaho Edition

National/World Briefly

BYLINE: wire reports (Compiled from)

SECTION: A; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 584 words


ARMY ORDERS SCRUTINY OF AFGHANISTAN CAMPS

Washington

The commander of U.S. forces in Afghanistan ordered a "top to bottom" assessment
of American prison camps in the country Wednesday, saying he wanted assurances
that facilities are adequate and that detainees are being treated in accordance
with the Geneva Convention.

Army Lt. Gen. David Barno ordered the probe as top U.S. military commanders
faced congressional scrutiny over the prison abuse scandal in Iraq. Barno said
he would appoint a U.S. general to undertake the Afghanistan review to ensure
that "internationally accepted standards of handling detainees are being met"
and that staffing is adequate to the job.

It is the third investigation announced by U.S. officials in Afghanistan in the
past week. Last week, two investigations were begun into individual complaints
by former detainees.

LEGISLATION RAISES VA HOME LOAN GUARANTEE

Washington

Members of a House committee said they hope to improve homeownership for
veterans facing an increasingly expensive housing market.

The House Veterans Affairs Committee approved bills Wednesday that would
increase from $60,000 to $83,425 the amount of money the federal government is
liable for in the event of a payment default on a home loan.

The current VA home loan guarantee was set in 2001. Lawmakers said the increase
helps bring the amount in line with current home prices. The legislation also
allows the guarantee to automatically increase as home prices rise without need
for additional congressional action.

The bill proceeds to the full House.

Also Wednesday, the committee: approved legislation to eliminate a requirement
that nurses who work for VA have bachelor's degrees; to drop a requirement that
the undersecretary of health be a medical doctor; and to update veterans job
training programs and create new ones.

RADIO SYSTEM AT BASE JAMMING GARAGE DOORS

Eglin Air Force Base,Fla.

A new military radio system is jamming remote-control garage doors in
communities near this Florida Panhandle base.

During testing last week of the $5.5 million two-way radio system at Eglin,
homeowners in Niceville, Valparaiso and the Crestview area reported that their
garage door openers failed to work.

Air Force officials said Tuesday the contractor, Motorola Inc., will try to
minimize the problem. Technicians will run the system at slightly different
frequencies from those used by garage door openers when another test is
conducted Friday through Monday.

"I want my garage door opener to work, too," said Col. Russell F. Miller,
commander of the 96th Communication Group.

Lauren Van Wazer, a spokeswoman for the Federal Communication Commission, said
if the Air Force has been running the system within its licensed frequencies -
the Air Force said it has - then users of garage door openers may have to change
theirs.

NANNIES CALLING FOR DOMESTIC BILL OF RIGHTS

New York

Normally, they watch other people's children, but today many local nannies are
heading to Central Park sans strollers to demand a living wage of at least $14
an hour plus health insurance and fringe benefits.

The event is an attempt to win public support for a "domestic workers bill of
rights" to raise the status and compensation levels of an occupation that
employs about 800,000 women statewide.

The charter of rights is included in a state legislative bill that would mandate
overtime pay, paid holidays and sick leave as well as 12 weeks of time off when
a full-time nanny gives birth or adopts a child.

TYPE: Briefs

LOAD-DATE: October 15, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                         Heppner Gazette-Times (Oregon)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 24, 2013

School children, USDA energize Earth Day

BYLINE: Heppner Gazette-Times staff

LENGTH: 475  words


Over the weekend, USDA Rural Development employees and several partner
organizations gave up their Saturday to celebrate Earth Day with elementary and
middle school-aged children at the Castle Rock farm worker housing complex in
Boardman, Oregon.

Volunteers from Energy Trust of Oregon, CASA of Oregon, Sustainable Agriculture
and Energy (SAGE) Center, Wind Turbine Industries Corporation, and Kardon
Construction joined USDA to lead a variety of interactive educational activities
about energy conservation and renewable energy alternatives.

"This event was a chance for USDA to join our community-based partners and
residents by celebrating environmentally friendly growth and development in
rural areas," said USDA State Director Vicki Walker, who joined in the
activities.

USDA Rural Development provided a $2.4 million loan to the Umatilla County
Housing Authority for the construction of Castle Rock Apartments, which opened
in September of 2012 to provide additional rental options for the many farm and
food processing workers who previously needed to commute long distances between
their jobs and adequate, affordable housing. The facility was constructed to
meet Earth Advantage Gold and LEED Platinum standards, featuring added
insulation to reduce heating and cooling costs, Energy Star appliances, low-flow
faucets and toilets and solar panels.

USDA Rural Development delivers more than 40 progratms that help rural
communities, businesses and residents develop infrastructure, improve housing
availability, and create jobs through a variety of economic development
activities.

"In all of our work, whether it's a new hospital, school, or a business
development, USDA strives to incorporate earth-friendly designs and innovative
energy solutions," Walker said.

In addition to support for rural housing and community facilities, USDA Rural
Development also provides grants and loan guarantees to help agricultural
producers and rural small businesses save energy and install renewables to save
money while reduc-reducing their overall carbon footprint. Last fiscal year,
USDA Rural development supported the installation of more than 1,600 renewable
energy facilities, including wind turbines, small hydropower generators,
geothermal systems, solar arrays, and anaerobic digesters across the country.

USDA has made a concerted effort to deliver results for the American people,
even as USDA implements sequestration the across-the-board budget reductions
mandated under terms of the Budget Control Act. USDA has already undertaken
historic efforts since 2009 to save more than $700 million in taxpayer funds
through targeted, common-sense budget reductions. These reductions have put USDA
in a better position to carry out its mission, while implementing sequester
budget reductions in a fair manner that causes as little disruption as possible.

LOAD-DATE: January 14, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Energy

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                       The Financial Express (Bangladesh)

                            March 31, 2016 Thursday

ADB to provide $40m loans, guarantees to four PCBs

LENGTH: 534 words

DATELINE: Bangladesh


Bangladesh, March 31 -- The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide loans and
guarantees involving US$40 million to four private commercial banks (PCBs) of
Bangladesh to support exporting and importing companies in the country,
including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). In this connection, the ADB
signed agreements with the four PCBs namely City Bank, Mutual Trust Bank, Pubali
Bank and Southeast Bank the ADB's Bangladesh Resident Mission Office in Dhaka on
Thursday, an ADB press release said. Deputy Country Director of ADB's Bangladesh
Resident Mission Oleg Tonkonojenkov, Acting Managing Director & CEO of City Bank
Faruq M Ahmed, Managing Director of Southeast Bank Shahid Hossain, Managing
Director & CEO of Pubali Bank Md Abdul Halim Chowdhury, Managing Director & CEO
of Mutual Trust Bank Anis A Khan and Head of the ADB's Trade Finance Programme
Steven Beck were present at the agreements signing ceremony. "Under these
agreements, ADB and our Bangladesh bank partners will provide loans and
guarantees to support exporting and importing companies in Bangladesh, including
small and medium-sized enterprises," the press statement said, quoting ADB's
Head of Trade Finance Steven Beck as saying.

"This agreement will help create economic growth and jobs," the ADB's head of
trade finance was also quoted as saying. The City Bank, Mutual Trust Bank and
Pubali Bank are all new banks joining the Trade Finance Programme, while
Southeast Bank-which is already part of the programme-has signed a new agreement
for a funded facility, it mentioned. Speaking on the occasion, the ADB's Trade
Finance Programme Relationship Manager for Bangladesh Edward Faber said
Bangladesh is a very active country under ADB's Trade Finance Programme. ADB's
TFP has had good experiences working with banks in Bangladesh and we are pleased
to be expanding our relationships and coverage here. We look forward to
continuing this trend, he mentioned. The programme has provided more than $2.2
billion in trade finance support in Bangladesh since 2009, through more than
1,400 transactions. With these latest agreements, the total number of banks
under TFP in Bangladesh will reach 15, according to the ADB. Backed by ADB's AAA
credit rating, the Trade Finance Programme provides guarantees and loans to over
200 partner banks to support trade, enabling more companies throughout Asia to
engage in import and export activities. With dedicated trade finance specialists
and a response time of 24 hours, the programme has established itself as a key
partner in the international trade community, providing fast, reliable, and
responsive support to fill gaps in the region's most challenging markets, it
said. Since 2009, the Trade Finance Programme has supported more than 7,000 SMEs
across the region, with about 10,000 transactions valued at over $20 billion, in
sectors ranging from commodities and capital goods, to medical supplies and
consumer goods, said the press statement. smajahangirfe@gmail.com

contact Editor at htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

Total Debt / Working Capital                           -         -         -
Total Debt / Total Assets                              -         -         -

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

Revision Date: May 16, 2016

   Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation provides a secondary market for
various loans made to borrowers primarily in the United States. It operates
through four segments: Farm & Ranch, USDA Guarantees, Rural Utilities, and
Institutional Credit. The Farm & Ranch segment purchases and retains eligible
mortgage loans that are secured by first liens on agricultural real estate;
securitizes eligible mortgage loans, and guarantees the timely payment of
principal and interest on securities representing interests in or obligations
secured by pools of eligible mortgage loans; and offers long-term standby
purchase commitments on designated eligible mortgage loans. The USDA Guarantees
segment purchases portions of certain agricultural, rural development, business
and industry, and community facilities loans guaranteed by the United States
Department of Agriculture (USDA). The Rural Utilities segment purchases and
guarantees securities that are backed by eligible rural electric and telephone
loans. The Institutional Credit segment purchases or guarantees general
obligations of lenders that are secured by pools of the types of loans eligible
for purchase under Farm & Ranch, USDA Guarantees, or Rural Utilities lines of
business. This segment also provides advances against eligible loans by
purchasing obligations secured by those loans. Federal Agricultural Mortgage
Corporation was founded in 1987 and is headquqrtered in Washington, District of
Columbia. BACKLOG, : Thous. $
2015.................0 2014.................0 2013.................0 EMPLOYEES-

                                 The Bond Buyer

New Bill Aims to Expand Bond Use in Enterprise Zones

                            April 16, 1996, Tuesday

By Joan Pryde



Rep. Tom Foglietta says he will introduce legislation today designed to increase
the use of tax-exempt bonds in enterprise zones, both to finance businesses and
to improve infrastructure in the areas.

Under the Pennsylvania Democrat's bill, the Department of Housing and Urban
Development would be authorized to use a combination of loan guarantees, grants,
and a revolving loan fund to finance infrastructure development projects in the
zones.

The loan guarantees "would give cities the ability to borrow funds in the bond
market more cheaply" for those projects, according to a description of the bill
released by Foglietta's office.

In addition, the measure would lift a key restriction on enterprise zone bonds,
which are exempt-facility bonds used to make loans to zone businesses. Under
current law, the amount of such bonds that can be used for any one business is
$20 million. Foglietta's bill would increase that amount to $40 million.

Foglietta's proposed changes, which include a number of other tax benefits,
would apply to all 104 enterprise zones created by Congress in 1993. They
include nine empowerment zones, which already have a wide array of tax benefits,
and 95 enterprise communities, which have few tax benefits other than the
ability to use enterprise zone bonds.

Although he is not a member of the House Ways and Means Committee, which handles
tax issues, Foglietta said he became interested in offering the legislation
because of the empowerment zone located in Philadelphia.

Foglietta said that while the Philadelphia zone and others have had a certain
amount of success in generating economic growth, the additional tax incentives
in his bill are needed to make the zones work better.

Prospects for Foglietta's bill are uncertain at best because tax- related
matters tend not to move through Congress on their own, but as part of a larger
tax package. Recently lobbyists have said that because Congress is preoccupied
with other issues, it is unlikely that tax lawmakers will turn their attention
to passing a tax package this year.

Foglietta's proposal contrasts with one offered by President Clinton as part of
the fiscal 1997 budget plan he presented in March. Clinton's proposal would
create 22 new empowerment zones and 80 enterprise communities. Tax-exempt bonds
issued by the 22 new empowerment zones would be exempt from the private-activity
volume cap and from the $20 million per-business limitation.

In addition, Clinton made some changes to the rules governing bonds for existing
zones. For example, he would lower from 80% to 50% the amount of business income
a bond-financed business would have to derive from activities within the zone.

SECTION: WASHINGTON; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 450 words

LOAD-DATE: April 15, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1996 The Bond Buyer, Inc.

                              Kirkintilloch Herald

                           January 23, 2013 Wednesday

Water tribute - club names boat after local hero

LENGTH: 299  words


A NEW boat for wheelchair users is to be named in memory of a devoted
councillor.

Caurnie Angling Club has purchased a wheelyboat' and built the necessary paths
and a ramp at Antermony Loch, in Milton of Campsie, to enable anglers in
weelchairs to fly-fish for trout.

The boat will be named The Charles Kennedy as a tribute to the dedicated Campsie
and Kirkintilloch North councillor who passed away on July 13 last year after a
long and courageous battle with cancer.

Roger Hughes, secretary of Caurnie Angling Club, said: "Charles was good to the
club and a great support. He said it was a great facility for the community.
Everyone knew him."

The club, in conjunction with the council's Criminal Justice Unit, obtained a
£10,000 grant from the Proceeds of Crime Fund for the project.

Roger added: "To ensure this new facility is fully utilised the club is asking
anyone using a wheelchair who is a fly-fisher or who is interested in taking up
the sport, to contact us for membership details.

"For those who have not fished before or do not have any fishing tackle, the
club can arrange instruction and the loan of equipment.

"We can't guarantee that you will always catch a  trout, but we can guarantee a
good time in beautiful surroundings, on your doorstep."

You can contact Roger by emailing roger.hughes15@ntlworld.com or call 0141 776
7134.
