                              951 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                             March 21, 2006 Tuesday

6 programs started to teach nurses

BYLINE: Bill Zlatos

LENGTH: 319 words


The Pennsylvania Higher Education Foundation has started six programs to teach
the next generation of nurses.

Because of a lack of qualified faculty, the state's nursing schools have been
forced to turn away applicants -- contributing to the nursing shortage in
Pennsylvania.

The Harrisburg-based foundation and the Leadership Council of the Pennsylvania
Center for Health Careers hopes these programs encourage nurses to return to
school, get graduate degrees and teach future nurses:

The Nurse Educator Loan Forgiveness Program forgives up to $50,000 of qualified
loan debt if the applicant works three to five years as a new nurse educator at
an approved Pennsylvania postsecondary nursing school.

The Graduate Nurse Education Grant Program gives scholarship money to graduate
nursing schools in the state. The money will be used to increase enrollment and
improve retention of students pursuing graduate degrees in nursing.

The Nurse Faculty Lines Program gives nonprofit nursing schools in the state
money to help pay for nursing facilities.

Supplemental Funding for Practical Nursing Programs allows Pennsylvania schools
to get additional scholarship money for their practical nursing students.

The Interim Student Loan Guarantee Program provides alternative loans to new
nursing schools, those trying to reopen and nursing schools providing
accelerated programs.

The Dr. McKenzie Scholarships for Disadvantaged Students still are being
developed. The awards are named in honor of the late Edna McKenzie, an educator
who served on the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency Board and the
foundation's board.

The foundation and the council will discuss the initiatives during a meeting at
3 p.m. today at the Boyce Campus of the Community College of Allegheny County,
595 Beatty Road, Monroeville.

For more information, call the foundation's office at 717-720-3961 or visit
www.FuturesInNursing.com.

LOAD-DATE: March 21, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                Copyright 2006 Tribune Review Publishing Company
                              All Rights Reserved


                              952 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                              April 8, 2013 Monday

Applications sought to promote rural economy

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 631 words


WASHINGTON - Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced Monday that
applications are being accepted from qualified non-profit and public
organizations (intermediaries) to provide loans to support rural businesses and
community development groups.

Funding, which is intended to spark business expansion and create jobs, will be
made available through USDA's Intermediary Relending Program. The announcement
is one part of the Department's efforts to strengthen the rural economy.

"This program is a part of the Obama Administration's ongoing effort to leverage
private investments with public funds to create jobs and expand economic
opportunity for rural entrepreneurs," Vilsack said. "Intermediaries serve as a
critical component to boosting local economies."

USDA Rural Development State Director Terry Brunner added, "This program has
been successful in leveraging private investments with public funds and expand
economic opportunity for rural entrepreneurs," Brunner said. "These loans will
continue to help small rural businesses grow, and create jobs."

Brunner is referring to a $400,000 loan that was made to the New Mexico Loan
Fund last fall which is using the funding to target ag-producers and small
businesses to fund renewable energy systems in communities such as Raton and in
Roswell. The rest of the funds will be used to provide sustainability to small
businesses in numerous small towns throughout the state.

The IRP is USDA Rural Development's primary program for capitalizing revolving
loan funds. USDA lends money to economic development intermediaries (nonprofits
and public bodies) who in turn re-lend the funds as commercial loans to rural
businesses (ultimate recipients) that might not otherwise be able to obtain such
financing. The repayment of the ultimate recipients' loans allows the
intermediary to continue to make more loans to new recipients, supporting
sustainable economic development. Since President Obama took office, the program
has created or saved an estimated 20,000 jobs.

Funds are used to assist with financing business and economic development
activity to create or retain jobs in disadvantaged and remote communities.
Intermediaries are encouraged to work with state and regional representatives
and in partnership with other public and private organizations that can provide
complimentary resources.

The USDA says that President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about
"historic investment and resulted in stronger rural communities."Under the
president's leadership, they say, the investments in housing, community
facilities, businesses and infrastructure have empowered rural America to
continue leading the way by strengthening America's economy, small towns and
rural communities.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, has an active portfolio of
more than $172 billion in loans and loan guarantees. These programs are designed
to improve the economic stability of rural communities, businesses, residents,
farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in rural America.

The USDA says it has made a concerted effort to deliver results for the American
people, even as USDA implements sequestration, the across-the-board budget
reductions mandated under terms of the Budget Control Act. USDA has already
undertaken efforts since 2009 to save more than $700 million in taxpayer funds
through targeted, common-sense budget reductions.

For more information about the Intermediary Relending Program, and to learn
about application deadlines, visit http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/BCP_irp.html. For
information on how to apply, see page 20883 of the April 8, 2013 Federal
Register (http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2013-04-08/html/2013-08186.htm).
Applications and forms may be obtained from any Rural Development State Office.

LOAD-DATE: April 9, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


          Copyright 2013 Deming Headlight, a MediaNews Group Newspaper
                              All Rights Reserved


                              953 of 998 DOCUMENTS


             Journal Record Legislative Report (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            March 18, 2009 Wednesday

Federal funding holds key to Tulsa-based Magellan Midstream Partners' ethanol
project

BYLINE: Kirby Lee Davis

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 522  words


A $3.5 billion ethanol pipeline may not proceed without federal funding, a
spokesman for Tulsa-based Magellan Midstream Partners said Monday.

On Monday, Magellan said the world's largest ethanol producer, Sioux Falls,
S.D.-based Poet, has joined the Tulsa company in a feasibility study for
building a 1,700-mile pipeline to connect Midwest producers with East Coast
users, representing one of the first major pipelines focusing on ethanol.

Poet replaced Buckeye Partners LP of Breinigsville, Pa., in the year-old project
that faces both financial and technical hurdles.

Pipeline construction has declined this year in all categories in the face of
tightening credit restrictions, declining fuel prices and onshore pipeline
construction costs averaging more than $3.3 million per mile, according to
reports by the Oil and Gas Journal.

"Federal financing, such as a federal loan guarantee, is necessary for the
project to proceed," said Magellan spokesman Bruce Heinz.

That could come in the form of House Resolution 864, amending the Energy Policy
Act of 2005 to provide loan guarantees for renewable-fuel pipeline construction.
That legislation is now before the U.S. House of Representatives.

"If Congress passes legislation which enhances the U.S. Department of Energy's
loan guarantee authority and we make a decision to proceed with the project, we
anticipate two years to obtain proper permits and an additional two years to
construct the pipeline system," said Heinz.

On the technical side, transported ethanol has been known to pick up water and
trailback from other products, forcing operators to block it from typical
batch-type pipelines. Ethanol transporters also have recorded stress corrosion
fractures along welds in carbon steel pipelines and tanks.

Magellan is working with the Association of Oil Pipelines in studying these
problems and others.

Association Director of Government Relations Raymond Paul said they have
received several encouraging results in ongoing research with the Pipeline
Research Council International and DNV/CC Technologies.

Despite falling commodity prices, the ethanol industry continues to grow. With
production hitting a record 9 billion gallons last year, the Renewable Fuels
Association projects ethanol output could rise to 10 billion gallons in 2009,
representing almost 9 percent of the U.S. gasoline supply.

Twenty plants remain under construction, joining the 170-plus now operating
across the nation, the RFA said in its 2009 annual report.

Buckeye pulled out of the construction project to focus on other priorities,
Magellan said Monday. Buckeye operates 5,400 miles of pipeline and 64 refined
petroleum products terminals.

Poet produces more than 1.5 billion gallons of ethanol per year from 26
production facilities in seven Midwestern states. It also markets 300 million
gallons for nine plants outside its network.

Poet Chief Executive Jeff Broin called the agreement with Magellan an important
step to boosting long-term transportation economics.

"A project of this nature would provide benefits throughout the ethanol
industry, agricultural community and the economy in general," he said.

LOAD-DATE: March 19, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: General news

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2009 Dolan Media Newswires
                              All Rights Reserved


                              954 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                             March 17, 2009 Tuesday

                              955 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                           Edmonton Journal (Alberta)

                            November 18, 2005 Friday
                                 Final Edition

Ottawa offers $2.8B aid for Arctic pipeline: Federal package would include loan
guarantees for native partners, aid for industry sponsors

BYLINE: Gordon Jaremko, The Edmonton Journal

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 667  words

DATELINE: EDMONTON


EDMONTON - The federal government lit a fire under the frozen Arctic natural gas
megaproject on Thursday by offering up to $2.8 billion in new aid.

A new target of Nov. 23 was set for a formal decision to advance the $7-billion
development into northern pipeline hearings and construction after Deputy Prime
Minister Anne McLellan unveiled the help.

Her offer includes $1.2 billion for the Mackenzie Gas Project's industry
sponsors and a $1.6-billion loan guarantee for their northern native partners in
the Aboriginal Pipeline Group.

"We're obviously pleased," project spokesman Pius Rolheiser said in an
interview. "Our concerns about fiscal terms have been largely addressed."

In outlining the aid package in a letter to project leader Imperial Oil Ltd.
McLellan wrote, "Let me be clear: The Government of Canada is not prepared to
subsidize construction of the Mackenzie Gas Project."

But she added Ottawa is prepared to implement a wide array of royalty and
investment options to make sure development goes ahead provided the assistance
is eventually repaid. She set a target of mid-2006 for working out details.
About the only option not under discussion is government part-ownership in the
proposed Mackenzie Valley Pipeline.

"We've been fairly adamant," Rolheiser said. "We're not interested in having
them (the government) assume an equity stake at this point."

Options described by McLellan include creating a northern gas counterpart to
incentive royalty deferrals for Alberta oilsands projects.

Federal royalties would be held down to a nominal level such as the initial
oilsands rate of one per cent until the forecast $7 billion costs of the Arctic
gas installations are paid off, Rolheiser indicated.

The total includes $2.2 billion in Mackenzie Delta production and processing
systems and $4.8 billion for the proposed 1,220-kilometre pipeline to
northwestern Alberta.

McLellan promised to give "serious consideration" to requests by the Aboriginal
Pipeline Group for a loan guarantee to support its one-third ownership of the
Mackenzie line, which commits it to cover $1.6 billion of the forecast
construction costs.

She acknowledged the industry consortium supports the native appeal for federal
aid and has made the potential help play a prominent role in negotiations with
aboriginal communities on land access and project benefits agreements.

A standardized deal is currently under discussion in Mackenzie Valley
communities and the project hopes approval will be granted within days,
Rolheiser said. Talks have been underway since April, when the project halted
field operations to work out relationships with northern natives before
advancing to hearings and construction.

In a letter to the National Energy Board, project backers promised to make up
their mind on next steps and announce the decision by noon next Wednesday.

In the Northwest Territories, the community discussions are confidential, but
aboriginal leaders signalled they are on the point of making a deal with the
industry.

The chiefs cancelled a consulting contract that employed former territorial
premier Stephen Kakfwi to take a hard line as lead northern benefits negotiator,
pressing demands that included a $40-million-a-year pipeline property or transit
tax.

"The confrontational approach brought more out onto the table," Kakfwi said in
an interview. "I don't apologize for it one bit."

He pledged to encourage native communities to keep on being aggressive in
fighting for financial independence.

"We will finally break the shackles of colonialism," Kakfwi vowed.

Documents released by McLellan included a letter formally rejecting Kakfwi's tax
scheme from federal Indian Affairs and Northern Development Minister Andy Scott
to Northwest Territories Premier Joe Handley.

Aboriginal pipeline taxes will remain out of the question until self-government
agreements are made with native communities, Scott wrote.

The proposal should be dropped as a threat to the northern gas project, he
suggested.

gjaremko@thejournal.canwest.com

                               South Wales Argus

                             June 22, 2010 Tuesday

Jones warns of broadband threat to economy

SECTION: LATEST NEWS (SWA NEWS)

LENGTH: 425 words


THE economy will be held back without an improved broadband network and faster
railway lines, First Minister Carwyn Jones said today.

He gave his reaction to today's Budget from Chancellor George Osborne, saying
the electrification of the main railway line into south Wales had
"disappeared''.

The UK Government is abolishing Labour's landline tax and will instead support
private broadband investment with funding in part from the digital switchover
under-spend within the TV licence fee.

But Mr Jones said the market would not pay for the extension of faster internet
access to the countryside and he feared rural Wales could be "left behind''
without more money from the Government.

At question time in the Senedd, he welcomed a £360 million loan guarantee for
Ford factories, including one in his own Bridgend constituency.

"But it has to be balanced against the fact that we want to make sure over the
next few years that infrastructure is improved in Wales for businesses,'' he
said.

Broadband access would be as important to the economy as the building of railway
lines was to communities in the 19th century, he said.

"So I'm afraid that welcome though the guarantee is, there are some major
structural issues now that will affect us over the next few years that will
affect businesses' ability to set up and prosper in Wales.'' He added: "It will
not help if we don't have the structure there for broadband and now don't have
the transport structure either.

"Both the announcements that I referred to in the Budget speech will have a
severe effect on Wales's ability to compete in the future.'' Opposition leader
Nick Bourne asked what had been done to improve relationships with the private
sector in Wales, something the First Minister said he wanted to do in February.

There had been "major criticisms'' of the Assembly Government's stance,
including from the Institute of Directors which said the administration appeared
"suspicious'' of the private sector, Mr Bourne said.

He asked: "What assurance can you give to the private sector that your
Government is still engaged with the private sector given the rather tardy
response when you said it would be a few weeks and it's now much more than a few
months that you would be setting up these new structures?'' Mr Jones said the
Assembly Government was analysing the responses of business and ministers would
make a statement soon on an economic renewal programme.

He said he wanted to make it clear that Wales was "open for business'' and a
place where young people could set up businesses and prosper.

                       Qatar News Agency (QNA) (English)

                              April 1, 2016 Friday

ADB Signs $40 Million Trade Finance Deals With Bangladesh Banks

LENGTH: 254  words


The City Bank, Mutual Trust Bank, and Pubali Bank are all new banks joining the
Trade Finance Program, while Southeast Bank, which is already part of the
program has signed a new agreement for a funded facility.



"Under these agreements, ADB and our Bangladesh bank partners will provide loans
and guarantees to support exporting and importing companies in Bangladesh,
including small and medium-sized enterprises," said Steven Beck, ADB&rsquo;s
head of trade finance. "This agreement will help create economic growth and
jobs."
The program has provided more than $2.2 billion in trade finance support in
Bangladesh since 2009, through more than 1,400 transactions. With these latest
agreements, the total number of banks under TFP in Bangladesh will reach 15.

Backed by ADB's AAA credit rating, the Trade Finance Program provides guarantees
and loans to over 200 partner banks to support trade, enabling more companies
throughout Asia to engage in import and export activities.

With dedicated trade finance specialists and a response time of 24 hours, the
program has established itself as a key partner in the international trade
community, providing fast, reliable, and responsive support to fill gaps in the
region&rsquo;s most challenging markets.

Since 2009, the Trade Finance Program has supported more than 7,000 small and
medium-sized enterprises across the region, with about 10,000 transactions
valued at over $20 billion, in sectors ranging from commodities and capital
goods, to medical supplies and consumer goods.  (QNA)

                              The Washington Post

                     March 30, 1984, Friday, Final Edition

COMMENTARY;
Bankers in Maryland Compound a PR Gaffe

BYLINE: By Rudolph A. Pyatt, Jr.; Pyatt is a staff writer for the Business &
Finance section of The Washington Post.

SECTION: Business & Finance; Capital Commerce; F11

LENGTH: 767 words


You can't blame Citicorp for trying. The giant New York-based bank holding
company deserves high marks, in fact, for its latest attempt to expand in
Maryland.

By the same token, some members of Maryland's banking industry deserve a failing
grade for yet another petulant reaction that, ironically, could enhance
Citicorp's image in the state.

Calling it a threat to their institutions, Maryland bankers effectively killed
legislation that would have approved a reciprocal banking agreement with New
York. A reciprocal agreement between the two states would have made it possible
for New York banks to open banks in Maryland and vice versa. Spokesmen for the
industry in Maryland contended the legislation that Citicorp advocated would
have allowed big money-center banks to gobble up Maryland institutions.

Citicorp may have suffered a setback in this latest bid to broaden its base in
Maryland (its Choice credit-card subsidiary is located in Towson), but not
before exposing a fair amount of hypocrisy in the state's banking industry.

Maryland is one of four states in which banks are paid a fee for making student
loans. The budget to provide the $40 fee paid on each student loan has been cut
by $1 million. That prompted some Maryland banks to suggest it may become
necessary for them to curtail participation in the guaranteed student loan
program.

Citicorp then volunteered to take over the program and forgo the fees that
Maryland banks receive from the state's Higher Education Loan Corp.

A "seedy attempt to get what the legislature didn't give them," a Maryland
banking official grumped in response to Citicorp's offer.

It's fair to say that Citicorp's student loan gambit was opportunistic, but
describing it as "seedy" only compounds a public relations gaffe by Maryland's
banking industry.

For one thing, it raises questions about the business acumen of bankers who, in
their pique over a cut in the state fees, would give up a solid asset in
guaranteed student loans. The fees offset some of the costs associated with
marketing and the production of applications and other materials.

A Citicorp official was right on the money when he called the Maryland banks'
response to the budget cut "amazing." He's correct in emphasizing that the
yields to lenders of guaranteed student loans are considerably higher than the
interest the borrower pays. He's also correct in noting that these loans are
risk-free because they're backed by a guarantee agency.

In the District, where several banks have become more aggressive in making
guaranteed student loans, one official says his bank does it for altruistic as
well as selfish reasons.

"We do have a commitment to the community, and we're also acquiring a future
customer base," said a D.C. bank officer. "We're not only complying with the
Community Reinvestment Act; we are also giving young people a start on building
a credit rating."

Officials at the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, which guarantees
student loans in the District, agree with bank officers that the loans provide a
stable asset without risk to the lender. The interest rate on a guaranteed
student loan is only 8 percent, but the yield for lenders is considerably
higher.

The loans are subsidized by the government and the yields on them are about 3
1/2 percentage points above the average Treasury-bill rate for a quarter. If the
average T-bill rate is 10 percent, for example, the lender is guaranteed a yield
of 13 1/2 percent on a guaranteed student loan.

"In that regard, the bank has a very stable asset," observed a District bank
official. What's more, he said, "There is very low operational maintenance to be
done on the loan while the student is in school. I would agree that it is one of
the safest loans a bank can make."

Not safe enough, and not profitable enough, apparently, for some Maryland banks.
They want to be more selective in making the loans.  Never mind passing up an
opportunity to build a customer base for the future. Forget the commitment to
the community. Let some other lender have the unwanted student loan business,
but don't give it to Citicorp. It has a "seedy" ulterior motive.

Citicorp's motive today is the same as it was last year when it formed an
alliance with Maryland banks to win approval of a banking bill. The measure
permits out-of-state banks to operate limited banking facilities in the state.
Passage of the bill kept Citicorp from moving its Choice subsidiary--and
jobs--out of the state, a spokesman for Maryland's banking industry explained.
But, then, there was nothing seedy in that.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1984 The Washington Post


                              959 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                           The Sunday Times (London)

                            November 1, 2015 Sunday
                                   Edition 1;
                                    Scotland

Cal Mac 'could use Scots steel'

BYLINE: Jason Allardyce ; Michael Glackin

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 323 words


A BILLIONAIRE businessman has offered to talk to Scotland's closure-threatened
steel works about supplying steel as part of a £97m contract to build new Cal
Mac ferries.

Jim McColl, one of Scotland's top entrepreneurs, made clear his willingness to
discuss the idea after pressure from Labour, which said his shipbuilding firm
Ferguson's should insist on steel from the two Tata works in Lanarkshire to help
fulfil the Scottish government order.

The party believes using the plants at Clydebridge and Dalzell on the order
recently secured by Port Glasgowbased Ferguson's could prove a lifeline after
Tata announced closure plans signalling the loss of 270 Scottish jobs.

Labour said the £1.5m pledged by Tata to support job creation in the Lanarkshire
communities affected should be at least matched by the Scottish and UK
governments to enhance the capability of the plants to win as many public
contracts as possible.

Nicola Sturgeon has refused to rule out nationalising the steel plants, saying
"nothing is off the table" but her immediate priority for Dalzell and
Clydebridge is to find a buyer, continue commercial production and keep as many
jobs as possible.

A source close to McColl, who has ruled out buying the works, said he would be
happy to speak to the firm about using steel from the plants. There is no
guarantee it will be used if it can be sourced more cheaply elsewhere, however.

Community, the trade union that represents steel workers, has called on the
Scottish government to guarantee that steel from the Scottish plants is used on
the new ferries but said ministers have so far failed to do so.

A union insider said the government would need to encourage a buyer by offering
to pay for refurbishing the plants to enable them to manufacture a greater
variety of steel plate for more markets.

The insider said this could be done through "soft loans" similar to those used
to keep state-owned Prestwick Airport in operation.

                              960 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                      Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)

                       March 8, 2002 Friday Final Edition

Buzz: we need to bribe automakers; Analysis

SOURCE: The Hamilton Spectator

BYLINE: Steve Erwin

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C02

LENGTH: 557 words

DATELINE: TORONTO


Canada will have to "bribe" automakers to attract new assembly work in the
post-auto pact era, according to the head of the country's largest
private-sector union.

Until last year, the Canada-U.S. auto pact required North American automakers to
build as many cars in Canada as they sold to avoid stiff import duties. Unless
the defunct pact is replaced, said Canadian Auto Workers president Buzz
Hargrove, governments must put up loan guarantees or grants to compete for new
investment with American states.

"Once you give up on the auto pact, and those kinds of rules are no longer
necessary and we just rely on the goodwill of corporations, you've only got one
thing left -- and that's to bribe them," Hargrove said yesterday at a Canadian
Urban Institute debate in Toronto.

"This is a game the companies play, whether we like it or not."

Hargrove said plants are being constructed for Honda in Alabama and Nissan in
Mississippi because those states offered hundreds of millions of dollars in
loans and grants. Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi and Ohio are in a bidding war
for a new Hyundai factory.

In exchange for the funds, the automakers commit to keeping the factories
running for a decade or more, Hargrove said.

"The investment is an initial investment that's paid back 10 times over in terms
of the community and taxes and services," Hargrove said after his debate on the
auto industry's future with analyst Dennis DesRosiers.

"In some cases, it's justifiable and a good investment if you've got long-term
job commitments."

Hargrove recently lobbied Ottawa to help finance the design and building of a
new van for a DaimlerChrysler plant in Windsor which he said could cost the
automaker about $430 million.

Yesterday, he suggested the Ontario government could offer $200 million in loan
guarantees to bring the new vehicle to the Pillette plant, where commercial van
production is scheduled to cease next year.

Hargrove's comments come as the CAW's membership at Canadian assembly plants is
dwindling. General Motors' Ste-Therese, Que., factory is slated to close this
fall and a Ford truck plant in Oakville is to close by 2004.

DesRosiers said those cuts are colouring the view of the union, whose membership
at assembly plants is falling while the total nonunion workforce for Toyota and
Honda plants in Ontario has swelled to 8,000 and stands to grow in coming years.

"Toyota alone could offset all other production losses," DesRosiers said.

DesRosiers said Hargrove is stuck in decades-old thinking that emphasizes
assembly-line work when Canada should instead be looking to be a leader in
emerging auto technologies, such as cleaner engines, research and development.

"We need a 2020 vision, not a 1965 vision," DesRosiers said.

He is more concerned about Canada's auto parts manufacturers, where 10,000 jobs
-- most in Ontario -- were lost last year. By comparison, only 700 assembly
plant jobs were lost in 2001.

However, DesRosiers agreed with Hargrove that politicians need to play a larger
role in coming up with ideas for the industry's future in Canada.

"Our ministers have been vacant," he said, adding that former industry minister
Brian Tobin "was more interested in fish than automotive, even though one in
seven jobs in Canada were automotive. He was nowhere."

LOAD-DATE: March 8, 2002

                              The American Banker

Merrill Bill Eludes Colorado Bankers

                            October 8, 1979, Monday

Special to the American Banker

DATELINE: DENVER


This article on Colorado discusses a measure, considered but not enacted this
year, which would have affected Merrill Lynch, which offers the Cash Management
Account here and in other states.

Legislative proposals by Colorado bankers ran into a brick wall at the Capitol
here in 1979.

Since Colorado operates by alternating long and short legislative sessions, it
probably will be two years before substantive banking legislation is considered
by the state House and Senate.

Next year is a short session.  That means any legislation, except for state
fiscal matters, must be called before the legislature by the governor.

At this point, none of Colorado's major banking groups plans to ask Gov. Richard
Lamm to place any banking measure on his call next year.

The major disappointment this year, according to Gerald Scarboro, executive
manager of the Colorado Bankers Association, was the continued failure of state
officials, elected or appointed, to provide the financial industry with a
definition of banking.

A proposal by the association stemmed from a fight with Merrill Lynch, Pierce,
Fenner & Smith over the brokerage firm's Cash Management Account.

The account allows customers to invest money, receive dividends and loans and
withdraw cash by plastic card or check.  Bankers contended that was the business
of banking and illegal without a charter.

A court suit filed by the State Banking Board in 1978 ended with an out-of-court
settlement which allowed Merrill Lynch to continue the account.  It also ended
with no definition of banking for the state.

Mr. Scarboro said bankers were not trying to restrict Merrill Lynch specifically
with the legislative proposal, but only to get a definition of banking in the
state so that everyone played by the same rules.

The proposal was simple.  Any institution that accepted deposits and allowed
people to withdraw money on demand, with or without interest, had to be a bank
or some other kind of regulated institution.

Since Merrill Lynch did not guarantee a return of money with its Cash Management
Account, Mr. Scarboro said, it accepted investments, not deposits, and did not
require a charter.

The first legislative opposition to the proposal was in the House business
affairs and labor committee, where it was shelved by Steven J. Durham,
R-Colorado Springs and chairman of the committee.

Remaining housekeeping measures in the bill passed the House and the definition
proposal was resurrected in the Senate, where it passed.

Mr. Durham again killed the proposal in a joint committee.He later explained,
"it was clearly anticompetitive, and it was vague and broad in places."

Another proposal defeated in the Legislature was drafted by the Convenience
Banking Association (holding company bankers) and opposed by the Independent
Bankers of Colorado.

Colorado is a nonbranching state in which banks are allowed one detached
facility, within 3,000 feet of the main bank building and offering limited
services.  The main use of that detached facility is for driveup banking.  some
banks also have loan production offices with even more limited functions.

The proposal would have allowed banks in metropolitan areas to establish up to
three detached facilities, and no more than one a year, within three miles of
the main bank building.

Proponents said the bill would decrease congestion and pollution in downtown
areas by eliminating traffic pile-ups at drive-in offices.  They also said it
would allow banking facilities in small, rural communities that cannot support a
full-service bank.

Opponents claimed the detached facilities were branches and illegal in Colorado.
They also claimed that, if these detached facilities were placed in small, rural
communities, it would eliminate the possibility of full-service bank ever being
built in the town.

The proposal was defeated in the Senate in a 19-9 vote.

Another controversial banking matter involved the legislature only slightly.

In response to a growing number of loan production offices in the state, both
from local banks and from out-of-state banks, the State Banking Commission
issued regulations for the activities that could be conducted at the offices.

The regulations prohibited some of the activities that had been going on, such
as the passing out of pamphlets explaining banking services other than loans.
They restricted activities to the filing out of loan applications.

As required by law, the proposal went before the Legislative Review Committee.
That body took the position, in a 3-2 vote, that the Banking Board did not have
the authority to issue the rule.

Nothing ever came from that decision, however.  State Bank Commissioner Harry
Bloom said he had heard that some legislation was being prepared to counter the
rule, but it never appeared.

The rule was supposed to have gone into effect on June 1, but it was blocked by
a suit from the Independent Bankers of Colorado.

In an action similar to a suit filed nationally, the organization claimed that
loan production offices are branch banks and illegal in Colorado.  That suit
still is in the courts.

SECTION: Pg. 2

LENGTH: 859 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1979 American Banker, Inc.

                     The Idaho Business Review (Boise, ID)

                             June 2, 2010 Wednesday

New Idaho National Laboratory manager to focus on nuclear energy research

BYLINE: Anne Wallace Allen

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 588  words


Rick Provencher assumes management of the Idaho National Laboratory as nuclear
energy appears poised to enter a period of development in the United States. The
nuclear industry has been re-energized by support from the White House and from
some movement to use billions of dollars in Department of Energy loans aimed at
promoting cleaner alternatives to fossil fuels. Provencher took over May 23 as
manager of the DOE's Idaho Operations Office, where he will oversee Idaho's
commercial nuclear energy research laboratory, and the environmental cleanup and
waste management mission at the site. "I'm mostly excited about our nuclear
energy mission," Provencher said June 1 as he visited Boise for a quarterly
meeting with the Idaho Department of Environmental Quality.

"There's a lot going on there at the site, including national defense type
activities. Nuclear energy gets me excited because I think the capability we
have there at the site provides a solution to the country for research on new
materials and fuel forms to lead towards improved nuclear reactors. "
Provencher, a Massachusetts native, has managed the Idaho Cleanup Project since
2004 at the INL working with Battelle, in Idaho Falls. He said he has
established close working relationships with contractors, with Idaho regulators,
and with the community in that time. "During that seven-year period we achieved
a lot that we set out to do," he said, noting that he has sought to build trust
in the community by completing the cleanup as specified and on schedule. "If we
can demonstrate we're addressing the legacy contamination and legacy nuclear
facilities, it goes a long way to establish trust and confidence for the people
of the state, and the DEQ," Provencher said. "We hope to build on that trust and
relationship we have with the state as we pursue new missions on the lab side. "
Provencher didn't say exactly what new missions the lab might pursue, but he did
say he expects partnerships with business to increase as the lab grows.
Provencher's new role coincides with increased nuclear energy interest and
activity in Idaho and the nation. The French company Areva in May received a $2
billion Department of Energy loan guarantee to help with a uranium enrichment
plant planned for an area 20 miles west of Idaho Falls, near INL. An Eagle
company, Alternate Energy Holdings, has made public its plans for a nuclear
power plant in Idaho. President Barack Obama's $3.8 trillion 2011 budget request
includes almost $800 million for new nuclear research. Nuclear energy appears
more attractive than ever because of recent problems with fossil fuels, such as
the disastrous BP oil spill April 20 in the Gulf of Mexico, said John Gardner,
the associate vice president for energy research at Boise State University. But
it's still very expensive to build a nuclear plant, making it a risky
proposition, even with large federal loan guarantees, said Gardner. The INL can
play an important role in researching more economical means of providing nuclear
power - such as smaller reactors - and other alternative energy, said Gardner.
Gardner said INL is also an important economic presence in Idaho beyond its
involvement with energy. "It's a huge employer, a huge engine for our economy,"
he said. "A place like INL that has a very dynamic, very visual image is a real
attractor of the people we want in Idaho: the creative, smart, innovative
people. I know a lot of people here in Boise who wouldn't have been in Idaho if
they hadn't come to the lab first. "

                              963 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           December 22, 2015 Tuesday

Agency Information Collection Activities; Proposals, Submissions, and Approvals,

LENGTH: 684  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington, DC:  This Notice document was issued by the Rural Utilities Service
(RUS)



  The Department of Agriculture has submitted the following information
collection requirement(s) to Office of Management and Budget (OMB) for review
and clearance under the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995, Public Law 104-13.
Comments regarding (a) whether the collection of information is necessary for
the proper performance of the functions of the agency, including whether the
information will have practical utility; (b) the accuracy of the agency's
estimate of burden including the validity of the methodology and assumptions
used; (c) ways to enhance the quality, utility and clarity of the information to
be collected; (d) ways to minimize the burden of the collection of information
on those who are to respond, including through the use of appropriate automated,
electronic, mechanical, or other technological collection techniques or other
forms of information technology should be addressed to: Desk Officer for
Agriculture, Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, Office of Management
and Budget, New Executive Office Building, 725--17th Street NW., Washington, DC
20502. Commenters are encouraged to submit their comments to OMB via email to:

OIRA_Submission@omb.eop.gov or fax (202) 395-5806 and to Departmental Clearance
Office, USDA, OCIO, Mail Stop 7602, Washington, DC 20250-7602. Comments
regarding these information collections are best assured of having their full
effect if received within 30 days of this notification. Copies of the
submission(s) may be obtained by calling (202) 720-8681.



 An agency may not conduct or sponsor a collection of information unless the
collection of information displays a currently valid OMB control number and the
agency informs potential persons who are to respond to the collection of
information that such persons are not required to respond to the collection of
information unless it displays a currently valid OMB control number.

 Rural Utilities Service



 Title: Request for Approval to Sell Capital Assets.



 OMB Control Number: 0572-0020.



 Summary of Collection: The Rural Utilities Service (RUS) is a credit agency of
the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). It makes mortgage loans and loan
guarantees to finance electric, telecommunications, and water and waste
facilities in rural areas. In addition to providing loans and loan guarantees,
one of RUS' main objectives is to safeguard loan security until the loan is
repaid. Accordingly, RUS manages loan programs in accordance with the Rural
Electrification Act of 1936, 7 U.S.C. 901 et.seq., as amended, (RE ACT) and as
prescribed by Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Circular A-129, Policies for
Federal Credit Programs and Non-Tax Receivables, which states that agencies
must, based on a review of a loan application, determine that an applicant
complies with statutory, regulatory, and administrative eligibility requirements
for loan assistance.



 Need and Use of the Information: RUS borrower will use form 369, Request for
Approval to Sell Capital Assets, to seek agency permission to sell some of its
assets. The form is used to collect detailed information regarding the proposed
sale of a portion of the borrowers systems. RUS will collect information to
determine whether or not the agency should approve a sale and also to keep track
of what property exists to secure the loan. If the information in Form 369 is
not collected when capital assets are sold, the capital assets securing the
Government's loans could be liquidated and the Government's security either
eliminated entirely or diluted to an undesirable level.



 Description of Respondents: Not-for-profit institutions; Business or other
for-profit.



 Number of Respondents: 5.



 Frequency of Responses: Recordkeeping; Reporting: On occasion.



 Total Burden Hours: 15.

 Charlene Parker,

 Departmental Information Collection Clearance Officer.

 [FR Doc. 2015-32169 Filed 12-21-15; 8:45 am]

                              965 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

              March 23, 1989, THURSDAY, ILLINOIS FIVE STAR Edition

GRANTS WILL REOPEN POULTRY PROCESSOR

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8I

LENGTH: 214 words


OLNEY, Ill. (AP) - Rich-Land Turkeys, Inc., will reopen a poultry-processing
plant and create 150 new jobs in Olney with $965,000 in state and local
incentives, officials say. The plan is part of a two-year effort to revive the
poultry industry in the state, according to an announcement this week from Gov.
James R. Thompson's office.  The company will get $315,000 from the state
Department of Commerce and Community Affairs and a $500,000 loan guarantee from
the Illinois Farm Development Authority, Thompson said. In addition, Olney will
lend the company $150,000.  Rich-Land is to use the money to reopen the former
Kralis Brothers Foods, Inc., poultry processing facility in Olney.  Lynn
Morford, spokeswoman for the Department of Commerce and Community Affairs, said
the facility should open by the end of May.

LOAD-DATE: October 23, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1989 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              966 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                                The Irish Times

                                 June 20, 2001

Kitt has no details of steel plant debts

SECTION: CITY EDITION; HOME NEWS; DAIL REPORT; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 226 words


Irish ISPAT was a private company and he had no information on its debts or the
possible impact of its closure on creditors, Minister of State for Labour, Mr
Tom Kitt told the House.

A creditors' meeting was planned for June 28th, he said. Mr Kitt was standing in
for the Tanaiste and replying to a private notice question from Mr David Stanton
(FG) who asked what steps Ms Harney was taking to avert the threatened closure
with the loss of 400 jobs.

Mr Pat Rabbitte (Labour) asked what plans the Tanaiste had for discussions with
ISPAT management. And Mr Simon Coveney (FG) asked what plans the Tanaiste had to
maximise the likelihood of a rescue package.

The Tanaiste had a prior engagement from which she could not be released, Mr
Kitt said. He traced the recent history of the Haulbowline plant. It was
formerly owned by the State, up to 1996, when it was sold for (pounds) 1: "It
had run up serious debts and the workforce at the time was facing a bleak
future."

ISPAT had undertaken to repay a $ 14 million outstanding loan to the European
Coal and Steel Community. That was repaid in 1999 and the State had given a
guarantee of (pounds) 10 million on an ACC loan taken out by Irish Steel. This
loan was due for repayment in 2003.

"My Department holds indemnities and a letter of credit in relation to this
debt," Mr Kitt said.

LOAD-DATE: June 20, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Copyright 2001 The Irish Times


                              967 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                              March 7, 2014 Friday

Washington: SPEECH OF HON. JANICE HAHN OF CALIFORNIA IN THE HOUSE OF
REPRESENTATIVES THURSDAY, MARCH 6, 2014

LENGTH: 755  words

DATELINE: Washington


The Library of Congress, The Government of USA has issued the following Speech:

Ms. HAHN. Mr. Speaker, today, I introduced the ``Brownfield Redevelopment and
Economic Development Innovative Financing Act of 2014,'' legislation that will
help redevelop large brownfield redevelopment projects that have the potential
to create jobs, provide affordable housing opportunities and transform regional
economies.

Across the country, from Baltimore to Los Angeles, there are large redevelopment
sites that communities have identified as the economic development futures of
their regions. Older manufacturing sites, retired steel mills, automotive legacy
sites and landfills within communities are in need of transformation.

These sites, known as brownfields, are untapped resources that, when
environmentally remediated and redeveloped, will address tax base shortfalls,
provide affordable housing, create jobs, attract new businesses as well as unify
communities with planned sustainable development that will meet the needs of a
changing economy and a growing population.

For instance, in my district, the city of Carson provides a shining example of
how large brownfield properties can be redeveloped and transformed into
successful redevelopment projects.

In 2003, using $90 million of redevelopment funding, Carson invested in the
cleanup of an 160 acre site along the 405. Immediately, the private sector
matched the city's funding and the project moved forward with the cleanup of the
site.

The project, called The Boulevards, is set to finish construction in 2016, and
will have two hotels, retail space, affordable housing, office buildings,
restaurants and movie theatres that will raise an estimated $107 million in
property tax revenues over the next 30 years.

The Boulevards is a great investment for Carson and for the region and will
ultimately end up paying for itself. What's changed for Carson, like most
communities, is that they do not have another $90 million dollars to quickly
redevelop their other large brownfield projects.

Unfortunately, there is no current federal funding or financing mechanism to
support and leverage local and private sector resources to move large brownfield
redevelopment sites forward.

While Title I of the 1949 Housing Authority Act used to provide a line of
federal credit to local communities to undertake major redevelopment projects
during the 1970's, this was later replaced with the current Community
Development Block Grant (CDBG) program administered by HUD. And CDBG funds are
currently stretched too thin to be able to adequately address the needs of large
scale redevelopment projects.

Additionally, private lenders are hesitant to loan money for these projects
since the extensive remediation and clean up of these sites means investors
aren't going to begin seeing returns for possibly a decade or longer.

That's why I have introduced the The Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic
Development Innovative Financing Act of 2014. This bill creates a pilot program
that re-establishes a partnership with communities by providing the HUD
Secretary the authority to guarantee the repayment of principal and interest on
loans made by lenders to local governments for large brownfield redevelopment
projects.

By providing a federally backed loan guarantee for brownfield redevelopment,
this will eliminate traditional lending risk and thus attract private resources
for projects that otherwise wouldn't have received funding. At the same time,
this bill grants local governments enough time to remediate and develop their
properties so they won't need to begin making loan repayments until they start
receiving revenue.

These tools will provide communities with the ability to make an immediate and
long term economic impact on their region and will be the drivers that help move
our national economy forward.

That is why this bill is supported by public and private stakeholders alike,
including, Weston Solutions, CH2M Hill, Parsons Brinckerhoff, the American
Council of Engineering Companies, Smart Growth America, the U.S. Conference of
Mayors, the National League of Cities, the National Brownfield Association, the
League of California Cities, the California State Association of Counties, and
the city of Carson, California.

By providing a platform for partnerships and innovative financing tools, we will
finally arm communities with the necessary tools to fully plan, invest and
develop their futures.

For more information please visit: http://thomas.loc.gov/

LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              968 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                             May 24, 1990, Thursday

EC PROPOSES ADDED FUNDING FOR E. EUROPE BILLIONS SEEN NECESSARY

BYLINE: RICHARD LAWRENCE; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: EXPORTS, Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 462 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


European Community officials are proposing new multibillion-dollar funds to
supplement the proposed European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and
existing financing sources.

One proposal, which Italy plans to promote, would provide as much as $ 15
billion a year from the EC to Eastern Europe. Another, advanced by Frans
Andriessen, the EC's vice president, would create a "general credit fund" to
inance multibillion-dollar credit lines for East European nations.

The East Europeans, meanwhile, are outlining their requests for additional
financial help.

Vaclav Klaus, Czechoslovakia's finance minister, said here Wednesday that his
government may seek up to $ 5 billion for an economic stabilization fund.

Imre Tarafas, the National Bank of Hungary's first deputy president, said his
government hopes to arrange a large multiyear loan from the International
Monetary Fund in follow-up to the $ 210 million IMF loan it recently received.

Their remarks and those of West European officials came at a conference arrang
ed by the Bretton Woods Committee, a non-profit group promoting international
economic cooperation.

So far, most of the Western aid to Eastern Europe has gone to Poland to support
the country's radical economic reforms. Poland has won a $ 1 billion
stabilization fund, financed by the EC, the United States and other nations, and
a $ 723 million IMF loan, among other credits and donations.

Mr. Andriessen's proposal is for the EC, the United States, Japan and other
wealthy nations to establish a fund to finance economic stabilization funds
similar to Poland's for other East European nations.

To be eligible for such funding, he said, an East European country would have to
be an IMF member and committed to an IMF-approved economic reform program.

The proposal immediately drew some skepticism. John Williamson, senior fellow at
the Institute for International Economics, a Washington, D.C.-based research
group, questioned whether it would create a regional IMF.

Gianni de Michelis, Italy's foreign minister, said his government favors the
EC's annually alloting, starting in 1993, of 1 percent of its gross product to
Eastern Europe and Third World countries. This, he said, would channel about $
15 billion in aid to Eastern Europe.

Philippe Maystadt, the Belgian finance minister, suggested Wednesday still other
initiatives to expand Western help for Eastern Europe.

Among them is a "multilateral facility" to counter-guarantee and reinsure export
credits to Eastern Europe that already have been guaranteed or insured by
Western governments.

The facility, he said, would mainly co-finance investment projects supported by
the World Bank and the coming European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1990 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              969 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                          PNG Post-Courier (Australia)

                           September 28, 2010 Tuesday
                                   1 Edition

Bank wants to help promote local banking

BYLINE: MOHAMMAD BASHIR

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 642 words


After five years of losses which led to rehabilitation following three
insolvencies, the National Development Bank (NDB), the only wholly Government
owned bank in the country is ready to go into retail banking to support the
country's grassroots population, who the mainstream financial institutions do
not entertain.

Finance and Treasurer Peter O'Neill announced this while launching a Textile
Credit Scheme with a K2 million seed capital for women to be implemented by
National Development Bank at the Crown Plaza last night.

"I am pleased to announce tonight that I am submitting to the Government to
provide capital to NDB in the 2010 Supplementary Budget and 2011 Budget, to
enable it to acquire appropriate license.

"The retail banking license will enable NDB to mobilise deposits from many
farmers and small business people using its current branch office network," he
said, adding, it was in line with the Government's vision for wealth creation.

Additional funds for the programs like agriculture, tourism and small to medium
sized businesses will also be provided with no political interference under
legislative changes.

Mr O'Neill said the Government would like to grow these sectors because they not
only provide opportunities to employ large number of people but also sufficient
resources such as land and varying cultures available to ensure its success.

"Interest rate will be fixed and low, with long term repayment period for loans
under the new proposed Government Assistance Loan Scheme which will be designed
and modeled along similar lines as the previously successful Stret Pasin Stoa
Scheme," Mr O'Neil announced.

He said the deliberate intervention by the Government to rehabilitate rather
than to wind up NDB following its third insolvency in 2004 was because of
several compelling reasons.

Mr O'Neill said the Government will not encourage handout mentality but ensure
tax payer funds are invested in National Development Bank and are managed to
improve business opportunities for the people in viable commercial projects.

"NDB has already developed a number of specific intervention programs including
the Fisheries Credit Facility, the Tourism Promotion Authority Credit Scheme,
the Co-operatives Societies Credit Schemes, the Small Business Development
Credit Guarantee Schemes and others planned for the future.

"National Development Bank must be able to build on success stories like the
STRET PASIN store Scheme," Minister O'Neill said while launching the event..

The rehabilitation of National Development Bank was to position it to obtain a
retail banking license so that millions of rural communities who remain unbanked
can have access to basic banking and financial services.

Mr O'Neill said experience in developing economics around the World showed that
access to banking and communication services have directly led to improvements
in quality of life, particularly in many rural communities.

He said enabling legislation passed to the NDB Act 2007 guarantees removal of
adverse political interference, successful implementation of a new management
information system and the establishment and operation of a strong board audit
and risk committee.

The completion of various operating manuals, change of name and re-branding,
recruitment, development and retention of highly qualified staff, improvement in
the balance sheet position from a net asset of K15 million in 2004 to over K160
million this year are some of the achievements so far.

Other notable achievements include good loan book with arrears over 90 days
averaging 2 per cent compared to over 70 per cent up to 2004. The quality of the
NDB loan book is now as good as any commercial banks.

Reduction of overall operating cost by 30 per cent post 2004 while its first
profit recorded in 2009 after five years of successive losses due to the high
bad debt provisioning.

LOAD-DATE: September 27, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              970 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                            Waikato Times (Hamilton)

                             June 17, 1997, Tuesday

Council split on stadium and new rates system

SECTION: FEATURES; EDITORIAL; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 514 words


Hamilton's political leaders are just a day away from confirming a new budget
yet they remain divided on two crucial issues. First, the 13 city councillors
and Mayor Margaret Evans are split on whether they should raise a $ 6 million
loan and spend the money on a proposed $ 34.2 million super sports stadium.
Second, the council is dithering over plans for a new way of levying rates and
has made a number of secret recommendations. Both issues are tricky: they carry
financial and political risks and are the subject of ferocious lobbying.
Tomorrow's budget meetings will reveal how councillors respond to pressure.

The stadium vote should be relatively simple. The project promises huge benefits
for Hamilton but will probably collapse if the council reneges on earlier votes
to back it financially. The $ 6 million will be a cornerstone pledge and will
allow Waikato Sports and Events Centre Trust to attract the other money it
needs. The council should agree to raise the loan but the cash must only be
handed over when the trust guarantees the stadium will be built. Today's
announcement that the Trust Bank Waikato Community Trust will give $ 6 million
to the project was timed to encourage councillors to back the stadium. The vote
tomorrow will still be tight. Lobbying, including calls for a referendum, will
continue until the last moment. Wavering councillors should consider Hamilton's
dire need for a modern sports and entertainment facility. They don't need a
non-binding referendum to tell them that.

The rating issue is more complex, partly because the council is refusing to
debate it openly. The draft 1997-98 annual plan recommends changes which would
significantly increase rates bills for a small number of ratepayers. The key
proposal is to make rural property owners within the city boundary pay a bigger
share of rates. A majority of councillors seems to have finally realised the
proposals are seriously flawed and would be unfair on a small group of
ratepayers. Last week these councillors, at a confidential meeting, reportedly
forced through recommendations to introduce a new uniform annual charge to be
paid by all ratepayers. They also eased some of the heavier rates burden for
rural landowners and backed away from introducing charges for schools. These
recommendations could be overturned again tomorrow. The debate, which again will
be held confidentially, should focus on the council's abject failure to
formulate a fairer system of levying rates. It is instead secretly tinkering
with a flawed method based solely on the land value of properties.

Significant progress could be made tomorrow if the council admits it is
ill-prepared at this point to make meaningful changes. It should stick with the
status quo for now while it thoroughly investigates a fairer way of deciding who
pays what to run the city. The improved system, perhaps based on the value of
each ratepayer's land and buildings, could be introduced in July 1998. The
council would then be seen to be acting openly, fairly and in the best interests
of the city.

LOAD-DATE: June 19, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1997 Fairfax New Zealand Newspaper


                              971 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                            Business World (Digest)

                           December 15, 2009 Tuesday

Carroll wins reprieve on E60m guarantee;
Carroll Letoff

LENGTH: 582 words



HIGHLIGHT: Beleaguered developer Liam Carroll has secured an unexpected reprieve
in a 60m euro personal guarantee action.


News In Brief

## Beleaguered developer Liam Carroll has secured an unexpected reprieve in a
60m euro personal guarantee action. His Zoe Group of companies was placed into
liquidation following a three-month battle for court protection. But yesterday
the Irish Nationwide Building Society, which is pursuing Mr Carroll for 60m
euro, had its action taken out of Ireland's fast-track Commercial Court because
of its "total failure" to obey a court order to provide certain documents to the
Dundalk-born builder. In a ruling which underscores the Commercial Court's
stringent rules of engagement, including strict deadlines, the INBS will now
have to wait for months -- possibly until the end of next year at the earliest
-- before its case is heard. - Irish Independent

## The director of human resources at Iarnrod Eireann, John Keenan, has brought
a High Court action for orders restraining the company taking any steps to
remove him from his position of the last 15 years. Mr Keenan claims he was
ordered to leave after Irish Rail chief executive Richard Fearn complained Mr
Keenan had failed to speedily inform him about the successful outcome of a
gender discrimination complaint brought by an employee. Mr Keenan was yesterday
given permission by Mr Justice Roderick Murphy to bring the injunction
proceedings on Thursday. - Irish Times

## Developer Paddy Kelly has consented to judgment orders for more than 2.7m
euro against him over unpaid loans, including one to buy two penthouse suites
adjoining the Clarion Hotel, Liffey Valley, in Dublin. Three loans were advanced
to him by AIB and yesterday counsel for the bank told the Commercial Court Mr
Kelly was consenting to summary judgment orders against him. Mr Justice Peter
Kelly entered judgment for a total of 2,782,317 euro against Mr Kelly, Clonmore,
Shrewsbury Road, Dublin, who was not in court but was represented by a
solicitor. The loans included a 1.39m euro facility to restructure existing debt
of two companies, Fabline Ltd and Latest Venture Ltd, and to take out personal
debt of Mr Kelly. - Irish Independent ## A construction company director has
pleaded guilty to 31 charges related to non-payment of pension contributions.
Gerard Walsh and the Wave Roofing and Cladding company were prosecuted by the
Pensions Board for non-remittance of pension contributions to the construction
Workers Pensions Scheme. The company was fined 1,000 euro on each of the 31
charges, for a total of 31,000 euro. Mr Walsh will be not be sentenced until
February, when the judge will decide whether to impose community service or a
custodial sentence. - RTE ## Aer Arann has restructured some of its debts and is
formulating a fresh business plan as it realigns its business model to the
current environment, according to its owner and chairman. Padraig O Ceidigh
declined to give details of the nature of the debt restructuring or the affected
parties, but added the move had assisted in improving the airline's working
capital position. "The terms of doing business two years ago have changed
because of the climate, and we've sat down with our creditors and suppliers and
remodelled the payment of existing debt," said Mr O Ceidigh. "We have a good
relationship with them, we've received no outside finance, and absolutely, every
single creditor and debt will be paid." Earlier this year it emerged that Aer
Arann was seeking outside investment -- possibly as much as 10m euro -- in order
to secure its longer-term future. - Irish Independent

LOAD-DATE: December 15, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              972 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                            Business World (Digest)

                           December 15, 2009 Tuesday

Carroll wins reprieve on E60m guarantee;
Carroll Letoff

LENGTH: 582 words



HIGHLIGHT: Beleaguered developer Liam Carroll has secured an unexpected reprieve
in a 60m euro personal guarantee action.


News In Brief

## Beleaguered developer Liam Carroll has secured an unexpected reprieve in a
60m euro personal guarantee action. His Zoe Group of companies was placed into
liquidation following a three-month battle for court protection. But yesterday
the Irish Nationwide Building Society, which is pursuing Mr Carroll for 60m
euro, had its action taken out of Ireland's fast-track Commercial Court because
of its "total failure" to obey a court order to provide certain documents to the
Dundalk-born builder. In a ruling which underscores the Commercial Court's
stringent rules of engagement, including strict deadlines, the INBS will now
have to wait for months -- possibly until the end of next year at the earliest
-- before its case is heard. - Irish Independent

## The director of human resources at Iarnrod Eireann, John Keenan, has brought
a High Court action for orders restraining the company taking any steps to
remove him from his position of the last 15 years. Mr Keenan claims he was
ordered to leave after Irish Rail chief executive Richard Fearn complained Mr
Keenan had failed to speedily inform him about the successful outcome of a
gender discrimination complaint brought by an employee. Mr Keenan was yesterday
given permission by Mr Justice Roderick Murphy to bring the injunction
proceedings on Thursday. - Irish Times

## Developer Paddy Kelly has consented to judgment orders for more than 2.7m
euro against him over unpaid loans, including one to buy two penthouse suites
adjoining the Clarion Hotel, Liffey Valley, in Dublin. Three loans were advanced
to him by AIB and yesterday counsel for the bank told the Commercial Court Mr
Kelly was consenting to summary judgment orders against him. Mr Justice Peter
Kelly entered judgment for a total of 2,782,317 euro against Mr Kelly, Clonmore,
Shrewsbury Road, Dublin, who was not in court but was represented by a
solicitor. The loans included a 1.39m euro facility to restructure existing debt
of two companies, Fabline Ltd and Latest Venture Ltd, and to take out personal
debt of Mr Kelly. - Irish Independent ## A construction company director has
pleaded guilty to 31 charges related to non-payment of pension contributions.
Gerard Walsh and the Wave Roofing and Cladding company were prosecuted by the
Pensions Board for non-remittance of pension contributions to the construction
Workers Pensions Scheme. The company was fined 1,000 euro on each of the 31
charges, for a total of 31,000 euro. Mr Walsh will be not be sentenced until
February, when the judge will decide whether to impose community service or a
custodial sentence. - RTE ## Aer Arann has restructured some of its debts and is
formulating a fresh business plan as it realigns its business model to the
current environment, according to its owner and chairman. Padraig O Ceidigh
declined to give details of the nature of the debt restructuring or the affected
parties, but added the move had assisted in improving the airline's working
capital position. "The terms of doing business two years ago have changed
because of the climate, and we've sat down with our creditors and suppliers and
remodelled the payment of existing debt," said Mr O Ceidigh. "We have a good
relationship with them, we've received no outside finance, and absolutely, every
single creditor and debt will be paid." Earlier this year it emerged that Aer
Arann was seeking outside investment -- possibly as much as 10m euro -- in order
to secure its longer-term future. - Irish Independent

News In Brief

## Beleaguered developer Liam Carroll has secured an unexpected reprieve in a
60m euro personal guarantee action. His Zoe Group of companies was placed into
liquidation following a three-month battle for court protection. But yesterday
the Irish Nationwide Building Society, which is pursuing Mr Carroll for 60m

of its "total failure" to obey a court order to provide certain documents to the

                          Australian Financial Review

                             August 1, 1988 Monday
                                  Late Edition

ROTHWELLS' PROBLEMS PUSH WA INTO DEAL

BYLINE: JENNI HEWETT and MARK SMITH

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1125 words


Fears that its $150 million guarantee of Rothwells Ltd could be triggered have
led the West Australian Government to take a huge political risk and stitch
together another deal with Mr Alan Bond.

But as the details of the deal unravel, the Dowding Government is finding that
it has crippled its efforts to distance itself from the Burke Government's
various deal-making and resurrected the issue of Labor's financial competence.

As the original October deadline for the Government to withdraw half of its
credit facility from Rothwells drew closer, there was dismay within the
Government that Rothwells' financial problems were only getting worse.

A government spokesman said yesterday that there had been growing "concern"about
the viability of Rothwells recently and that a "primary consideration for the
Government was to cut itself adrift" from Rothwells' founder, Mr Laurie Connell.

At the same time, the plans for a giant petrochemical plant devised by Mr
Connell and another WA businessman, Mr Dallas Dempster, were stalled because the
two were having difficulty obtaining finance.

In a state of near panic at the potential for political damage from Rothwells,
the Government agreed to the exit route offered by Mr Bond.

This involves the Government in a joint venture with Mr Bond to develop the
petrochemical plant.

In return, Mr Bond has provided Mr Connell with the money to buy out $350
million worth of problem loans from Rothwells at face value, many of them to
companies associated with Mr Connell, and is also arranging to buy out Mr
Dempster.

This means that Rothwells can now retire the entire guarantee put up by the
Government.

"We have swapped a $150 million guarantee and the risks involved in that for an
involvement in a bricks and mortar project that is important for the State's
development," Mr Dowding said.

The Government's argument is that the alternative would have been no
petrochemical plant and the very strong possibility of a collapsed Rothwells.

But with an election due early next year, the timing and details of the deal are
extraordinarily awkward for the Government and provide the battered Liberals
with a badly needed assault weapon.

It emphasises the fragility of Rothwells' position since the October Crash and
the Government's continuing willingness to directly invest in entrepreneurial
projects.

Mr Connell has certainly conveniently bought out Rothwells' non-performing loans
at the last minute to allow Rothwells' balance sheet to look infinitely more
healthy on its July 31 balance date. Rothwells' shareholders agreed to that in a
brief meeting last Friday.

But the business community is putting a very low real value on the loans bought
back by Mr Connell.

At the same time, Mr Bond has effectively forced the Government into paying for
a share in a project that is only in the planning stages and where the figures
are, to say the least, still vague.

Mr Connell and Mr Dempster are believed to have spent at the most around$10
million on developing the project so far.

While it is being promoted as a $1 billion project on completion in 1991, the
Government must still negotiate now with Mr Bond exactly what percentage it
should take and for what cost. The last estimate of costs of construction, done
earlier this year, was $680 million.

Yet the the guidelines for pricing at this stage seem to have been worked out
chiefly by Mr Bond and Mr Connell.

Mr Bond has taken Mr Connell's 500,000 shares of the Petrochemical Industries
Company Ltd for $150 million as well as apparently providing another $200
million under some separate arrangement to allow Mr Connell to buy back the
loans from Rothwells.

Mr Bond's willingness to provide an extra $200 million to Mr Connell suggests he
is confident of doing well out of a petrochemical plant suddenly valued at $1
billion.

It is still unclear what Mr Dempster will get for his half share from Mr Bond
although sources say it will be considerably less than the $150 million paid to
Mr Connell.

These two factors raise doubts about the value of the project and the likely
entry prices for the participants in the project's new joint venture.

The Government is considering Bond Corporation's request for it to take 25 per
cent although this is not definite and it will be anxious to minimise its role
even though it thinks the plant should be built as quickly as possible.

It is already clear that one way the Government may help to pay for its equity
is through reductions to the price of gas. This will have a rise and fall
contract to allow variations according to the prices the petrochemical products
receives.

To compound the political sensitivity, the Government has appointed its most
senior bureaucrat, Kevin Edwards, to head the taskforce on the petrochemical
plant, including the negotiations with the Bond Group.

Mr Edwards, as the chief executive of the Department of Cabinet and deputy
chairman of the State Government Insurance Corporation was the key figure in the
SGIC's purchase of 19.9 per cent of the Bell Group earlier this year.

This created another flurry of controversy about the links between the
Government and Bond Corporation and resulted in an NCSC investigation into the
legality and fairness of the Bell Group transactions.

The negotiations will also concentrate attention on just how the Dowding
Government runs its own version of "WA Inc".

Mr Tony Lloyd, former finance director of the West Australian Development
Corporation, was appointed to Rothwells' board after the Government joined in
the rescue package of Rothwells last October and became its managing director

Brian Burke, Kevin Edwards and Tony Lloyd are all old friends and share a belief
in the benefits of an interventionist government, particularly to get major
projects off the ground.

One of Mr Lloyd's major roles was to allow the Government to extricate itself
from its association with Rothwells while turning the former high-risk,
high-profit merchant banker into a sober investment bank, with emphasis on
resources.

This was a major change from the heady days when Rothwells was the lender of
last resort in Perth, a position shattered by the crash and only patched by a
$384 million rescue package put together by Mr Bond and other leading Australian
businesses.

It led to the Rothwells $100 million purchase earlier this year of Western
Collieries, which left the business community wondering how a company with such
problems could afford the investment.

But there was still little recognition until recently of how many difficulties
Rothwells was having with its cash flow, particularly with a loan portfolio that
could not be easily reduced.

In March, when releasing its interim report, Rothwells allowed $67 million for
doubtful debts and another $118 million in contingencies.

LOAD-DATE: March 15, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Mr DOWDING

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
