                              976 of 998 DOCUMENTS



                                The Jordan Times

                             July 30, 2016 Saturday

Donors approve $340m assistance to Jordan, Lebanon

LENGTH: 552  words


By JT - Jul 30,2016 - Last updated at Jul 30,2016

AMMAN -- The Concessional Financing Facility (CFF), an international initiative
to address the impacts of the Syrian refugee crisis, has announced the first
financing to support refugees and host communities in Jordan and Lebanon, a
World Bank statement said.

The initiative was launched in April when eight nations and the European
Commission pledged a package of more than $1 billion -- $141 million in grants,
$1 billion in soft loans, $500 million in guarantees -- to a World Bank-led
financing initiative in support of Syrian refugees and host communities in
Jordan and Lebanon, as well as recovery and reconstruction across the region.

The package, it was announced then, means that the new facility would be able to
generate up to $800 million in concessional loans in the next year.

The facility has been made operational, supporting two projects totalling over
$340 million, the statement, issued Thursday, said, following the CFF steering
committee's first meeting.

The two projects will help generate jobs for over 200,000 Syrian refugees, and
address the urgently needed rehabilitation of municipal infrastructure in
Jordan, including the economic opportunities project and the Ain Ghazal
wastewater plant, which will be supported by the World Bank and the European
Bank for Reconstruction and Development, respectively, subject to approval by
their respective boards.

According to the statement, the objective of the CFF is to raise a total of $1
billion in grants over the next five years in order to provide Jordan and
Lebanon with around $3-$4 billion in concessional financing to support refugees
and host communities in key sectors such as jobs, education, health and
infrastructure.

The first steering committee meeting of the CFF in Beirut brought together
representatives from the eight donors: Japan, the UK, the US, Germany, Canada,
the Netherlands, Norway and the EU, along with additional observer countries,
multilateral development banks and the UN.

Jordan and Lebanon also presented their respective pipelines of projects that
could potentially benefit from concessional financing through the facility,
according to the statement.

Secretary General at the Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation
Saleh Kharabsheh was quoted as saying: "This facility will play a significant
role in contributing to build the resilience of Jordan's host communities and
boost economic growth so that we are able to provide basic services and economic
opportunities to both Jordanians and Syrian refugees."

Franck Bousquet, World Bank director for regional programmes and partnerships in
the Middle East and North Africa, said it is critical to begin to finance
projects to support vulnerable populations in Jordan and Lebanon.

"These countries have made enormous sacrifices to meet the global responsibility
of providing refuge from conflict, and it is vital that the international
community unite to provide the long-term support that will help them both
withstand shocks and continue to develop and prosper."

Conflicts and instability across the Middle East and North Africa region have
caused over 15 million people to flee their homes over the past five years, the
statement noted, representing the largest forced displacement crisis since World
War II.

LOAD-DATE: July 31, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 62


                        Copyright 2016 The Jordan Times.
                        Provided by Syndigate Media Inc.

                              977 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                The Irish Times

                              May 10, 2010 Monday

EU assembling 'big bang' response to euro crisis

BYLINE: ARTHUR BEESLEY

SECTION: OPINION; Opinion; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 1021 words


ANALYSIS:The 16 euro zone countries will get drawn ever deeper into each other s
fiscal affairs

AFTER MONTHS of indecision, moves to set up a rescue mechanism for all euro
countries are a huge leap into the dark for the European authorities. The
development, which marks a capitulation to market forces, suggests EU leaders
perceive a serious threat to the single currency in the turmoil unleashed by
Greece s financial crisis.

As a fully-fledged sovereign debt crisis in the euro zone draws closer, this is
Europe s  big bang  response. The rescue mechanism as framed would essentially
enable distressed euro countries to draw special loans from the European
Commission. In a separate but related development, the purchase of government
debt by the European Central Bank (ECB) is also in prospect.

While numerous technical and legal questions remain to be answered, it is clear
that hundreds of billions of euro would be involved if either plan was deployed.
Each is emblematic of a massive expansion in the EU s economic remit and each
takes the 16 countries that use the euro deeper and deeper into each other s
fiscal affairs. For Minister for Finance Brian Lenihan, this will mean yet more
pressure to balance the public finances from Brussels and the markets.

If the euro is the single biggest example of European integration, more
integration could yet flow from this affair. Already on the table, for example,
are plans that would oblige governments to submit their budget plans for prior
approval to other capitals. Whatever the outcome of the talks, budgetary
surveillance will intensify in the future and economic targets will be tougher.

Thus the plans are fraught with tension, weighed down by huge financial risk and
riddled with potential for conflict.

As the 27 EU finance ministers gathered in Brussels yesterday, the atmosphere
was described as  tense . It was the same on Friday night when the leaders of
the 16 euro countries decided to rush out a drastic plan to shore up the euro
before markets reopen this morning after the weekend break.

This raises serious questions about the merits of creating the expectation of a
silver bullet to diminish a crisis whose ultimate solution lies in a years-long
effort to bring wayward public finances to heel throughout the euro zone. That
said, the move reflects the sense of alarm that has taken hold in capital cities
throughout Europe.

While the relentless politicking that delayed the Greek rescue exposed seismic
schisms between Berlin, Paris and Brussels, the present debate is no less
barbed. In many ways, however, this is but the logical outcome of the Greek
rescue. After all, the EUR 110 billion bailout for Athens set a precedent for
euro countries assuming the financial burden of a partner in distress.

Once they went down that road   and not a single cent has yet been handed over
to Athens   every country was essentially on the hook for every other country.
EU leaders certainly didn t want to go any further than their ad hoc
intervention in Greece, but the force of the contagion that took hold as Spain
and Portugal came under pressure last week was such that further action was
inevitable.

There would be two separate strands to the loan mechanism. First, an existing EU
scheme which enables non-euro members to draw down loans from the European
Commission to help balance their books will be extended to empower the
commission to lend to members of the single currency.

In the past, Hungary, Romania and Latvia were beneficiaries of such funding. The
commission sources money for this scheme   known as the  Balance of Payments
Facility    on international markets using its own budget as collateral. Under
discussion yesterday was a proposal to increase the money available from the
facility by some EUR 60 billion to about EUR 110 billion. Comparatively,
however, this is small money.

Hence a separate manoeuvre massively to increase the commission s borrowing
power by having member states guarantee the money it sourced on the markets to
be lent to distressed euro countries. In its conception, this is a simple idea.
In practice, the notion spawns a litter of dilemmas. Prime among the unanswered
questions yesterday was whether the loan guarantees should come exclusively from
the euro zone countries or from all 27 member states.

In favour of a 27-country guarantee is the argument that the  community
instrument  such as the mooted stabilisation fund   whose activation would bring
a huge financial weight on the commission   should be supported by all member
states. As the talks began, however, British chancellor Alistair Darling argued
that only the euro 16 should be guarantors.

While numerous other questions arise, the legal significance of the initiative s
structure is that it would not violate the no-bailout clause in the EU treaties.
The bailout ban prohibits special ECB overdraft facilities for euro countries.
The commission would lean on a separate legal provision that allows the granting
of EU  financial assistance  where a member state is in difficulties or is
seriously threatened with severe difficulties caused by natural disasters or
exceptional occurrences beyond its control.

Still, the ECB was widely expected last night to make a significant intervention
in its own right by promising to buy up government bonds from euro countries.
This lies within the bank s powers, but is itself highly risky as it essentially
involves releasing hundreds of billions of euro into the European economy.

With that comes the threat of rising inflation and the prospect of higher
interest rates, something that carries its own risks in a volatile economic
scenario.

Still, the clear sense in Brussels is that the time for decisive action to save
the euro is nigh. It was not without irony that the talks yesterday took place
on Europe Day, when the EU marks the anniversary of the 1950 call by French
foreign minister Robert Schuman for Franco-German coal and steel production to
be placed under a common high authority. While the EU traces its roots to that
clarion call, its unity and sense of mission are being tested now as never
before.

LOAD-DATE: May 10, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                         Copyright 2010 The Irish Times
                              All Rights Reserved


                              978 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Q and A: CEO of the Community Preservation Corp. Tries to Build on His
Institution's Success

                            August 23, 1993, Monday


Michael D. Lappin is president and chief executive of the not-for profit
Community Preservation Corp., which he says is the nation's biggest building
operation for low cost.

The organization, which is based in New York City, was founded in 1974 and
currently is sponsored by 50 banks and insurance companies.

The institution hasn't suffered a loss, and it has helped to rehabilitate and
build 34,000 units of housing with more than $1 billion in public and private
investment. It also is managing a loan consortium of 80 banks in upstate New
York.

Mr. Lappin visited the American Banker bureau last week while in Washington
trying to persuade agencies such as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to guarantee the
loans underwritten by his operation and others like it.

Q.: You have quite a few foreign banks as sponsors, don't you? LAPPIN: That's a
recent development. We opened up membership about four or five years ago.

Q.: How does one join up? LAPPIN:You have to make a contribution and then you
have to participate in our credit facilities - a $144 million construction
credit facility and a permanent credit facility.

The minimum contribution to is $15,000, plus $450,000 of each line of credit.
Chemical Bank is our largest investor. They provide about $30 million.

Q.: Who are your customers? LAPPIN: Small borrowers, lots of recent immigrants
who own, say, a 40-unit dilapidated building in the South Bronx and want to
renovate it. We not only provide credit, but help obtain timly approval by the
building departments and other help.

Q.: That sounds like a lot of work. How many people do you have working for you?
LAPPIN: Forty. In many cases, public subsidies are available for the borrower,
and we try to link these subsidies when proper.

There also are various tax abatements, and we understand them and weave them
into the underwriting. We also do all the negotiating with the various public
agencies that administer these diverse programs.

What we've done - and this is key to our success - has been to create a one-stop
shop, where we work with the government and try to work many of these things out
in advance.

For example, there is a program where the city will put in below market money -
in a secondary position to private money - to fix up old apartment houses.

So rather than the owner going to the city to make a separate application, we
basically handle the application for them.

And there's a single commitment where we commit our funds and the public funds
at the same time. There's a single closing. And there's one engineer that
approves the requisitions. The public deposits all the funds with us. And so we
manage that process for the city.

Q.: What rates do you charge on the loans? LAPPIN: Market rates. The
underwriting is conventional underwriting. It's bankable underwriting. A lot of
our guys (bankers) say it's the best real estate portfolio in town.

We borrow from the banks at prime and lend at prime plus two.  We price
long-term financing off of Ginnie Mae.

Q.: Do the banks participate because they're trying to comply with the Community
Reinvestment Act? LAPPIN: It's a reasonable way to invest. Part of the reason
may be CRA. But most tell me, "do what's best for the community."

Q.: Explain the lending process. LAPPIN: We use the $144 million line of credit
for construction loans. Simultaneously, we'll do a permanent takeout. The source
of that can be the banks, in which case we'll issue them a privately placed
mortgage backed security, an unrated piece. A second source used a lot now is
public pension funds.

New York City and New York State, together, have committed to purchase up to
$550 million of whole loans from us on a forward basis if they get the State of
New York Mortgage Agency, our local credit enhancement agency, to ensure these
loans, which they do very readily.

They also commit at the date of construction to lock in a rate. The rate for a
project that will be completed two years from now is 820 (8.20%) or 830 for 30
years, fixed-rate paper. It's a terrific deal.

Q.: What are you asking for down here in Washington? LAPPIN: We think there is a
way of doing nationally what we're doing in New York to allow pension funds and
insurance companies and large institutional investors to purchase on a forward
basis.

There are other organizations like ours around the country that do an excellent
job but can't get long-term holders for this paper. That's what we're asking
Freddie and Fannie about.

Also, if we had Freddie and Fannie, our institutional investors would take a
lower yield.

SECTION: WASHINGTON MONDAY; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 772 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              979 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                              North Bay Nipissing

                            October 28, 2013 Monday
                                  ONT Edition

Waste and fines responsible gas plant bill

SECTION: Pg. 0

LENGTH: 415  words


NIPISSING - The full price tag for canceling two gas plants in southern Ontario
has only just come to light and the local MPP said northern Ontarians are going
to have to help pay the bill.

Vic Fedeli, MPP for the Nipissing riding, said Ontarians will end up paying more
than $1 billion for canceling gas plants in Mississauga and Oakville. The plans
for the two facilities, which were intended to fill the growing power needs of
those communities, were canceled prior to the 2011 provincial election.

"All together it's a billion dollars for absolutely nothing," said Fedeli.

An auditor general's report on the cost released earlier this month detailed a
bill that included requiring the government to compensate the full value of the
canceled contract to the developer and to pay back a number of lenders.

"In Oakville they had to purchase gas turbines they can't use - that's $210
million. They spent $40 million preparing the site. They spent $3 million on
legal fees," Fedeli said.

"They relocated the project to Napanee, Ontario which is hundreds of kilometres
away from where they need the power in Oakville. So now they have to ship gas
down there to run the gas plant - that's $577 million."

Moving the plant to Napanee led to a number of increased costs. Additional
turbines had to be purchased, and a new transmission system is required to
transfer power between where the power is being generated and where it is most
needed.

"The Mississauga gas plant is even more heinous," said Fedeli. "$150 million was
spent to pay off a loan holder down in the U.S. even though the loan was only
$49 million. They have to pay back the whole loan guarantee of $150 million so
that company made $101 million for absolutely no money being lent."

Fedeli says the whole thing started back in the mid-2000s when the government
decided additional power was needed for the communities of Mississauga and
Oakville. When they started lobbying against having the construction within
their community, the provincial government changed the plan.

After months of questioning and requests for documents the full cost of the
change was revealed.

"It brings the two of them together to over a billion dollars, and that's only
to cancel the gas plants - it does not give us one megawatt of power," said
Fedeli.

"How do you pay for all that? Your hydro bills are going up on Nov. 1."

Fedeli said there will be a 12 per cent year-over-year increase to the hydro
bill.

Story by Rolland Cilliers rcilliers@metrolandnorthmedia.com

LOAD-DATE: October 29, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                             July 30, 2015 Thursday

Failed Brattleboro project gets $2.5 million in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By Robert Audette raudette@reformer.com @audette.reformer on Twitter

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 704 words


KEENE, N.H. &GT;&GT; A failed project to use methane as energy at the Windham
Solid Waste Management District in Brattleboro got a new lease on life in the
Granite State.

On Thursday, at Keene's transfer and recylcing station on Route 12 North, Dean
Lizotte, the CFO of the Keene Energy and Agricultural Project, announced KEAP
has secured $2.5 million to construct a facility to grow 500,000 pounds of
lettuce a year.

"The proposal in Brattleboro was much different," said Lizotte. "It was to be a
model and training facility. And the investor group for KEAP is much different,
too."

The Local Food Project, which will operate KEAP, was founded by former Carbon
Harvest president Donald McCormick, who attempted to start an
aquaculture/agriculture project at WSWMD. That project failed in 2012 and Carbon
Harvest was placed into bankruptcy. Much of its equipment   $270,000 worth   was
sold off in the bankruptcy proceedings to a Portsmouth company.

Lizotte said Carbon Harvest had only one investor, and according to the Keene
Sentinel, McCormick told Keene officials Carbon Harvest failed because the
investor pulled out of the project.

KEAP was approved in the summer of 2014 and hopes to break ground on a
40,000-square-foot greenhouse this year. In addition to the greenhouse, a
15,000-square-foot processing facility is planned for the site. Lizotte said the
project will bring 25 "living wage jobs" to the Keene area.

KEAP will use the waste heat from a methane-powered turbine funded by an EPA
Climate Showcase Communities Grant to heat the greenhouse. The methane for the
power plant will be tapped from the capped and closed landfill at the transfer
station. Keene has been operating an on-site 250kw power generator since the
1990s but it has not been connected to the grid. As part of the KEAP project,
the Keene methane-to electricity project will be refurbished, a 350kw generator
will be added and it will be connected to the grid.

Lizotte said KEAP has several investors for the project, including the New
Hampshire Community Loan Fund and that the Bank of New Hampshire is also
supplying funding. He also said KEAP is the sub-recipient of the $500,000
Climate Showcase Communities Grant, which was awared to Keene. The city of Keene
also committed $225,000 in improvements to the site, which is on a hill
overlooking the transfer station.

KEAP also received $480,000 in low-interest loans from a Community Development
Block Grant administered by the Monadnock Economic Development Corporation. As
repayment is made, $250,000 of the loaned amount will be routed into a revolving
loan fund and investment program seeded with $250,000 donated by the Entergy
Charitable Foundation.

When McCormick proposed the project in Brattleboro, he received $40,000 from the
town's revolving loan fund. When the project failed, Carbon Harvest paid back
$26,000 of the total.

"We don't have any expectations of getting that $14,000 back," said Patrick
Moreland, Brattleboro's Assistant Town Manager. "We are pretty far down on
Carbon Harvest's list of creditors. We did have a personal guarantee from
McCormick, and reason to expect it would be honored, but, unfortunately, we lost
out."

Carbon Harvest also took out $810,000 in loans from Vermont Economic Development
Authority, which held the first lien on the company's equipment.

KEAP will be similar to the proposal in Brattleboro. The project will produce
high quality fish protein and fresh vegetables, which will be sold locally.
Water from the aqualculture operation will be used to provide high value organic
nutrients for the plants and an algae culture system. Working in partnership
with the University of Vermont's Rubenstein School, Keene State College and
Dartmouth College, the algae culture system will be designed to capture
remaining wastes and carbon and convert them to algae for production of biofuel
and livestock feed for fish and poultry.

This zero-fossil-fuel facility is expected to remove approximately 20,000 metric
tons of carbon per year from landfill gas emissions and convert this source of
greenhouse gas into high quality local food, biofuel and aquaculture feed while
producing virtually zero waste.

Bob Audette can be contacted at 802-254-2311, ext. 160.

LOAD-DATE: July 31, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


   Copyright 2015 MediaNews Group, Inc. and New England Newspaper Group Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              981 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                       The Daily Gleaner (New Brunswick)

                           January 13, 2007 Saturday

PULPMISSION; Two years after Nackawic's biggest employer shut down without
warning, the mill is back on the path to prosperity

BYLINE: By MICHAEL STAPLES staples.michael@dailygleaner.com

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 1079  words


NACKAWIC - Millions of dollars will be poured into this community's pulp mill
over the next several months.

The operators of AV Nackawic Inc. announced this week they are moving ahead with
a $30-million plan to convert the former St. Anne-Nackawic mill into a plant
that produces dissolving pulp, a product used to manufacture rayon.

Peter Vinall, president and CEO of the AV Group, said the plan sends a positive
sign to the community that the company is committed to Nackawic.

"It sends a good signal that somebody is prepared to invest in this sector,"
Vinall said in an interview with The Daily Gleaner.

"You haven't seen many investments in this sector of that scale. We haven't seen
mills re-starting with this kind of vision and this kind of an opportunity. "

The St. Anne-Nackawic Pulp Co. Ltd. was purchased in 2005 by the Aditya Birla
Group of India and Quebec-based Tembec, after $67.5 million in loans and loan
guarantees were provided by the province.

It resumed production in late January 2006 after being closed in September 2004
when the previous owners declared bankruptcy.

While a large portion of the $30 million being invested also comes with a loan
guarantee by the province, that doesn't mean there is a cost to the taxpayer,
Vinall said.

"There is zero cost to the province. A loan guarantee does not mean cash."

Vinall said that while the province has supported the mill, residents should not
be concerned because the company has a good business plan in place.

Since re-opening its doors, AV Nackawic, which now employs almost 300 workers,
has produced kraft pulp, a product used in the manufacture of specialized paper
products.

While the conversion to dissolving pulp is costing about $5-million more than
was anticipated, the commitment is to build a good plant that has a long- term
future, Vinall said.

The mill is expected to produce its first dissolved pulp next winter.

"The next 12 months are crucial because we're designing the future of the mill
and we're building it," Vinall said. "In the following 12 months, we have to
live up to the expectations and the plans that we have set for ourselves."

Construction work, set to begin this spring, will include an expansion of the
digesting plant and the incorporation of "significant" changes to the overall
production process.

Vinall said the construction phase of the conversion could result in the
creation of scores of temporary jobs.

The plan is for the company, which also operates a dissolving pulp mill in
Atholville, to ship the majority of its new product to India, Thailand,
Indonesia and possibly China.

"That's the exciting part of our business - getting to a value-added product, "
Vinall said. "Getting to a place where we have secure customers. Ninety-per-
cent (and more) of our product is going to be sold to Birla. They have big
operations to convert this specialty pulp into rayon in India, Thailand and
Indonesia."

One of the things being looked at, once the conversion is completed, is
establishing a marketing presence in New Brunswick - one that will serve as a
portal into the U.S. market for the many garments produced.

"The first steps for that would be to set up some sort of a design studio with a
portfolio of products - a place where we can bring potential customers in,"
Vinall said. "The idea would be to situate that here in New Brunswick."

The main competition for the company is South Africa and Brazil - areas that
have access to cheaper wood supplies.

Vinall said the AV Nackawic mill will maintain its capability to produce kraft
products.

Both, however, cannot be manufactured simultaneously. The plan is to produce
dissolving pulp 75 per cent of the time.

Mark Cloutier, president of the Canadian Auto Workers union local representing
unionized workers at the mill, said workers share the company's vision for the
mill and its enthusiasm. He said he's confident about the mill's future.

"When we get on to this dissolving pulp ... this dissolving pulp will be our
future," he said. "Without it, I don't think it will go. They are committed to
putting money into the mill, changing over to dissolving pulp and to basically
getting this community back on its feet."

Cloutier said the union, which has given up a lot, has made a commitment to work
with the company.

Vinall said since the mill re-started in January 2006, it has met all
expectations and had an "outstanding" initial period.

"The mill is making money and we recently skipped into the black, which is a
good place to be," Vinall said.

"But you know we have got $100 million invested into the place to date and
that's a long-term investment. We need to make money to pay back the loans, and
we have a lot of debt on our books right now that's been accrued to get us to
the place we are today."

The plant currently produce 3,300 bales of kraft product a day - with each bale
weighing about 240 kilograms. The product makes its way into the U.S., Europe,
China, Japan, Korea, Pakistan, Turkey and Israel.

That's about where the company wants to be with regard to production, said Tim
Benesh, manager of customer service and logistics for the AV Group.

"This (the kraft product now being produced) is used for everything from
specialty printing grades, writing grades to specialty packaging for food
products and medical products," Benesh said. "It is (also) used for laminates in
flooring - just a broad range of uses."

Customers buying the Nackawic product usually mix it with other types of wood
pulp, ranging from softwood to eucalyptus.

Benesh said AV Nackawic runs 24 hours a day and products are shipped on a
continuous basis.

"We are probably in the top of the market right now and have been for the last
couple of months," Benesh said. "What we are seeing now is more supply coming
into the market, which is completely a supply-driven situation."

Vinall, meanwhile, said the company is confident about its future.

"We have a lot to live up to, but so far it has been a good run. But we also
recognize there are going to be challenges into the future."

QUICK FACTS

- The mill produces about 3,300 bales of kraft products a day.

- Financially, the mill is in the black.

* AV Nackawic Inc. is moving ahead with a $30-million plan to convert the mill
to produce dissolving pulp, a product used to manufacture rayon.

- Some work is already underway, with construction expected to start in the
spring.

- Scores of spinoff jobs are expected to be created.

- First dissolving-pulp products are expected to be produced in about 12 months.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Regulatory update: North Carolina Utilities Commission;Frontier Natural Gas
Company, LLC , has issued (G-40 Sub 133) Affidavit of James E. Sprague

LENGTH: 6059 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Raleigh: North Carolina Utilities Commission has issued the following document
(filing):



 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 UTILITIES COMMISSION

 RALEIGH

 Docket No. G-40, Sub 133

 BEFORE THE NORTH CAROLINA UTILITIES COMMISSION:

 In the Matter of:

 Application of Frontier Natural Gas

 Company, LLC for Conditional Approvals

 Relating to Corporate Reorganization and

 Debt Refinancing

 )



 )

 )

 )

 )

 AFFIDAVIT OF FRED A. STEELE

 The undersigned, having first been duly sworn, deposes and says as follows:

 1. My name is Fred A. Steele. I am over the age of 18 and otherwise competent
to

 testify. I have reviewed the statements herein, and swear that they are true,
to the best of my

 personal knowledge.

 2. I am the President and General Manager of Frontier Natural Gas Company, LLC

 ("Frontier"). My business address is 110 PGW Drive, Elkin, NC 28621.

 3. The purpose ofthis Affidavit is to generally describe the Application for

 Approvals of Corporate Reorganization and Debt Refinancing ("Application") that
is filed

 concurrently herewith, as well as a new proposed corporate reorganization
between Frontier's

 ultimate parent, Gas Natural Inc. ("GNI"), and it's various subsidiaries. In
addition, I will also

 summarize the proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier by
which Frontier

 will access the funds available through the GNI refinancing, and provide my
opinion, as General

 Manager of Frontier, that this financing is in the best long-term interest of
Frontier and its

 customers.

 4. The proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier include three

 (3) agreements: (1) Revolving Line of Credit for access to $7.2 million; (2)
Long Term Note in

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 1

 the amount of$8.7 million; and (3) Four Year Term Note for the SAP IT Operating
System in

 the amount of$1.075 million.

 5. As is more fully described in the Application verified by Kevin Degenstein
and

 Jim Sprague, this new corporate structure and the new the intercompany
financing agreements

 through which Frontier will receive its financing require Commission approval
pursuant to

 N.C.G.S. §§ 62-111(a), 62-153, and 62-161 . I am providing this Affidavit
concurrently with,

 and in support of, the Application requesting this approval.

 Corporate Reorganization

 6. Under the current corporate structure, GNI is the ultimate parent of several


 entities including Energy West Incorporated (EWI). GNI also separately owns
other regulated

 utilities that operate distribution systems and an intrastate pipeline in Ohio
and is the parent of

 several unregulated entities as well. EWI is the parent of several regulated
utilities in Montana,

 Maine, and North Carolina, including Frontier Utilities of North Carolina, Inc.
("Frontier

 Utilities"), which is the intermediate holding company for Frontier. A current
corporate

 structure is set forth in Exhibit 1 attached to this Affidavit.

 Having EWI, which is regulated by the Montana Commission, serve as the parent
of

 Frontier Utilities and other regulated utilities, as well as GNI' s ownership
of other unregulated

 businesses in other states, has created in my opinion the potential for
jurisdictional conflict,

 confusion in accountability, and the potential for inconsistent practices among
subsidiaries.

 7. Under the newly proposed corporate structure, GNI would continue to be the

 ultimate parent of Frontier. However, Frontier Utilities will be dissolved and
a new subsidiary

 of GNI (currently designated as a newly formed intermediary company ("NIC") for
the purpose

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 2

 of the Application) would serve as the holding company for Frontier as well as
the other

 regulated affiliates operating in Ohio, Montana and Maine.

 8. The regulated subsidiaries would all become direct, separate subsidiaries of
GNI

 through NIC, not through a variety of different regulated and non-regulated
holding companies.

 GNI will also directly own the other non-regulated companies currently
operating in the Midwest

 and Montana, but these unregulated companies will be separate from the
regulated companies

 The new proposed corporate structure is set forth below in Exhibit 2 attached
to this Affidavit.

 9. It is my opinion and belief that this new proposed structure is beneficial
for a

 number of reasons. It essentially separates Frontier, as a North Carolina
regulated utility, for

 corporate formation, operational, regulatory, and financing purposes and
provides for consistent

 governance over all regulated utilities. It eliminates the concern of potential
multi-jurisdictional

 regulatory conflict and potential confusion by GNI' s current ownership
structure of regulated

 and unregulated subsidiaries. It still provides, however, the benefits of being
part of a larger

 organization with shared resources, expertise, and best practices, economies of
scale, and access

 to capital, as illustrated by the proposed financed discussed below.

 Debt Financing Agreements

 10. As part ofthe last financing case filed in Docket G-40, Sub 105 and
approved by

 Commission Order dated August 8, 2012 ("Refinancing Order"), the Commission
approved a

 credit agreement between Energy West Incorporated ("EWI") and Frontier that
consisted of a

 $30 million unsecured revolving line of credit and a $10 million unsecured
long-term debt

 facility. Frontier was a part of the pool of guarantors of this financing,
along with other EWI

 subsidiaries, and provided a limited recourse guarantee of $12.8 million of the
aggregate amount.

 During the proceedings, the Public Staff expressed concerns that the $12.8
million limited

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 3

 recourse guarantee of Frontier could cause Frontier to guarantee more debt than
EWI had

 borrowed and provided on Frontier's behalf, but ultimately recommended the
approval to avoid

 the risks created by rejection of the proposed refinancing transactions.

 11. That debt package is not in default and is still providing financing to
Frontier, but

 it expires in a little over a year, on April 1, 2017. Since the time of the
Refinancing Order in

 2012, GNI and its subsidiaries, including Frontier, have been exploring
alternative forms of

 financing, as well as a new corporate structure, as described above, to
accommodate and

 facilitate this financing.

 12. Beginning in November 2014, I began identifying potential lenders for

 replacement financing directly to Frontier. I sent letters attached to this
Affidavit as Exhibit 3 to

 Yadkin Bank, BB&T, Carter Banlc & Trust, and First Community Bank requesting
term sheets

 for a Term Loan and revolving Line of Credit for Frontier. I also provided each
ofthese banks

 with information about Frontier in order for them to evaluate and respond to
our request,

 including financial statements, service territory maps, corporate
organizational chart, listing of

 the property, plant, and equipment, schedule of rates for all classes of
customers, schedule of

 largest customers and their annual usage, regulatory reports, pipeline maps
showing the

 transmission, distribution, and service lines, and schedule showing the number
of customers in

 each of the service areas served by Frontier.

 13. To follow-up, I had several individual meetings with representatives from
Yadkin

 Bank and First Community Bank, culminating in meetings by Kevin Degenstein, Jed
Henthorne,

 and me with each banlc on April27, 2015. In addition, I met with
representatives ofBB&T in

 mid-2015. I also had several telephone conversations with bankers at Carter
Bank & Trust to

 assess their interest and answer their questions.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 4

 14. After all of these efforts over several months, the only bank that
submitted a term

 sheet was First Community Bank which is attached hereto as Confidential Exhibit
4. Based

 upon this experience, it is my belief that Frontier's small size was a major
impediment to

 receiving attractive financing options from independent lenders.

 15. I evaluated the proposal from First Community Bank carefully, but concluded
that

 it did not provide the flexibility and terms necessary for Frontier's financing
needs and that

 would allow Frontier to continue to operate successfully and expand as we
intend. It was

 certainly not comparable to the financing being offered through the
intercompany agreements

 with GNI described below.

 16. GNI management, on behalf of its subsidiaries and in consultation with me
and

 my counterparts with the other regulated operating utilities, also solicited
and evaluated debt

 financing options. We evaluated the financing options that were presented and
the

 organizational structure that would allow us to achieve the company's goal and
accommodate the

 necessary financing within the regulatory framework in which we operate. We
have now

 finalized that process and are proposing an organizational structure and
financing arrangement

 that I believe should simplify regulatory oversight, ensure accountability,
improve operational

 efficiencies, and provide sufficient capital to Frontier on the most cost
effective basis.

 17. Under the proposed financing, as explained in the Application, the
currently

 effective amended and restated credit agreement between EWI and Bank of America
("BOA")

 will be replaced by a new senior credit agreement between GNI and BOA ("the BOA
Senior

 Credit Facility"). This GNI financing will take the form of a $42 million
revolving line of credit

 that will be available for a period of five years for GNI to provide funds
pursuant to

 intercompany notes to Frontier and the other regulated operating utilities,
designed to ensure the

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 5

 regulated utilities such as Frontier have adequate access to capital during the
winter season and

 in order to procure gas supply in connection with operations, as well as for
other general

 operational purposes. Guarantees of the BOA Senior Credit Facility will be
required only from

 the unregulated subsidiaries of GNI and from NIC, while GNI will be the sole
Borrower. No

 direct recourse from BOA will extend to regulated subsidiaries downstream ofNIC
such as to

 Frontier. The revolving facility will terminate five years from closing.

 18. GNI also plans to issue up to $50 million ofNew Senior Unsecured Notes
("the

 Senior Unsecured Notes"), the terms of which are fully discussed by James E.
Sprague, GNI

 Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, in his Affidavit. Both the proceeds
from the Senior

 Credit Facility and from the Senior Unsecured Notes will be used to refinance
the existing debt

 and provide financing for general operational purposes and system expansion.

 19. The long-term note, which details the obligations ofGNI as the issuer, as
well as

 the non-regulated subsidiary guarantors, does not include Frontier as a direct
issuer or guarantor

 (similar to the revolving line with BOA). Neither Frontier, nor any of GNI's
other regulated

 operating utilities, will have any obligation for activities, borrowings, or
guarantees provided by

 any other GNI company or directly on the long-term note.

 20. The third component of the financing is a four (4) year term debt facility
in the

 amount of $7.0 million that will be used to consolidate several smaller loans
by GNI used for

 acquisition and development of an SAP software based operating system used by
all of the GNI

 companies (the "SAP Financing"). As is the case with the revolving line of
credit and the long

 term note issuance, GNI will be the sole borrower for the SAP Financing, no
guarantees will be

 required of the regulated operating utilities, including Frontier, and Frontier
will only be

 responsible through an intercompany note between GNI and Frontier for a
proportional piece of

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 6

 the SAP Financing. BOA is the proposed lender on the SAP Financing and will
require the SAP

 Software license to be pledged by GNI as collateral for this $7.0 million loan.


 21. Frontier will not have any guarantees directly to BOA. Based upon the
credit

 available through the BOA Senior Credit Facility, Senior Unsecured Notes, and
SAP Financing,

 Frontier will be eligible to draw a total of$15.9 million for its own
operational needs ($7.2

 million under the revolving line of credit, $8.7 million under the long-term
debt) and in addition

 receive $1.07 5 million from the SAP Financing (of which $820,000 will pay
Frontier's portion

 of the cost of the SAP software, licenses, and installation). If approved,
Frontier will enter into

 three intercompany notes with GNI, without any obligations directly to BOA or
Merrill Lynch

 ("ML"). Under the intercompany agreements, Frontier's only obligations will be
to GNI and its

 exposure is limited to what is has borrowed and used and extends no further.

 22. There are several benefits to Frontier under this financing structure as
compared

 to the structure that has been in place since 2012. First, as mentioned,
Frontier has no direct

 responsibility to BOA for either credit facility. Further, because funds for
the individual

 operating companies are treated separately and are reserved for the operating
subsidiaries under

 distinct, standalone "silos", there is no danger that the needs of other
utilities will impinge upon

 Frontier's access to its own capital or create any risk to Frontier. Upon
approval of the

 intercompany loans requested in this application, the new debt will be put in
place, paying off the

 existing debt and Frontier will execute its intercompany notes for access to
stand-alone line of

 credit through GNI. The other operating utilities will execute their own
intercompany notes and

 have access to their own lines, independent of Frontier and any other GNI
obligations. As a

 result of this structure, there is no potential for cross-collateralization or
cross-default. Also,

 Frontier will have full access to the SAP Software and operating system and all
of the associated

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 7

 developments related to the system although it will only be responsible for a
fraction of the

 development costs. Each of the GNI entities will benefit similarly.

 23. The Company has reviewed its operating needs over the last four years,
which

 have included periods of major construction and capital expansion efforts and
periods when the

 cost of gas has been high during winter months. The total amount of the
proposed debt should

 be sufficient to give Frontier adequate headroom in meeting its operational
needs, including

 anticipated construction, cost of gas, etc. in the years ahead, based on its
current capital

 expenditure forecasts.

 24. In the previous financing proceeding, the Public Staff expressed concerns
with

 Frontier's financial obligations to BOA for the credit facility and its
execution of a limited

 recourse guarantee. The proposed financing arrangement addresses those
concerns. Unlike the

 last financing proceeding, the current financing arrangement is between GNI and
BOA, and

 Frontier and other regulated subsidiaries have no obligations to the ultimate
lender or to each

 other. Frontier will only be obligated for funds to which it has access, and no
other subsidiary or

 GNI will have access to those funds. The intercompany loan agreements between
Frontier and

 GNI will establish the limits of its obligations and make it clear that
Frontier's obligations are

 limited by its borrowings. No assets will be pledged or required by Frontier to
secure access to

 this working capital and long term debt. The only asset that is pledged as
collateral for any of

 the three facilities is the SAP Software, pledged by GNI. This structure should
significantly

 reduce or even eliminate the prior concerns that the Public Staff had regarding
Frontier's

 obligations.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 8

 25. Frontier has continued to add to its infrastructure to access new market
areas and

 to expand service in its service territory. As noted in the testimony filed in
Frontier's annual

 review of gas costs dockets, the number of customers served by Frontier has
increased 26% from

 2011 to 2012, 28% from 2012 to 2013, 27.7% from 2013 to 2014 and 11.8% from
2014 to 2015.

 Frontier needs both short-term and long-term debt resources in order to have
sufficient access to

 meet cyclical cash flow needs throughout the year, to pay fixed expenses during
non-heating

 months, to benefit from seasonal opportunities and provide operational
flexibility to lower

 overall costs, and to provide long-term financing for capital investments to
allow it to continue to

 grow as it has over the past few years.

 26. I believe that the proposed intercompany agreements with GNI offer the most
cost

 effective option for financing for Frontier. What I have learned over the past
year is that many

 lenders are not familiar with the utility and gas industry and are hesitant to
lend or offer credit at

 a premium in order to cover their perception of potential risks. In addition,
financing is an area

 where there are economies of scale. At the parent level, due to the size of the
facility, GNI is

 better able to secure more favorable interest rates and other terms, and pass
those benefits on to

 Frontier through the intercompany agreements.

 27. Finally, I want to note that Frontier currently has a shared services
agreement with

 EWI, which has been previously filed with the Commission. This agreement
allowed EWI to

 charge Frontier for shared services. Since EWI will no longer be the parent of
Frontier, the

 Company will need to enter into a new shared services agreement with NIC (and
NIC will in turn

 enter into a similar agreement with GNI). The new shared services agreements
shall contain the

 same terms as those in the existing agreement; the only difference is that
current intermediate

 holding company has been substituted for GNI as the party to the agreement with
Frontier.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 9

 Under these arrangements, centralized administrative and professional services
such as

 accounting, legal, engineering, technology systems, data management or other
shared services

 for GNI subsidiaries are provided. Expenses that arise from the individual
needs of any specific

 subsidiary are directly assigned to that entity. This will continue to ensure
that Frontier's

 ratepayers are only responsible for those expenditures necessary for the
efficient and reliable

 operation of Frontier. This new shared service agreement will be filed with the
Commission

 upon approval of the corporate reorganization,

 Further affiant sayeth not.

 Fred A. Steele

 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 SURRY COUNTY

 Sworn to~d subscribed before me

 this ~&middot;aay 2016.

 aWl~

 Notary Public

 \ (SEAL)

 RALEIGH 501299,5

 10

 Re: Term Loan and Revolving Line of Credit Inquiry for Frontier Natural Gas

 Dear Van:

 Thank you for lunch and for taking the time to discuss the financing needs of
Frontier Natural Gas, LLC

 (FNG). We discussed several options for financing and we are very interested in
any proposals that you

 find worthy of consideration. Following up on our lunch and telephone
discussions I felt it best to seek

 the input of senior management and formalize our thoughts on a credit facility.


 We would like to formalize our request for the stand-alone financing package in
the form of this letter.

 Frontier Natural Gas (FNG) requests a term sheet from your bank specifying the
conditions under which

 you would consider offering a senior credit facility to FNG. We are seeking a
facility that might contain

 the following general characteristics:

 1. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for

 issuing standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Tenn Facility: Up to $11,000,000 term loan facility ("term facility", and
together with

 the revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility
")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and

 payable in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily

 unused portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees

 of Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

 6. Closing anticipated immediately upon Borrower's receipt of all required
regulatory approvals.

 While BoiTower cannot predict with certainty the timing of receipt of such
approvals,

 Borrower anticipates such receipt by or before May 31, 2015.

 The loan proceeds of the term facility will be employed for re-financing of all
FNG's existing long term

 debt and for other general corporate purposes including long term capital
expenditures. Draws on the

 revolving facility will be employed for working capital requirements including
gas purchases and short

 term capital expenditures.

 110 PGW Drive &middot; Elkin &middot; North Carolina &middot; 28621&middot; Ph:
336-526-2690 &middot; Fax: 336&middot;526-9940

 FNG is a local natural gas public utility subject to the statutory regulatory
jurisdiction of the North

 Carolina Public Utilities Commission. We serve approximately 2,900 customers in
Ashe, Watauga,

 Warren, Wilkes, Surry and Yadkin Counties, North Carolina. We are a subsidiary
of Energy West

 Incorporated which is in turn a subsidiary of Gas Natural Inc., which is a
utility holding company

 publicly traded on the NYSE MKT Equities Exchange (ticker symbol: EGAS).

 In addition to the information previously provided-, we enclose the latest
annual report for FNG filed with

 the North Caro1ina Public Utilities Commission for CY 2013 .. That annual
report includes balance sheet

 and income statements for the calendar year and information regarding employees
in this state, and the

 volumes of natural gas sold at retail and delivered or transported to
consumers. Also included is the

 December 31,2013 Form 10-K filed by Gas Natural Inc. with the Securities
Exchange Commission,

 reflecting both segment financial information of the regulated utility segment
and consolidated results.

 We have also enclosed our corporate organizational chart. If there is any
additional information you

 require, please do not hesitate to request it.

 I emphasize that if you do not find the conceptual framework we have laid out
in this proposal to be

 acceptable to you, we specifically solicit a response from you that includes a
financing facility on terms

 you would consider. I request the favor of your response before close of
business on January 7, 2015.

 Thank you.

 Sincerely yours,

 F~ A S}JJ

                                US Official News

                            February 19, 2016 Friday

Regulatory update: North Carolina Utilities Commission;Frontier Natural Gas
Company, LLC , has issued (G-40 Sub 133) Affidavit of James E. Sprague

LENGTH: 6059 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Raleigh: North Carolina Utilities Commission has issued the following document
(filing):



 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 UTILITIES COMMISSION

 RALEIGH

 Docket No. G-40, Sub 133

 BEFORE THE NORTH CAROLINA UTILITIES COMMISSION:

 In the Matter of:

 Application of Frontier Natural Gas

 Company, LLC for Conditional Approvals

 Relating to Corporate Reorganization and

 Debt Refinancing

 )



 )

 )

 )

 )

 )

 AFFIDAVIT OF FRED A. STEELE

 The undersigned, having first been duly sworn, deposes and says as follows:

 1. My name is Fred A. Steele. I am over the age of 18 and otherwise competent
to

 testify. I have reviewed the statements herein, and swear that they are true,
to the best of my

 personal knowledge.

 2. I am the President and General Manager of Frontier Natural Gas Company, LLC

 ("Frontier"). My business address is 110 PGW Drive, Elkin, NC 28621.

 3. The purpose ofthis Affidavit is to generally describe the Application for

 Approvals of Corporate Reorganization and Debt Refinancing ("Application") that
is filed

 concurrently herewith, as well as a new proposed corporate reorganization
between Frontier's

 ultimate parent, Gas Natural Inc. ("GNI"), and it's various subsidiaries. In
addition, I will also

 summarize the proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier by
which Frontier

 will access the funds available through the GNI refinancing, and provide my
opinion, as General

 Manager of Frontier, that this financing is in the best long-term interest of
Frontier and its

 customers.

 4. The proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier include three

 (3) agreements: (1) Revolving Line of Credit for access to $7.2 million; (2)
Long Term Note in

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 1

 the amount of$8.7 million; and (3) Four Year Term Note for the SAP IT Operating
System in

 the amount of$1.075 million.

 5. As is more fully described in the Application verified by Kevin Degenstein
and

 Jim Sprague, this new corporate structure and the new the intercompany
financing agreements

 through which Frontier will receive its financing require Commission approval
pursuant to

 N.C.G.S. §§ 62-111(a), 62-153, and 62-161 . I am providing this Affidavit
concurrently with,

 and in support of, the Application requesting this approval.

 Corporate Reorganization

 6. Under the current corporate structure, GNI is the ultimate parent of several


 entities including Energy West Incorporated (EWI). GNI also separately owns
other regulated

 utilities that operate distribution systems and an intrastate pipeline in Ohio
and is the parent of

 several unregulated entities as well. EWI is the parent of several regulated
utilities in Montana,

 Maine, and North Carolina, including Frontier Utilities of North Carolina, Inc.
("Frontier

 Utilities"), which is the intermediate holding company for Frontier. A current
corporate

 structure is set forth in Exhibit 1 attached to this Affidavit.

 Having EWI, which is regulated by the Montana Commission, serve as the parent
of

 Frontier Utilities and other regulated utilities, as well as GNI' s ownership
of other unregulated

 businesses in other states, has created in my opinion the potential for
jurisdictional conflict,

 confusion in accountability, and the potential for inconsistent practices among
subsidiaries.

 7. Under the newly proposed corporate structure, GNI would continue to be the

 ultimate parent of Frontier. However, Frontier Utilities will be dissolved and
a new subsidiary

 of GNI (currently designated as a newly formed intermediary company ("NIC") for
the purpose

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 2

 of the Application) would serve as the holding company for Frontier as well as
the other

 regulated affiliates operating in Ohio, Montana and Maine.

 8. The regulated subsidiaries would all become direct, separate subsidiaries of
GNI

 through NIC, not through a variety of different regulated and non-regulated
holding companies.

 GNI will also directly own the other non-regulated companies currently
operating in the Midwest

 and Montana, but these unregulated companies will be separate from the
regulated companies

 The new proposed corporate structure is set forth below in Exhibit 2 attached
to this Affidavit.

 9. It is my opinion and belief that this new proposed structure is beneficial
for a

 number of reasons. It essentially separates Frontier, as a North Carolina
regulated utility, for

 corporate formation, operational, regulatory, and financing purposes and
provides for consistent

 governance over all regulated utilities. It eliminates the concern of potential
multi-jurisdictional

 regulatory conflict and potential confusion by GNI' s current ownership
structure of regulated

 and unregulated subsidiaries. It still provides, however, the benefits of being
part of a larger

 organization with shared resources, expertise, and best practices, economies of
scale, and access

 to capital, as illustrated by the proposed financed discussed below.

 Debt Financing Agreements

 10. As part ofthe last financing case filed in Docket G-40, Sub 105 and
approved by

 Commission Order dated August 8, 2012 ("Refinancing Order"), the Commission
approved a

 credit agreement between Energy West Incorporated ("EWI") and Frontier that
consisted of a

 $30 million unsecured revolving line of credit and a $10 million unsecured
long-term debt

 facility. Frontier was a part of the pool of guarantors of this financing,
along with other EWI

 subsidiaries, and provided a limited recourse guarantee of $12.8 million of the
aggregate amount.

 During the proceedings, the Public Staff expressed concerns that the $12.8
million limited

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 3

 recourse guarantee of Frontier could cause Frontier to guarantee more debt than
EWI had

 borrowed and provided on Frontier's behalf, but ultimately recommended the
approval to avoid

 the risks created by rejection of the proposed refinancing transactions.

 11. That debt package is not in default and is still providing financing to
Frontier, but

 it expires in a little over a year, on April 1, 2017. Since the time of the
Refinancing Order in

 2012, GNI and its subsidiaries, including Frontier, have been exploring
alternative forms of

 financing, as well as a new corporate structure, as described above, to
accommodate and

 facilitate this financing.

 12. Beginning in November 2014, I began identifying potential lenders for

 replacement financing directly to Frontier. I sent letters attached to this
Affidavit as Exhibit 3 to

 Yadkin Bank, BB&T, Carter Banlc & Trust, and First Community Bank requesting
term sheets

 for a Term Loan and revolving Line of Credit for Frontier. I also provided each
ofthese banks

 with information about Frontier in order for them to evaluate and respond to
our request,

 including financial statements, service territory maps, corporate
organizational chart, listing of

 the property, plant, and equipment, schedule of rates for all classes of
customers, schedule of

 largest customers and their annual usage, regulatory reports, pipeline maps
showing the

 transmission, distribution, and service lines, and schedule showing the number
of customers in

 each of the service areas served by Frontier.

 13. To follow-up, I had several individual meetings with representatives from
Yadkin

 Bank and First Community Bank, culminating in meetings by Kevin Degenstein, Jed
Henthorne,

 and me with each banlc on April27, 2015. In addition, I met with
representatives ofBB&T in

 mid-2015. I also had several telephone conversations with bankers at Carter
Bank & Trust to

 assess their interest and answer their questions.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 4

 14. After all of these efforts over several months, the only bank that
submitted a term

 sheet was First Community Bank which is attached hereto as Confidential Exhibit
4. Based

 upon this experience, it is my belief that Frontier's small size was a major
impediment to

 receiving attractive financing options from independent lenders.

 15. I evaluated the proposal from First Community Bank carefully, but concluded
that

 it did not provide the flexibility and terms necessary for Frontier's financing
needs and that

 would allow Frontier to continue to operate successfully and expand as we
intend. It was

 certainly not comparable to the financing being offered through the
intercompany agreements

 with GNI described below.

 16. GNI management, on behalf of its subsidiaries and in consultation with me
and

 my counterparts with the other regulated operating utilities, also solicited
and evaluated debt

 financing options. We evaluated the financing options that were presented and
the

 organizational structure that would allow us to achieve the company's goal and
accommodate the

 necessary financing within the regulatory framework in which we operate. We
have now

 finalized that process and are proposing an organizational structure and
financing arrangement

 that I believe should simplify regulatory oversight, ensure accountability,
improve operational

 efficiencies, and provide sufficient capital to Frontier on the most cost
effective basis.

 17. Under the proposed financing, as explained in the Application, the
currently

 effective amended and restated credit agreement between EWI and Bank of America
("BOA")

 will be replaced by a new senior credit agreement between GNI and BOA ("the BOA
Senior

 Credit Facility"). This GNI financing will take the form of a $42 million
revolving line of credit

 that will be available for a period of five years for GNI to provide funds
pursuant to

 intercompany notes to Frontier and the other regulated operating utilities,
designed to ensure the

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 5

 regulated utilities such as Frontier have adequate access to capital during the
winter season and

 in order to procure gas supply in connection with operations, as well as for
other general

 operational purposes. Guarantees of the BOA Senior Credit Facility will be
required only from

 the unregulated subsidiaries of GNI and from NIC, while GNI will be the sole
Borrower. No

 direct recourse from BOA will extend to regulated subsidiaries downstream ofNIC
such as to

 Frontier. The revolving facility will terminate five years from closing.

 18. GNI also plans to issue up to $50 million ofNew Senior Unsecured Notes
("the

 Senior Unsecured Notes"), the terms of which are fully discussed by James E.
Sprague, GNI

 Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, in his Affidavit. Both the proceeds
from the Senior

 Credit Facility and from the Senior Unsecured Notes will be used to refinance
the existing debt

 and provide financing for general operational purposes and system expansion.

 19. The long-term note, which details the obligations ofGNI as the issuer, as
well as

 the non-regulated subsidiary guarantors, does not include Frontier as a direct
issuer or guarantor

 (similar to the revolving line with BOA). Neither Frontier, nor any of GNI's
other regulated

 operating utilities, will have any obligation for activities, borrowings, or
guarantees provided by

 any other GNI company or directly on the long-term note.

 20. The third component of the financing is a four (4) year term debt facility
in the

 amount of $7.0 million that will be used to consolidate several smaller loans
by GNI used for

 acquisition and development of an SAP software based operating system used by
all of the GNI

 companies (the "SAP Financing"). As is the case with the revolving line of
credit and the long

 term note issuance, GNI will be the sole borrower for the SAP Financing, no
guarantees will be

 required of the regulated operating utilities, including Frontier, and Frontier
will only be

 responsible through an intercompany note between GNI and Frontier for a
proportional piece of

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 6

 the SAP Financing. BOA is the proposed lender on the SAP Financing and will
require the SAP

 Software license to be pledged by GNI as collateral for this $7.0 million loan.


 21. Frontier will not have any guarantees directly to BOA. Based upon the
credit

 available through the BOA Senior Credit Facility, Senior Unsecured Notes, and
SAP Financing,

 Frontier will be eligible to draw a total of$15.9 million for its own
operational needs ($7.2

 million under the revolving line of credit, $8.7 million under the long-term
debt) and in addition

 receive $1.07 5 million from the SAP Financing (of which $820,000 will pay
Frontier's portion

 of the cost of the SAP software, licenses, and installation). If approved,
Frontier will enter into

 three intercompany notes with GNI, without any obligations directly to BOA or
Merrill Lynch

 ("ML"). Under the intercompany agreements, Frontier's only obligations will be
to GNI and its

 exposure is limited to what is has borrowed and used and extends no further.

 22. There are several benefits to Frontier under this financing structure as
compared

 to the structure that has been in place since 2012. First, as mentioned,
Frontier has no direct

 responsibility to BOA for either credit facility. Further, because funds for
the individual

 operating companies are treated separately and are reserved for the operating
subsidiaries under

 distinct, standalone "silos", there is no danger that the needs of other
utilities will impinge upon

 Frontier's access to its own capital or create any risk to Frontier. Upon
approval of the

 intercompany loans requested in this application, the new debt will be put in
place, paying off the

 existing debt and Frontier will execute its intercompany notes for access to
stand-alone line of

 credit through GNI. The other operating utilities will execute their own
intercompany notes and

 have access to their own lines, independent of Frontier and any other GNI
obligations. As a

 result of this structure, there is no potential for cross-collateralization or
cross-default. Also,

 Frontier will have full access to the SAP Software and operating system and all
of the associated

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 7

 developments related to the system although it will only be responsible for a
fraction of the

 development costs. Each of the GNI entities will benefit similarly.

 23. The Company has reviewed its operating needs over the last four years,
which

 have included periods of major construction and capital expansion efforts and
periods when the

 cost of gas has been high during winter months. The total amount of the
proposed debt should

 be sufficient to give Frontier adequate headroom in meeting its operational
needs, including

 anticipated construction, cost of gas, etc. in the years ahead, based on its
current capital

 expenditure forecasts.

 24. In the previous financing proceeding, the Public Staff expressed concerns
with

 Frontier's financial obligations to BOA for the credit facility and its
execution of a limited

 recourse guarantee. The proposed financing arrangement addresses those
concerns. Unlike the

 last financing proceeding, the current financing arrangement is between GNI and
BOA, and

 Frontier and other regulated subsidiaries have no obligations to the ultimate
lender or to each

 other. Frontier will only be obligated for funds to which it has access, and no
other subsidiary or

 GNI will have access to those funds. The intercompany loan agreements between
Frontier and

 GNI will establish the limits of its obligations and make it clear that
Frontier's obligations are

 limited by its borrowings. No assets will be pledged or required by Frontier to
secure access to

 this working capital and long term debt. The only asset that is pledged as
collateral for any of

 the three facilities is the SAP Software, pledged by GNI. This structure should
significantly

 reduce or even eliminate the prior concerns that the Public Staff had regarding
Frontier's

 obligations.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 8

 25. Frontier has continued to add to its infrastructure to access new market
areas and

 to expand service in its service territory. As noted in the testimony filed in
Frontier's annual

 review of gas costs dockets, the number of customers served by Frontier has
increased 26% from

 2011 to 2012, 28% from 2012 to 2013, 27.7% from 2013 to 2014 and 11.8% from
2014 to 2015.

 Frontier needs both short-term and long-term debt resources in order to have
sufficient access to

 meet cyclical cash flow needs throughout the year, to pay fixed expenses during
non-heating

 months, to benefit from seasonal opportunities and provide operational
flexibility to lower

 overall costs, and to provide long-term financing for capital investments to
allow it to continue to

 grow as it has over the past few years.

 26. I believe that the proposed intercompany agreements with GNI offer the most
cost

 effective option for financing for Frontier. What I have learned over the past
year is that many

 lenders are not familiar with the utility and gas industry and are hesitant to
lend or offer credit at

 a premium in order to cover their perception of potential risks. In addition,
financing is an area

 where there are economies of scale. At the parent level, due to the size of the
facility, GNI is

 better able to secure more favorable interest rates and other terms, and pass
those benefits on to

 Frontier through the intercompany agreements.

 27. Finally, I want to note that Frontier currently has a shared services
agreement with

 EWI, which has been previously filed with the Commission. This agreement
allowed EWI to

 charge Frontier for shared services. Since EWI will no longer be the parent of
Frontier, the

 Company will need to enter into a new shared services agreement with NIC (and
NIC will in turn

 enter into a similar agreement with GNI). The new shared services agreements
shall contain the

 same terms as those in the existing agreement; the only difference is that
current intermediate

 holding company has been substituted for GNI as the party to the agreement with
Frontier.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 9

 Under these arrangements, centralized administrative and professional services
such as

 accounting, legal, engineering, technology systems, data management or other
shared services

 for GNI subsidiaries are provided. Expenses that arise from the individual
needs of any specific

 subsidiary are directly assigned to that entity. This will continue to ensure
that Frontier's

 ratepayers are only responsible for those expenditures necessary for the
efficient and reliable

 operation of Frontier. This new shared service agreement will be filed with the
Commission

 upon approval of the corporate reorganization,

 Further affiant sayeth not.

 Fred A. Steele

 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 SURRY COUNTY

 Sworn to~d subscribed before me

 this ~&middot;aay 2016.

 aWl~

 Notary Public

 \ (SEAL)

 RALEIGH 501299,5

 10

 Mr. Van Hamlin

 Re: Term Loan and Revolving Line of Credit Inquiry for Frontier Natural Gas

 Dear Van:

 Thank you for lunch and for taking the time to discuss the financing needs of
Frontier Natural Gas, LLC

 (FNG). We discussed several options for financing and we are very interested in
any proposals that you

 find worthy of consideration. Following up on our lunch and telephone
discussions I felt it best to seek

 the input of senior management and formalize our thoughts on a credit facility.


 We would like to formalize our request for the stand-alone financing package in
the form of this letter.

 Frontier Natural Gas (FNG) requests a term sheet from your bank specifying the
conditions under which

 you would consider offering a senior credit facility to FNG. We are seeking a
facility that might contain

 the following general characteristics:

 1. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for

 issuing standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Tenn Facility: Up to $11,000,000 term loan facility ("term facility", and
together with

 the revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility
")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and

 payable in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily

 unused portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees

 of Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

 6. Closing anticipated immediately upon Borrower's receipt of all required
regulatory approvals.

 While BoiTower cannot predict with certainty the timing of receipt of such
approvals,

 Borrower anticipates such receipt by or before May 31, 2015.

 The loan proceeds of the term facility will be employed for re-financing of all
FNG's existing long term

 debt and for other general corporate purposes including long term capital
expenditures. Draws on the

 revolving facility will be employed for working capital requirements including
gas purchases and short

 term capital expenditures.

 110 PGW Drive &middot; Elkin &middot; North Carolina &middot; 28621&middot; Ph:
336-526-2690 &middot; Fax: 336&middot;526-9940

 FNG is a local natural gas public utility subject to the statutory regulatory
jurisdiction of the North

 Carolina Public Utilities Commission. We serve approximately 2,900 customers in
Ashe, Watauga,

 Warren, Wilkes, Surry and Yadkin Counties, North Carolina. We are a subsidiary
of Energy West

 Incorporated which is in turn a subsidiary of Gas Natural Inc., which is a
utility holding company

 publicly traded on the NYSE MKT Equities Exchange (ticker symbol: EGAS).

 In addition to the information previously provided-, we enclose the latest
annual report for FNG filed with

 the North Caro1ina Public Utilities Commission for CY 2013 .. That annual
report includes balance sheet

 and income statements for the calendar year and information regarding employees
in this state, and the

 volumes of natural gas sold at retail and delivered or transported to
consumers. Also included is the

 December 31,2013 Form 10-K filed by Gas Natural Inc. with the Securities
Exchange Commission,

 reflecting both segment financial information of the regulated utility segment
and consolidated results.

 We have also enclosed our corporate organizational chart. If there is any
additional information you

 require, please do not hesitate to request it.

 I emphasize that if you do not find the conceptual framework we have laid out
in this proposal to be

 acceptable to you, we specifically solicit a response from you that includes a
financing facility on terms

 you would consider. I request the favor of your response before close of
business on January 7, 2015.

 Thank you.

 Sincerely yours,

 the following general characteristics:
