                                US Official News

                            February 19, 2016 Friday

Regulatory update: North Carolina Utilities Commission;Frontier Natural Gas
Company, LLC , has issued (G-40 Sub 133) Affidavit of James E. Sprague

LENGTH: 6059 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Raleigh: North Carolina Utilities Commission has issued the following document
(filing):



 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 UTILITIES COMMISSION

 RALEIGH

 Docket No. G-40, Sub 133

 BEFORE THE NORTH CAROLINA UTILITIES COMMISSION:

 In the Matter of:

 Application of Frontier Natural Gas

 Company, LLC for Conditional Approvals

 Relating to Corporate Reorganization and

 Debt Refinancing

 )



 )

 )

 )

 )

 )

 AFFIDAVIT OF FRED A. STEELE

 The undersigned, having first been duly sworn, deposes and says as follows:

 1. My name is Fred A. Steele. I am over the age of 18 and otherwise competent
to

 testify. I have reviewed the statements herein, and swear that they are true,
to the best of my

 personal knowledge.

 2. I am the President and General Manager of Frontier Natural Gas Company, LLC

 ("Frontier"). My business address is 110 PGW Drive, Elkin, NC 28621.

 3. The purpose ofthis Affidavit is to generally describe the Application for

 Approvals of Corporate Reorganization and Debt Refinancing ("Application") that
is filed

 concurrently herewith, as well as a new proposed corporate reorganization
between Frontier's

 ultimate parent, Gas Natural Inc. ("GNI"), and it's various subsidiaries. In
addition, I will also

 summarize the proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier by
which Frontier

 will access the funds available through the GNI refinancing, and provide my
opinion, as General

 Manager of Frontier, that this financing is in the best long-term interest of
Frontier and its

 customers.

 4. The proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier include three

 (3) agreements: (1) Revolving Line of Credit for access to $7.2 million; (2)
Long Term Note in

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 1

 the amount of$8.7 million; and (3) Four Year Term Note for the SAP IT Operating
System in

 the amount of$1.075 million.

 5. As is more fully described in the Application verified by Kevin Degenstein
and

 Jim Sprague, this new corporate structure and the new the intercompany
financing agreements

 through which Frontier will receive its financing require Commission approval
pursuant to

 N.C.G.S. §§ 62-111(a), 62-153, and 62-161 . I am providing this Affidavit
concurrently with,

 and in support of, the Application requesting this approval.

 Corporate Reorganization

 6. Under the current corporate structure, GNI is the ultimate parent of several


 entities including Energy West Incorporated (EWI). GNI also separately owns
other regulated

 utilities that operate distribution systems and an intrastate pipeline in Ohio
and is the parent of

 several unregulated entities as well. EWI is the parent of several regulated
utilities in Montana,

 Maine, and North Carolina, including Frontier Utilities of North Carolina, Inc.
("Frontier

 Utilities"), which is the intermediate holding company for Frontier. A current
corporate

 structure is set forth in Exhibit 1 attached to this Affidavit.

 Having EWI, which is regulated by the Montana Commission, serve as the parent
of

 Frontier Utilities and other regulated utilities, as well as GNI' s ownership
of other unregulated

 businesses in other states, has created in my opinion the potential for
jurisdictional conflict,

 confusion in accountability, and the potential for inconsistent practices among
subsidiaries.

 7. Under the newly proposed corporate structure, GNI would continue to be the

 ultimate parent of Frontier. However, Frontier Utilities will be dissolved and
a new subsidiary

 of GNI (currently designated as a newly formed intermediary company ("NIC") for
the purpose

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 2

 of the Application) would serve as the holding company for Frontier as well as
the other

 regulated affiliates operating in Ohio, Montana and Maine.

 8. The regulated subsidiaries would all become direct, separate subsidiaries of
GNI

 through NIC, not through a variety of different regulated and non-regulated
holding companies.

 GNI will also directly own the other non-regulated companies currently
operating in the Midwest

 and Montana, but these unregulated companies will be separate from the
regulated companies

 The new proposed corporate structure is set forth below in Exhibit 2 attached
to this Affidavit.

 9. It is my opinion and belief that this new proposed structure is beneficial
for a

 number of reasons. It essentially separates Frontier, as a North Carolina
regulated utility, for

 corporate formation, operational, regulatory, and financing purposes and
provides for consistent

 governance over all regulated utilities. It eliminates the concern of potential
multi-jurisdictional

 regulatory conflict and potential confusion by GNI' s current ownership
structure of regulated

 and unregulated subsidiaries. It still provides, however, the benefits of being
part of a larger

 organization with shared resources, expertise, and best practices, economies of
scale, and access

 to capital, as illustrated by the proposed financed discussed below.

 Debt Financing Agreements

 10. As part ofthe last financing case filed in Docket G-40, Sub 105 and
approved by

 Commission Order dated August 8, 2012 ("Refinancing Order"), the Commission
approved a

 credit agreement between Energy West Incorporated ("EWI") and Frontier that
consisted of a

 $30 million unsecured revolving line of credit and a $10 million unsecured
long-term debt

 facility. Frontier was a part of the pool of guarantors of this financing,
along with other EWI

 subsidiaries, and provided a limited recourse guarantee of $12.8 million of the
aggregate amount.

 During the proceedings, the Public Staff expressed concerns that the $12.8
million limited

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 3

 recourse guarantee of Frontier could cause Frontier to guarantee more debt than
EWI had

 borrowed and provided on Frontier's behalf, but ultimately recommended the
approval to avoid

 the risks created by rejection of the proposed refinancing transactions.

 11. That debt package is not in default and is still providing financing to
Frontier, but

 it expires in a little over a year, on April 1, 2017. Since the time of the
Refinancing Order in

 2012, GNI and its subsidiaries, including Frontier, have been exploring
alternative forms of

 financing, as well as a new corporate structure, as described above, to
accommodate and

 facilitate this financing.

 12. Beginning in November 2014, I began identifying potential lenders for

 replacement financing directly to Frontier. I sent letters attached to this
Affidavit as Exhibit 3 to

 Yadkin Bank, BB&T, Carter Banlc & Trust, and First Community Bank requesting
term sheets

 for a Term Loan and revolving Line of Credit for Frontier. I also provided each
ofthese banks

 with information about Frontier in order for them to evaluate and respond to
our request,

 including financial statements, service territory maps, corporate
organizational chart, listing of

 the property, plant, and equipment, schedule of rates for all classes of
customers, schedule of

 largest customers and their annual usage, regulatory reports, pipeline maps
showing the

 transmission, distribution, and service lines, and schedule showing the number
of customers in

 each of the service areas served by Frontier.

 13. To follow-up, I had several individual meetings with representatives from
Yadkin

 Bank and First Community Bank, culminating in meetings by Kevin Degenstein, Jed
Henthorne,

 and me with each banlc on April27, 2015. In addition, I met with
representatives ofBB&T in

 mid-2015. I also had several telephone conversations with bankers at Carter
Bank & Trust to

 assess their interest and answer their questions.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 4

 14. After all of these efforts over several months, the only bank that
submitted a term

 sheet was First Community Bank which is attached hereto as Confidential Exhibit
4. Based

 upon this experience, it is my belief that Frontier's small size was a major
impediment to

 receiving attractive financing options from independent lenders.

 15. I evaluated the proposal from First Community Bank carefully, but concluded
that

 it did not provide the flexibility and terms necessary for Frontier's financing
needs and that

 would allow Frontier to continue to operate successfully and expand as we
intend. It was

 certainly not comparable to the financing being offered through the
intercompany agreements

 with GNI described below.

 16. GNI management, on behalf of its subsidiaries and in consultation with me
and

 my counterparts with the other regulated operating utilities, also solicited
and evaluated debt

 financing options. We evaluated the financing options that were presented and
the

 organizational structure that would allow us to achieve the company's goal and
accommodate the

 necessary financing within the regulatory framework in which we operate. We
have now

 finalized that process and are proposing an organizational structure and
financing arrangement

 that I believe should simplify regulatory oversight, ensure accountability,
improve operational

 efficiencies, and provide sufficient capital to Frontier on the most cost
effective basis.

 17. Under the proposed financing, as explained in the Application, the
currently

 effective amended and restated credit agreement between EWI and Bank of America
("BOA")

 will be replaced by a new senior credit agreement between GNI and BOA ("the BOA
Senior

 Credit Facility"). This GNI financing will take the form of a $42 million
revolving line of credit

 that will be available for a period of five years for GNI to provide funds
pursuant to

 intercompany notes to Frontier and the other regulated operating utilities,
designed to ensure the

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 5

 regulated utilities such as Frontier have adequate access to capital during the
winter season and

 in order to procure gas supply in connection with operations, as well as for
other general

 operational purposes. Guarantees of the BOA Senior Credit Facility will be
required only from

 the unregulated subsidiaries of GNI and from NIC, while GNI will be the sole
Borrower. No

 direct recourse from BOA will extend to regulated subsidiaries downstream ofNIC
such as to

 Frontier. The revolving facility will terminate five years from closing.

 18. GNI also plans to issue up to $50 million ofNew Senior Unsecured Notes
("the

 Senior Unsecured Notes"), the terms of which are fully discussed by James E.
Sprague, GNI

 Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, in his Affidavit. Both the proceeds
from the Senior

 Credit Facility and from the Senior Unsecured Notes will be used to refinance
the existing debt

 and provide financing for general operational purposes and system expansion.

 19. The long-term note, which details the obligations ofGNI as the issuer, as
well as

 the non-regulated subsidiary guarantors, does not include Frontier as a direct
issuer or guarantor

 (similar to the revolving line with BOA). Neither Frontier, nor any of GNI's
other regulated

 operating utilities, will have any obligation for activities, borrowings, or
guarantees provided by

 any other GNI company or directly on the long-term note.

 20. The third component of the financing is a four (4) year term debt facility
in the

 amount of $7.0 million that will be used to consolidate several smaller loans
by GNI used for

 acquisition and development of an SAP software based operating system used by
all of the GNI

 companies (the "SAP Financing"). As is the case with the revolving line of
credit and the long

 term note issuance, GNI will be the sole borrower for the SAP Financing, no
guarantees will be

 required of the regulated operating utilities, including Frontier, and Frontier
will only be

 responsible through an intercompany note between GNI and Frontier for a
proportional piece of

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 6

 the SAP Financing. BOA is the proposed lender on the SAP Financing and will
require the SAP

 Software license to be pledged by GNI as collateral for this $7.0 million loan.


 21. Frontier will not have any guarantees directly to BOA. Based upon the
credit

 available through the BOA Senior Credit Facility, Senior Unsecured Notes, and
SAP Financing,

 Frontier will be eligible to draw a total of$15.9 million for its own
operational needs ($7.2

 million under the revolving line of credit, $8.7 million under the long-term
debt) and in addition

 receive $1.07 5 million from the SAP Financing (of which $820,000 will pay
Frontier's portion

 of the cost of the SAP software, licenses, and installation). If approved,
Frontier will enter into

 three intercompany notes with GNI, without any obligations directly to BOA or
Merrill Lynch

 ("ML"). Under the intercompany agreements, Frontier's only obligations will be
to GNI and its

 exposure is limited to what is has borrowed and used and extends no further.

 22. There are several benefits to Frontier under this financing structure as
compared

 to the structure that has been in place since 2012. First, as mentioned,
Frontier has no direct

 responsibility to BOA for either credit facility. Further, because funds for
the individual

 operating companies are treated separately and are reserved for the operating
subsidiaries under

 distinct, standalone "silos", there is no danger that the needs of other
utilities will impinge upon

 Frontier's access to its own capital or create any risk to Frontier. Upon
approval of the

 intercompany loans requested in this application, the new debt will be put in
place, paying off the

 existing debt and Frontier will execute its intercompany notes for access to
stand-alone line of

 credit through GNI. The other operating utilities will execute their own
intercompany notes and

 have access to their own lines, independent of Frontier and any other GNI
obligations. As a

 result of this structure, there is no potential for cross-collateralization or
cross-default. Also,

 Frontier will have full access to the SAP Software and operating system and all
of the associated

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 7

 developments related to the system although it will only be responsible for a
fraction of the

 development costs. Each of the GNI entities will benefit similarly.

 23. The Company has reviewed its operating needs over the last four years,
which

 have included periods of major construction and capital expansion efforts and
periods when the

 cost of gas has been high during winter months. The total amount of the
proposed debt should

 be sufficient to give Frontier adequate headroom in meeting its operational
needs, including

 anticipated construction, cost of gas, etc. in the years ahead, based on its
current capital

 expenditure forecasts.

 24. In the previous financing proceeding, the Public Staff expressed concerns
with

 Frontier's financial obligations to BOA for the credit facility and its
execution of a limited

 recourse guarantee. The proposed financing arrangement addresses those
concerns. Unlike the

 last financing proceeding, the current financing arrangement is between GNI and
BOA, and

 Frontier and other regulated subsidiaries have no obligations to the ultimate
lender or to each

 other. Frontier will only be obligated for funds to which it has access, and no
other subsidiary or

 GNI will have access to those funds. The intercompany loan agreements between
Frontier and

 GNI will establish the limits of its obligations and make it clear that
Frontier's obligations are

 limited by its borrowings. No assets will be pledged or required by Frontier to
secure access to

 this working capital and long term debt. The only asset that is pledged as
collateral for any of

 the three facilities is the SAP Software, pledged by GNI. This structure should
significantly

 reduce or even eliminate the prior concerns that the Public Staff had regarding
Frontier's

 obligations.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 8

 25. Frontier has continued to add to its infrastructure to access new market
areas and

 to expand service in its service territory. As noted in the testimony filed in
Frontier's annual

 review of gas costs dockets, the number of customers served by Frontier has
increased 26% from

 2011 to 2012, 28% from 2012 to 2013, 27.7% from 2013 to 2014 and 11.8% from
2014 to 2015.

 Frontier needs both short-term and long-term debt resources in order to have
sufficient access to

 meet cyclical cash flow needs throughout the year, to pay fixed expenses during
non-heating

 months, to benefit from seasonal opportunities and provide operational
flexibility to lower

 overall costs, and to provide long-term financing for capital investments to
allow it to continue to

 grow as it has over the past few years.

 26. I believe that the proposed intercompany agreements with GNI offer the most
cost

 effective option for financing for Frontier. What I have learned over the past
year is that many

 lenders are not familiar with the utility and gas industry and are hesitant to
lend or offer credit at

 a premium in order to cover their perception of potential risks. In addition,
financing is an area

 where there are economies of scale. At the parent level, due to the size of the
facility, GNI is

 better able to secure more favorable interest rates and other terms, and pass
those benefits on to

 Frontier through the intercompany agreements.

 27. Finally, I want to note that Frontier currently has a shared services
agreement with

 EWI, which has been previously filed with the Commission. This agreement
allowed EWI to

 charge Frontier for shared services. Since EWI will no longer be the parent of
Frontier, the

 Company will need to enter into a new shared services agreement with NIC (and
NIC will in turn

 enter into a similar agreement with GNI). The new shared services agreements
shall contain the

 same terms as those in the existing agreement; the only difference is that
current intermediate

 holding company has been substituted for GNI as the party to the agreement with
Frontier.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 9

 Under these arrangements, centralized administrative and professional services
such as

 accounting, legal, engineering, technology systems, data management or other
shared services

 for GNI subsidiaries are provided. Expenses that arise from the individual
needs of any specific

 subsidiary are directly assigned to that entity. This will continue to ensure
that Frontier's

 ratepayers are only responsible for those expenditures necessary for the
efficient and reliable

 operation of Frontier. This new shared service agreement will be filed with the
Commission

 upon approval of the corporate reorganization,

 Further affiant sayeth not.

 Fred A. Steele

 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 SURRY COUNTY

 Sworn to~d subscribed before me

 this ~&middot;aay 2016.

 aWl~

 Notary Public

 \ (SEAL)

 RALEIGH 501299,5

 10

 Re: Term Loan and Revolving Line of Credit Inquiry for Frontier Natural Gas

 Dear Van:

 Thank you for lunch and for taking the time to discuss the financing needs of
Frontier Natural Gas, LLC

 (FNG). We discussed several options for financing and we are very interested in
any proposals that you

 find worthy of consideration. Following up on our lunch and telephone
discussions I felt it best to seek

 the input of senior management and formalize our thoughts on a credit facility.


 We would like to formalize our request for the stand-alone financing package in
the form of this letter.

 Frontier Natural Gas (FNG) requests a term sheet from your bank specifying the
conditions under which

 you would consider offering a senior credit facility to FNG. We are seeking a
facility that might contain

 the following general characteristics:

 1. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for

 issuing standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Tenn Facility: Up to $11,000,000 term loan facility ("term facility", and
together with

 the revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility
")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and

 payable in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily

 unused portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees

 of Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

 6. Closing anticipated immediately upon Borrower's receipt of all required
regulatory approvals.

 While BoiTower cannot predict with certainty the timing of receipt of such
approvals,

 Borrower anticipates such receipt by or before May 31, 2015.

 The loan proceeds of the term facility will be employed for re-financing of all
FNG's existing long term

 debt and for other general corporate purposes including long term capital
expenditures. Draws on the

 revolving facility will be employed for working capital requirements including
gas purchases and short

 term capital expenditures.

 110 PGW Drive &middot; Elkin &middot; North Carolina &middot; 28621&middot; Ph:
336-526-2690 &middot; Fax: 336&middot;526-9940

 FNG is a local natural gas public utility subject to the statutory regulatory
jurisdiction of the North

 Carolina Public Utilities Commission. We serve approximately 2,900 customers in
Ashe, Watauga,

 Warren, Wilkes, Surry and Yadkin Counties, North Carolina. We are a subsidiary
of Energy West

 Incorporated which is in turn a subsidiary of Gas Natural Inc., which is a
utility holding company

 publicly traded on the NYSE MKT Equities Exchange (ticker symbol: EGAS).

 In addition to the information previously provided-, we enclose the latest
annual report for FNG filed with

 the North Caro1ina Public Utilities Commission for CY 2013 .. That annual
report includes balance sheet

 and income statements for the calendar year and information regarding employees
in this state, and the

 volumes of natural gas sold at retail and delivered or transported to
consumers. Also included is the

 December 31,2013 Form 10-K filed by Gas Natural Inc. with the Securities
Exchange Commission,

 reflecting both segment financial information of the regulated utility segment
and consolidated results.

 We have also enclosed our corporate organizational chart. If there is any
additional information you

 require, please do not hesitate to request it.

 I emphasize that if you do not find the conceptual framework we have laid out
in this proposal to be

 acceptable to you, we specifically solicit a response from you that includes a
financing facility on terms

 you would consider. I request the favor of your response before close of
business on January 7, 2015.

 Thank you.

 Sincerely yours,

 F~ A S}JJ

 Dear Tony:

Natural Gas, LLC (FNG). We

 discussed several options for financing and we are very interested in any
proposals that you find worthy

 of consideration. After our telephone discussion of yesterday I felt that it
best seek Senior Management's

 input on the credit facility that they feel would best suit FNG.

 We would like to formalize our request for the stand-alone financing package in
the form of this letter.

 Frontier Natural Gas (FNG) requests a term sheet from your bank specifying the
conditions under which

 you would consider offering a senior credit facility to FNG. We are seeking a
facility that might contain

 the following general characteristics:

 1. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for

 issuing standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Tenn Facility: Up to $11,000,000 term loan facility ("term facility", and
together with

 the revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility
")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and

 payable in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily

 unused portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees

 of Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

 6. Closing anticipated immediately upon Borrower's receipt of all required
regulatory approvals.

approvals,

FNG's existing long term

 debt and for other general corporate purposes including long term capital
expenditures. Draws on the

 revolving facility will be employed for working capital requirements including
gas purchases and short

 term capital expenditures.

                            February 19, 2016 Friday

Regulatory update: North Carolina Utilities Commission;Frontier Natural Gas
Company, LLC , has issued (G-40 Sub 133) Affidavit of James E. Sprague

LENGTH: 6059 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Raleigh: North Carolina Utilities Commission has issued the following document
(filing):



 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 UTILITIES COMMISSION

 RALEIGH

 Docket No. G-40, Sub 133

 BEFORE THE NORTH CAROLINA UTILITIES COMMISSION:

 In the Matter of:

 Application of Frontier Natural Gas

 Company, LLC for Conditional Approvals

 Relating to Corporate Reorganization and

 Debt Refinancing

 )



 )

 )

 )

 )

 )

 AFFIDAVIT OF FRED A. STEELE

 The undersigned, having first been duly sworn, deposes and says as follows:

 1. My name is Fred A. Steele. I am over the age of 18 and otherwise competent
to

 testify. I have reviewed the statements herein, and swear that they are true,
to the best of my

 personal knowledge.

 2. I am the President and General Manager of Frontier Natural Gas Company, LLC

 ("Frontier"). My business address is 110 PGW Drive, Elkin, NC 28621.

 3. The purpose ofthis Affidavit is to generally describe the Application for

 Approvals of Corporate Reorganization and Debt Refinancing ("Application") that
is filed

 concurrently herewith, as well as a new proposed corporate reorganization
between Frontier's

 ultimate parent, Gas Natural Inc. ("GNI"), and it's various subsidiaries. In
addition, I will also

 summarize the proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier by
which Frontier

 will access the funds available through the GNI refinancing, and provide my
opinion, as General

 Manager of Frontier, that this financing is in the best long-term interest of
Frontier and its

 customers.

 4. The proposed intercompany agreements between GNI and Frontier include three

 (3) agreements: (1) Revolving Line of Credit for access to $7.2 million; (2)
Long Term Note in

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 1

 the amount of$8.7 million; and (3) Four Year Term Note for the SAP IT Operating
System in

 the amount of$1.075 million.

 5. As is more fully described in the Application verified by Kevin Degenstein
and

 Jim Sprague, this new corporate structure and the new the intercompany
financing agreements

 through which Frontier will receive its financing require Commission approval
pursuant to

 N.C.G.S. §§ 62-111(a), 62-153, and 62-161 . I am providing this Affidavit
concurrently with,

 and in support of, the Application requesting this approval.

 Corporate Reorganization

 6. Under the current corporate structure, GNI is the ultimate parent of several


 entities including Energy West Incorporated (EWI). GNI also separately owns
other regulated

 utilities that operate distribution systems and an intrastate pipeline in Ohio
and is the parent of

 several unregulated entities as well. EWI is the parent of several regulated
utilities in Montana,

 Maine, and North Carolina, including Frontier Utilities of North Carolina, Inc.
("Frontier

 Utilities"), which is the intermediate holding company for Frontier. A current
corporate

 structure is set forth in Exhibit 1 attached to this Affidavit.

 Having EWI, which is regulated by the Montana Commission, serve as the parent
of

 Frontier Utilities and other regulated utilities, as well as GNI' s ownership
of other unregulated

 businesses in other states, has created in my opinion the potential for
jurisdictional conflict,

 confusion in accountability, and the potential for inconsistent practices among
subsidiaries.

 7. Under the newly proposed corporate structure, GNI would continue to be the

 ultimate parent of Frontier. However, Frontier Utilities will be dissolved and
a new subsidiary

 of GNI (currently designated as a newly formed intermediary company ("NIC") for
the purpose

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 2

 of the Application) would serve as the holding company for Frontier as well as
the other

 regulated affiliates operating in Ohio, Montana and Maine.

 8. The regulated subsidiaries would all become direct, separate subsidiaries of
GNI

 through NIC, not through a variety of different regulated and non-regulated
holding companies.

 GNI will also directly own the other non-regulated companies currently
operating in the Midwest

 and Montana, but these unregulated companies will be separate from the
regulated companies

 The new proposed corporate structure is set forth below in Exhibit 2 attached
to this Affidavit.

 9. It is my opinion and belief that this new proposed structure is beneficial
for a

 number of reasons. It essentially separates Frontier, as a North Carolina
regulated utility, for

 corporate formation, operational, regulatory, and financing purposes and
provides for consistent

 governance over all regulated utilities. It eliminates the concern of potential
multi-jurisdictional

 regulatory conflict and potential confusion by GNI' s current ownership
structure of regulated

 and unregulated subsidiaries. It still provides, however, the benefits of being
part of a larger

 organization with shared resources, expertise, and best practices, economies of
scale, and access

 to capital, as illustrated by the proposed financed discussed below.

 Debt Financing Agreements

 10. As part ofthe last financing case filed in Docket G-40, Sub 105 and
approved by

 Commission Order dated August 8, 2012 ("Refinancing Order"), the Commission
approved a

 credit agreement between Energy West Incorporated ("EWI") and Frontier that
consisted of a

 $30 million unsecured revolving line of credit and a $10 million unsecured
long-term debt

 facility. Frontier was a part of the pool of guarantors of this financing,
along with other EWI

 subsidiaries, and provided a limited recourse guarantee of $12.8 million of the
aggregate amount.

 During the proceedings, the Public Staff expressed concerns that the $12.8
million limited

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 3

 recourse guarantee of Frontier could cause Frontier to guarantee more debt than
EWI had

 borrowed and provided on Frontier's behalf, but ultimately recommended the
approval to avoid

 the risks created by rejection of the proposed refinancing transactions.

 11. That debt package is not in default and is still providing financing to
Frontier, but

 it expires in a little over a year, on April 1, 2017. Since the time of the
Refinancing Order in

 2012, GNI and its subsidiaries, including Frontier, have been exploring
alternative forms of

 financing, as well as a new corporate structure, as described above, to
accommodate and

 facilitate this financing.

 12. Beginning in November 2014, I began identifying potential lenders for

 replacement financing directly to Frontier. I sent letters attached to this
Affidavit as Exhibit 3 to

 Yadkin Bank, BB&T, Carter Banlc & Trust, and First Community Bank requesting
term sheets

 for a Term Loan and revolving Line of Credit for Frontier. I also provided each
ofthese banks

 with information about Frontier in order for them to evaluate and respond to
our request,

 including financial statements, service territory maps, corporate
organizational chart, listing of

 the property, plant, and equipment, schedule of rates for all classes of
customers, schedule of

 largest customers and their annual usage, regulatory reports, pipeline maps
showing the

 transmission, distribution, and service lines, and schedule showing the number
of customers in

 each of the service areas served by Frontier.

 13. To follow-up, I had several individual meetings with representatives from
Yadkin

 Bank and First Community Bank, culminating in meetings by Kevin Degenstein, Jed
Henthorne,

 and me with each banlc on April27, 2015. In addition, I met with
representatives ofBB&T in

 mid-2015. I also had several telephone conversations with bankers at Carter
Bank & Trust to

 assess their interest and answer their questions.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 4

 14. After all of these efforts over several months, the only bank that
submitted a term

 sheet was First Community Bank which is attached hereto as Confidential Exhibit
4. Based

 upon this experience, it is my belief that Frontier's small size was a major
impediment to

 receiving attractive financing options from independent lenders.

 15. I evaluated the proposal from First Community Bank carefully, but concluded
that

 it did not provide the flexibility and terms necessary for Frontier's financing
needs and that

 would allow Frontier to continue to operate successfully and expand as we
intend. It was

 certainly not comparable to the financing being offered through the
intercompany agreements

 with GNI described below.

 16. GNI management, on behalf of its subsidiaries and in consultation with me
and

 my counterparts with the other regulated operating utilities, also solicited
and evaluated debt

 financing options. We evaluated the financing options that were presented and
the

 organizational structure that would allow us to achieve the company's goal and
accommodate the

 necessary financing within the regulatory framework in which we operate. We
have now

 finalized that process and are proposing an organizational structure and
financing arrangement

 that I believe should simplify regulatory oversight, ensure accountability,
improve operational

 efficiencies, and provide sufficient capital to Frontier on the most cost
effective basis.

 17. Under the proposed financing, as explained in the Application, the
currently

 effective amended and restated credit agreement between EWI and Bank of America
("BOA")

 will be replaced by a new senior credit agreement between GNI and BOA ("the BOA
Senior

 Credit Facility"). This GNI financing will take the form of a $42 million
revolving line of credit

 that will be available for a period of five years for GNI to provide funds
pursuant to

 intercompany notes to Frontier and the other regulated operating utilities,
designed to ensure the

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 5

 regulated utilities such as Frontier have adequate access to capital during the
winter season and

 in order to procure gas supply in connection with operations, as well as for
other general

 operational purposes. Guarantees of the BOA Senior Credit Facility will be
required only from

 the unregulated subsidiaries of GNI and from NIC, while GNI will be the sole
Borrower. No

 direct recourse from BOA will extend to regulated subsidiaries downstream ofNIC
such as to

 Frontier. The revolving facility will terminate five years from closing.

 18. GNI also plans to issue up to $50 million ofNew Senior Unsecured Notes
("the

 Senior Unsecured Notes"), the terms of which are fully discussed by James E.
Sprague, GNI

 Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, in his Affidavit. Both the proceeds
from the Senior

 Credit Facility and from the Senior Unsecured Notes will be used to refinance
the existing debt

 and provide financing for general operational purposes and system expansion.

 19. The long-term note, which details the obligations ofGNI as the issuer, as
well as

 the non-regulated subsidiary guarantors, does not include Frontier as a direct
issuer or guarantor

 (similar to the revolving line with BOA). Neither Frontier, nor any of GNI's
other regulated

 operating utilities, will have any obligation for activities, borrowings, or
guarantees provided by

 any other GNI company or directly on the long-term note.

 20. The third component of the financing is a four (4) year term debt facility
in the

 amount of $7.0 million that will be used to consolidate several smaller loans
by GNI used for

 acquisition and development of an SAP software based operating system used by
all of the GNI

 companies (the "SAP Financing"). As is the case with the revolving line of
credit and the long

 term note issuance, GNI will be the sole borrower for the SAP Financing, no
guarantees will be

 required of the regulated operating utilities, including Frontier, and Frontier
will only be

 responsible through an intercompany note between GNI and Frontier for a
proportional piece of

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 6

 the SAP Financing. BOA is the proposed lender on the SAP Financing and will
require the SAP

 Software license to be pledged by GNI as collateral for this $7.0 million loan.


 21. Frontier will not have any guarantees directly to BOA. Based upon the
credit

 available through the BOA Senior Credit Facility, Senior Unsecured Notes, and
SAP Financing,

 Frontier will be eligible to draw a total of$15.9 million for its own
operational needs ($7.2

 million under the revolving line of credit, $8.7 million under the long-term
debt) and in addition

 receive $1.07 5 million from the SAP Financing (of which $820,000 will pay
Frontier's portion

 of the cost of the SAP software, licenses, and installation). If approved,
Frontier will enter into

 three intercompany notes with GNI, without any obligations directly to BOA or
Merrill Lynch

 ("ML"). Under the intercompany agreements, Frontier's only obligations will be
to GNI and its

 exposure is limited to what is has borrowed and used and extends no further.

 22. There are several benefits to Frontier under this financing structure as
compared

 to the structure that has been in place since 2012. First, as mentioned,
Frontier has no direct

 responsibility to BOA for either credit facility. Further, because funds for
the individual

 operating companies are treated separately and are reserved for the operating
subsidiaries under

 distinct, standalone "silos", there is no danger that the needs of other
utilities will impinge upon

 Frontier's access to its own capital or create any risk to Frontier. Upon
approval of the

 intercompany loans requested in this application, the new debt will be put in
place, paying off the

 existing debt and Frontier will execute its intercompany notes for access to
stand-alone line of

 credit through GNI. The other operating utilities will execute their own
intercompany notes and

 have access to their own lines, independent of Frontier and any other GNI
obligations. As a

 result of this structure, there is no potential for cross-collateralization or
cross-default. Also,

 Frontier will have full access to the SAP Software and operating system and all
of the associated

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 7

 developments related to the system although it will only be responsible for a
fraction of the

 development costs. Each of the GNI entities will benefit similarly.

 23. The Company has reviewed its operating needs over the last four years,
which

 have included periods of major construction and capital expansion efforts and
periods when the

 cost of gas has been high during winter months. The total amount of the
proposed debt should

 be sufficient to give Frontier adequate headroom in meeting its operational
needs, including

 anticipated construction, cost of gas, etc. in the years ahead, based on its
current capital

 expenditure forecasts.

 24. In the previous financing proceeding, the Public Staff expressed concerns
with

 Frontier's financial obligations to BOA for the credit facility and its
execution of a limited

 recourse guarantee. The proposed financing arrangement addresses those
concerns. Unlike the

 last financing proceeding, the current financing arrangement is between GNI and
BOA, and

 Frontier and other regulated subsidiaries have no obligations to the ultimate
lender or to each

 other. Frontier will only be obligated for funds to which it has access, and no
other subsidiary or

 GNI will have access to those funds. The intercompany loan agreements between
Frontier and

 GNI will establish the limits of its obligations and make it clear that
Frontier's obligations are

 limited by its borrowings. No assets will be pledged or required by Frontier to
secure access to

 this working capital and long term debt. The only asset that is pledged as
collateral for any of

 the three facilities is the SAP Software, pledged by GNI. This structure should
significantly

 reduce or even eliminate the prior concerns that the Public Staff had regarding
Frontier's

 obligations.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 8

 25. Frontier has continued to add to its infrastructure to access new market
areas and

 to expand service in its service territory. As noted in the testimony filed in
Frontier's annual

 review of gas costs dockets, the number of customers served by Frontier has
increased 26% from

 2011 to 2012, 28% from 2012 to 2013, 27.7% from 2013 to 2014 and 11.8% from
2014 to 2015.

 Frontier needs both short-term and long-term debt resources in order to have
sufficient access to

 meet cyclical cash flow needs throughout the year, to pay fixed expenses during
non-heating

 months, to benefit from seasonal opportunities and provide operational
flexibility to lower

 overall costs, and to provide long-term financing for capital investments to
allow it to continue to

 grow as it has over the past few years.

 26. I believe that the proposed intercompany agreements with GNI offer the most
cost

 effective option for financing for Frontier. What I have learned over the past
year is that many

 lenders are not familiar with the utility and gas industry and are hesitant to
lend or offer credit at

 a premium in order to cover their perception of potential risks. In addition,
financing is an area

 where there are economies of scale. At the parent level, due to the size of the
facility, GNI is

 better able to secure more favorable interest rates and other terms, and pass
those benefits on to

 Frontier through the intercompany agreements.

 27. Finally, I want to note that Frontier currently has a shared services
agreement with

 EWI, which has been previously filed with the Commission. This agreement
allowed EWI to

 charge Frontier for shared services. Since EWI will no longer be the parent of
Frontier, the

 Company will need to enter into a new shared services agreement with NIC (and
NIC will in turn

 enter into a similar agreement with GNI). The new shared services agreements
shall contain the

 same terms as those in the existing agreement; the only difference is that
current intermediate

 holding company has been substituted for GNI as the party to the agreement with
Frontier.

 RALEIGH 501299.5

 9

 Under these arrangements, centralized administrative and professional services
such as

 accounting, legal, engineering, technology systems, data management or other
shared services

 for GNI subsidiaries are provided. Expenses that arise from the individual
needs of any specific

 subsidiary are directly assigned to that entity. This will continue to ensure
that Frontier's

 ratepayers are only responsible for those expenditures necessary for the
efficient and reliable

 operation of Frontier. This new shared service agreement will be filed with the
Commission

 upon approval of the corporate reorganization,

 Further affiant sayeth not.

 Fred A. Steele

 STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA

 SURRY COUNTY

 Sworn to~d subscribed before me

 this ~&middot;aay 2016.

 aWl~

 Notary Public

 \ (SEAL)

 RALEIGH 501299,5

 10

 Re: Term Loan and Revolving Line of Credit Inquiry for Frontier Natural Gas

 Dear Van:

 Thank you for lunch and for taking the time to discuss the financing needs of
Frontier Natural Gas, LLC

 (FNG). We discussed several options for financing and we are very interested in
any proposals that you

 find worthy of consideration. Following up on our lunch and telephone
discussions I felt it best to seek

 the input of senior management and formalize our thoughts on a credit facility.


 We would like to formalize our request for the stand-alone financing package in
the form of this letter.

 Frontier Natural Gas (FNG) requests a term sheet from your bank specifying the
conditions under which

 you would consider offering a senior credit facility to FNG. We are seeking a
facility that might contain

 the following general characteristics:

 1. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for

 issuing standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Tenn Facility: Up to $11,000,000 term loan facility ("term facility", and
together with

 the revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility
")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and

 payable in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily

 unused portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees

 of Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

 6. Closing anticipated immediately upon Borrower's receipt of all required
regulatory approvals.

 While BoiTower cannot predict with certainty the timing of receipt of such
approvals,

 Borrower anticipates such receipt by or before May 31, 2015.

 The loan proceeds of the term facility will be employed for re-financing of all
FNG's existing long term

 debt and for other general corporate purposes including long term capital
expenditures. Draws on the

 revolving facility will be employed for working capital requirements including
gas purchases and short

 term capital expenditures.

 110 PGW Drive &middot; Elkin &middot; North Carolina &middot; 28621&middot; Ph:
336-526-2690 &middot; Fax: 336&middot;526-9940

 FNG is a local natural gas public utility subject to the statutory regulatory
jurisdiction of the North

 Carolina Public Utilities Commission. We serve approximately 2,900 customers in
Ashe, Watauga,

 Warren, Wilkes, Surry and Yadkin Counties, North Carolina. We are a subsidiary
of Energy West

 Incorporated which is in turn a subsidiary of Gas Natural Inc., which is a
utility holding company

 publicly traded on the NYSE MKT Equities Exchange (ticker symbol: EGAS).

 In addition to the information previously provided-, we enclose the latest
annual report for FNG filed with

 the North Caro1ina Public Utilities Commission for CY 2013 .. That annual
report includes balance sheet

 and income statements for the calendar year and information regarding employees
in this state, and the

 volumes of natural gas sold at retail and delivered or transported to
consumers. Also included is the

 December 31,2013 Form 10-K filed by Gas Natural Inc. with the Securities
Exchange Commission,

 reflecting both segment financial information of the regulated utility segment
and consolidated results.

 We have also enclosed our corporate organizational chart. If there is any
additional information you

 require, please do not hesitate to request it.

 I emphasize that if you do not find the conceptual framework we have laid out
in this proposal to be

 acceptable to you, we specifically solicit a response from you that includes a
financing facility on terms

 you would consider. I request the favor of your response before close of
business on January 7, 2015.

 Thank you.

 Sincerely yours,

 F~ A S}JJ

 Fred Steele

 General Manager

facility that might contain the following

 general characteristics:

 I. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for issuing

 standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Term Facility: Up to $11,000,000 term loan facility ("term facility", and
together with the

 revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and payable

 in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily unused

 portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees of

 Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

regulatory approvals. While

Borrower anticipates

 such receipt by or before May 31, 2015.

FNG' s existing long term debt and

 Re: Term Loan and Revolving Line of Credit Inquiry for Frontier Natural Gas

 Dear Mr. Staton:

 Following up on my telephone messages, Frontier Natural Gas, LLC (FNG) requests
a term sheet from your bank

 specifying the conditions under which you would consider offering a senior
credit facility to FNG. We are seeking

 a facility that might contain the following general characteristics:

 I. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for issuing

 standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Term Facility: Up to $1 I ,000,000 term Joan facility ("term facility", and
together with the

 revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and payable

 in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily unused

 portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees of

 Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

 6. Closing anticipated immediately upon Borrower's receipt of all required
regulatory approvals. While

 Borrower cannot predict with certainty the timing of receipt of such approvals,
Borrower anticipates

 such receipt by or before May 31, 2015.

 The loan proceeds of the term facility will be employed for re-financing of all
FNG' s existing long term debt and

 for other general corporate purposes including long term capital expenditures.
Draws on the revolving facility will

 be employed for working capital requirements including gas purchases and short
term capital expenditures.

 FNG is a local natural gas public utility subject to the statutory regulatory
jurisdiction of the North Carolina Public

 Utilities Commission. We serve approximately 2,900 customers in Ashe, Watauga,
Warren, Wilkes, Surry and

 Yadkin Counties, North Carolina We are a subsidiary of Energy West Incorporated
which is in tum a subsidiary of

 Gas Natural Inc., which is a utility holding company publicly traded on the
NYSE MKT Equities Exchange (ticker

 symbol: EGAS).

 Enclosures

 Frontier Natural Gas

 NC~s GREEN ENERGY CHOICE

 Mr. Tony Hyde

 Vice President/Commercial Relationship Manager

 First Community Bank

 312 Jonestown Road

 Winston Salem, NC 27104

 Re: Term Loan and Revolving Line of Credit Inquiry for Frontier Natural Gas

 Dear Tony:

 Thank you for taking the time to discuss the financing needs of Frontier
Natural Gas, LLC (FNG). We

 discussed several options for financing and we are very interested in any
proposals that you find worthy

 of consideration. After our telephone discussion of yesterday I felt that it
best seek Senior Management's

 input on the credit facility that they feel would best suit FNG.

 We would like to formalize our request for the stand-alone financing package in
the form of this letter.

 Frontier Natural Gas (FNG) requests a term sheet from your bank specifying the
conditions under which

 you would consider offering a senior credit facility to FNG. We are seeking a
facility that might contain

 the following general characteristics:

 1. Aggregate principal amount of up to $20,000,000 available through the
following facilities:

 a. Revolving Facility: $9,000,000 facility which would possibly include a
sublimit for

 issuing standby letters of credit ("revolving facility")

 b. Tenn Facility: Up to $11,000,000 term loan facility ("term facility", and
together with

 the revolving facility, referred to collectively as the "senior credit facility
")

 2. Maturity/Repayment: all amounts outstanding under the senior credit facility
will be due and

 payable in full not less than five years from the date of closing.

 3. Interest: market rates

 4. The same applicable interest rate would be payable quarterly in arrears on
the average daily

 unused portion of the Revolving Facility.

 5. Expenses of Lender associated with preparation, due diligence and closing
including legal fees

 of Lender's counsel to be reimbursed by Borrower.

 6. Closing anticipated immediately upon Borrower's receipt of all required
regulatory approvals.

 While Borrower cannot predict with certainty the timing of receipt of such
approvals,

 Borrower anticipates such receipt by or before May 31, 2015.

 The loan proceeds of the term facility will be employed for re-financing of all
FNG's existing long term

 debt and for other general corporate purposes including long term capital
expenditures. Draws on the

 revolving facility will be employed for working capital requirements including
gas purchases and short

 term capital expenditures.

 110 PGW Drive &middot; Elkin &middot; North Carolina &middot; 28621 o Ph:
336-526-2690 &middot; Fax: 336-526-9940

 FNG is a local natural gas public utility subject to the statutory regulatory
jurisdiction of the North

 Carolina Public Utilities Commission. We serve approximately 2,900 customers in
Ashe, Watauga,

 Warren, Wilkes, Surry and Yadkin Counties, North Carolina We are a subsidiary
of Energy West

 Incorporated which is in tum a subsidiary of Gas Natural Inc.,&middot;which is
a utility holding company

 publicly traded on the NYSE MKT Equities Exchange (ticker symbol: EGAS).

 In addition to the information I have previously provided- we enclose the
latest annual report for FNG

 filed with the North Carolina Public Utilities Commission for CY 2013. That
annual report includes the

 balance sheet and income statement for the calendar year and information
regarding employees in this

 state, and the volumes of natural gas sold at retail and delivered or
transported to consumers. Also

 included is the December 31, 2013 Form 10-K filed by Gas Natural Inc. with the
Securities Exchange

 Commission, reflecting both segment financial information of the regulated
utility segment and

 consolidated results.

 We have also enclosed our corporate organizational chart. If there is any
additional information you

 require, please do not hesitate to request it.

 I emphasize that if you do not find the conceptual framework we have laid out
in this proposal to be

 acceptable to you, we specifically solicit a response from you that includes a
financing facility on terms

 you would consider. I request the favor of your response before close of
business on January 7, 2015.

 Thank you.

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *
Rent-A-Center, Inc. is a rent-to-own operator in the United States. As of
December 31, 2008, the Company operated 3,037 Company-owned stores nationwide
and in Canada and Puerto Rico, including 31 retail installment sales stores
under the name Get It Now and Home Choice, and eight rent-to-own stores located
in Canada under the name Rent-A-Centre. The Company's subsidiary, ColorTyme, is
a national franchisor of rent-to-own stores. As of December 31, 2008, ColorTyme
had 222 franchised rent-to-own stores in 34 states. The Company's stores
generally offer durable products, such as consumer electronics, appliances,
computers and furniture, and accessories under flexible rental purchase
agreements that generally allow the customer to obtain ownership of the
merchandise at the conclusion of an agreed upon rental period.

 * * * * * * * * * * ANNOUNCEMENTS * * * * * * * * * *
COMPANY RELEASE

   [News Story] PLANO, Texas--Rent-A-Center, Inc. (the "Company")
(NASDAQ/NGS:RCII) announced today that it intends, subject to market conditions,
to offer $250 million in aggregate principal amount of senior unsecured notes
due 2021 (the "notes") in a private offering that is exempt from the
registration requirements of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the
"Securities Act"). The Company intends to use the net proceeds of the offering
to repay $46 million of the revolving loans outstanding under its revolving
credit facility and apply the remainder to accelerated common stock repurchases
as market conditions permit and, to the extent not so applied, for general
corporate purposes.

   The notes and the related guarantees will be offered only to qualified
institutional buyers in reliance on the exemption from registration set forth in
Rule 144A under the Securities Act, and outside the United States to non-U.S.
persons in reliance on the exemption from registration set forth in Regulation S
under the Securities Act. The notes and the related guarantees have not been
registered under the Securities Act, or the securities laws of any state or
other jurisdiction, and may not be offered or sold in the United States without
registration or an applicable exemption from the registration requirements of
the Securities Act and applicable state securities or blue sky laws and foreign
securities laws.

   This press release shall not constitute an offer to sell, or the solicitation
of an offer to buy, any securities, nor shall there be any sales of the notes in
any jurisdiction in which such offer, solicitation or sale would be unlawful
prior to registration or qualification under the securities laws of any such
jurisdiction. This press release is being issued pursuant to and in accordance
with Rule 135(c) under the Securities Act.

   Source: NASDAQ Stock Exchange

EXTRA ORDINARY / SPECIAL SHAREHOLDER MEETING

   [News Story] RALEIGH, N.C. Rent-A-Center Manager David Elkin and his
four-person sales team are pleased to offer residents of Raleigh an additional
option when it comes to acquiring ownership of high-quality furniture,
appliances, electronics and computers. "We're very excited to bring this new
store to the Raleigh community," said Elkin. "We hope that the store will help
the area in its growth and overall expansion."

   The new Rent-A-Center is located at 6270 Glenwood Avenue, Suite 6282-100.
Members of the community will welcome Rent-A-Center to the neighborhood at a
grand opening celebration on Friday, October 12, 2012 at 10:00 a.m. At the
ribbon-cutting ceremony, Rent-A-Center is contributing $1,000 to the Food Bank
of Central and Eastern North Carolina. Linda Fisher, special events and food
drive manager for the organization, expressed her gratitude for the
contribution. "We are grateful to be the beneficiary of Rent-A-Center's
financial support of our mission to ensure no one goes hungry in our
communities," said Fisher. "This donation will put meals on thousands of tables
for children and their families who need it most."

   In conjunction with the grand opening ceremony, the store will also hold a
drawing for a new HD TV on October 12, 2012. To enter, simply visit the store.
No purchase is necessary.

   Rent-A-Center operates 120 locations in the state of North Carolina. The
Raleigh location is open from 10:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. Monday through Friday and
9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Saturdays.

   Source: NASDAQ Stock Exchange

OTHERS

   [News Story] PLANO, Texas--Rent-A-Center, Inc. (the "Company")
(NASDAQ/NGS:RCII) announced today that it intends, subject to market conditions,
to offer $250 million in aggregate principal amount of senior unsecured notes
due 2021 (the "notes") in a private offering that is exempt from the
registration requirements of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the
"Securities Act"). The Company intends to use the net proceeds of the offering
to repay $46 million of the revolving loans outstanding under its revolving
credit facility and apply the remainder to accelerated common stock repurchases
as market conditions permit and, to the extent not so applied, for general
corporate purposes.

   The notes and the related guarantees will be offered only to qualified
institutional buyers in reliance on the exemption from registration set forth in
Rule 144A under the Securities Act, and outside the United States to non-U.S.
persons in reliance on the exemption from registration set forth in Regulation S
under the Securities Act. The notes and the related guarantees have not been
registered under the Securities Act, or the securities laws of any state or
other jurisdiction, and may not be offered or sold in the United States without
registration or an applicable exemption from the registration requirements of
the Securities Act and applicable state securities or blue sky laws and foreign
securities laws.

   This press release shall not constitute an offer to sell, or the solicitation
of an offer to buy, any securities, nor shall there be any sales of the notes in
any jurisdiction in which such offer, solicitation or sale would be unlawful
prior to registration or qualification under the securities laws of any such
jurisdiction. This press release is being issued pursuant to and in accordance
with Rule 135(c) under the Securities Act.

   Source: NASDAQ Stock Exchange

DIVIDEND

   PLANO, Texas Rent-A-Center, Inc. (the "Company") (NASDAQ/NGS: RCII), the
nation's largest rent-to-own operator, today announced that its Board of
Directors has declared a $0.16 per share cash dividend for the fourth quarter of
2012 to be paid to the Company's common stockholders. The dividend will be paid
on October 24, 2012, to common stockholders of record as of the close of
business on October 1, 2012.

   Source: NASDAQ Stock Exchange

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                          December 21, 2011 Wednesday
                                 METRO EDITION

Savage moves cautiously ahead with sports dome

BYLINE: DAVID PETERSON; STAFF WRITER, STAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1AA

LENGTH: 549 words



HIGHLIGHT: Taking pains to admit it's no lock to break even, the City Council
nevertheless decided the idea is worth exploring further.


Assailed by doubts and aggressive lobbying, Savage's city council signaled late
Monday that it is willing to go ahead with a $5 million sports bubble.

"My first question was, 'how in the world can we afford this?'" said Council
Member Christine Kelly. "But I have a comfort level now with the numbers we've
been given."

Monday's voice vote was mainly to spend the money to formally draw up a site
plan. Before bonds would be sold, officials said, there will need to be public
reaction to the specifics of the plan.

But it was clear that Monday's vote was a key step in a two-year process that
featured lots of hesitation.

During that time, a northern suburb careened from a February 2010 headline
reading "Sports complex will be 'huge' in Vadnais Heights" to the August 2011
headline "City loans Vadnais Sports Center $127k to make debt payment."

In Savage, officials say the demand from thousands of families for cold-weather
facilities close to home should guarantee more than enough revenue to cover the
payback for the bonds -- even under conservative projections that don't assume,
for instance, any concession revenue or daytime rentals. But the discussion has
been held under a cloud of grim what-ifs.

"Is it worth it if we lost $100,000 or $200,000 a year?" City Administrator
Barry Stock urged council members last week to ask themselves, during an
informal, un-televised workshop. "I don't want us to be like some communities,
offering pie-in-the-sky projections and a year later the media's on their case,
asking, 'Why didn't this make money?'"

The dome will be aimed at sports such as soccer and lacrosse. The goal is to
hurry and catch next winter's season of use, with the first huge payment,
$500,000, coming due in 2014.

Council members are insisting that the youth sports groups -- which are pushing
for the dome as a way of ending their nightmare winter drives to venues such as
Faribault and Vadnais Heights -- sign memorandums of understanding in which they
undertake to guarantee a certain number of hours of use.

But city staff members discouraged the council from trying to force the groups
to become full financial partners, liable for shortfalls. You could try, Stock
told council members at the workshop last week, but be serious: You will not
take a bunch of soccer moms and dads who are your own constituents to court for
non-performance.

If a subsidy is needed, Stock said, the options include the parks fund -- an
idea parks people are not keen on -- or the plain old general fund, meaning tax
dollars. Every $100,000 in losses would mean a $9 surcharge on property taxes
for the owner of the average home.

Neighbor Kirk Sumner, calling it "a six-story building where we used to see a
beautiful park," said he "doesn't want it keeping me awake every night." He
recalled living near a park in another community where he wound up calling
police regularly about juveniles hanging out selling drugs.

But there were many proponents, including lacrosse coach Mike Walton of Savage.
"As coaches, we can't leave the facility till the kids are picked up. We're your
neighbors and we won't let this facility turn into the justified fears you have.
The proximity to the police department will be a blessing," he added, with
police cruisers passing by regularly.

David Peterson - 952-746-3285

LOAD-DATE: December 21, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                          Copyright 2011 Star Tribune
                              All Rights Reserved


                              988 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                            Derby Evening Telegraph

                               December 17, 2003

Loan bank's plea for help rejected

BYLINE: Kate Gent

SECTION: News; Politics; LocalGovernment; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 407 words


Calls for Derby City Council to back a £50,000 overdraft for a community bank
have been rejected.  It was revealed last month that Derby Loans, based at
Rosehill Business Centre, Normanton Road, needed extra cash to ensure it could
continue to make credit available for city people, who may otherwise go to loan
sharks.

Since its launch in May, 70 people, many of whom are council tenants, have been
given loans totalling about £70,000 at an APR of 18 per cent.

Another 120 people have made inquiries and the organisation lends cash to
fledgling businesses.

Given the current demand, managers of Derby Loans estimate they will need a pot
of about £225,000 next year. So far, they are about £100,000 short.

At a meeting last night, the council's cabinet turned down a recommendation from
one of the council's own watchdogs - the Community Regeneration Commission - to
act as a guarantor for an overdraft for Derby Loans.

The cabinet said that, based on advice from director of finance Paul Dransfield,
it would not act as guarantor.

Mr Dransfield said that the council did not usually guarantee overdrafts and
that there was a risk that it may have to repay the loan if the bank called in
the overdraft.

Derby Loans is also experiencing difficulties in lending businesses money
because of Government under-funding.

It received £75,000 instead of the £380,000 it had requested from the DTI's
Small Business Service Phoenix Fund.

Councillor Paul Bayliss, chairman of the Community Regeneration Commission,
tried to persuade the cabinet to back the proposal.

He said: "The commission put forward this recommendation as it wouldn't require
the council to commit any funds.

"This way would give the council an opportunity to do things differently.

"This should be considered as an exception to the rule." Council leader Maurice
Burgess said: "The council has long listened to the advice of our finance
officers, and when Mr Dransfield says that he doesn't believe it would be
sensible to act as a guarantor for an overdraft facility in this way, I believe
that we should listen to him." Andrew Baker, chief executive of Derby Loans,
said: "I realise it is very difficult for the council to underwrite an overdraft
for an independent organisation.

"I'm due to meet with the council today to discuss how we can use our combined
energies to find other ways that the council can be supportive."

LOAD-DATE: December 18, 2003

LANGUAGE: English

                     Copyright 2003 Derby Evening Telegraph


                              989 of 998 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                  September 2, 1981, Wednesday, Final Edition

SECTION: First Section; The Federal Report; Yesterday; A21

LENGTH: 143 words


The Agriculture Department's Rural Electrification Administration will guarantee
a $900 million loan to Deseret Generation and Transmission Cooperative of Sandy,
Utah, REA administrator Harold V. Hunter said. The loan will help the
cooperative provide electricity to more than 125,000 people in rural areas of
Utah, Wyoming, Nevada and Arizona.

Specific projects partially funded by the loan will include construction of a
360-megawatt coal-fired generating unit near Bonanza, Utah; the construction of
276 miles of transmission line and related facilities, and development of a coal
mine to fuel the plant.

Private funds in a five-year $330 million loan from the National Rural Utilities
Cooperative Finance Corp. will supplement the USDA loan, according to Hunter.
Deseret Generation supplies wholesale power to six member distribution systems.

                              992 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                                This Day (Lagos)

                            June 13, 2012 Wednesday

NIRSAL - Unlocking Nigeria's Agricultural Potentials

LENGTH: 1213 words


Over the years, the uninspiring performance of the Nigerian agricultural sector,
in terms of its contribution to country's total revenue have been a source of
concern to successive government.

This had led to the creation of various initiatives aimed at taking the agric
sector out of the doldrums. Unfortunately, despite various policies that were
created in the past, the sector had remained prostrate and had discouraged
investors.

But as the world population explodes and the threats to global food security
heighten, attention is gradually turning more and more to agriculture. Countries
and institutions have continued to push for large-scale agricultural
transformation as part of efforts to achieve increased growth and reduced rural
poverty.

In fact, disturbed by the development, the Nigerian Bankers' Committee in
conjunction with the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) conceived a policy aimed at
repositioning the agricultural production in the country.

The agric development programme tagged Nigerian Incentive-based Risk Sharing
Agricultural Lending (NIRSAL) - an idea that has been proposed to drive
agricultural revolution in the country.

According to the CBN, the Nigerian agriculture sector stands before an enormous
opportunity and in order to capture that prospect, a revolutionary approach is
required for agricultural value chains and agriculture financing by commercial
banks.

NIRSAL is an innovative mechanism targeted at de-risking lending to the
agricultural sector.

The CBN described NIRSAL as a wide ranging, ambitious programme whose goals
fully align with President Jonathan's administration's commitment to achieving
food security, increased job creation and poverty reduction in Nigeria.

A report by the Alliance for Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA), founded by a
former Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr. Kofi Annan, showed that
Agriculture accounts for roughly 41 per cent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in
Nigeria and 50 per cent of the economically active population in the country.
Figures revealed by the report showed that if the Nigerian government is sincere
in its poverty reduction campaign, it absolutely has to fix agriculture.

The report also showed that the country has 70 per cent of its population
rightly in rural areas and about 70 per cent also living in less than one dollar
a day. It attributed the 70 per cent population figure still living on one
dollar a day to the fact that the Nigerian agricultural sector is still at the
subsistence level . It stated that since 2000, agriculture has been the slowest
growing sector, growing roughly at about 5.1 per cent per annum.

AGRA said: "Nigeria represents a macrocosm of agricultural opportunities.
Agriculture plays a huge role in the economy. Historically, a growth sector,
agriculture has slowed over the last decade and today it is underperforming.
Absurdly, Nigeria relies heavily on imports to feed its people. Yet agriculture
still offers immense opportunities for growth. By transforming the sector,
Nigeria can produce more food to feed itself, lower the cost of food imports,
and even become a major food exporter and a breadbasket for the whole of West
Africa.

"Agriculture can generate additional growth and employment. We estimate that by
increasing yield and acreage, production can grow a massive 160 per cent by
2030, rising from $99 billion in 2010 to $256 billion in 2030. Already in
2001-2007, it accounted for 51 per cent of job creation in Nigeria. In a short,
agriculture harbours the key growth reserves to drive Nigeria's economic
greatness."

It however insisted that the country must first tackle major challenges such as
low productivity, saying that the average farmer produces less than 75 percent
of household food requirements.

The report listed other challenges to include: infrastructure - roads, energy,
storage are insufficient. Research and Development (R&D), a key factor in the
transformation of the new agricultural powerhouses, as shown in the case of
Brazil, need to be intensified in Nigeria.

"Agricultural chains in the country are broken, missing out vital links for
instance, between the processors and seed manufacturers. Estimates put the
nation's improved seed demand at over 1 million metric tons a year; yet, the
country produces only a mere 8,000 metric tons," it added.

The CBN last week restated its resolve to guarantee 75 per cent loans provided
by Deposit Money Banks to farmers in the 36 states of the federation and the
Federal Capital Territory (FCT) as part of efforts to transform the agricultural
sector. The loan guarantee is being packaged under the NIRSAL.

Head of NIRSAL Project Implementation Office under the Development Finance
Department, CBN, Mr. Jude Uzonwanne, had stated that the guarantee would be
issued by the NIRSAL to the farmers in the states and FCT through commercial
banks and other financial institutions.

He had explained: "NIRSAL mobilises financing for Nigerian agro-business by
using credit guarantees to address the risk of default. NIRSAL is a flexible
financing tool designed to change the behaviour of financial institutions.

"It covers all crops and livestock activities in Nigeria, while driving improved
investment outcomes and job creation. It is also building on a legacy of
previous CBN interventions in agriculture that has helped create thousands of
jobs."

According to him, the programme was designed to create access to finance by
integrating end-to-end agriculture value chains such as input producers,
farmers, agro dealers, agro processors and industrial manufacturers with
agricultural financing value chains - loan product development, credit
distribution, loan origination, managing and pricing for risk, and loan
disbursement.

"The integration is driven by NIRSAL's 5 pillars, particularly the Risk Sharing
Pillar and the Technical Assistance pillars such as risk sharing facility (N45
billion), insurance facility (N4.5 billion), technical assistance facility,
agricultural bank rating scheme (N1.5 billion), and bank incentive mechanism
(N15 billion)," he noted.

The Minister of State for FCT, Chief Olajumoke Akinjide, said that the NIRSAL
should be encouraged, pointing out that the programme was fundamental to the
success of the Federal Government's Agricultural Transformational Agenda (ATA).

According to him, the programme was established to address the grey areas
inhibiting agricultural growth in Nigeria.

"NIRSAL under the ATA seeks to address all the technical, administrative and
financial needs of the farmers along the selected agricultural value chain
commodities in which the country has comparative advantage," he added.

On her part, the Group Managing Director/Chief Executive Officer, Union Bank of
Nigeria Plc, Mrs. Funke Osibodu, recently called for concerted efforts by banks
to make agricultural financing attractive and profitable for investors by
focusing on a holistic value chain.

Osibodu identified the benefits of the approach to include the production of
input/output linkages, meeting the needs of industries, infrastructure needs of
stakeholders, among others.

The Union Bank boss said: "The value chain model will enhance increase in per
capita income, employment generation, rural development, empowerment of citizens
and well informed banking customers."

LOAD-DATE: June 13, 2012
